meta.description: d100 roll tables from the campaign. Each table records the full range of outcomes and the actual roll result.

tables.title: Isabel's Emotional Response to Marital Intimacy
tables.context: Diplomacy/Personal — Queen Isabel (age 15) adjusts to intimate married life with King Juan II (age 18) in the weeks following their wedding in late January 1431. The d100 roll determines how she emotionally responds to the physical and relational aspects of marriage.

ranges.label: Overwhelmed and Retreating
ranges.summary: Isabel finds the frequency and intensity overwhelming despite Juan's kindness. She becomes anxious, performing duty but withdrawing emotionally, seeking refuge in familiar rituals and becoming quieter around Juan.

ranges.label: Dutiful but Disconnected
ranges.summary: Isabel fulfills marital obligations properly without complaint, but treats intimacy as exactly that—an obligation. She shows no particular emotional engagement beyond duty, remaining polite and accommodating but emotionally detached.

ranges.label: Slowly Adjusting
ranges.summary: Isabel is still adjusting to physical realities of married life without distress but also without enthusiasm. Some discomfort remains; she appreciates Juan's consideration and gradually becomes more comfortable, but still in transition.

ranges.label: Comfortable and Dutiful
ranges.summary: Isabel has adjusted well to married life. Physical intimacy is no longer strange or uncomfortable. She fulfills duties willingly, finds comfort in Juan's affection, and appreciates his gentleness. Developing genuine affection—not fiery love, but steady, growing fondness and a solid foundation.

ranges.label: Awakening Affection
ranges.summary: Isabel discovers she genuinely enjoys Juan's touch and attention. Physical intimacy has deepened her emotional attachment significantly. She finds herself thinking about him during the day, looking forward to evenings, feeling a flutter when he enters a room. She's falling in love with Juan himself, not just the idea of her husband-king.

ranges.label: Blossoming Devotion
ranges.summary: Isabel has fallen deeply for Juan. The combination of his consideration, shared faith, and intimate bond has transformed her from dutiful bride to genuinely devoted wife. She seeks his company, lights up when he's near, and actively desires the physical aspect of their marriage, though she'd be mortified to admit it aloud.

ranges.label: Deep Love Emerging
ranges.summary: Isabel is experiencing genuine, deep romantic love. Juan's tenderness has unlocked something in her heart. She's not just content or affectionate; she's ardently attached to him, thinking of him constantly, worrying at his absence, experiencing almost physical pain at separation.

ranges.label: Transformative Love
ranges.summary: Against all expectations of arranged marriage, Isabel has fallen completely and overwhelmingly in love with Juan. The weeks of intimacy combined with genuine care have transformed her utterly. She discovers courage and willingness to be her true self. This is the great love of her life, and she knows it.

tables.title: Isabel's Pregnancy Timeline (Wedding to May 1431)
tables.context: Economy/Personal — King Juan and Queen Isabel have been intimate frequently since their late January wedding. The roll determines when conception occurs and pregnancy is confirmed during the period through May 1431.

ranges.label: No Pregnancy by May
ranges.summary: Despite youth and frequency, Isabel does not conceive by May 1431. Unusual but not impossible—sometimes it takes longer. No signs of pregnancy by May's end; Isabel begins to worry privately if something is wrong.

ranges.label: Very Late Conception (Late April/Early May)
ranges.summary: Isabel conceives in late April or early May. By May's end, she has missed one period and suspects pregnancy but it's too early to be certain. Some morning nausea but attributes it to anxiety about crusade. Won't be confirmed until June/July.

ranges.label: Late March Conception
ranges.summary: Isabel conceives in late March. By mid-to-late May, she has missed two periods and is fairly certain she's pregnant, though hasn't told Juan yet—waiting to be absolutely sure. Morning sickness, breast tenderness, fatigue present. Will confirm early June around 10-11 weeks along.

ranges.label: Early March Conception
ranges.summary: Isabel conceives in early March, about 4-5 weeks after the wedding. By April she misses her first period; by May she's missed two and experiencing clear symptoms: nausea, fatigue, breast changes. She tells Juan in late April/early May, around 8-10 weeks pregnant. Confirmed pregnancy well before crusade departure.

ranges.label: Late February Conception
ranges.summary: Isabel conceives in late February, within 3-4 weeks of wedding. By late March/early April she knows she's pregnant. Tells Juan mid-April. By May she's 12-14 weeks along—pregnancy clearly established, past most dangerous early weeks. Beginning to show slightly. Affects crusade planning significantly.

ranges.label: Mid-February Conception
ranges.summary: Isabel conceives within 2-3 weeks of wedding (mid-February). By late March she's certain; tells Juan in early April. By May she's 14-16 weeks along and definitely showing. Quickening may occur in late May. Pregnancy well-established with major impact on crusade decisions.

ranges.label: Early February Conception (Immediate)
ranges.summary: Isabel conceives within first week of marriage (early February). By mid-March she suspects; by late March/early April she knows. Tells Juan in April. By May she's 16-18 weeks along, clearly pregnant, possibly feeling movement. Very fast but not unheard of historically. Significantly impacts spring crusade plans.

ranges.label: Wedding Night/First Week Conception
ranges.summary: Isabel conceived on or immediately after wedding night. Strong early symptoms by mid-March. Tells Juan in late March. By May she's 18-20 weeks along, visibly pregnant, definitely feeling movement. Medieval midwives confirm 'quickening.' This rapid conception seen as divine blessing. Dramatically affects campaign planning.

tables.title: Journey from Toledo to Jaén - Weather and Travel Conditions
tables.context: Travel — Queen Isabel travels with King Juan from Toledo to the staging area at Jaén in early March 1431 (~120 miles, 6-7 days planned). The d100 roll determines overall journey quality, weather conditions, Isabel and companions' stamina, and travel success.

ranges.label: Disaster
ranges.summary: Severe spring storms hit; roads turn to impassable mud. Wagon carrying Isabel's belongings overturns; she falls ill from cold rain exposure. Journey takes 12 days instead of 7. Isabel arrives exhausted, feverish, requiring bed rest. Army assembly delayed while King tends sick wife.

ranges.label: Serious Complications
ranges.summary: Heavy rains and muddy roads slow progress significantly. Isabel suffers from travel sickness—nausea, fatigue, possibly early pregnancy symptoms. One Portuguese lady becomes ill. Journey takes 10 days with frequent stops. Isabel arrives worn out and needs recovery time before campaign.

ranges.label: Multiple Difficulties
ranges.summary: Moderate rain and poor road conditions in mountain passes. Isabel finds journey more taxing than expected—constant movement, sleeping in tents, simple camp food cause struggle. Takes 9 days. Relief to arrive but journey has dampened enthusiasm for traveling with army.

ranges.label: Challenging but Manageable
ranges.summary: Some rain and muddy stretches slow progress. Isabel experiences discomfort—sore from riding/wagon travel, tired from irregular sleep, possibly early morning nausea. Takes 8 days. Handles it with dutiful grace but clearly not enjoying experience. Realizes traveling with army is harder than anticipated.

ranges.label: Adequate Journey
ranges.summary: Weather is mixed but manageable. Isabel finds travel tiring but bearable. Some discomfort, some beautiful moments. Makes decent time—7-8 days as planned. Arrives in reasonable condition, having learned what campaigning involves. Evening prayers together provide comfort.

ranges.label: Good Journey
ranges.summary: Weather cooperates reasonably well. Isabel proves more resilient than expected, finding journey an adventure despite discomfort. Takes 7 days as planned. Some lovely moments—sunrises, evening prayers, conversations. Arrives at Jaén tired but in good spirits. Bond with Juan strengthens through shared experience.

ranges.label: Very Successful
ranges.summary: Excellent weather for early March. Isabel adapts well to travel life, discovering she's more capable than thought. Takes 6-7 days. Beautiful scenery, good roads, no incidents. Arrives in good condition and good spirits. Isabel feels confident about remaining with army. Relationship deepens significantly.

ranges.label: Excellent Journey
ranges.summary: Perfect traveling conditions. Isabel genuinely enjoys much of journey—the freedom of the road, changing landscapes, time alone with Juan. Takes 6 days. Several memorable moments that become fond memories. Arrives energized rather than exhausted. Experience deepens their marriage.

ranges.label: Exceptional Journey with Notable Event
ranges.summary: Ideal weather and conditions, combined with something notable occurring—spiritual revelation at shrine, profound conversation, witnessing inspiring devotion, or rescue of travelers. Journey becomes transformative. Both feel blessed and unified. Arrives not just successfully but transformed, with relationship deepened in meaningful ways. Something memorable for years to come.

tables.title: Transformative Event During Journey to Jaén
tables.context: Intrigue/Personal — During the exceptional journey from Toledo to Jaén, a significant event occurs that transforms Juan and Isabel's relationship. The d100 roll determines which specific transformative moment happens.

ranges.label: The Miracle at the Shrine
ranges.summary: At wayside shrine to Santiago, Isabel experiences profound spiritual moment—possible vision or sign (light illuminating saint's statue, finding white dove feather). She becomes convinced God has blessed their union and will grant them a child. Certainty transforms her from dutiful wife to passionate believer in shared destiny.

ranges.label: Saving the Children
ranges.summary: They encounter village devastated by Granada raiders. Isabel takes charge organizing food, comforting orphaned children, revealing commanding, compassionate side. Juan sees her fierce in protecting innocent, crystallizing crusade's moral purpose. Shared conviction deepens their bond.

ranges.label: The Bandit Ambush
ranges.summary: Bandits attack; one breaks through toward Isabel's wagon. Instead of freezing, Isabel grabs a fallen guard's sword (awkwardly) and tries to defend herself. Juan arrives to dispatch threat. Isabel discovers courage she didn't know existed. Mutual respect deepens enormously.

ranges.label: The Confession Under Stars
ranges.summary: Under brilliant stars, they have longest, most honest conversation ever. They truly talk about fears, hopes, inadequacies. Realize they're both young people thrust into enormous roles, both scared, both doing their best. Profound intimacy born of genuine understanding. Genuine passion follows, different from before.

ranges.label: The Pregnant Woman
ranges.summary: They find pregnant woman in labor on roadside, abandoned by fleeing family. Isabel insists on stopping to help deliver baby with midwife's assistance. Juan witnesses his wife's fierce, commanding nature during birthing. Baby born healthy—boy named Juan. Isabel tells Juan: 'I want this. I want to give you a son.' Motherhood becomes real and urgent.

ranges.label: The Old Knight's Blessing
ranges.summary: They stop at castle where ancient knight—veteran of earlier Granada campaigns—offers hospitality. He tells stories of decades of frontier warfare, then blesses both Juan and Isabel, seeing in them the ones who will finally finish what his generation could not. His death days later makes blessing treasured—passing torch between generations.

ranges.label: The Moorish Merchant
ranges.summary: They encounter Moorish merchant traveling under safe-conduct. Over shared meal, he speaks candidly about Granada's divisions, Muslims who might welcome peace, difference between warriors and ordinary people. Isabel engages in thoughtful conversation about faith and coexistence. Challenges assumptions without diminishing resolve. Merchant gifts Isabel book of Arabic poetry.

ranges.label: The Thunderstorm Revelation
ranges.summary: Massive thunderstorm forces shelter in small church. Lightning strikes close by. In darkness holding each other, Isabel admits deepest fear: 'What if I can't give you a son? What if I fail?' Juan's response—that she could never fail, is already more than hoped—unlocks something. She realizes he truly loves her as person, not duty. Rainbow emerges as sign. Relationship transforms.

ranges.label: The Veteran Crusader
ranges.summary: They meet old crusader who fought in Juan's grandfather's campaigns. He's now blind, in monastery. Asks to touch Juan's face, declares: 'You have your grandfather's spirit, but kinder heart.' Asks to meet Isabel, touches her face too: 'A queen of Portugal for Castile crusade. God works in patterns. You're meant to be here.' Blessing profoundly moves both, giving sense of destiny.

ranges.label: The Village Welcome
ranges.summary: A village turns out en masse to welcome them—not ordered to, but from genuine enthusiasm. Flowers thrown, children sing, people weep with joy. Old woman touches Isabel's gown, says: 'You'll give us the prince who finishes the Reconquista. I've seen it.' Display of popular faith overwhelms both to tears. They realize how many depend on them. Isabel feels weight and honor of being queen.

ranges.label: The Shared Danger
ranges.summary: Crossing swollen river, Isabel's wagon nearly overturns in current. Juan plunges into water (armor and all), risking drowning to reach her. Gets her to safety. Afterward Isabel is furious—'You could have died!' He responds: 'You're my wife. I'd drown a thousand times.' Her anger collapses into overwhelming emotion. Realizes he would literally die for her. Terrifying and profound.

ranges.label: The Letter from Portugal
ranges.summary: Courier catches up with letter from Isabel's mother—lengthy, loving, revealing her parents' arranged marriage became deep love over years. Mother writes: 'Give it time. Let him see all of you, not just dutiful princess. Love grows like a garden—plant seeds now.' Isabel shares with Juan. Conversation about marriage, about their parents, about how love develops. Creates permission for both to be imperfect, grow together.

ranges.label: The Combined Event
ranges.summary: Roll twice more on this table (reroll if 97-100 again). TWO significant events occur during journey, creating powerful combined impact that transforms both in complementary ways.

tables.title: Portuguese Ladies' Response to Hard Journey Request
tables.context: Diplomacy/Personal — Queen Isabel asks her Portuguese ladies-in-waiting if any are willing to accompany her on a hard-riding journey to Seville (80 miles, 2-3 days each way of fast travel, sleeping in field, no wagon comfort). The d100 roll determines which ladies volunteer or refuse.

ranges.label: Complete Refusal with Concern
ranges.summary: All ladies refuse; they're worried about propriety and safety. Doña Beatriz is distressed, arguing journey unsuitable for queen, begging Isabel to reconsider. Ladies point out scandal, danger, inappropriateness. Creates tension and doubt, though Isabel can still choose to go alone.

ranges.label: Polite Refusals
ranges.summary: All decline graciously. Doña Beatriz explains she physically cannot manage hard riding. Younger ladies admit they're not skilled enough riders and would slow party or risk injury. Apologetic but firm—honest assessment of limitations. No judgment. Isabel travels with only Juan's guards as escort.

ranges.label: Reluctant Single Volunteer (Inadequate)
ranges.summary: One lady (Maria) volunteers out of pure duty despite being clearly unsuited—poor rider, frightened of hard travel, but feels obligated to prevent scandal. Volunteering would make journey worse—she'd struggle, slow them down, possibly get injured. Isabel would need to decide whether to accept her sacrifice or decline.

ranges.label: Duty-Bound Single Volunteer (Adequate)
ranges.summary: Catarina volunteers, recognizing it's her duty though not enthusiastic. She's competent rider—not brilliant, but adequate. Won't slow party down much. 'You need a lady-in-attendance and I'm the only one here who can manage it. So I'll do it.' No excitement, no resentment—just acceptance of obligation. Provides bare minimum of propriety.

ranges.label: Willing Single Volunteer (Good)
ranges.summary: Catarina volunteers and seems somewhat excited by adventure, despite hardships. She's a good rider, younger, more resilient. She admits it will be difficult but says willing to try and wants to support Queen. Will manage journey well, provide companionship and propriety. Solid, positive outcome.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Single Volunteer (Excellent)
ranges.summary: Catarina eagerly volunteers, revealing she actually misses hard riding from her youth in northern Portugal. She's excellent horsewoman, physically capable, genuinely excited for challenge. Will manage journey excellently while enjoying it, providing good companionship. Best single-volunteer outcome.

ranges.label: Two Volunteers (Mixed Capability)
ranges.summary: Both Catarina and Maria volunteer. Catarina is capable and willing; Maria is less skilled but determined. Having two ladies provides better propriety and companionship, but Maria will struggle. Group might need to slow slightly or show extra patience. Still workable, and Isabel appreciates their loyalty.

ranges.label: Two Volunteers (Both Capable)
ranges.summary: Both Catarina and Maria volunteer and both prove to be better riders than initially apparent. They're young, resilient, rise to challenge. Tired and sore but manage without slowing party. Having two ladies makes journey much more proper, provides companionship, shows strong devotion. Very good outcome.

ranges.label: Three Volunteers (Excellent Support)
ranges.summary: Catarina, Maria, and third younger lady (Ana) all volunteer. All three are capable riders in early-to-mid 20s, loyal and willing. Having three ladies provides excellent propriety, good companionship, demonstrates strong household devotion. They manage journey well, support each other. Isabel well-attended.

ranges.label: Unexpected Devotion
ranges.summary: All younger ladies volunteer (Catarina, Maria, Ana, and 1-2 others—4-5 total). They're inspired by Isabel's transformation and want to be part of new, bolder version of their queen. Even Doña Beatriz, though unable to ride, gives blessing and organizes others. Younger ladies prove surprisingly capable and enthusiastic. Strengthens bonds between Isabel and household.

tables.title: Journey to Seville - Travel Conditions and Party Dynamics
tables.context: Travel — Queen Isabel travels with King Juan from Jaén to Seville (~80 miles) with limited party including Catarina (lady-in-waiting) and small guard force. Journey is meant to be quick, hard riding without comfort of wagons. The d100 roll determines overall success, weather, physical toll on women riders, and relationship dynamics.

ranges.label: Disaster - Granada Raid
ranges.summary: Party encounters Granada raiding force (20-30 cavalry). Running fight ensues; someone injured (guard, Catarina, or worst—Isabel). Forced to shelter in fortified village for days while wounded recover. Takes 8-10 days instead of 3. Creates serious complications for campaign timeline and potentially Isabel's safety going forward.

ranges.label: Serious Incident - Injury
ranges.summary: Catarina's horse stumbles second day, throwing her. Badly bruised, possibly sprained wrist or ankle. Not life-threatening but painful. Party must slow dramatically or stop for a day. Isabel feels guilty. Takes 5-6 days. Catarina bears it stoically but clearly suffering.

ranges.label: Significant Complications - Weather
ranges.summary: Severe spring storms hit—cold rain, high winds, muddy roads. Everyone soaked and miserable. Isabel and Catarina particularly struggle. Must seek poor shelter (rundown inns, barns). Takes 5-6 days. No serious injury but everyone exhausted, cold, bedraggled. Not impressive arrival Juan hoped for.

ranges.label: Multiple Difficulties - Hard Journey
ranges.summary: Pace proves too much for both women. By end of first day, both exhausted and saddle-sore. Juan slows significantly, turning 3-day journey into 5 days. Beautiful moments camping, but mostly grinding discomfort. Both are tough, don't complain, but Juan sees them struggling.

ranges.label: Challenging But Managed - Learning Experience
ranges.summary: Journey is hard. Isabel and Catarina both struggle with long hours and fast pace, especially first two days. Juan adjusts to moderate pace—steady progress, not fast ride envisioned. Takes 4 days instead of 3. Discomfort, soreness, but manageable. Both women prove resilience even if not enjoying it.

ranges.label: Adequate Journey - Building Stamina
ranges.summary: Journey takes 4 days at steady pace. First day rough for both women, but by day two they're adapting. Isabel's Toledo-Jaén experience helps—knows how to manage discomfort now. Catarina proves more capable than dutiful acceptance suggested. Nice evening moments around campfires. Arrive tired but in good spirits. Workmanlike, successful journey.

ranges.label: Good Journey - Pleasant Surprise
ranges.summary: Weather cooperates beautifully. Both women manage pace better than expected. Isabel comfortable on horseback now; Catarina reveals she actually enjoys riding. Takes 3-4 days with lovely moments: sunrise over olive groves, evening prayers under stars, good campfire conversation. Small group bonds. Arrive in good condition.

ranges.label: Very Good Journey - Bonding Experience
ranges.summary: Perfect weather and good roads. Both women not only manage but seem to thrive. Isabel continues transformation into confident, capable version of herself. Catarina, initially reluctant, discovers she enjoys adventure and freedom from court restrictions. Opens up, becomes friendlier with Isabel. Guards impressed by stamina. Takes 3 days.

ranges.label: Excellent Journey - Memorable Adventure
ranges.summary: Everything goes remarkably well—beautiful weather, good pace, no incidents. Isabel rides with growing confidence and joy, becoming genuinely skilled. Catarina transforms from dutiful volunteer to enthusiastic companion. Two women bond over shared experience. One particularly beautiful moment (stunning sunset, meaningful conversation) creates lasting memory. Arrive energized.

ranges.label: Outstanding Journey with Notable Event
ranges.summary: Excellent journey AND something notable occurs: encounter pilgrims with spiritual sharing, witness moving display of popular crusade devotion, Isabel/Catarina have deep conversation transforming Catarina from servant to friend, rescue travelers in distress earning gratitude, or spot Granada scouts and evade cleverly giving tactical intelligence. Journey becomes story worth telling.

ranges.label: Exceptional Journey - Transformative Experience
ranges.summary: Not just successful but transformative. Perfect conditions combine with multiple meaningful moments. Isabel fully comes into her own as rider/traveler, impressing even veteran guards. Catarina becomes genuinely devoted friend, not just servant. Small group bonds into tight unit. Something profound happens—spiritual experience or crisis handled perfectly. Arrive not just successfully but transformed with strengthened relationships.

tables.title: Sultan Muhammad IX's Intelligence on Crusade Preparations
tables.context: Espionage — Juan has taken precautions to keep crusade plans secret, but Granada has intelligence networks. The question is what information has reached the Sultan despite these security measures.

ranges.label: Almost Blind
ranges.summary: Sultan knows only that some crusade is being prepared and Juan recruited crusaders. Does not know scale (16,000-20,000 underestimate), assembly locations, timeline, existence of two armies, naval component, or artillery. Granada maintains dispersed defenses with no special preparations.

ranges.label: Minimal Intelligence
ranges.summary: Sultan knows crusade launches spring 1431 with ~15,000-20,000 total troops, Juan personally leading with papal backing. Missing: true scale (35,000), two-army coordination, naval invasion, artillery details, specific targets. Granada concentrates 12,000-14,000 troops near Granada city and frontier.

ranges.label: Partial Intelligence
ranges.summary: Sultan knows major crusade launching early April with ~20,000 eastern army at Jaén and 8,000-10,000 western force at Seville, Juan leading with banner and relics, artillery present, crusader force included. Missing: true western force size (actually 12K), naval component coordination, staggered deployment strategy, 3,000 cavalry raiders, specific targets. Granada concentrates 16,000-18,000 eastern troops, 6,000-8,000 western defenders.

ranges.label: Substantial Intelligence
ranges.summary: Sultan knows both armies: 23,000 east (Jaén), 12,000 west (Seville), eastern has banner/relics/Juan, western has naval support, 5 bombards, 8-month campaign planned, 500+ crusaders, 3,000 cavalry raiders, four supply depots. Missing: staggered deployment strategy, relay system, exact siege targets, western naval assault timing. Granada faces strategic dilemma.

ranges.label: Detailed Intelligence
ranges.summary: Sultan knows everything from 51-70 plus western army deliberately timed for after eastern commits, relay coordination system, strategic intent to force impossible dilemma, specific fortress targets, command structure (Infante Juan west, Infante Enrique east, Master Pedro González eastern commander). Missing: exact western assault date, detailed siege tactics, internal command relationships.

ranges.label: Comprehensive Intelligence
ranges.summary: Sultan knows virtually everything about crusade except most sensitive tactical details: detailed maps, force compositions, command structures, supply chains, timeline, coordination systems, objectives. Likely has spies in noble households or corrupted officials. Granada can prepare innovative counters but still faces strategic dilemma.

ranges.label: Near-Perfect Intelligence
ranges.summary: Sultan has penetrated inner circle or corrupted high-level officials. Knows everything including contingency plans, internal disagreements, personal matters (Isabel's pregnancy?), operational timetables. Can prepare optimal counterstrategy but must still fight the war with Granada's inherent constraints.

tables.title: Sultan Muhammad IX's Strategic Response to Crusade
tables.context: Intrigue — Sultan knows substantial details about crusade (rolled 41). Now he must decide how to respond with his 24,000-25,000 troops, considering his disadvantage and the upcoming jihad expectations.

ranges.label: Passive Fortress Defense
ranges.summary: Sultan withdraws all forces to Granada city, abandoning frontier fortresses except minimal garrisons. Waits for crusaders to exhaust themselves in sieges. Avoids offensive operations. Strategically sound but politically devastating after jihad declaration—undermines entire campaign.

ranges.label: Traditional Defensive Deployment
ranges.summary: Sultan positions main army (14,000-16,000) near Granada city with strong frontier garrisons (500-1,000 each), western coast defended (6,000-8,000 troops), limited raiding. Safe but uninspired—doesn't leverage unprecedented support received or jihad momentum.

ranges.label: Active Defense with Frontier Focus
ranges.summary: Sultan fortifies and supplies all frontier castles for extended sieges (6+ months), positions main army centrally, employs limited cavalry raids against supply lines, considers scorched earth. Solid defensive strategy making each fortress expensive to besiege, favoring attrition over crusaders.

ranges.label: Mobile Defense with Raiding
ranges.summary: Sultan positions main field army (18,000) to respond rapidly, maintains western defense (6,000-8,000), organizes 2,000-3,000 light cavalry for constant raiding, targets crusader supply lines and isolated units, avoids pitched battles. Smart strategy leveraging Granada's mobility advantage without excessive risk.

ranges.label: Concentration Against Eastern Army
ranges.summary: Sultan commits 18,000-20,000 troops to eastern defense, accepts western vulnerability (5,000-6,000 defenders only), prepares mountain pass ambushes, reinforces chokepoint fortresses, raids western coast to pin down western army. Bold but risky—could work decisively or leave Granada exposed.

ranges.label: Aggressive Spoiling Strategy
ranges.summary: Sultan launches raids against Jaén staging area and coastal targets (Seville) in late March before full crusade assembly, burns supplies, kills draft animals, assassinates commanders if possible, then withdraws to prepared positions. Disruptive but doesn't solve underlying problem—still heavily outnumbered.

ranges.label: Preemptive Offensive Against Eastern Army
ranges.summary: Sultan commits 16,000-18,000 troops to strike Jaén while eastern army still assembling (mid-late March), catches 8,000-10,000 troops unprepared, destroys forward elements and supplies. Could force crusade cancellation but extremely risky—leaves Granada defenseless if fails.

ranges.label: Maximum Aggression - Dual Offensive
ranges.summary: Sultan launches 12,000 troops at Jaén and 10,000 + naval assault at Seville simultaneously in late March. All-out offensive to shatter crusade before it launches. Extremely risky—leaves Granada city minimal garrison. Both offensives must succeed or Granada loses everything.

ranges.label: Scorched Earth Total War
ranges.summary: Sultan evacuates and burns frontier settlements, destroys all resources crusaders could use, concentrates 22,000+ troops in Granada city defenses, employs all galleys for coastal raids, hires corsairs, prepares for year-long siege. Total commitment to making conquest impossibly expensive. Only choice for those convinced crusade intends genocide.

tables.title: Castilian Cavalry Intelligence Detection of Sultan's Rapid Relief Force
tables.context: Military — Sultan has committed to rapid relief (rolled 44), marching 40 miles in 2 days to catch Castilians building fieldworks. The question is how quickly and accurately Juan's cavalry scouts detect this movement.

ranges.label: Total Surprise
ranges.summary: Sultan's army spotted only when it appears on horizon, Day 3 evening or morning. First warning is scouts shouting 'the Moors are here!' No advance warning, uncertain numbers, no time to prepare. Fieldworks barely begun. Granada's cavalry screen completely dominated, possibly used deception or night marching.

ranges.label: Minimal Warning
ranges.summary: Morning of Day 3 warning (Sultan arrives evening Day 3 or morning Day 4). Single scout reports large force 10-15 miles away, 'many thousands,' uncertain composition. 6-12 hours warning only. Granada's screening highly effective, only one-two scouts penetrated. Castilians can form defensive positions but not extensive preparation.

ranges.label: Late Warning
ranges.summary: Evening Day 2 or early morning Day 3 warning. Multiple scouts report large army moving north toward Alcalá, 15,000-18,000 troops (reasonably accurate), forced march pace observed, arriving 24-36 hours out. General direction known but exact route uncertain. Castilians have one day to adjust—fieldworks still incomplete but can improve defenses.

ranges.label: Adequate Warning
ranges.summary: Day 2 afternoon while Juan's army marching or just arriving. Multiple scout reports: Sultan mobilizing entire field army, ~16,000-17,000 troops, forced march pace confirmed, composition breakdown (10,000 infantry, 6,000-7,000 cavalry), general direction, 36-48 hours warning. Juan can make informed strategic decisions about fieldwork vs. defensive positioning.

ranges.label: Good Warning
ranges.summary: Day 1 evening or Day 2 early morning—within 12 hours of Sultan's departure. Scout reports Sultan mobilizing entire field army now (~17,000), forced march exhausting troops, composition breakdown (9,000-10,000 infantry including Moroccan professionals, 7,000 cavalry), specific route (main Loja road toward Alcalá), light supplies for speed, 48-60 hours warning. Castilians have nearly 2 days to prepare.

ranges.label: Excellent Warning
ranges.summary: Day 1 afternoon—within hours of Sultan's mobilization. Immediate report: Sultan mobilizing now, 16,000-17,000 troops confirmed, detailed composition with unit breakdowns, specific approach routes, precise timeline ('2.5-3 days hard marching'), Sultan personally commanding, morale assessment (troops pushed hard), supply situation (light supplies, aggressive action planned). Near-perfect warning for strategic advantage.

ranges.label: Advance Warning
ranges.summary: Day 1 morning or even late Day 0—before Sultan even departs. Scouts detect mobilization preparations. Warning of imminent mobilization followed by hour-by-hour updates during march. Complete order of battle, exact route, timeline, even strategic intent understood. Castilians have maximum flexibility and advantage.

ranges.label: Perfect Intelligence
ranges.summary: Continuous intelligence from before Sultan mobilizes through entire march. Hour-by-hour position updates, detailed unit dispositions and commanders, internal Granada command discussions, exact tactical plans, troops' psychological state (morale, exhaustion), supply problems, dissent in command. Intelligence coup allowing perfect counter-strategy and potential ambush.

tables.title: Scout Report - Enemy Troop Observation
tables.context: Military/Reconnaissance — Sultan Muhammad IX's scouts attempt to observe the Castilian deployment before his forced-march army arrives. The GM presents a d100 table to determine how accurate their intelligence will be, ranging from complete interception to detailed strategic insight.

ranges.label: EXCELLENT CASTILIAN COUNTER-RECONNAISSANCE
ranges.summary: Castilian cavalry intercepts scouts miles out; scouts killed or driven off before close observation. Sultan receives no tactical intelligence and must advance blind, knowing only that Castilians are present.

ranges.label: MINIMAL OBSERVATION - DECEPTION SUCCEEDS COMPLETELY
ranges.summary: Scouts observe from 2+ miles distant through smoke and evening light; see ~5,000-8,000 troops and one bombard with hasty fieldworks. Sultan believes he faces only a forward element and that deception succeeds perfectly.

ranges.label: LIMITED OBSERVATION - DECEPTION MOSTLY WORKS
ranges.summary: Scouts get closer (~1 mile) before driven off; see siege works clearly and glimpse main camp through smoke. Report: siege works with ~5,000 troops, one gun, main camp to north (10,000-12,000 estimated). Sultan underestimates total strength significantly.

ranges.label: MODERATE OBSERVATION - ACCURATE COUNT, UNCLEAR DISPOSITION
ranges.summary: Experienced scouts evade patrols and observe from multiple angles. Report accurately counts 23,000 total troops, identifies three infantry formations plus heavy cavalry reserve, sees one bombard. Sultan knows true numbers but doesn't understand hidden bombards or that vulnerability is deliberate deception.

ranges.label: GOOD OBSERVATION - TACTICAL CLARITY
ranges.summary: Skilled scouts penetrate deep over several hours, identify force composition and organization. Report: 23,000 troops total, siege works with 5,000 elite troops (crusaders, Military Orders), main camp with three large formations and heavy cavalry reserve, extensive cavalry screen, one bombard visible (likely more hidden), construction appears deliberate and systematic. Sultan understands strength and basic organization; may suspect forward position is bait.

ranges.label: SUPERIOR INTELLIGENCE - STRATEGIC INSIGHT
ranges.summary: Elite scouts with extended observation or local knowledge. Report identifies 23,000 troops in three-tier deployment with Infante Enrique commanding siege works under King Juan II's heavy cavalry reserve. Recognizes professional preparation and suspects deliberate trap. Sultan understands the deception attempt.

ranges.label: CRITICAL INTELLIGENCE BREAKTHROUGH
ranges.summary: Captured Castilian deserter or exceptional reconnaissance reveals complete strategy. Report details three-battle infantry organization by name, confirms hidden bombards, explains King Juan's trap of baiting Sultan into apparent weakness. Sultan knows entire strategic design and can attempt counter-trap or refuse engagement.

tables.title: Sultan's Strategic Response to Enemy Strength
tables.context: Military/Strategy — Given his situation (16,000 exhausted troops, limited supplies, outnumbered, intelligence showing prepared positions), Sultan Muhammad IX must decide how to respond. The GM presents a d100 table determining whether he attacks immediately, deploys defensively, maneuvers for advantage, or withdraws.

ranges.label: DESPERATE FRONTAL ASSAULT - IMMEDIATE ATTACK
ranges.summary: Sultan refuses to accept he missed the window; orders immediate attack on siege works with no rest. Relies on jihad fervor and aggressive surprise despite exhaustion and numerical disadvantage. Attacks prepared positions with exhausted troops in direct frontal assault without tactical refinement. Likely outcome is disaster.

ranges.label: AGGRESSIVE BUT TACTICAL - DAWN ASSAULT AFTER REST
ranges.summary: Sultan rests troops overnight at defensive positions 3-4 miles away, then launches dawn attack on siege works with fresh troops. Uses cavalry superiority to pin Castilian screening forces and attempts to overrun forward position. Still attacks the apparent bait but with better execution and rested troops.

ranges.label: CAVALRY HARASSMENT - FORCE CASTILIAN ERROR
ranges.summary: Deploys 2-3 miles south in defensive position; uses superior light cavalry (6,000+) to harass constantly, raid supply lines, and attack foraging parties. Attempts to provoke Castilian heavy cavalry into disadvantageous pursuit or wait for tactical error. Conserves infantry and maximizes cavalry advantage.

ranges.label: TACTICAL REDEPLOYMENT - SEEK BETTER GROUND
ranges.summary: Recognizes prepared positions are too strong; maneuvers east or west to threaten different approach to Alcalá. Forces Castilians to abandon prepared works and respond; attempts to negate numerical and artillery advantages through terrain advantage and surprise.

ranges.label: DEFENSIVE DEPLOYMENT - MAKE THEM COME TO YOU
ranges.summary: Takes strong defensive position 2-3 miles south on anchored high ground; challenges King Juan to attack him in prepared positions instead. Uses time to rest troops and improve defenses. Forces Juan to choose: ignore siege or attack defended position. Problem: supplies only last 3-4 days.

ranges.label: CONTROLLED ENGAGEMENT - BAIT AND COUNTER-TRAP
ranges.summary: Suspects siege works are bait; deploys defensively but sends strong probe force (4,000-5,000) to test enemy reaction. If Castilian main army deploys, withdraws probe using cavalry screen and attempts to draw heavy cavalry into pursuing exposed infantry. Uses tactical deception to counter Juan's deception.

ranges.label: STRATEGIC BYPASS - RELIEVE ALCALÁ AND WITHDRAW
ranges.summary: Recognizes unwinnable battle conditions; makes rapid march around Castilian positions to break through to Alcalá fortress, resupplies garrison, leaves reinforcements (1,000-2,000 troops), and withdraws south before intercept. Claims political victory while avoiding decisive battle.

ranges.label: TACTICAL WITHDRAWAL - PRESERVE THE ARMY
ranges.summary: Realizes strategic situation is untenable against superior numbers in prepared positions with exhausted troops; begins immediate withdrawal toward Granada using cavalry to screen retreat. Loses political face but preserves 16,000-troop field army for future engagement. Most militarily sound option.

tables.title: Initial Infantry Engagement and Castilian Deployment Execution
tables.context: Military/Tactics — As Juan's three infantry battles advance and the exhausted Sultan's troops commit to desperate assault on the siege works, the GM rolls to determine how effectively Juan's plan executes and whether the Sultan's attack creates unexpected problems or breaks down as expected.

ranges.label: CASTILIAN DEPLOYMENT COMPLICATIONS
ranges.summary: Sultan's 6,000 cavalry aggressively screens his infantry advance; Castilian three battles struggle to maintain formation under harassment. Gaps open between formations; Moorish light cavalry causes confusion and delay. Infante Enrique's position under heavy pressure with mounting casualties. Heavy cavalry flanking movement slowed. Battle becomes chaotic meeting engagement rather than coordinated trap.

ranges.label: MOORISH FURY INITIALLY EFFECTIVE
ranges.summary: Sultan's exhausted troops fight with desperate religious fervor; initial assault more effective than expected. Enrique's lines buckling, casualties mounting. Castilian First Battle engages piecemeal. Sultan's professional core showing quality despite exhaustion. Real battle developing with neither side having clear advantage initially.

ranges.label: GENERAL ENGAGEMENT - BATTLE JOINED
ranges.summary: Enrique holds siege works under serious pressure; Castilian First Battle crashes into Sultan's left flank as planned. Second and Third Battles deploying in sequence. Fighting general along 2-mile front with cavalry in separate engagement. Infantry battle becoming grinding match with no clear advantage yet; outcome depends on execution and endurance.

ranges.label: PLAN EXECUTING WELL - CASTILIAN ADVANTAGE DEVELOPING
ranges.summary: Enrique holds easily with elite troops steadfast in prepared positions; three battles deploy in coordinated sequence. First Battle engages Sultan's flank effectively with overwhelming numbers. Moorish infantry showing exhaustion and cannot maintain combat intensity. Cavalry working around flank successfully. Sultan's lines holding but clearly overmatched.

ranges.label: THE TRAP SPRINGS - MOORISH POSITION DETERIORATING
ranges.summary: Sultan's desperate assault breaks down within an hour; exhausted Moorish infantry cannot sustain combat against fresh troops. Enrique's position rock-solid with elite troops inflicting heavy casualties and minimal losses. Three battles deploy flawlessly in enveloping movement with numerical superiority becoming decisive. Enemy formations losing cohesion; some units pulling back and wavering.

ranges.label: OVERWHELMING SUCCESS - ENEMY COLLAPSE IMMINENT
ranges.summary: Sultan's assault shatters within 90 minutes against prepared defenses; exhaustion proves catastrophic for Moorish troops too tired to fight effectively. Enrique's casualties minimal as defenders cut down exhausted attackers. Three battles advance like clockwork in perfect coordination. Moorish formations disintegrating; mass wavering visible with units fleeing. Cavalry in perfect position for devastating charge into exposed flank.

ranges.label: CATASTROPHIC MOORISH COLLAPSE - IMMEDIATE ROUT
ranges.summary: Sultan's gambit fails spectacularly within first hour; exhausted troops cannot sustain assault. Multiple Moorish units break and flee on initial contact; panic spreads like wildfire through Sultan's army. Enrique's defenders barely scratched as enemy too exhausted to press effective attack. Deploying Castilian battles encounter fleeing enemies, not formed resistance. Sultan's infantry in full rout before cavalry even charges. Army disintegrating into mob and pursuit/slaughter phase beginning immediately.

tables.title: Heavy Cavalry Flanking Charge Against Routed Enemy
tables.context: Military/Cavalry — King Juan leads his 4,000 heavy cavalry in a flanking charge against the Sultan's disintegrating left flank. The roll determines both overall effectiveness of the charge and Juan's personal experience during close combat.

ranges.label: ENEMY CAVALRY COUNTER-CHARGES - CHAOTIC MELEE
ranges.summary: Moroccan elite cavalry launches desperate counter-charge to protect disintegrating infantry. Heavy cavalry melee erupts; Juan's charge blunted by enemy horsemen. Guardian Company engaged in fierce fighting around Juan; Juan personally in serious danger. Several guardians wounded protecting him. Charge disrupted but Moroccan cavalry eventually driven off. Infantry still routing but cavalry took casualties and didn't deliver killing blow.

ranges.label: PARTIAL SUCCESS - HARD FIGHTING
ranges.summary: Charge hits wavering Moorish infantry effectively; enemy formations shatter on impact with hundreds cut down. But Moroccan cavalry launches limited counter-attack on flank. Fighting becomes confused—cavalry melee mixed with pursuit. Juan stays relatively safe behind Guardian Company but combat swirls around him. Witness brutal close-quarters fighting. Charge successful but not clean; enemy cavalry escapes mostly intact. Successful but messy—Juan shaken by violence.

ranges.label: SOLID EXECUTION - EFFECTIVE CHARGE
ranges.summary: Cavalry crashes into Moorish right flank like hammer on anvil; enemy formations collapse immediately on contact. Hundreds trampled, cut down, fleeing in panic. Enemy cavalry attempts intervention too late/disorganized. Guardian Company keeps Juan safe; Juan near action but protected. Witness devastating effectiveness of heavy cavalry against broken infantry. Rout spreads rapidly. Your horsemen pursuing and cutting down fleeing soldiers. Clean tactical success; Juan safe but sees pursuit horror.

ranges.label: DEVASTATING BREAKTHROUGH - CONTROLLED SLAUGHTER
ranges.summary: Charge perfectly timed and positioned; Moorish infantry already fleeing when cavalry arrives. Lance charge becomes pursuit of routing mob with minimal resistance. Enemy formations cease to exist. Juan leads initial charge then falls back as planned; Guardian Company never seriously threatened. Cavalry cuts through enemy like knife through cloth. Moroccan cavalry withdraws rather than counter-charge. Thousands cut down in rout. Total tactical victory; Juan completely safe.

ranges.label: OVERWHELMING SUCCESS - ARMY ANNIHILATION
ranges.summary: Charge hits enemy at moment of complete collapse; no organized resistance, pure massacre of fleeing troops. Enemy cavalry flees immediately rather than contest field. Guardian Company barely needs to protect Juan—no serious threats. Juan witnesses complete disintegration of Sultan's field army; thousands fleeing in all directions with cavalry pursuing. No meaningful combat—just pursuit and killing. Sultan's personal guard attempting desperate withdrawal. Historic victory; Juan safe.

ranges.label: GLORIOUS TRIUMPH - MINIMAL CASTILIAN CASUALTIES
ranges.summary: Everything goes perfectly—textbook cavalry charge; enemy already running before contact. Cavalry pursuit efficient and devastating. Juan personally safe throughout; Guardian Company not tested. Witness Sultan's banners falling and formations dissolving. Moroccan cavalry fleeing without fighting. Infantry advancing unopposed. Complete battlefield dominance. Juan's charge remembered in chronicles—personal glory with minimal risk.

ranges.label: LEGENDARY CHARGE - COMPLETE VICTORY & PERSONAL MOMENT
ranges.summary: Charge becomes legendary—everything perfect. Juan leads 4,000 knights in devastating flanking maneuver; enemy collapses before him like waves before ship. Guardian Company not engaged—no threats materialize. Surreal moment watching enemy army cease to exist. Sultan's standard falls; he flees with handful of guards. Juan's banner advances unopposed. Some enemies throwing down weapons and kneeling. Chronicles remember young King Juan leading charge that destroyed Granada's army. Personal glory, safety, military triumph for the ages.

tables.title: King's Attempt to Rally Scattered Cavalry
tables.context: Military/Leadership — After the initial cavalry charge succeeds but leaves the cavalry formation scattered across the pursuit, King Juan attempts to rally the dispersed knights into an organized striking force. The roll determines how successfully he commands authority and how many cavalry respond to his call.

ranges.label: POOR RALLY - KNIGHTS IGNORE THE CALL
ranges.summary: Most knights ignore the call, focused on personal pursuit and plunder; only Guardian Company (80 knights) and perhaps 100-200 others respond. Total force 200-300 cavalry. Many lords' retinues refuse to abandon independent pursuit. King's authority questioned in moment of victory.

ranges.label: WEAK RESPONSE - MINIMAL RALLY
ranges.summary: Guardian Company plus perhaps 300-400 knights respond; total force 400-500 cavalry. Most continue individual pursuits. Younger knights or household troops with strong loyalty join. Great lords' retinues largely ignore the call. Authority challenged; many prioritize personal glory over royal command.

ranges.label: MODERATE RALLY - RESPECTABLE FORCE
ranges.summary: ~700-800 knights respond to the call; Guardian Company forms core with mixed units from various houses. Some great lords' retinues join when they see others responding. Momentum builds as knights see banner and realize king is rallying. Not everyone responds, but solid striking force forms. Takes 10-15 minutes to form up properly. Adequate response—meaningful force assembled.

ranges.label: GOOD RALLY - STRONG RESPONSE
ranges.summary: ~1,000-1,200 knights respond enthusiastically; visible presence and white armor works. Guardian Company forms core; others flow toward banner. Several prominent lords ride to join personally. Knights abandon individual pursuits to reform with king. Formation comes together in 8-10 minutes. Clear that king commands battlefield. Strong authority—most nearby cavalry responds to call.

ranges.label: EXCELLENT RALLY - OVERWHELMING RESPONSE
ranges.summary: ~1,500-1,800 knights rally to banner; nearly all reforming cavalry responds immediately. Some pursuing knights wheel back when they see rally. Great lords bring entire retinues. Visible enthusiasm—knights want to be with victorious king. Formation tight and ready within 5-7 minutes. White armor becomes focal point. Commanding presence—cavalry eager to follow.

ranges.label: MAGNIFICENT RALLY - LEGENDARY COMMAND
ranges.summary: ~2,000-2,500 knights rally with enthusiasm; not just nearby cavalry but knights abandon pursuits to join. Lords shouting to men: "To the king! Rally to the king!" Formation comes together rapidly and professionally. Knights competing to be close to banner. Even tired troops find energy. Exceptional leadership—absolute loyalty in moment of triumph.

ranges.label: EPIC RALLY - THE KING'S CAVALRY
ranges.summary: ~3,000+ knights respond; cavalry abandons everything to form on banner. Wave of horsemen flowing toward king from across battlefield. Great lords galloping to take position at side. Even Infante Enrique sends cavalry from siege works to join. Formation massive, disciplined, eager. Spontaneous war cries: "¡El Rey! ¡El Rey!" This moment will be painted, sung about, remembered for generations. Total command of battlefield.

tables.title: Contested Cavalry Breakthrough in Final Pursuit
tables.context: Military/Pursuit — King Juan leads his rallied 800 cavalry in a final flanking maneuver to complete the encirclement and destruction of the Sultan's routed forces. The roll determines effectiveness of the charge, Juan's personal combat experience, and the degree to which the rout becomes an annihilation.

ranges.label: MOROCCAN DESPERATE STAND - HEAVY FIGHTING
ranges.summary: Moroccan cavalry sees flanking maneuver and turns to meet it; elite mamluks form blocking force fighting to save infantry. Charge hits organized resistance—fierce cavalry melee erupts. Momentum blunted; fighting becomes grinding cavalry battle. Guardian Company heavily engaged protecting Juan. Juan personally in danger—multiple enemy riders pressing close. Several guardians wounded or killed. Moroccans eventually broken but delay achieved; most infantry escapes in darkness.

ranges.label: CONTESTED BREAKTHROUGH - HARD FIGHT
ranges.summary: Moroccan cavalry attempts to block but numbers overwhelming; running cavalry battle develops. Juan leads charge into their flank; Guardian Company engaged immediately. Close combat around Juan—swords clashing, horses colliding. One guardian takes blade meant for Juan and goes down wounded. Formation breaks through but scattered in the process. Some fleeing infantry killed but disorganized pursuit. Perhaps 500-800 enemy infantry cut down before darkness/exhaustion end pursuit. Sultan's main body escapes with 3,000+ survivors. Partial success; Juan shaken but unharmed; limited casualties.

ranges.label: MOROCCAN FIGHTING WITHDRAWAL - MODERATE SUCCESS
ranges.summary: Moroccan cavalry contests advance but cannot stop it; brief skirmishing as they fall back trying to delay. Some missile fire (arrows, javelins) ineffective against armor. Guardian Company keeps Juan safe; no serious threats materialize. Charge reaches fleeing infantry mass. Systematic pursuit and slaughter begins—hundreds cut down. Moroccans continue harassing but can't prevent massacre. Darkness and exhaustion eventually halt pursuit. Perhaps 1,000-1,500 enemy infantry killed. Sultan escapes with 2,500-3,500 survivors. Solid success; Juan safe; significant casualties.

ranges.label: MOROCCAN WITHDRAWAL - GOOD EXECUTION
ranges.summary: Moroccan cavalry sees organized force and chooses not to contest; conducts fighting withdrawal preserving themselves. Charge encounters minimal resistance. Guardian Company not seriously tested. Charge crashes into fleeing infantry with devastating effect. Routed troops cannot resist—pure massacre. Cavalry cuts through for mile or more until darkness. Systematic pursuit kills 1,500-2,000 enemy infantry. Sultan escapes with 2,000-3,000 survivors. Moroccan cavalry mostly intact covering withdrawal. Strong success; Juan completely safe; heavy enemy casualties.

ranges.label: BREAKTHROUGH AND SLAUGHTER - OVERWHELMING SUCCESS
ranges.summary: Moroccan cavalry breaks before charge arrives; flees rather than contest 800 organized knights. Charge encounters no meaningful resistance. Guardian Company rides beside Juan—no combat threats. Fleeing infantry completely helpless. Systematic massacre over two miles of pursuit until darkness. Exhausted Moors can't run, can't fight. 2,000-3,000 enemy infantry killed before darkness ends pursuit. Sultan escapes with 1,500-2,500 survivors—fraction of original army. Decisive victory; Juan safe; Sultan's army devastated.

ranges.label: COMPLETE ROUT - ARMY ANNIHILATION
ranges.summary: Moroccan cavalry flees immediately when seeing formation; no resistance whatsoever. 800 knights plus scattered cavalry converge on fleeing mob. Complete massacre of defenseless troops. Juan leads pursuit three miles, cutting down exhausted soldiers. Guardian Company never engaged—no threats exist. 3,000-4,000 enemy killed in pursuit. Sultan escapes with 500-1,000 personal guards only. Field army ceased to exist as military force. Darkness finally ends slaughter. Historic victory; Juan safe; Granada's army destroyed.

ranges.label: TOTAL ANNIHILATION - SULTAN NEARLY CAPTURED
ranges.summary: Moroccan cavalry abandons field entirely; charge reaches fleeing infantry unopposed. Systematic destruction of entire routed force. 3,500-4,500 enemy killed in running pursuit. Sultan's guards disintegrating around him. Cavalry nearly catches Sultan's personal group. Black and gold banner falls. Sultan escapes with maybe 200-300 survivors into darkness. Of 16,000 who marched north, fewer than 500 reach Granada. Chronicles call this "The Destruction." Juan personally led pursuit destroying Granada's military power. Legendary victory; complete safety; triumph for the ages.

tables.title: Fortress Garrison's Response to Surrender Terms and Conversion Offer
tables.context: Diplomacy/Religion — After witnessing the Sultan's field army completely destroyed, the fortress commander Yusuf ibn Rashid approaches Juan with unprecedented terms. The commander and garrison face a spiritual and practical crisis. The roll determines whether they simply surrender, negotiate terms, or take the extraordinary step of converting to Christianity and swearing fealty to Juan.

ranges.label: RELIGIOUS DEFIANCE - REJECTION
ranges.summary: Qadi speaks passionately about duty to defend holy ground; commander torn but bound by religious obligation. "We cannot surrender a fortress of Islam while we yet live." Garrison chooses martyrdom over pragmatic surrender. Siege required despite hopeless position.

ranges.label: HARDLINER RESISTANCE - CONDITIONAL REJECTION
ranges.summary: Commander wants to accept but hardcore faction in garrison refuses; demand impossible terms (keep weapons, honor guard, etc.). Internal garrison politics complicate negotiation. "Perhaps Sultan regroups!" Second negotiation after reality sets in likely needed.

ranges.label: CAUTIOUS ACCEPTANCE - MANY CONDITIONS
ranges.summary: Commander accepts principle but demands clarifications: Where can they go? Timeline for evacuation? What about families? Guarantee of safety during withdrawal? Food and water for journey? Want written terms, witnesses, oaths. Will accept with 2-3 days to negotiate details and prepare.

ranges.label: NEGOTIATED ACCEPTANCE - REASONABLE TERMS
ranges.summary: Commander accepts core terms; requests 48 hours to prepare garrison for departure. Asks for safe conduct documents and confirmation families can accompany. Requests small food/water for journey. Will surrender fortress intact with no sabotage. Pragmatic acceptance with face-saving details.

ranges.label: READY ACCEPTANCE - GRATEFUL FOR MERCY
ranges.summary: Commander accepts immediately—"Your Majesty's terms are generous beyond expectation." Clearly relieved to avoid bombardment. Requests 24-36 hours to organize departure. Will surrender all arms and armor. Asks only for safe passage and no pursuit. Qadi agrees this is acceptable. Smooth acceptance; minimal complications.

ranges.label: ENTHUSIASTIC ACCEPTANCE - SWIFT SURRENDER
ranges.summary: Commander accepts without hesitation—"There is no shame in this." Offers to begin surrendering arms tonight if desired. Will open gates at dawn. Minimal possessions needed—just want to leave alive. Some garrison members actually relieved. Can complete handover within 24 hours. Quick, clean surrender.

ranges.label: EAGER SURRENDER - ADDITIONAL OFFERS
ranges.summary: Commander accepts immediately and gratefully; offers intelligence on other fortresses, Granada's military state, supply locations. Some garrison members want to defect entirely (don't want to return to Granada). Commander hints at potential service to Castile. Will surrender fortress completely intact. Offers to convince other fortresses to surrender similarly. Intelligence and defection windfall.

ranges.label: COMPLETE CAPITULATION - STRATEGIC BREAKTHROUGH
ranges.summary: Commander and entire garrison want to surrender AND convert to Christianity; believe God's will demonstrated in today's battle. Qadi himself shaken by catastrophic defeat. Offer to swear fealty to Castilian crown. Will not just surrender but join crusade against Granada. Provide detailed intelligence on Granada's defenses and politics. Conversion becomes model for other surrenders. Historic propaganda victory—Muslim garrison converts and joins crusade.

tables.title: Qadi Ahmad's Response to Court Invitation and Religious Freedom
tables.context: Religion/Personal — King Juan offers the garrison's qadi (Islamic judge) complete religious freedom to join his court, study Christianity, and resolve his profound spiritual crisis without coercion or pressure. The roll determines how the qadi responds to this extraordinary offer.

ranges.label: OUTRIGHT REJECTION - MUST RETURN HOME
ranges.summary: Qadi appreciates offer but cannot accept; feels must return to Granada and community. Serving Christian king = betrayal regardless of religious freedom. Needs to be among own people. Fears cannot think clearly in king's court. Will leave with departing garrison. Polite but firm refusal.

ranges.label: SUSPICIOUS REFUSAL - FEARS A TRAP
ranges.summary: Suspects generous offer is scheme to eventually force conversion; doesn't trust religious freedom will be honored. Thinks serving Christian court will compromise him. Better to face uncertainty in Granada than potential coercion. Appreciates honesty but cannot accept.

ranges.label: UNCERTAIN - NEEDS TIME TO DECIDE
ranges.summary: Offer unexpected and overwhelming; wants to accept but fears implications. Can he serve Christian king while Muslim? What will Granada think? His family? Asks for days to consider. May ask to return with garrison but leave door open to come back. Deeply conflicted—not ready to decide now.

ranges.label: CAUTIOUS CONSIDERATION - MANY QUESTIONS
ranges.summary: Shows interest but raises concerns: What exactly would his role be? Prisoner or genuine advisor? Can he practice his faith openly? Pray five times daily? Dietary restrictions? What about never converting? Can he leave later? Interested but needs reassurances before accepting.

ranges.label: QUALIFIED ACCEPTANCE - CONDITIONAL YES
ranges.summary: Agrees to join court with understanding: must be allowed to practice Islam openly, no pressure to participate in Christian rituals, no conversion pressure or can leave, trial period perhaps 6 months. Will serve as translator/advisor but won't convert to please. Accepts with clear conditions to protect himself.

ranges.label: GENUINE ACCEPTANCE - SEES OPPORTUNITY
ranges.summary: "Your Majesty, I will come." Recognizes this as rare chance to understand Christianity deeply; perhaps understanding "enemy's" faith will help resolve doubts. Values intellectual/spiritual exploration over certainty. Sees offer as genuine. Practical: safer than returning to Granada after fortress fell. Honest: "I do not promise conversion, but I promise honest seeking." Sincere acceptance motivated by intellectual and spiritual curiosity.

ranges.label: GRATEFUL ACCEPTANCE - PROFOUND RELIEF
ranges.summary: "Your Majesty, I accept with gratitude." Your offer answers unspoken prayer. Was dreading return—how counsel faith he doubts? Sees as providential: time and space to search for truth. Moved by respect for his struggle. Recognizes wisdom in learning from both traditions. Commits to serving faithfully. "Perhaps God has led me to this moment."

ranges.label: ENTHUSIASTIC ACCEPTANCE - SEES DIVINE PURPOSE
ranges.summary: "Your Majesty, I believe you were meant to make this offer." Offer itself feels like answer to spiritual crisis. Witnessing battle AND receiving offer = divine guidance. Excited by intellectual challenge of understanding both faiths. Your respect convinces him this is right path. Commits fully to seeking truth, serving faithfully. "If God wishes me to convert, I will know. If not, I will know that too. But I must walk this path."

tables.title: Embassy Journey to Rome Complications
tables.context: Diplomatic mission - Diego Gómez de Sandoval, Fray Hernando, Ahmad al-Zarqali, and three guards travel from Jaén to Rome carrying important letters and reports to Pope Martin V about the crusade victory at Alcalá.

ranges.label: Disaster
ranges.summary: Major incident such as serious ambush, severe illness, detention by hostile authorities, documents damaged or lost, or one person seriously injured, compromising the mission.

ranges.label: Serious Complications
ranges.summary: Attacked by bandits (fought off but with injuries/delays), traveler falls seriously ill, detained and questioned extensively by Aragonese authorities, Ahmad faces open hostility, significant weather delays.

ranges.label: Moderate Difficulties
ranges.summary: Bad weather causes 3-5 day delay, minor illness (recovers), suspicious local authorities require extensive documentation review, some harassment of Ahmad in villages, nervous encounters with armed patrols, horse goes lame.

ranges.label: Minor Complications
ranges.summary: Normal travel challenges: uncomfortable questions at borders, brief detainment for credential verification, travel fatigue and minor aches, small delays from poor roads, wary receptions in some towns, routine difficulties.

ranges.label: Smooth Journey
ranges.summary: Journey proceeds as expected with normal travel challenges but nothing serious. Credentials accepted readily, on schedule, group bonds well, Ahmad adapts to travel, arrive Rome in good condition.

ranges.label: Exceptional Journey
ranges.summary: Everything goes remarkably well: faster than expected, made valuable contacts along the route, Ahmad's story generates positive interest, credentials open doors, arrive ahead of schedule in excellent condition.

tables.title: Rome's Reception of the Embassy
tables.context: Diplomacy - The embassy arrives in Rome (late May/early June 1431) carrying Juan II's military report of the victory at Alcalá, 70+ conversions including a qadi, and a personal letter pledging perpetual crusade service. Pope Martin V is elderly and in poor health; the crusade has his significant personal investment.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure
ranges.summary: Pope Martin V dies before or immediately after arrival. Embassy caught in conclave chaos. Letters acknowledged but lost in political turmoil. Ahmad questioned harshly, some cardinals skeptical of conversion authenticity. No clear papal response.

ranges.label: Poor Reception
ranges.summary: Pope too ill to grant audience or grants only brief formal meeting. Cardinals divided - some enthusiastic, others skeptical. Ahmad faces intense interrogation, some hostility. Response is acknowledgment but not enthusiastic endorsement. Bureaucratic delays.

ranges.label: Mixed Reception
ranges.summary: Pope Martin grants audience but visibly very ill, can't engage deeply. Cardinals interested but divided. Ahmad examined extensively - some fascinated, some suspicious. Theological debates about forced vs. free conversion. Political factions complicate response. Eventually positive but muted.

ranges.label: Adequate Reception
ranges.summary: Pope Martin receives them despite illness, clearly moved by news. Cardinals generally positive with some political skepticism. Ahmad well-received though subjected to thorough examination. Formal papal blessing and letters of commendation granted. Response validates Juan's efforts but not overwhelming.

ranges.label: Strong Positive Reception
ranges.summary: Pope Martin deeply moved, grants substantial audience despite health. Cardinals largely enthusiastic - Ahmad's story captivates Rome. Theological examination of Ahmad goes well, most convinced of genuine conversion. Formal papal letter praising Juan's success. Rome begins spreading the story across Christendom.

ranges.label: Exceptional Reception
ranges.summary: Pope Martin grants multiple audiences, calls it validation of his papacy. Cardinals enthusiastic - Ahmad becomes sensation in Rome. Papal letter elevates Juan as model crusader king. Cardinal Orsini ensures maximum political support. Promises of additional resources. Rome actively promoting Juan's crusade.

ranges.label: Triumph Beyond Expectations
ranges.summary: Pope Martin treats as capstone of his papacy. Public ceremony with Ahmad. Overwhelming enthusiasm spreads through Rome and beyond. Pope declares Juan exemplar of Christian kingship. Cardinals compete to associate with success. Substantial additional support pledged. Juan's reputation elevated to legendary status.

tables.title: Siege of Íllora Progress with Artillery
tables.context: Military - Master of Calatrava's 15,000-troop siege with 5 medium bombards against Íllora fortress (garrison 400-800). Three weeks into siege; Granada conducting sophisticated guerrilla raids and harassment campaign. Artillery present but facing operational difficulties.

ranges.label: Disaster
ranges.summary: Despite artillery, siege failing catastrophically. Major guerrilla raid destroyed powder supplies or damaged bombards. Artillery crews taking casualties. Multiple breaches attempted but repulsed. Relief force approaching or major resupply succeeded. Morale collapsing. Total casualties: 400-600.

ranges.label: Poor Progress
ranges.summary: Artillery functioning but guerrilla harassment severely disrupting operations. Bombards firing intermittently due to security concerns. Some wall damage but garrison repairing at night. Failed assaults costly. Supply raids constant. Morale declining. Total casualties: 250-400.

ranges.label: Slow Progress Due to Harassment
ranges.summary: Artillery creating damage but guerrilla raids slowing everything. Bombards heavily guarded, reducing available troops. Wall breaches created slowly. Garrison determined and repairing damage. Supply stress for both sides. Total casualties: 150-250. Breakthrough possible in 4-6 weeks.

ranges.label: Steady Siege Progress
ranges.summary: Artillery doing its job - systematic bombardment creating wall damage. Guerrilla raids ongoing but manageable. Outworks taken, outer walls breached in places. Garrison holding but under real pressure. Supply deteriorating for defenders. Total casualties: 100-180. Fortress likely to fall in 2-4 weeks.

ranges.label: Good Progress
ranges.summary: Siege progressing well. Artillery systematically dismantling defenses - multiple breaches opened. Effective counter-guerrilla operations keeping raids minimal. Outer defenses fallen, garrison concentrated in inner keep. Defenders showing supply stress and declining morale. Total casualties: 60-120.

ranges.label: Excellent Progress
ranges.summary: Siege going very well. Artillery highly effective - major sections of wall collapsed. Counter-guerrilla operations successful - harassment minimal. Garrison demoralized, low on supplies, requesting terms. Could fall within days to week. Masterful siege management. Total casualties: 40-80.

ranges.label: Imminent Victory
ranges.summary: Outstanding success. Artillery devastated defenses rapidly. Brilliant counter-guerrilla operations eliminated harassment. Garrison commander requesting surrender terms - fortress about to fall. Minimal casualties due to excellent coordination. Total losses: 20-50. Surrender within 2-5 days.

tables.title: Journey from Jaén to Alcalá la Real
tables.context: Travel - Juan II rides from Jaén to Alcalá la Real (50-60 miles) with his personal retinue approximately 50-100 people. Route goes through contested frontier territory during active guerrilla warfare campaign. Two-to-three-day journey.

ranges.label: Catastrophe
ranges.summary: Major ambush by large Moorish raiding force (200+ men). Coordinated attack targeting king specifically. Heavy escort casualties, Juan wounded or in serious danger. Desperate fighting and possible capture attempt. Requires rescue or dramatic escape.

ranges.label: Severe Danger
ranges.summary: Significant ambush (50-100 raiders). Serious fighting, multiple escort casualties, Juan's life endangered. Successfully fight through or escape but at high cost. Several guards killed, possible injuries to Juan.

ranges.label: Dangerous Encounter
ranges.summary: Ambush by moderate raiding party (20-40 men). Real combat, some casualties (2-5 guards wounded/killed). Juan not directly threatened but serious situation. Successfully repel or evade attackers. Some delay and heightened tension.

ranges.label: Close Call
ranges.summary: Encounter scouts or small raiding party (5-15 men). Brief skirmish or tense standoff. Minor casualties or near-misses. Successfully avoid or drive off threat. Some delay and heightened tension.

ranges.label: Minor Complications
ranges.summary: See signs of enemy activity (distant scouts, abandoned ambush sites, warnings from patrols). Take defensive precautions and longer routes. Some delays and nervous travel. Encounter Castilian patrols who provide intelligence. Arrive safely but journey is tense.

ranges.label: Smooth Journey
ranges.summary: Normal wartime travel. Some caution required, occasional distant sightings of possible threats, but no direct encounters. Meet friendly patrols, receive updates. Arrive safely on schedule. Journey uneventful given circumstances.

ranges.label: Favorable Journey
ranges.summary: Journey goes well. Good weather, clear routes, meet several friendly patrols who provide escort sections. Intelligence gathered from soldiers encountered. Arrive ahead of schedule in good condition. Perhaps witness withdrawing Calatrava forces.

ranges.label: Exceptional Journey
ranges.summary: Everything goes remarkably well. Perfect conditions, excellent intelligence from patrols, personally intercept and redirect some withdrawing army elements effectively. Arrive early, fresh, with valuable firsthand observations. Possibly intercept useful intelligence or make strategic decisions en route that help situation.

tables.title: Counter-Ambush Against Moorish Raiders
tables.context: Military - Juan's 20-man force (including Juan, Captain Fernán, guards) counter-ambushes 23 Moorish raiders attempting to ambush a 3,000-man Calatrava withdrawal column. Juan's plan: position to ambush the ambushers, strike when raiders commit to attacking the column.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure
ranges.summary: Discovered before positioning complete. Raiders (100+) surround Juan's force. Desperate fighting, Juan wounded or captured. Multiple casualties, potential disaster. Column too far to help immediately. Complete failure requiring rescue.

ranges.label: Severe Setback
ranges.summary: Poor positioning or discovered too early. Raiders (50-80) turn on Juan's force before counter-ambush triggers properly. Heavy fighting, serious casualties (5-8 guards killed/wounded). Juan endangered directly. Must withdraw under pressure. Intervention fails and costs dearly.

ranges.label: Partial Failure
ranges.summary: Timing off or raider force larger than expected (40-60). Counter-ambush works partially. Intense skirmish, raiders take casualties but inflict some too (2-3 guards wounded). Raiders forced to withdraw but not routed. Column aware and deploys defensively. Limited success, costly.

ranges.label: Mixed Result
ranges.summary: Counter-ambush works partially. Raiders (30-40) surprised when struck from behind but numerous enough to fight back. Brief fighting, raiders take casualties but inflict some. Raiders forced to withdraw but in reasonable order. Column grateful, morale boost. Solid tactical success.

ranges.label: Modest Success
ranges.summary: Counter-ambush effective. Raiders (25-35) caught by surprise when struck from behind. Swift, decisive action breaks raider attack before it develops. Raiders scatter with significant casualties (8-12 killed/wounded). Minimal friendly casualties (1-2 wounded). Column safe. Clear tactical victory.

ranges.label: Clear Success
ranges.summary: Counter-ambush very effective. Raiders (20-30) completely surprised when struck from behind. Devastating surprise attack breaks them decisively. Raiders scatter with significant casualties (8-12 killed/wounded). No friendly casualties or only minor wounds. Column safe, Master personally grateful. Clear victory.

ranges.label: Major Victory
ranges.summary: Brilliant execution. Raiders (30-40) caught completely off-guard and routed decisively. Counter-ambush timed perfectly - hit when positioning for attack. Heavy raider casualties (15-20+ killed/wounded/captured). No friendly casualties or only minor wounds. Prisoners taken. Column witnesses royal courage. Massive morale boost. Story spreads through army.

ranges.label: Legendary Success
ranges.summary: Perfect execution creating extraordinary result. Raiders (30-40) routed completely. Heavy enemy casualties (20-30+ killed/wounded), several high-value prisoners including raid commander. Zero or trivial friendly casualties. Royal banner's reveal at critical moment creates panic. Column deeply inspired. Story becomes legend. Enormous morale impact across entire army.

tables.title: Scout Intelligence: Granada's Military Dispositions
tables.context: Espionage/Reconnaissance - Two weeks of scouting from Alcalá la Real (May 4-18, 1431) to determine Granada's military position, fortress strengths, guerrilla locations, and strategic assembly of forces. Operating from secure base with 19,800 Castilian troops.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Intelligence Failure
ranges.summary: Multiple scout parties ambushed and destroyed (20-40 casualties). Granada knows exact Castilian positions and strength. Counter-intelligence completely effective. Almost no useful information gathered. Possible major enemy force positioned nearby undetected. Dangerous intelligence gap.

ranges.label: Poor Intelligence
ranges.summary: Heavy scout casualties (10-20 killed/captured). Granada's counter-scouting very effective. Minimal useful information gathered - only basic defensive dispositions of nearest fortresses. No intelligence on Granada's army assembly, reinforcements, or strategic intentions. Several contradictory reports suggesting enemy deception.

ranges.label: Limited Intelligence
ranges.summary: Moderate scout casualties (5-10). Gathered basic tactical intelligence about immediate area - fortress strengths, guerrilla patrol patterns, local terrain. But little strategic intelligence. Vague reports about army assembly but no specifics. Moroccan reinforcement rumors but unconfirmed.

ranges.label: Adequate Tactical Intelligence
ranges.summary: Light scout casualties (2-5). Good intelligence on immediate operational area (20 miles) - fortress dispositions, guerrilla operating patterns, supply routes, terrain obstacles. Some strategic intelligence: Granada assembling ~8,000-12,000 troops by summer, Moroccan reinforcements 2,000-3,000 confirmed, mercenary hiring ongoing. Can plan local operations confidently.

ranges.label: Good Intelligence
ranges.summary: Minimal scout casualties (0-2). Excellent tactical intelligence on 30-mile radius - detailed fortress assessments, guerrilla base locations, supply depots, route security. Solid strategic intelligence: Granada fielding 12,000-14,000 by July, specific Moroccan numbers (2,500), mercenary contracts identified, timeline clear. Coastal campaign causing Granada concern.

ranges.label: Excellent Intelligence
ranges.summary: No significant casualties. Comprehensive tactical intelligence - detailed assessments of all fortresses within 40 miles, complete guerrilla order of battle, supply network mapped. Strong strategic intelligence: Granada 14,000-16,000 by mid-July, specific Moroccan details, mercenary information. Intelligence on Sultan's strategic debates and political divisions.

ranges.label: Outstanding Intelligence
ranges.summary: Complete tactical picture plus exceptional strategic intelligence. All nearby fortresses assessed with garrison strengths, leadership, morale, supply status. Guerrilla networks thoroughly mapped. Granada's army details: 14,000-16,000 by July, composition breakdown (Moroccan 2,500, mercenaries 3,500, regular troops). Sultan's court politics known. Specific fortress vulnerabilities identified.

ranges.label: Exceptional Intelligence Coup
