ranges.summary: Everything above PLUS major intelligence breakthrough. Either: high-ranking defector, captured enemy courier with strategic documents, turned Granada spy, or successful infiltration of Granada city. Complete picture of enemy dispositions, intentions, timeline, internal politics. Knowledge of specific upcoming operations. Identifiable weaknesses and opportunities.

tables.title: Sultan Muhammad IX's Response to Castilian Approach
tables.context: Military/Strategy - Sultan has 24-48 hours warning that Juan II is marching 10,000 troops toward Granada city to demand surrender. Sultan's main army not ready until June/July, has only 3,000-4,000 scattered troops available. Must decide defensive response.

ranges.label: Elaborate Ambush/Trap
ranges.summary: Sultan positioned 1,500-1,800 troops in concealed ambush 2-3 miles from Granada. Combines sortie from city with ambush from concealed position. Plan: let Castilians approach and withdraw, then strike during dispersal phase. High risk but potentially high reward. Demonstrates Sultan learned from Alcalá.

ranges.label: Devastating Night Raid
ranges.summary: Elite Moorish force (300-500 raiders) conducts sophisticated night attack on Castilian camp during approach. Target: supplies, command tents, create chaos. Well-planned, executed by best troops. Could cause significant disruption and casualties. Shows Sultan willing to take offensive action.

ranges.label: Coordinated Harassment Network
ranges.summary: Mobile forces (1,200-1,500) positioned brilliantly along approach and around Granada. Constant harassment from multiple directions - never decisive engagement but bleeding casualties. Combined with fortress coordination means Castilians under pressure from all sides. Professional harassment maximizing Granada's advantage.

ranges.label: High-Value Diplomatic Envoy
ranges.summary: Sultan sends senior diplomatic mission to intercept Castilians before Granada. Either Sultan's brother, Grand Vizier, or respected religious figure. Not offering surrender but requesting formal parley. Creates diplomatic complications - refusing to meet looks bad, meeting gives Sultan time and intelligence.

ranges.label: Propaganda and Psychological Operation
ranges.summary: Sultan stages elaborate show of force and confidence. When Castilians arrive at gates, city heavily defended, population visibly defiant, defenders performing military displays. Possibly captive Castilians displayed on walls. Professional psychological warfare to undermine Juan's dramatic gesture.

ranges.label: Intelligence Advantage - Sultan Knows the Plan
ranges.summary: Through spies or deduction, Sultan knows Juan's intentions: demand surrender, get refused, devastate countryside. Prepared accordingly. When demand comes, Sultan's response perfectly calibrated to undermine it. Counter-offer prepared or economic assets fortified or turned into propaganda victory.

ranges.label: Unexpected Military Reinforcement
ranges.summary: Moroccan contingent (800-1,200 troops) arrived earlier than expected, or Sultan pulled more fortress forces than intelligence suggested. Granada has 3,000-3,500 troops in city, not 2,000. Not enough for field battle but enough to sortie aggressively. Makes operation more dangerous than anticipated.

ranges.label: Combined Challenge - Envoy Plus Trap
ranges.summary: Sultan executes sophisticated dual approach. Sends high-ranking envoy to request parley and buy time. While diplomatic mission proceeds, positions military forces (1,500-2,000) for potential ambush or harassment during withdrawal. If Juan refuses envoy, looks unreasonable. If meets envoy, gives Sultan time. Brilliant tactical and political positioning.

ranges.label: Masterful Multi-Layered Response
ranges.summary: Sultan executes comprehensive strategy combining: high-value diplomatic envoy, hidden military forces positioned for surprise, propaganda operation, intelligence advantage, coordinated defensive network. Juan faces multiple simultaneous challenges requiring careful navigation. Sultan turned defensive crisis into opportunity.

tables.title: Sultan's Specific Tactical Plan with Available Force
tables.context: Military/Tactics - Sultan has assembled 3,000-3,500 troops in/near Granada despite intelligence suggesting only 2,000-2,500. Now must decide specific deployment and execution plan for these forces when Juan arrives to demand surrender.

ranges.label: Passive Defense - All Forces Inside City
ranges.summary: All 3,000-3,500 troops positioned inside Granada walls in purely defensive posture. No ambush, no sortie, no harassment. Purely defensive until attacked. When Juan makes demand, Sultan refuses from safety of walls. Castilians can devastate countryside unopposed but achieve no military engagement.

ranges.label: Pure Harassment Strategy
ranges.summary: 1,200-1,500 mobile cavalry in 3-4 groups around Granada's approaches. Remaining 2,000+ inside city. Plan: harass Castilian column constantly during approach - hit supply elements, stragglers, isolated units. Never commit to battle. When demand is made, pause harassment. Resume aggressively during devastation phase. Goal: bleed Castilians without risking defeat.

ranges.label: Hidden Ambush Near City
ranges.summary: Sultan positioned 1,500-1,800 troops in concealed position 2-3 miles from Granada. Remaining forces defend city. Plan: let Castilians approach and make demand, then after refusal when spreading out for devastation, hidden force strikes at vulnerable moment hitting dispersed units. One decisive blow then withdraw to city.

ranges.label: Sortie During Demand Ceremony
ranges.summary: All 3,000-3,500 troops positioned inside city, gates positioned for rapid sortie. Plan: when Juan approaches gates with small escort to make formal demand (vulnerable moment), launch major sortie - 2,000+ troops pour out attempting to capture/kill Juan or disrupt ceremony and inflict casualties. Extremely aggressive, high-risk move. Could kill the king or cause many casualties.

ranges.label: Defensive Sortie During Withdrawal
ranges.summary: All forces inside city during approach. Sultan refuses demand from walls. Waits while Castilians devastate countryside. Once army dispersed destroying infrastructure (units separated, focused on destruction), Sultan launches coordinated sortie of 2,500-3,000 troops targeting dispersed units. Hit when scattered and busy, inflict maximum casualties, withdraw before concentration.

ranges.label: Two-Pronged Defense
ranges.summary: 1,500 cavalry positioned outside city for mobile harassment. 2,000 troops inside city. Plan: cavalry harasses during approach. When demand is made, cavalry withdraws. During devastation phase, city garrison launches limited sortie (800-1,000 troops) while cavalry resumes harassment - pincer attack on dispersed units. Coordinated two-element defense.

ranges.label: Ambush During Withdrawal March
ranges.summary: All 3,000-3,500 troops inside city during approach and demand. Sultan refuses formally. Waits while Castilians devastate countryside. Then launches major pursuit with 2,500-3,000 troops as Castilians march back (column formation, loaded with loot). Combined with fortress harassment, creates dangerous gauntlet during withdrawal.

ranges.label: Coordinated Network Defense
ranges.summary: Sophisticated multi-element network: 800-1,000 mobile cavalry harassing during approach, 1,500 troops in city ready for opportunity sortie, 700-1,000 troops at fortress (probably Moclín) to hit during withdrawal. No single decisive engagement but coordinated pressure from multiple directions throughout operation. Comprehensive plan maximizing all assets.

ranges.label: Aggressive Ambush at Optimal Moment
ranges.summary: Sultan positioned 2,200-2,500 troops in elaborate concealed ambush at narrow valley or river crossing 5-8 miles from Granada on approach route. Plan: let vanguard pass, hit main body in kill zone with overwhelming local superiority before deployment. One massive, well-planned blow then rapid withdrawal to city. Could inflict 300-800 casualties.

ranges.label: Desperate All-Out Sortie
ranges.summary: Sultan makes extremely bold/reckless decision: launches all-out sortie with nearly entire garrison (3,000+ troops) when Castilians approach gates, attempting to defeat army in field battle by catching unprepared during approach. Either catches Castilians by surprise and inflicts major defeat, or Sultan's army destroyed in open battle. Extremely high risk, potentially war-deciding either way.

tables.title: Detection of Sultan's Sortie Plan
tables.context: Espionage - Juan's army captures a Moorish officer (Muhammad ibn Tariq) carrying sealed documents containing Sultan's strategic orders for defensive operations when Castilians approach Granada. Intelligence indicates Major sortie planned when Juan makes formal demand at gates.

ranges.label: No Suspicion - Complete Surprise
ranges.summary: Commanders see nothing unusual. Heavy garrison seems normal defensive response. No special precautions recommended. If sortie happens, Castilians caught completely off-guard. Juan would approach with minimal escort expecting safe parley.

ranges.label: Minimal Awareness - Vague Unease
ranges.summary: Some commanders feel something is 'off' but can't articulate what. Heavy garrison noted but not alarming. Recommend standard escort (100-150 cavalry) as normal precaution. No special preparations. Would be badly surprised but not completely unprepared.

ranges.label: General Wariness - Something Feels Wrong
ranges.summary: Multiple commanders express unease. Heavy garrison noted, gate positioning remarked upon, concentration around western gate observed. Can't identify specific threat but experienced instincts say be careful. Recommend larger escort (200-300 cavalry) and heightened alertness. Moderately prepared for trouble.

ranges.label: Strong Suspicion - Specific Concerns
ranges.summary: Commanders identify multiple indicators suggesting possible sortie: gate positioning, troop concentration patterns, unusual activity, command staff visible near gates. Can't confirm but multiple officers voice concern about sortie during parley. Strong recommendation: substantial escort (300-500 cavalry), main army in battle readiness. Prepared for sortie but not certain.

ranges.label: High Confidence - Sortie Expected
ranges.summary: Multiple clear indicators observed: massive troop concentration directly behind western gate, officers positioned for command, gate mechanisms tested during night, artillery positioned to cover sortie. Commanders near-certain Sultan plans sortie during parley. Strong consensus. Recommendations: large escort (500+ cavalry), main army in full combat readiness.

ranges.label: Near-Certainty - Specific Intelligence
ranges.summary: Overwhelming evidence of sortie preparation: captured scout or deserter provides information, observable preparations unmistakable, possibly intercepted messenger. Commanders know with high confidence that Sultan plans major sortie when Juan approaches gates. Specific numbers and timing unclear but intent certain. Can turn Sultan's trap into Castilian advantage.

ranges.label: Perfect Intelligence - Complete Knowledge
ranges.summary: Definitive intelligence about sortie plan - captured high-value prisoner, intercepted detailed orders, or spy inside Granada. Know exactly: 2,000-3,000 troops massed behind gates, plan to sortie when Juan approaches, goal to kill/capture king or inflict major casualties. Know timing, numbers, commanders involved. Can prepare perfect counter or expose plan publicly.

tables.title: Sultan Muhammad IX's Response to Juan's Challenge
tables.context: Diplomacy/Military Provocation — Juan stands before Granada's gates with 300 cavalry, publicly challenging Sultan Muhammad IX to face him, demanding surrender. The Sultan's response determines whether he launches the sortie force that Juan's army has trapped.

ranges.label: Absolute Refusal, Gate Stays Closed
ranges.summary: Sultan refuses entirely. No sortie, no engagement. Shouts defiance from walls but takes no military action. Complete rejection of challenge.

ranges.label: Missile Response Only
ranges.summary: Sultan orders concentrated crossbow/arrow fire from walls at your position. No troops emerge. Defensive response using fortification advantage.

ranges.label: Token Response
ranges.summary: Sultan sends 200-400 troops out to 'show presence' but with orders not to fully engage. Face-saving gesture without real commitment.

ranges.label: Partial Sortie - Conservative
ranges.summary: Sultan deploys 1,000-1,500 troops (about half his assembled force). Keeps substantial reserve. Measured, cautious engagement.

ranges.label: Partial Sortie - Moderate
ranges.summary: Deploys 1,500-2,000 troops. Commits majority of force but retains some reserve inside gates. Serious engagement but not all-in.

ranges.label: Full Sortie As Originally Planned
ranges.summary: Launches complete sortie force of 2,500-3,000 troops as his plan dictated. Full commitment of prepared forces but nothing beyond that.

ranges.label: Full Sortie Plus Reserves
ranges.summary: Commits sortie force PLUS additional troops from garrison - 3,000-3,500 total. Goes beyond original plan due to rage/desperation.

ranges.label: Massive Overcommitment
ranges.summary: Sultan commits 3,500-4,200 troops - stripping city garrison dangerously. Personal insults drive abandonment of caution.

ranges.label: Reckless Total Commitment
ranges.summary: Nearly entire available force - 4,200-5,000 troops. Sultan either leads personally or sends all senior commanders. Complete loss of strategic restraint.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Overcommitment
ranges.summary: Sultan leads personally with 4,500-5,500 troops, including royal guard and key court figures. Absolute maximum deployment driven by rage and desperation.

tables.title: Opening Phase Battle Execution - Granada Sortie
tables.context: Military — Juan's 300-man escort conducts a fighting retreat to the defensive rally point while hidden flanking infantry emerges and light cavalry responds. The execution of this opening phase determines casualties, formation integrity, and how well the Castilian counter-trap functions.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure
ranges.summary: Multiple critical breakdowns. Hidden infantry fails to emerge on time. Light cavalry delayed. Your escort takes 80-120 casualties and barely reaches rally point in disorder. Must rely entirely on main force to prevent rout.

ranges.label: Severe Problems
ranges.summary: Major execution failures. One flanking group emerges late or in wrong position. Light cavalry sluggish. Your escort suffers 50-80 casualties in disarray. Defensive line incomplete. Enemy maintains initiative.

ranges.label: Significant Issues
ranges.summary: Notable timing problems. Hidden infantry emerges but formation ragged. Light cavalry deployment imperfect. Your escort takes 35-55 casualties. Rally point reached but weak. Enemy maintains initiative.

ranges.label: Mixed Execution
ranges.summary: Plan mostly works with complications. Hidden infantry emerges on schedule but one group slower. Light cavalry adequate but not optimal. Your escort suffers 20-40 casualties. Rally point reached, defensive line forms but gaps exist.

ranges.label: Adequate Execution
ranges.summary: Plan executes as designed with minor issues. Both flanking infantry groups emerge and form defensive line acceptably. Light cavalry responds within expected timeframe. Your escort takes 15-30 casualties. Rally point reached in good order. Defensive line solid.

ranges.label: Good Execution
ranges.summary: Plan works well. Hidden infantry emerges right on time, forms defensive line efficiently. Light cavalry charges promptly, begins harassing enemy. Your escort's retreat is professional with 10-20 casualties. Rally point secure. Strong defensive position established.

ranges.label: Excellent Execution
ranges.summary: Nearly flawless coordination. Hidden infantry surprises enemy completely, emerges precisely. Light cavalry hits enemy flanks at perfect moment. Your escort's retreat textbook with 5-12 casualties. Rally point secure. Enemy momentum completely broken.

ranges.label: Outstanding Success
ranges.summary: Perfect tactical execution. Hidden infantry emergence stuns enemy. Flanking groups form impenetrable line. Light cavalry charge devastates enemy cavalry screen. Your escort nearly untouched (2-8 casualties). Rally point fortress-like. Enemy sortie momentum completely broken.

ranges.label: Masterful Trap Sprung
ranges.summary: Legendary execution. Hidden infantry emergence causes visible terror. Formation instant. Light cavalry charge routes enemy cavalry entirely. Your 300 cavalry virtually untouched (0-4 casualties). Enemy walks straight into perfect ambush. Total tactical surprise achieved.

ranges.label: Historic Perfection
ranges.summary: Perfect execution across all elements. Hidden infantry causes panic. Formation unbreakable. Light cavalry routs enemy cavalry screen. Your escort takes virtually no casualties (0-2). Enemy sortie walks into century-defining tactical ambush.

tables.title: Battle Outcome - Granada Sortie Engagement
tables.context: Military — The main battle begins with the hidden flanking infantry and reinforcements arriving. The sortie force engages Juan's defensive line, then faces the phased arrival of additional infantry and the heavy cavalry hammer blow. Success determines enemy casualties, Castilian losses, and impact on Granada's military capacity.

ranges.label: Disaster - Defensive Line Breaks
ranges.summary: Your defensive line collapses under initial assault. Northern section breaks completely. Moorish troops pour through gaps. Your reserve must commit immediately to prevent rout. Heavy casualties (400-600 killed, 300+ wounded). Enemy suffers moderate losses but achieves tactical success.

ranges.label: Severe Setback - Line Nearly Breaks
ranges.summary: Defensive line holds barely with multiple breaches. Desperate fighting. Your reserve must commit to plug gaps. Heavy Castilian casualties (300-450 killed, 250-400 wounded). Moorish losses moderate (700-1,100). Most enemy force escapes intact. Tactical draw.

ranges.label: Costly Victory - Line Holds at Great Price
ranges.summary: Defensive line holds but takes severe punishment. Heavy casualties (220-350 killed, 200-350 wounded). Moorish losses significant (1,100-1,500 killed/wounded). 1,000-1,400 enemy troops escape. Tactical victory but expensive.

ranges.label: Hard-Fought Success
ranges.summary: Defensive line holds under pressure. Main infantry arrival provides relief. Heavy cavalry charge effective but not devastating. Castilian casualties (160-250 killed, 180-300 wounded). Moorish losses substantial (1,400-1,800 killed/wounded/captured). 700-1,100 escape. Solid tactical victory.

ranges.label: Clear Victory - Plan Works
ranges.summary: Defensive line holds well. Reinforcements arrive with good timing. Heavy cavalry charge breaks enemy formation. Moderate Castilian casualties (120-200 killed, 150-250 wounded). Heavy Moorish losses (1,600-2,100 killed/wounded/captured). 400-900 escape. Strong tactical victory.

ranges.label: Strong Victory - Execution Solid
ranges.summary: Defensive line holds comfortably. Phased reinforcements execute well. Heavy cavalry charge devastating. Moderate Castilian casualties (90-160 killed, 120-200 wounded). Very heavy Moorish losses (1,800-2,400 killed/wounded/captured). 250-700 escape. Convincing tactical victory.

ranges.label: Decisive Victory - Trap Springs Well
ranges.summary: Defensive line dominates. Enemy realizes trap too late to adapt. Reinforcements arrive at perfect moments. Heavy cavalry charge crushes enemy formation. Light Castilian casualties (60-120 killed, 90-160 wounded). Devastating Moorish losses (2,000-2,600 killed/wounded/captured). 150-500 escape. Decisive tactical victory.

ranges.label: Crushing Victory - Near Perfect Execution
ranges.summary: Defensive line overwhelms initial assault. Enemy formation fragments quickly. Phased reinforcements create multiple killing zones. Heavy cavalry charge routes surviving enemy. Minimal Castilian casualties (40-90 killed, 60-130 wounded). Catastrophic Moorish losses (2,200-2,800 killed/wounded/captured). 100-300 escape. Crushing tactical victory.

ranges.label: Overwhelming Victory - Masterful Battle
ranges.summary: Defensive line demolishes enemy assault. Trap execution nearly flawless. Enemy caught in perfect killing ground. Heavy cavalry charge annihilates surviving formations. Very light Castilian casualties (25-60 killed, 40-90 wounded). Massive Moorish losses (2,400-3,000 killed/wounded/captured). 50-150 escape. Overwhelming victory.

ranges.label: Historic Triumph - Complete Destruction
ranges.summary: Perfect execution. Defensive line becomes killing ground. Enemy formation disintegrates. Heavy cavalry charge achieves total rout. Minimal Castilian casualties (15-40 killed, 25-60 wounded). Total Moorish catastrophe (2,600-3,200 killed/wounded/captured). 20-100 straggle back. Historic tactical masterpiece.

ranges.label: Legendary Victory - The Sultan Falls
ranges.summary: Everything goes perfectly. Enemy walks into perfect trap. Total annihilation. Castilian casualties trivial (10-25 killed, 15-40 wounded). Moorish force destroyed (2,800-3,500 killed/wounded/captured). Sultan or key commanders killed/captured. Legendary victory. Campaign potentially shortened dramatically.

tables.title: Western Army Campaign Operations (April-May 1431)
tables.context: Military — The western army under Don Álvaro de Estúñiga conducts a coastal campaign starting from early April. This roll determines how many fortresses are taken, what quality targets are captured, casualty rates, and their current strategic position on the coast.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure
ranges.summary: Landing disasters or major defeat. Beachhead contested, heavy casualties (400-700 killed/wounded). Failed to take any fortresses or only one weak position before forced to withdraw. Granada sent significant forces west and defeated the invasion.

ranges.label: Severe Setback
ranges.summary: Landing succeeded but operations failed. Besieged one fortress, couldn't take it without artillery. Heavy casualties (300-500 killed/wounded). No territorial conquests. Army barely holding beachhead. Granada contesting invasion.

ranges.label: Minimal Progress
ranges.summary: Secured beachhead and took ONE weak coastal fortress. Moderate casualties (200-350 killed/wounded). Progress stalled—next targets prove too strong without artillery. Army intact but frustrated.

ranges.label: Limited Success
ranges.summary: Took ONE significant coastal fortress. Required 3-4 weeks of siege. Moderate to heavy casualties (250-400 killed/wounded). Good position established but no further progress. Army needs rest before continuing.

ranges.label: Modest Success
ranges.summary: Secured TWO coastal positions (one significant, one minor). Combined casualties moderate (200-350 killed/wounded). Established supply chain along coast. Currently preparing for next operation. Decent progress but slower than hoped.

ranges.label: Adequate Success
ranges.summary: Took TWO to THREE coastal fortresses of varying importance. One significant, others smaller. Casualties acceptable (150-280 killed/wounded). Secure supply bases established. Army ready for continued operations. Solid progress matching expectations.

ranges.label: Good Success
ranges.summary: Secured THREE coastal fortresses including at least one major position. Light to moderate casualties (120-220 killed/wounded). Strong coastal foothold established over 25-30 miles. Supply chain secure. Army in good condition, ready for major operation.

ranges.label: Strong Success
ranges.summary: Took FOUR coastal positions including one or two significant fortresses. Light casualties (100-180 killed/wounded). Extensive coastal territory secured (35-40 miles). Excellent supply situation. Army experienced and confident, positioned for push toward Málaga.

ranges.label: Excellent Success
ranges.summary: Secured FOUR to FIVE coastal fortresses including multiple significant positions. Minimal casualties (80-150 killed/wounded). Dominant coastal presence established over 40-50 miles. Granada unable to contest. Army in excellent condition, possibly already besieging Málaga.

ranges.label: Overwhelming Success
ranges.summary: Took FIVE to SIX positions including major fortresses. Very light casualties (60-120 killed/wounded). Granada's entire western coast effectively controlled. May have already taken Málaga or be on verge of doing so. Exceptional campaign execution.

ranges.label: Miraculous Campaign
ranges.summary: Secured SIX+ fortresses including Málaga itself or other major cities. Minimal casualties (40-100 killed/wounded). Granada's western coastal defenses collapsed. Potentially threatening Granada from the west. Historic campaign success exceeding all projections.

tables.title: March to Loja - Movement and Opposition
tables.context: Travel/Military — Juan's army of 19,000 troops and five bombards march 25 miles southwest from Alcalá to Loja. This roll determines the difficulty of the journey, guerrilla harassment, casualties, equipment damage, and delays encountered.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Disaster
ranges.summary: Major coordinated ambush by 500-800 guerrillas at vulnerable point. One bombard damaged beyond field repair, another's ox team scattered. Heavy casualties (120-200 killed, 150-250 wounded). Arrive 4-5 days late. Strategic setback.

ranges.label: Severe Problems
ranges.summary: Large guerrilla ambush (300-500 raiders). Heavy casualties (80-140 killed, 120-180 wounded). Artillery slowed—one carriage needs 2 days repair. Some supplies destroyed. Arrive 3 days late. Morale damaged.

ranges.label: Major Difficulties
ranges.summary: Multiple guerrilla attacks (150-300 total). Moderate casualties (60-100 killed, 80-140 wounded). Artillery progress slowed. One river crossing takes full day for gun transport. Supplies damaged. Arrive 2 days late. Troops tired.

ranges.label: Significant Issues
ranges.summary: Several guerrilla attacks (100-200 total). Moderate casualties (40-70 killed, 60-100 wounded). Artillery movement slower due to road conditions. Some supply difficulties. Arrive 1 day late (3 days total). Army intact but worn. Loja garrison fully alerted.

ranges.label: Minor Problems
ranges.summary: Small guerrilla harassment (50-100 scattered groups). Light casualties (20-40 killed, 30-60 wounded). Some delays at terrain points. Arrive on schedule or slightly late. Army functional, minor wear and tear. Loja knows you're coming.

ranges.label: Routine March
ranges.summary: Occasional guerrilla sightings, few attacks (20-40 raids). Minimal casualties (10-25 killed, 15-35 wounded). Artillery moves at expected pace. Normal march difficulties. Arrive on schedule (2 days). Army in good condition.

ranges.label: Smooth March
ranges.summary: Light guerrilla presence, easily driven off. Very light casualties (5-15 killed, 10-20 wounded). Artillery moves well. Good march pace. Arrive on schedule in good condition. Troops fresh and ready.

ranges.label: Efficient Operation
ranges.summary: Minimal guerrilla activity (scouts spotted and avoided). Trivial casualties (2-8 killed, 5-12 wounded). Artillery moves smoothly. Arrive slightly ahead of schedule. Army in excellent condition. Textbook march.

ranges.label: Excellent March
ranges.summary: No guerrilla encounters. Minimal casualties (0-4 killed, 2-8 wounded). Artillery faster than planned. Perfect weather and terrain. Arrive significantly ahead of schedule. Army fresh, morale high.

ranges.label: Near-Perfect Execution
ranges.summary: Zero enemy contact. No casualties except minor accidents (0-2 wounded). Artillery exceeds expectations. Arrive morning of second day. Catch Loja partially unprepared. Army in peak condition.

ranges.label: Flawless Campaign March
ranges.summary: Perfect execution. Zero casualties, zero delays. Artillery moves like clockwork. Surprise Loja scouts. Arrive evening first day. Complete surprise achieved. Loja garrison not fully prepared. Historic march efficiency.

tables.title: The Strange Bodies Discovery
tables.context: Chaos — Scout patrol found dead Moorish raiders outside Loja fortress; manner of death is unusual and requires investigation to understand factional tensions within Granada's forces.

ranges.label: Disease or Natural Causes
ranges.summary: Bodies show signs of sudden illness with no wounds; disease might be spreading in Granada's forces, suggesting potential weakness but unclear scope.

ranges.label: Executed Deserters
ranges.summary: Clean throat cuts and bound hands indicate Granada's own forces executed them; suggests morale problems, harsh discipline, or internal conflict.

ranges.label: Starvation and Desperation
ranges.summary: Extremely emaciated bodies showing prolonged hunger; Granada's supply situation more dire than intelligence suggested, enemy may be closer to collapse.

ranges.label: Factional Conflict
ranges.summary: Wounds from Moorish weapons killed by fellow Muslims; different tribal insignia indicate infighting between Granada's North African allies and local forces, exploitable political division.

ranges.label: Poisoning
ranges.summary: No visible wounds but bodies show toxic death signs; either accidental poisoning from bad supplies or deliberate poisoning by unknown party.

ranges.label: Christian Partisan Activity
ranges.summary: Killed with Christian weapons; evidence suggests local Christian populations or resistance movement fighting back, potential allies behind enemy lines.

ranges.label: Ritual Execution with Message
ranges.summary: Bodies arranged in specific pattern with carved symbols; clear message sent through psychological warfare, factional messaging, or warning.

ranges.label: Evidence of Secret Negotiations
ranges.summary: Bodies carry documents or tokens suggesting they were messengers meeting with someone; potential intelligence coup or conspiracy with critical strategic value.

ranges.label: Mysterious Circumstances
ranges.summary: Manner of death defies clear explanation with unusual details; unknown origin requires investigation, could be chemical weapon test or elaborate staging.

tables.title: Loja Garrison Response to Surrender Offer
tables.context: Diplomacy — Fortress garrison receives formal offer to surrender before bombardment begins; commanders must decide whether to accept, negotiate, resist, or attempt aggressive action.

ranges.label: Immediate Unconditional Surrender
ranges.summary: Gates open within hours with white flags raised; complete victory but potentially suspicious given ease, possible trap.

ranges.label: Negotiated Conditional Surrender
ranges.summary: Envoys come within 1-2 days requesting safe passage and property retention; pragmatic commander sees writing on wall, rare but possible outcome.

ranges.label: Offer to Convert and Swear Fealty
ranges.summary: Commander converts to Christianity and offers to hold fortress for Castile; potentially huge strategic gain but reliability questionable.

ranges.label: Stalling Tactics
ranges.summary: Request time to consider, ask clarifications; garrison buying time to strengthen defenses or await relief, exposes their strategy.

ranges.label: Defiant Refusal, Professional Preparation
ranges.summary: Polite but firm rejection; garrison settles in for long siege with professional defensive preparations and no heroics, standard siege warfare begins.

ranges.label: Hostile Refusal with Propaganda
ranges.summary: Angry rejection with insults and display of confidence; defenders mock Christian forces and make show of strength, high morale defense with psychological warfare.

ranges.label: Limited Probing Sortie
ranges.summary: Small raid of 30-80 men against siege works testing Castilian defenses; smart military tactics to learn enemy quality with minor skirmish result.

ranges.label: Messenger Escape Attempt
ranges.summary: Riders attempt to break through siege lines at night to reach Granada requesting relief; logical move if relief expected, chase sequence likely.

ranges.label: Major Sally Before Bombardment
ranges.summary: Significant force of 200-400 men attempts aggressive action to destroy siege engines before bombardment; risky but smart strategy, serious battle results.

ranges.label: Factional Violence Erupts Inside
ranges.summary: Internal conflict between different groups becomes visible with fighting on walls; exploitable chaos from Berber and Granadan tensions, opportunity for infiltration.

tables.title: Bombardment Progress at Loja
tables.context: Military — Five medium bombards with experienced crews begin bombardment of Loja's walls after three days preparation; outcome determines siege timeline from rapid breach to slow grinding campaign.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure
ranges.summary: Barrel bursts within first few days killing/wounding crew; down to 4 guns with 4-7 day delay, hidden crack missed in inspection despite preparation.

ranges.label: Major Setback
ranges.summary: Serious mechanical failure or powder quality worse than expected; one gun out of action with 3-5 day delay, equipment worn from campaign.

ranges.label: Slow Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment proceeds inefficiently with walls damaged but repairs keeping pace; after 1 week minimal breach, timeline estimate 3-4 weeks.

ranges.label: Standard Siege Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment effective but not exceptional; after 1 week significant damage, after 2 weeks viable breach, timeline estimate 10-16 days.

ranges.label: Good Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment more effective than expected with two-point strategy working well; after 1 week multiple weak points, timeline estimate 8-12 days to breach.

ranges.label: Excellent Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment highly effective from start with walls poorly maintained; after 4-5 days major section crumbling, timeline estimate 6-9 days to breach.

ranges.label: Rapid Breach
ranges.summary: Walls have hidden structural weakness (earthquake damage, poor repairs); first day bombardment reveals critical vulnerability, cascade failure within 3-4 days.

ranges.label: Psychological Collapse
ranges.summary: Bombardment effective and garrison morale breaks under stress; factional tensions explode, white flags appear after 2-3 days, internal civil conflict.

ranges.label: Commander Offers Terms
ranges.summary: After 1-2 days bombardment, commander sends envoys offering negotiated surrender; pragmatic commander sees inevitability, wants to save lives.

ranges.label: Immediate Dramatic Effect
ranges.summary: First day bombardment causes major structural collapse; tower falls or wall section collapses immediately, white flags within 24-48 hours.

tables.title: Qaid Yusuf's Response to Surrender Terms
tables.context: Diplomacy — Fortress commander considers King Juan's generous surrender offer allowing garrison to depart with arms, colors, and safe conduct; decision impacts immediate surrender terms and future garrison morale across Granada.

ranges.label: Accepts Immediately and Gratefully
ranges.summary: Commander accepts with visible relief, needs 2-3 days to organize garrison departure; smooth surrender with garrison departs peacefully.

ranges.label: Accepts but Needs Time to Convince Garrison
ranges.summary: Commander finds terms acceptable but must consult with captains; some hardliners resist, needs 1-2 days for consensus, ceasefire requested.

ranges.label: Accepts with Face-Saving Request
ranges.summary: Commander accepts but requests small ceremony—formal surrender of keys, written guarantee, or night departure to preserve honor and convince men he negotiated, not capitulated.

ranges.label: Requests Modifications for Civilians
ranges.summary: Accepts garrison terms but wants guarantee Christians won't resettle immediately; requests time for evacuation, property protection, or escort for departing civilians.

ranges.label: Requests Modifications for Garrison
ranges.summary: Accepts but requests horses, supplies, written safe-conduct documents, or provision for wounded; practical concerns for journey through war zone.

ranges.label: Requests Timeline Adjustment
ranges.summary: Seeks 5-6 days instead of 3 to prepare garrison and convince holdouts; possibly waiting for Sultan's permission to surrender for political cover.

ranges.label: Garrison Split on Terms
ranges.summary: Commander accepts but some men refuse; North African troops want to fight to death, asks if refusers can fight while others surrender, factional split.

ranges.label: Commander Accepts but Can't Control All Forces
ranges.summary: Commander accepts but warns may not speak for everyone inside; hardliners might fight anyway, mostly peaceful surrender but risk of incidents.

ranges.label: Religious/Honor Obligation Rejection
ranges.summary: Refuses due to religious duty or fear of Sultan's punishment; apologetic but firm, must fight to preserve faith or honor, siege continues.

ranges.label: Hardliners Override Commander
ranges.summary: Commander wants to accept but others seize control; possible coup inside fortress, commander can no longer speak for garrison, assault required.

ranges.label: Stalling for Relief
ranges.summary: Appears to accept but secretly waiting for reinforcements; uses negotiation to repair defenses or prepare trap, deception likely discovered.

ranges.label: Assassination/Trap Attempt
ranges.summary: Negotiation is ambush setup attempting to kill or capture Juan; violates parley sacred trust, outrage if detected, no mercy in assault follows.

tables.title: Málaga Garrison Reaction to Surrender Demand
tables.context: Military diplomacy — Juan approaches Málaga's gates to offer honorable surrender terms before beginning bombardment, following his successful precedent at Loja.

ranges.label: Treacherous Ambush
ranges.summary: Gates open and 200 cavalry burst out attempting to kill or capture Juan personally in a premeditated trap. Heavy fighting, extremely dangerous situation for the king.

ranges.label: Hostile Rejection with Violence
ranges.summary: Arrows and crossbow bolts fired from walls (falling short but demonstrating intent). Governor appears declaring jihad and religious condemnation. No negotiations possible, absolute defiance.

ranges.label: Firm Professional Refusal
ranges.summary: A senior military officer appears on walls with respectful but unyielding response: they honor Juan's reputation but cannot surrender without defending the city. Absolute refusal but no insults. They will fight with military professionalism.

ranges.label: Cautious Conditional Response
ranges.summary: Garrison requests clarification on exact terms. What happens to garrison, civilians, property? Can they keep weapons? This is buying time while testing Juan's seriousness, but genuine questions indicate possible negotiation.

ranges.label: Serious Negotiation Begins
ranges.summary: Gates open partially and three senior officials emerge under white banner wanting to negotiate in earnest. Real possibility of surrender if terms acceptable. Internal divisions visible between those wanting to fight and those wanting terms.

ranges.label: Strong Inclination to Surrender
ranges.summary: Governor himself appears on walls, clearly troubled, expressing willingness to consider terms seriously. Sends emissaries immediately. High chance of acceptance if terms generous. Garrison visibly divided.

ranges.label: Immediate Acceptance
ranges.summary: Within an hour, gates open and governor emerges with senior commanders unarmed. Overwhelming force and Juan's reputation convinced them resistance is futile. Málaga submits with conditions.

tables.title: Week One Bombardment Complications
tables.context: Chaos/military — First week of siege operations (June 17-24) encounters unexpected difficulties that slow progress but don't prevent bombardment continuation.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Disaster
ranges.summary: Massive explosion in powder magazine kills 15-20 gunners including senior staff. Two bombards damaged, one possibly destroyed. Sortie overruns siege works killing 80-120 Castilians. Bombardment halted 5-7 days for repairs.

ranges.label: Serious Military Setback
ranges.summary: Night assault spikes one bombard (3 days repair), damages another, destroys 2 barrels of powder. 40-60 Castilian casualties. OR: Bombard suffers barrel failure killing crew of 6. Down to 3-4 operational guns, bombardment significantly slowed.

ranges.label: Significant Complications
ranges.summary: Major sortie (300-400 troops) overruns forward siege works, kills 50-80 men, forces temporary withdrawal requiring 1 day to restore positions. OR: Unusual summer storm damages gun platforms requiring 2-3 days rebuilding. Bombardment delayed but continues.

ranges.label: Minor Tactical Setback
ranges.summary: Small sortie damages one gun platform, kills 15-25 men (1 day repair). OR: Powder contaminated by moisture reducing fire rate. OR: One bombard cracks requiring 2 days offline. Annoyance rather than crisis.

ranges.label: Defender Resilience
ranges.summary: Walls prove tougher than expected, requiring 10-12 days instead of 7-10 for adequate breaches. Defenders maintain high morale, repair damage nightly, maintain strong watch. No major incidents but slower progress.

ranges.label: Steady Expected Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment proceeds as planned with two breach points forming after 7-8 days, neither yet assault-ready but growing. Minor sorties easily repulsed. Naval blockade holding firm. Supply situation excellent. Progress on schedule.

ranges.label: Solid Progress with Advantages
ranges.summary: Bombardment highly effective with two good breach points developing, will be assault-ready in 2-3 more days. Minor sortie easily repulsed with light Castilian casualties (8-12) and heavier defender losses (30-50). Blockade perfect, intelligence shows growing tension inside city.

ranges.label: Excellent Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment exceptionally effective with one breach nearly assault-ready and second developing well after just 5-6 days. Successful night raid on defender supply depot. Intelligence indicates factional tensions inside city. Small civilian delegation attempts reaching Castilian lines.

ranges.label: Major Tactical Success
ranges.summary: After 5-6 days, breakthrough achieved with one section of wall collapsing (100+ foot gap). Second breach excellent. Defenders attempt desperate sortie, crushed with 100+ dead and 60+ captured vs. 15-25 Castilian casualties. Clear assault opportunity developing.

ranges.label: Extraordinary Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Multiple successes compound. After just 4-5 days, two excellent breaches opened and weak point discovered. Major defender sortie ambushed and routed with 150+ dead, 80+ captured. Intelligence from prisoners shows serious factional split and worse-than-expected food situation.

ranges.label: Strategic Collapse Imminent
ranges.summary: After just 4 days, three major breaches opened. Major sortie turns into rout with 200+ casualties and 100+ captured. Prisoners reveal garrison commander killed, successor arguing with governor, civilian bread riots, secret delegation negotiating behind garrison's back.

ranges.label: Surrender Delegation Emerges
ranges.summary: Before full breaches completed, white flags appear. Internal coup against hardline governor by city notables and merchants. Delegation requests negotiation terms before blood is shed. Garrison split, civilian population demanding action. Major shortcut to victory possible.

tables.title: Specific Bombardment Phase Complications
tables.context: Chaos/military — Detailed breakdown of specific complications during the significant setback period, ranging from military sorties to weather events to equipment failures.

ranges.label: Major Coordinated Sortie
ranges.summary: Three specific sortie scenarios: (1) Dawn assault on gun positions killing 58 guards, spiking one bombard, damaging another, burning powder (36-hour halt); (2) Night raid on supply convoy killing 35 guards, burning 12 wagons (1-day delay); (3) Massive daylight sortie (400 troops) killing 67 men, forcing 1-day positional restoration.

ranges.label: Severe Weather Event
ranges.summary: Three weather scenarios: (1) Mediterranean storm floods positions, spoils 30% powder, undermines gun platform requiring 2.5 days recovery; (2) Extreme heat wave exceeding 100°F drops bombardment rate 40% for 3 days, 120+ heat casualties; (3) Flash flooding from mountains sweeps 3-4 feet water through camp, drowns 12 men, requires 2-day recovery.

ranges.label: Technical/Equipment Failure
ranges.summary: Three technical scenarios: (1) Powder shipment contaminated, must be destroyed, reduces bombardment to 60% for 3 days while replacement arrives; (2) Gun platform structural failure during firing collapses, kills 2 crew, injures 6, requires 2.5 days rebuild; (3) Other equipment failures causing scattered problems.

ranges.label: Defender Tactical Success
ranges.summary: Two scenarios: (1) Gibralfaro counter-battery begins effective fire, forces two gun positions relocation further back reducing effectiveness, ongoing harassment; (2) Defenders demonstrate extraordinary repair capability, nightly crews rebuild damage with rubble and timber, breaches require 10-11 days instead of 7 due to effective repairs.

ranges.label: Supply/Logistics Disruption
ranges.summary: Two scenarios: (1) Fleet anchorage disrupted by wind, forced to relocate 15 miles east for 48 hours, one transport damaged, supply convoy arrives 2 days late; (2) Disease outbreak (dysentery) affects 180+ men, 8 deaths, one gun crew offline 3 days, takes 4 days to contain.

ranges.label: Combined/Unusual Complications
ranges.summary: Three scenarios: (1) Sortie during storm exploiting chaos, kills 34 men, combined weather+sortie damage = 3 days recovery; (2) Gibralfaro observation advantages allowing defenders to time sorties perfectly, three raids over 4 days total 45 casualties; (3) Morale crisis from unexpected resistance, rumors of months-long siege, minor mutinies requiring leadership intervention and 1-day delay.

tables.title: Week Two Siege Progress
tables.context: Military — Second week of bombardment (June 25-July 1) experiences ongoing counter-battery fire harassment from Gibralfaro fortress above, slowing but not preventing progress toward assault readiness.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Powder Explosion
ranges.summary: Explosion in powder magazine June 27th kills 22 men including 8 gunners, destroys one bombard completely, damages two others requiring 3-4 days repair. Requires 4-5 days to clear wreckage and restore operations. Major morale blow.

ranges.label: Major Coordinated Assault
ranges.summary: Another major sortie (300 troops) June 28th targets different positions, kills 47 men, damages two gun platforms requiring 2 days repair each. Shows garrison still capable despite blockade. Bombardment delayed 48 hours.

ranges.label: Serious Equipment Failure
ranges.summary: One bombard suffers barrel crack June 26th from metal fatigue and heat, kills 4 crew, wounds 8, gun beyond field repair. Down to 4 operational bombards. Progress slowed 25-30% for remainder of siege.

ranges.label: Heat Wave Crisis
ranges.summary: Extreme heat (105°F+) June 25-29 makes operations dangerous. Gun crews can only work dawn/dusk safely. Powder becomes volatile causing two flash-fire incidents (6 men burned). 150+ heat exhaustion cases, 3 deaths. Bombardment rate drops 50% for 4-5 days.

ranges.label: Counter-Battery Success
ranges.summary: Gibralfaro artillery finds range and accuracy June 26-30. One direct hit kills 9 gunners. Multiple near-misses cause casualties. Forces relocation of one gun position further back reducing effectiveness. Ongoing harassment—not crippling but constant threat to crews.

ranges.label: Minor Setbacks
ranges.summary: Small sortie (80 troops) June 27th causes minor disruption killing 18 men, burns supplies, driven off. OR: Powder shipment delayed 2 days by fleet logistics. OR: Gun platform subsidence requiring 1 day repairs. OR: Mild dysentery outbreak affects crew for 3 days. Progress continues but slowed.

ranges.label: Steady Grinding Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment proceeds as planned through the week. By July 1st, primary breach 25-30 feet wide and 8-10 feet deep, secondary breach 18-20 feet wide. Neither quite assault-ready yet but close. Blockade holding firm, intelligence reports food prices inside tripling.

ranges.label: Good Progress with Advantages
ranges.summary: Bombardment highly effective. By June 30th, primary breach 30+ feet wide and assault-ready, secondary nearly ready. One small sortie easily repulsed, defenders suffered 35 casualties vs. 12 Castilian. Prisoners report food rationing, civilian complaints, command arguments.

ranges.label: Excellent Progress
ranges.summary: Multiple successes compound. By June 29th, two excellent breaches assault-ready, third weak point discovered. Defenders attempt sortie, intercepted and ambushed, driven back with 45 casualties vs. 8 Castilian. Intelligence reports serious food situation and civilian pressure.

ranges.label: Major Breakthrough
ranges.summary: June 28th, section of wall collapses spontaneously from bombardment undermining foundations. Three excellent breach points now available. Defenders demoralized with sluggish wall response. Major sortie crushed with 90+ dead and 40+ captured.

ranges.label: Internal Collapse Signs
ranges.summary: By June 30th, multiple breaches opened AND internal crisis visible. Deserters report civilian bread riots, merchant guild demanding surrender, Qaid Ibrahim losing authority to competing factions. City visibly fracturing with opposing power groups.

ranges.label: Negotiation Attempt
ranges.summary: June 29th, white banner appears with senior official requesting parley. Does not have full garrison backing—clear factional split visible. Wants to discuss terms but can't guarantee garrison compliance. Parallel power structures emerging.

ranges.label: Garrison Command Requests Terms
ranges.summary: June 30th, Qaid Ibrahim himself requests formal parley. Professional soldier recognizing reality after two weeks bombardment and multiple breaches. Wants honorable surrender terms similar to Loja. Still has garrison loyalty but needs face-saving terms.

ranges.label: Unconditional Surrender Offer
ranges.summary: July 1st, city gates open with white flags everywhere. Complete internal collapse from civilian pressure, food crisis, and bombardment damage. Delegation emerges asking only for safety of people. Complete victory without final assault.

tables.title: Week Three Siege Progress Toward Assault
tables.context: Military — Third week of bombardment (July 1-7) sees steady methodical progress as breaches become assault-ready despite ongoing counter-battery harassment and defender resilience.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Disaster
ranges.summary: Powder magazine explosion kills 35+ men, destroys two bombards, damages third severely, destroys weeks of supplies. Delays assault 2-3 weeks minimum while rebuilding. Catastrophic morale impact.

ranges.label: Major Disaster - Successful Massive Sortie
ranges.summary: All-out sortie (600+ troops) June 4th catches Castilians during shift change. Kills 70-90 men, destroys one bombard, heavily damages another, burns supplies. Two-hour battle. Delays assault 7-10 days.

ranges.label: Serious Setback - Gibralfaro Massacre
ranges.summary: Counter-battery fire achieves devastating accuracy. Multiple direct hits kill 23 gunners, wound 35, destroy one platform completely. Forces relocation of all guns further back to 400+ yards. Reorganization takes 4-5 days.

ranges.label: Significant Problem - Disease Outbreak
ranges.summary: Serious dysentery outbreak July 1-5 affects 300+ men, 15 deaths. One gun crew offline 4 days. Quarantine and medical response required. Assault delayed 5-7 days while situation controlled.

ranges.label: Moderate Setback - Heat Wave Crisis
ranges.summary: Extreme heat (108°F+) July 2-6 restricts bombardment to dawn/dusk only (4-5 hours daily). 200+ heat casualties, 5 deaths. Progress slowed 40%. Troops irritable with discipline problems. Normal operations resume July 7th.

ranges.label: Steady Progress Toward Assault
ranges.summary: Bombardment continues methodically through week despite counter-battery harassment. By July 6-7, both primary breaches assault-ready (30+ feet wide, rubble slopes climbable). Third breach point developing. Minor sortie July 3rd easily repulsed, 35 defender casualties vs. 15 Castilian. Blockade effect visible with slower defender movements. Assault can proceed July 7-8.

ranges.label: Good Progress - Early Assault Readiness
ranges.summary: Bombardment highly effective. By July 5th, two excellent breaches ready, third nearly ready. Counter-battery minimal (Gibralfaro conserving ammunition?). One sortie intercepted with 45 dead vs. 8 Castilian. Prisoners report exhaustion, civilians demanding action, critical food situation. Assault ready immediately.

ranges.label: Excellent Progress - Multiple Advantages
ranges.summary: Exceptional week. By July 4th, three excellent breaches (primary 35+ feet). Wall sections between breaches weakened. Sortie crushed with 65 dead and 28 captured vs. 12 Castilian. Prisoners report quarter rations, bread riots July 2nd (garrison killed 20 civilians), command chaos.

ranges.label: Major Breakthrough - Wall Collapse
ranges.summary: July 3rd, section of wall collapses spontaneously creating 60+ foot gap. Three major entry points now available. Defenders demoralized with visible panic. Desperate sortie July 4th driven back immediately, 40 casualties vs. 5 Castilian.

ranges.label: Internal Crisis Visible
ranges.summary: By July 5th, breaches ready AND internal collapse signs. Three deserters report massive civilian unrest, garrison split between hardliners and moderates, Qaid Ibrahim lost command authority, food riots daily, supplies for only 7-10 more days. White flags briefly appeared July 4th then hauled down.

ranges.label: Negotiation Delegation Emerges
ranges.summary: July 4-5, white flags on walls. Senior delegation (qadi, merchant leaders, junior officers) requests parley. Internal coup in progress against hardliners. Real chance of negotiated entry if acceptable terms offered.

ranges.label: Garrison Command Requests Terms
ranges.summary: July 5th, Qaid Ibrahim appears with white banner. Accepts reality after three weeks bombardment—no relief coming, breaches ready, food running out, civilians in open revolt. Wants honorable surrender terms. Can avoid assault entirely.

ranges.label: Mass Desertion
ranges.summary: July 4-5, 30-40 garrison soldiers desert, reach Castilian lines. Report complete internal collapse—morale shattered, officers losing control, civilians rioting, food nearly exhausted. Remaining garrison demoralized and fragmented.

ranges.label: Civilian Revolt Opens Gates
ranges.summary: July 6th early morning, civilian uprising inside city. Merchants and common people overwhelm gate guards, throw open section. White flags everywhere. Mob of civilians seeks protection. City effectively fallen though Alcazaba and Gibralfaro still hold.

ranges.label: Complete Surrender - All Fortifications
ranges.summary: July 5th, total collapse. Gates open, white flags on city walls, Alcazaba, AND Gibralfaro. All commanders including Qaid Ibrahim, Alcazaba commander, Gibralfaro commander emerge to surrender. Complete victory without assault.

tables.title: Málaga Assault Success Outcome
tables.context: Military — July 9th assault on Málaga's breached walls to storm the city and take the Alcazaba fortress, measuring overall effectiveness and casualties incurred.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Disaster
ranges.summary: Multiple coordinated disasters. Major pre-dawn sortie kills 60+ men and disrupts formations. Breach assault bogs down under fierce resistance with garrison prepared killing zones. Crusader force takes wrong streets and ambushed (80+ casualties). Alcazaba repulses first assault (150+ dead). Forced withdrawal after 6 hours. 400+ dead, 600+ wounded. Must reorganize and retry in 2-3 days.

ranges.label: Major Setback
ranges.summary: Assault succeeds but at terrible cost. Breach fighting bloodier than expected with garrison prepared defensive positions. 200+ casualties at breaches. Crusader force reaches Alcazaba but first assault repulsed (100+ casualties). Takes 8 hours brutal fighting to subdue fortress. Final toll: 350-450 dead, 500-700 wounded. Victory very costly.

ranges.label: Serious Complications
ranges.summary: City walls breached successfully but urban fighting chaotic. Plunder discipline breaks immediately—troops scatter to loot. Crusader assault force undermanned, struggles against fierce Alcazaba defense. Takes 6-7 hours to subdue fortress. Significant civilian casualties. Final cost: 250-350 dead, 400-600 wounded.

ranges.label: Significant Difficulties
ranges.summary: Breaches taken with moderate casualties (80-100 dead). Urban fighting spreads, some garrison fights from strongpoints. Crusaders reach fortress but face determined resistance—two assaults repulsed before third succeeds. Takes 5-6 hours to secure city and fortress. Final toll: 180-250 dead, 350-500 wounded. Hard-fought victory.

ranges.label: Moderate Challenges
ranges.summary: Wall breaches successful, casualties light (50-70 dead). Most garrison retreats to Alcazaba as expected. Crusader assault force navigates successfully, assaults from three directions. Fierce fighting but overwhelmed by numbers and coordination. City secured in 4-5 hours. Final cost: 140-180 dead, 280-400 wounded.

ranges.label: Expected Hard-Fought Success
ranges.summary: Assault proceeds as planned. Breaches taken efficiently (40-60 dead), crusaders drive for Alcazaba while main army secures city. Fortress assault difficult but coordinated three-pronged attack succeeds after 2-3 hours. Some garrison surrender, others fight to death. 3-4 hours to complete. Final toll: 100-140 dead, 220-320 wounded. Good execution.

ranges.label: Solid Professional Victory
ranges.summary: Well-executed assault. Breaches taken quickly with light casualties (30-50 dead). Garrison morale cracking—many flee to Alcazaba, some surrender in streets. Crusaders reach fortress rapidly, coordinated assault succeeds. Qaid Ibrahim accepts defeat when position hopeless. 2-3 hours total. Final cost: 80-110 dead, 180-260 wounded. Clean victory.

ranges.label: Efficient Success
ranges.summary: Excellent execution. Breaches taken minimally (20-40 dead)—defenders already demoralized. Most garrison retreats, smaller groups surrender. Crusaders assault aggressively, defenders' morale breaks quickly. Qaid Ibrahim negotiates surrender after 30 minutes fighting. Most garrison surrenders. 2 hours total. Final cost: 60-90 dead, 140-200 wounded.

ranges.label: Superior Performance
ranges.summary: Swift, decisive assault. Walls breached easily (15-30 dead)—garrison exhausted and demoralized. Rapid city advance, crusaders reach Alcazaba within 45 minutes. First assault meets fierce resistance but second wave breaks through. Qaid Ibrahim orders surrender after brief fighting. 90 minutes total. Final cost: 40-65 dead, 100-160 wounded.

ranges.label: Excellent Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Rapid success with low casualties. Breaches taken with ease (10-20 dead), garrison broken. Widespread desertion—soldiers drop weapons in streets. Crusaders reach Alcazaba unopposed. First fortress assault succeeds—defenders half-hearted, many surrendering immediately. Qaid Ibrahim fights briefly for honor then surrenders. 60-90 minutes total. Final cost: 25-40 dead, 70-120 wounded.

ranges.label: Near-Perfect Execution
ranges.summary: Assault goes remarkably smoothly. Breaches virtually unopposed (5-15 dead)—defenders flee or surrender. Crusaders surge through city meeting no resistance. Fortress defenders see inevitability—white flags appear almost immediately. Qaid Ibrahim negotiates ceremonial resistance then formal surrender. 45-60 minutes. Final cost: 15-25 dead, 50-90 wounded.

ranges.label: Early Surrender During Assault
ranges.summary: Breaches taken minimally (10 dead), crusaders begin advancing when white flags appear from Alcazaba. Qaid Ibrahim sees walls fall and chooses surrender over pointless death. Garrison lays down arms. Bloodless city entry. Some plunder but controlled. 30 minutes after surrender accepted. Final cost: 10-15 dead, 30-50 wounded. Near-bloodless victory.

ranges.label: Mass Surrender at Breach
ranges.summary: White flags appear on walls as assault columns form at breaches. Internal collapse visible—garrison morale shattered, civilians demanding surrender, Qaid Ibrahim recognizes futility. Gates open before assault begins. Garrison disarms, most civilians shelter peacefully. Bloodless occupation. Final cost: 5-10 dead, 20-40 wounded.

ranges.label: Complete Capitulation
ranges.summary: Night before assault (July 8th evening), delegation emerges. Qaid Ibrahim, city officials, civilian leaders request surrender with honor. They have seen breaches and know what assault means. Negotiate terms overnight. Gates open peacefully July 9th. Zero casualties. Complete victory. Málaga submits intact.

tables.title: Gibralfaro Garrison Response to Surrender Ultimatum
tables.context: Diplomacy/military — Isolated mountain fortress garrison chooses between accepting immediate surrender terms or holding out for starvation siege after watching city and Alcazaba fall.

ranges.label: Fanatical Defiance
ranges.summary: Hardline commander rejects surrender utterly, executes officers advocating surrender. Garrison committed to fight to death. Will hold 4-6 weeks until starvation forces surrender as prisoners per Juan's warning. Bitter end.

ranges.label: Determined Resistance
ranges.summary: Commander refuses surrender on principle—wants to defend the fortress without fighting yet. Plans indefinite holdout hoping Granada sends relief. Garrison unified behind resistance. Requires 3-5 week siege before forced surrender as prisoners.

ranges.label: Divided Garrison - Holdouts Win
ranges.summary: Internal debate rages with hardliners prevailing. Some desertions (20-30 slip away at night), but majority stays. Will hold 2-4 weeks before food exhaustion forces surrender. Final surrender as prisoners with lingering resentment.

ranges.label: Conditional Negotiation
ranges.summary: Commander sends delegation to negotiate better terms: personal weapons, horses for officers, safe conduct to specific location, no mistreatment guarantee. Trying to improve the offer. Accept concessions or 50/50 chance they hold out.

ranges.label: Delayed Acceptance
ranges.summary: Commander needs time to consider. Internal debate ongoing—professionally recognize hopelessness but pride demands not seeming too eager. Will accept same terms but after 12-24 hour delay. Tests Juan's patience slightly.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Surrender
ranges.summary: Commander recognizes reality quickly. City fell, Alcazaba surrendered honorably with mercy. Professional soldiers see the inevitable. Formal surrender process takes 3-4 hours (mustering troops, organizing exit), but no resistance.

ranges.label: Prompt Acceptance
ranges.summary: Commander responds within 30 minutes accepting terms. Garrison relieved they're getting generous terms. Expected to die but got reprieve. Surrender complete within 2 hours. Commander thanks Juan for mercy. Very smooth process.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Acceptance
ranges.summary: Commander almost eager to accept after seeing what happened below. If King Juan honors his word with Qaid Ibrahim, they would be fools to refuse. Rapid surrender, grateful garrison. Relocation within 1.5 hours. Professional respect from commander.

ranges.label: Immediate Surrender with Praise
ranges.summary: Delegation meets Don Rodrigo halfway down mountain without waiting full two hours. Accepts immediately, praising Juan's honor. Commander eager to formalize, asks to meet king personally to thank. Garrison orderly and respectful. Complete within 1 hour.

ranges.label: Surrender with Offer of Service
ranges.summary: Not only surrenders but offers more: 50-80 professional soldiers willing to serve King Juan as garrison troops if pay and treatment acceptable. Commander and twenty officers willing to switch sides given honorable treatment. Unusual offer of employment. Major recruitment opportunity.

ranges.label: Defection En Masse
ranges.summary: Commander and twenty officers want to convert to Christianity and serve King Juan—see his crusade and honor as clearly favored by God. Most garrison just wants safe passage but leadership seriously considering switching sides. Major propaganda victory if genuine.

ranges.label: Formal Alliance Offer
ranges.summary: Commander proposes more than service—suggests formal alliance where garrison troops swear permanent loyalty, convert to Catholicism, integrate fully into Castilian military structure. Permanent garrison force from turned enemies. Extraordinary political victory.

tables.title: Granada's Strategic Response While Awaiting Moroccan Aid
tables.context: Military Strategy — The Sultan must decide how to employ his forces during the crucial months while waiting for Moroccan reinforcements promised to arrive by October/November 1431. His strategy has been diplomatic (the foreign aid appeal), but now he must choose his operational approach.

ranges.label: Pure Passivity
ranges.summary: Sultan orders complete defensive withdrawal with no offensive operations. All forces pull back to Granada city and key strongholds, focusing on fortification and supply stockpiling. Politically risky as some commanders see this as cowardice, morale suffers, but forces remain intact.

ranges.label: Defensive Fortification Focus
ranges.summary: Sultan commits resources to strengthening remaining positions with wall repairs and supply depot preparation. Only small cavalry patrols for intelligence, minimal harassment. Conservative approach preserving forces intact while preparing for Moroccan integration.

ranges.label: Active Harassment Campaign
ranges.summary: Sultan deploys 1,500-2,500 light cavalry and raiders to make Castilian occupation painful through ambushes, supply convoy attacks, and foraging party strikes while avoiding pitched battles. Balances caution with activity, forcing Juan to spread troops and slowing western operations.

ranges.label: Aggressive Raiding Strategy
ranges.summary: More aggressive version of harassment with 3,000-4,000 troops committed to systematic raiding across multiple fronts. Targets Loja garrison supplies and Master of Santiago's columns, showing strength to demoralized troops while risking larger engagements.

ranges.label: Limited Objective - Probe for Weakness
ranges.summary: Sultan sends 4,000-5,000 troops to test Castilian positions for isolated garrisons or weak points. Calculated risk seeking opportunity without committing to major battle, willing to withdraw if opposition is strong.

ranges.label: Overambitious Counter-Offensive
ranges.summary: Political pressure leads Sultan to attempt recapture of recently lost position with 6,000-8,000 troops. High risk showing boldness but poor judgment given strategic situation, could suffer catastrophic defeat right before Moroccan aid arrives.

ranges.label: Divided Strategy / Internal Conflict
ranges.summary: Competing factions prevent unified approach. Some commanders raid aggressively while others stay defensive, resources split between fortification and offensive prep. Confused execution wastes the waiting period with internal squabbling.

ranges.label: Desperate Gamble Before Aid Arrives
ranges.summary: Sultan attempts major operation attacking Juan's main army or Master of Santiago hoping to win victory before Moroccans arrive. Terrible timing and political desperation overrules military sense, risks disaster right when help is coming.

ranges.label: Strategic Disaster
ranges.summary: Major blunder: attacks just as Moroccans arrive disrupting coordination, gets caught repositioning forces, or loses key commander to assassination/defection. Whatever time was bought gets wasted through catastrophic error.

tables.title: Foreign Aid Appeal Success - Moroccan Response
tables.context: Diplomacy — Sultan Yusuf III has dispatched an embassy to Morocco and North African powers seeking military and financial aid. This roll determines how successful the desperate appeal to Morocco is and what aid is actually committed.

ranges.label: Complete Failure
ranges.summary: Sultan's envoys find doors closed in Morocco. The Marinid Sultan views Granada as lost cause, fears Portuguese retaliation, and has internal troubles. Offers symbolic prayers but no troops or money. Embassy returns empty-handed by October, Granada is truly alone.

ranges.label: Token Support Only
ranges.summary: Morocco sends diplomatic encouragement, religious scholars for morale, and perhaps 50,000 dinars in emergency funds. Symbolic rather than strategic support showing solidarity but no meaningful military impact, highlighting Granada's abandonment.

ranges.label: Modest Success
ranges.summary: Morocco commits to sending 2,000-3,000 troops arriving late autumn/winter 1431, plus 100,000+ dinars arriving by September. Not enough to change strategic situation but complicates Juan's plans. Granada gets breathing room but not salvation, with 2,500 Moroccan troops arriving October/November.

ranges.label: Significant Support
ranges.summary: Morocco takes threat seriously, commits 4,000-5,000 troops with experienced commanders and 200,000+ dinars arriving October/November. Enough to matter strategically, forcing Juan to face 15,000-20,000 enemy troops by winter and changing calculations for 1432 campaign.

ranges.label: Major Commitment
ranges.summary: Full Marinid intervention with 6,000-8,000 elite troops, substantial funds (300,000+ dinars), and naval support. First contingents arrive September, main force October/November. Becomes Moroccan-backed proxy war with Granada having genuinely dangerous military capabilities.

ranges.label: Regional Coalition
ranges.summary: Morocco rallies multiple North African powers (Tunis, Tlemcen) collectively committing 8,000-10,000 troops and massive funds. Pan-Islamic response complicates Juan's situation: Aragon pressured, naval warfare intensifies, crusade becomes multi-year commitment.

ranges.label: Strategic Game-Changer
ranges.summary: Morocco commits 10,000+ troops and proposes joint naval offensive against Castilian coast while Granada reinforced. Threatens to open new fronts, could force Juan to divide forces or negotiate. Fundamentally alters strategic picture despite months-away timeline.

ranges.label: Miraculous Intervention
ranges.summary: Perfect storm with Morocco inspired by religious fervor, other powers joining, 12,000+ reinforcements arriving by late August/September via emergency naval transport. Granada gets 12,000+ reinforcements by autumn making Sultan's position suddenly viable again and stalling Juan's conquest.

tables.title: Master of Santiago's Western Campaign - First 30 Days
tables.context: Military Campaign — The Master of Santiago has been sent west with 10,000 troops, artillery, and naval support to capture coastal fortresses. This roll determines how well his first month of campaigning proceeds despite Granada's harassment campaign and fortress resistance.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Setback
ranges.summary: Major disaster strikes through ambush or critical error. Heavy casualties (800-1,200 men), artillery damaged or lost, campaign stalls completely. Master of Santiago wounded or discredited, requiring Juan's direct intervention to salvage situation.

ranges.label: Significant Complications
ranges.summary: Multiple problems converge: Granada raiders hit supply trains successfully, heat causes serious attrition, one fortress resists longer than expected. Takes only Marbella with higher casualties (400-600). Campaign behind schedule, morale strained.

ranges.label: Modest Progress with Difficulties
ranges.summary: Takes Marbella after week-long siege but faces resistance and complications. Granada harassment effective against supply lines. Estepona either still under siege or bypassed due to problems. Captures 1-2 positions total. Casualties moderate (250-400). On track but struggling.

ranges.label: Steady Progress
ranges.summary: Campaign proceeds competently. Marbella falls after 5-7 days, Estepona more easily. Takes 2 significant fortresses plus 1-2 minor positions. Casualties light-moderate (150-250). Granada raiders annoy but don't stop advance. Solid professional campaign.

ranges.label: Good Success
ranges.summary: Master performs well with reputation effect working. Marbella falls quickly (4-5 days), Estepona surrenders after single offer. Takes 2-3 significant fortresses plus several minor positions. Casualties light (80-150). Naval coordination excellent, campaign ahead of schedule.

ranges.label: Excellent Results
ranges.summary: Everything clicks with strong reputation effect. Takes 3-4 significant positions with minimal fighting. Casualties very light (40-80). Granada raiders fail to disrupt operations. Master demonstrates tactical brilliance, western coast crumbling faster than expected.

ranges.label: Outstanding Success
ranges.summary: Master exceeds all expectations with cascade of surrenders. Takes 4-5 significant fortresses plus numerous minor positions. Some garrisons surrender before arrival after hearing news. Casualties minimal (15-40). Granada harassment crushed, approaching Gibraltar by month's end.

ranges.label: Strategic Windfall
ranges.summary: Beyond military success, captures political/strategic bonus like Granada commander defection or major intelligence discovery. Territory gains PLUS game-changing advantage. Master of Santiago becomes legendary, changes strategic calculus for entire war.

ranges.label: Miraculous Campaign
ranges.summary: Entire western coast to Gibraltar collapses in 30 days. Multiple simultaneous surrenders, zero casualties in some operations. Master returns in triumph having accomplished 3 months' work in one, Granada's western infrastructure disintegrates.

tables.title: Infante Enrique's Counter-Raiding Campaign - 30 Days
tables.context: Military Campaign — Infante Enrique is tasked with organizing a 3,000-cavalry counter-raiding force to hunt down and destroy Granada's harassment raiders who have been bleeding Castilian forces. This roll determines the success of his hunt against experienced frontier fighters.

ranges.label: Campaign Failure
ranges.summary: Enrique's operations backfire badly. Raiders ambush one of his columns, inflicting heavy casualties (150-250 men). Intelligence network compromised—informants killed or turned. Raiders become more effective, emboldened. Enrique forced to defensive posture. Losses to raiding actually increase.

ranges.label: Poor Results
ranges.summary: Enrique struggles adapting to guerrilla warfare. Catches few raiders (50-100 killed), but at similar cost to own forces. Intelligence network develops slowly, locals afraid or unsympathetic. Raiders remain elusive, continue nearly unhindered. Raiding continues at roughly same level.

ranges.label: Modest Success
ranges.summary: Mixed results with 2-3 raiding bands destroyed (200-300 enemy killed/captured total), forcing others to be cautious. Raids reduce by 30-40%. Moderate casualties (100-180). Intelligence network developing slowly. Progress frustratingly slow.

ranges.label: Solid Performance
ranges.summary: Enrique adapts well destroying 4-5 raiding bands (400-500 killed/captured), capturing staging areas. Intelligence network functioning—informants providing useful tips. Raids reduced by 50-60%. Acceptable casualties (60-120). Granada's raiders forced onto defensive.

ranges.label: Good Success
ranges.summary: Highly effective operations destroying 6-8 raiding bands (600-800 killed/captured), capturing multiple camps and supply caches. Intelligence network excellent. Raids reduced by 70%. Light casualties (30-80). Successful 'hammer and anvil' operations frequent.

ranges.label: Excellent Results
ranges.summary: Masterful counter-insurgency destroying 10+ bands (1,000+ killed/captured), eliminating staging areas, capturing senior commanders. Intelligence network highly effective with increasing local cooperation. Raids reduced 85-90%. Minimal casualties (15-40).

ranges.label: Outstanding Campaign
ranges.summary: Campaign becomes textbook counter-insurgency with total infrastructure destruction (1,200-1,500 killed/captured), captured high-ranking officials, rolled-up communication network. Raiding completely eliminated. Nearly bloodless for Enrique's forces (under 20 casualties).

ranges.label: Strategic Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Captures high-ranking Granada official or turns major commander, or discovers communication network. Raiding completely eliminated PLUS actionable intelligence about Granada's main defenses or Moroccan aid. Changes war's trajectory.

ranges.label: Legendary Victory
ranges.summary: Perfect counter-insurgency success destroying Granada's raiding capacity (1,500+ killed/captured), capturing enemy leadership, local Muslim population actively supporting Christians. Zero significant casualties. Morale triumph making Enrique legendary. Granada demoralized.

tables.title: Journey to Málaga - d100 Resolution Table
tables.context: Military - Juan travels south from Jaén to Málaga to take personal command of western operations against Granada raiders who have been plaguing supply lines for months.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Journey
ranges.summary: Major ambush by large raider force inflicts significant casualties (30-50 men) and endangers Juan's life. Serious injury or potential capture attempt with major intelligence failure.

ranges.label: Bad Complications
ranges.summary: Encounter with raiders requiring fighting withdrawal. 5-15 casualties among escort, delays of 1-2 days, lose supplies/horses. Arrive shaken and depleted.

ranges.label: Minor Issues
ranges.summary: Near-misses with raider scouts, evidence of recent attacks, forced detours around dangerous areas. Arrive 1 day delayed with nervous troops but no combat.

ranges.label: Uneventful Journey
ranges.summary: Reach Málaga safely in 3-4 days without incident. Standard travel with no significant encounters beyond distant sightings.

ranges.label: Good Journey
ranges.summary: Swift travel in 3 days with useful intelligence gathered from patrols. Learn raider patterns and locations of recent attacks.

ranges.label: Excellent Journey
ranges.summary: Very fast travel (2.5 days), encounter and capture raider scouts, extract valuable intelligence about raider base locations and numbers.

tables.title: March to Ronda - D100 Resolution Table
tables.context: Military - Juan's 6,000-man army marches northeast from Málaga toward Ronda (stronghold of Granada raiders) through 8-10 days of hostile hill country with multiple opportunities for ambush by coordinated raider bands.

ranges.label: Catastrophic March
ranges.summary: Major coordinated raider attacks at multiple chokepoints with villages resisting violently. Heavy casualties (400-600 men), lose significant supplies, potential bombard damage. Arrive severely weakened.

ranges.label: Serious Difficulties
