ranges.summary: Multiple significant raider ambushes inflict steady casualties (200-350 men). 2-3 villages resist and must be assaulted. Delays mount (11-13 days). Arrive depleted and demoralized.

ranges.label: Moderate Challenges
ranges.summary: Regular raider harassment throughout march with mixed village responses. 1-2 villages resist requiring military action. Casualties moderate (100-180 men). Reach Ronda in 9-11 days, tired but functional.

ranges.label: Good Progress
ranges.summary: Raiders shadow and probe but crossbow discipline prevents major attacks. Most villages submit when they see the army; one resists and is destroyed as example. Casualties light (50-90 men). Arrive Ronda in 9-10 days, army intact and ready for siege operations.

ranges.label: Strong March
ranges.summary: Overwhelming show of force intimidates opposition. Villages submit rapidly after first example made. Raiders harass but can't penetrate formation—minimal casualties (20-40 men). Arrive Ronda in 8-9 days, fresh and psychologically dominant.

ranges.label: Triumphant March
ranges.summary: Perfect execution. Villages capitulate immediately seeing the king and massive host. Raiders attempt attacks but are bloodied and withdraw. Capture raider scouts with intelligence. Very light casualties (5-15 men). Arrive Ronda in 8 days at full strength.

tables.title: Ronda Garrison Response to Surrender Demand - D100 Resolution Table
tables.context: Diplomacy - Juan rides out personally in white armor to demand surrender of Ronda, one of Granada's strongest fortresses. The garrison commander Muhammad ibn Rashid must decide whether to resist or negotiate.

ranges.label: Fanatical Defiance
ranges.summary: Commander spits from walls, garrison fires on delegation. Declares they'll die before converting. Hardliners suppress moderates violently. Siege will be brutal and costly.

ranges.label: Defiant Rejection
ranges.summary: Formal refusal citing honor and faith. Closes gates, prepares for siege. Will fight but may negotiate later if bombardment proves devastating.

ranges.label: Conditional Negotiation
ranges.summary: Willing to discuss terms but not immediate surrender. Wants guarantees: safe passage for those refusing baptism, property retention, proof of good faith. Suspicious of promises despite Juan's reputation.

ranges.label: Internal Division
ranges.summary: Garrison splits with visible arguments on walls (30-40% wanting surrender). Request time to consult—actually internal power struggle. Outcome depends on which faction wins.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Consideration
ranges.summary: Commander requests parley, wants to understand terms clearly. Doesn't refuse outright but needs convincing. Sees Juan's logic but struggles with religious implications.

ranges.label: Reluctant Agreement to Terms
ranges.summary: Commander recognizes hopelessness. Agrees to surrender if terms match Alcalá la Real: converters keep property; refusers get safe passage to Granada. Needs 24-48 hours to present to garrison.

ranges.label: Immediate Surrender
ranges.summary: Commander rides out personally within hours, kneels before Juan, offers sword. Garrison demoralized after watching systematic conquest. Mass conversions expected. Gates open by nightfall.

tables.title: Journey to Toledo at Best Speed - D100 Resolution Table
tables.context: Travel - Juan travels 150 miles from Ronda to Toledo at best speed with 100-man cavalry escort after consolidating the conquest. Isabel is in Toledo, 6 months pregnant, waiting.

ranges.label: Serious Incident
ranges.summary: Encounter with desperate raider band or major horse breakdown forces fighting or significant 2-3 day delay. Minor casualties (3-8 men) or Juan takes minor injury. Arrive Toledo late and depleted.

ranges.label: Major Complications
ranges.summary: Bad weather, multiple horse breakdowns, or minor raider harassment forces slower pace. Significant delays (1-2 extra days). Arrive exhausted with ruined horses. 8-9 days total journey.

ranges.label: Minor Delays
ranges.summary: One incident (weather, minor encounter, horse problems) slows progress. Brief detour or rest needed. Arrive 1 day late (7-8 days journey) but safely. Troops tired but intact.

ranges.label: Solid Journey
ranges.summary: Hard riding with minor inconveniences (tough terrain, brief weather, distant sightings). Arrive in 6-7 days as planned. Troops and horses tired but functional.

ranges.label: Good Progress
ranges.summary: Fast travel with few problems. Good roads past hill country, cooperative weather, no real threats. Arrive in 6 days, troops tired but satisfied.

ranges.label: Excellent Journey
ranges.summary: Near-perfect conditions with clear weather, good roads, strong horses, no threats. Arrive in 5-6 days, minimal exhaustion.

ranges.label: Swift and Fortunate
ranges.summary: Exceptional journey with favorable encounters (friendly patrols provide fresh horses, perfect weather, excellent roads). Arrive in 5 days, fresher than expected. Good news or helpful allies en route.

tables.title: Reports and Issues for Royal Attention (Late October 1431)
tables.context: Chaos — Álvaro de Luna presents a selection of reports and developments requiring Juan II's attention across military, diplomatic, economic, and religious domains during crusade preparations.

ranges.label: Very Positive Developments
ranges.summary: Major breakthroughs include a Granadan commander offering to defect with 500 troops, wealthy merchant guilds provisioning the crusade, or reports of Sultan Muhammad IX being seriously ill with succession crisis brewing.

ranges.label: Positive Developments
ranges.summary: Favorable outcomes such as new crusader volunteers from León, successful frontier raids capturing supplies, or reports that Granadan garrison morale is declining and economy is strained.

ranges.label: Neutral or Mixed Developments
ranges.summary: Complex situations requiring judgment, such as competing merchant requests for post-conquest trade rights, disputes over command structure, or theological questions about conversos joining the crusade.

ranges.label: Negative Developments
ranges.summary: Concerning but manageable problems including banditry on supply routes, disease outbreaks, late contingents, desertion among crusaders, or talented officers receiving better offers from rival kingdoms like Aragon.

ranges.label: Serious Negative Developments
ranges.summary: Major crises such as Granadan raids penetrating deep into Castilian territory, disease striking crusader camps, key infrastructure collapse, or evidence of spying undermining crusade security.

ranges.label: Crisis Developments
ranges.summary: Severe threats including rebellion in northern provinces, Pope reconsidering crusade authorization due to Basel disputes, major Granadan preemptive invasions, or disappearance of the Infantes.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Developments
ranges.summary: Multiple simultaneous catastrophic crises such as rebellion combined with invasion and mutiny, or massive Marinid reinforcements far exceeding expectations arriving in Granada.

tables.title: Cortes Response to Opening Speech on Crusade Tax
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan II presents his opening speech to the Cortes of Castile, announcing a new 8% crusade tax with troop compensation structure, elimination of regular crown taxes, and invoking military victories and papal authority. The nobles must react to this major fiscal reform.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure - Open Revolt
ranges.summary: Multiple great houses stand in outrage, accusing Juan of tyranny disguised as crusade. Representatives of resistant houses lead walkout threatening to withdraw support entirely. Some shout about summoning retinues. Juan's authority is directly challenged and the Cortes might collapse before debate begins.

ranges.label: Serious Failure - Unified Opposition
ranges.summary: Strong, coordinated resistance from 40-50% of nobles. The resistant houses' representatives speak eloquently about taxation without true consent and royal overreach. Motion made to reject the law entirely. Moderate nobles waver and Juan faces potential defeat of the proposal.

ranges.label: Failure - Hostile Reception
ranges.summary: Clear majority skeptical or opposed. Many nobles visibly angry about 8% rate. Questions shouted about duration, compensation for small estates, and confiscation. Resistant houses find unexpected allies among exhausted middling nobility. Archbishop Gutiérrez looks concerned and major concessions will be needed.

ranges.label: Mixed/Poor - Cold Reception
ranges.summary: Polite but unenthusiastic response. Scattered applause dies quickly. Most faces show concern rather than support. Nobles begin calculating quietly and realize many will pay more. Questions about 'crusade complete' definition and whether this sets permanent precedent. Debate will be contentious with genuinely uncertain outcome.

ranges.label: Mixed/Neutral - Divided Response
ranges.summary: Hall splits visibly with don Íñigo the Elder and loyal houses nodding approvingly, but many others look troubled. Murmuring is not hostile but not supportive. Representatives of resistant houses sit stone-faced. Moderate nobles calculating whether compensation offsets tax. Will require significant debate and possibly modifications.

ranges.label: Success - Cautious Acceptance
ranges.summary: Respectful attention throughout. Moderate applause when Juan finishes. Don Íñigo the Elder stands in approval. Questions are serious but not hostile, seeking clarifications about payment schedules and ending conditions. Resistant houses' representatives object but are clearly minority. Strong chance of passage with minor modifications.

ranges.label: Good Success - Positive Reception
ranges.summary: Solid applause and many nobles nodding, especially those who supplied troops. 'Fair compensation!' someone calls out. Even some neutral nobles look pleased with the math. Questions are constructive rather than hostile. Resistant houses' representatives isolated. High probability of passage without major changes.

ranges.label: Great Success - Enthusiastic Support
ranges.summary: Strong applause breaks out with multiple nobles standing immediately in support. 'Justice for those who serve!' they cry. Don Íñigo: 'WELL SPOKEN, YOUR MAJESTY!' Others echo support. Nobles begin calculating loudly that they'll actually profit. Representatives of resistant houses sit silent and isolated. Near-certain passage.

ranges.label: Extraordinary Success - Overwhelming Acclaim
ranges.summary: The hall erupts in applause with nobles rising to their feet. 'The King honors warriors!' they shout. The compensation structure is praised as brilliant - finally recognizing military contribution properly. Multiple nobles volunteer to speak in favor during debate. Resistant houses' representatives look shocked at isolation. Some nobles call to vote immediately without debate.

tables.title: Cortes Response to Recovery Arguments with Granada Promise
tables.context: Diplomacy — After receiving cold reception, Juan answers Don Pedro's concerns about 'when the crusade ends' by clarifying the papal bull, comparing 8% favorably to the 10% tithe, and promising land and titles in Granada to warriors. He challenges the Cortes to recognize the advantages of the new opportunity.

ranges.label: Makes It Worse - Outrage at Implication
ranges.summary: Don García de Mendoza rises flushed: 'Your Majesty implies we are cowards?' Multiple nobles shout agreement. The accusatory tone has backfired catastrophically. Nobles who were neutral now lean hostile. Even some loyal houses look uncomfortable. Juan has insulted men who can't afford large retinues through no fault of their own.

ranges.label: Serious Failure - Deepens Opposition
ranges.summary: The 'ask themselves why' comment lands poorly. Murmurs of discontent spread. 'Easy for great houses to profit,' someone mutters. Don Pedro: 'Your Majesty, some serve faithfully with what they have. This law favors the already powerful.' Many nobles nod. Even Archbishop Gutiérrez winces at the tone.

ranges.label: Failure - Concerns Not Addressed
ranges.summary: Your arguments don't sway the skeptics. 'Still doesn't explain how we pay 8% after eight months in the field,' a voice calls. Another: 'Granada could take years to fully conquer!' Fundamental financial burden remains. The tithe comparison is dismissed as irrelevant. Hostile questions multiply.

ranges.label: Poor - Minimal Movement
ranges.summary: A few nobles nod at the Granada land promises, which is attractive. But most remain unconvinced. Don Pedro: 'Your Majesty clarifies the duration, but that could still be years.' The compensation explanation doesn't satisfy those without large retinues. Some take offense at the implication. Hall remains divided and tense, perhaps slightly worse than before.

ranges.label: Mixed - Partial Recovery
ranges.summary: The Granada land promises generate real interest with several ambitious nobles leaning forward. The endpoint clarification helps somewhat. But the 'ask themselves why' line causes uncomfortable shifting. Don Íñigo tries to help. Some convinced, many still troubled. Juan has stopped the slide but hasn't won them over.

ranges.label: Modest Success - Slight Improvement
ranges.summary: The arguments register with several nobles nodding at the tithe comparison - 8% does sound more reasonable framed that way. Granada land promises spark visible excitement among warrior houses. Duration clarification satisfies some concerns. But inequality issue remains for smaller houses. Don Pedro sits down, not fully satisfied but no longer openly challenging.

ranges.label: Success - Clear Improvement
ranges.summary: Your confidence and clear answers shift the mood. The Granada land promises work brilliantly with multiple nobles sitting straighter. 'Those who fight will be rewarded with estates!' The tithe comparison makes 8% seem reasonable. Even some skeptics nod. The 'ask themselves why' line is forgiven as passionate rather than insulting. Don Íñigo: 'The King speaks truth!' Momentum shifting in Juan's direction.

ranges.label: Good Success - Strong Recovery
ranges.summary: The hall's energy changes notably. Granada land promises ignite ambition with nobles imagining southern estates. 'This is opportunity!' The tithe comparison lands well. Your confident tone reassures rather than offends. Don Pedro de Velasco: 'His Majesty makes fair points. The compensation IS generous for those who serve.' Even smaller houses see the appeal.

ranges.label: Great Success - Decisive Shift
ranges.summary: The Granada vision catches fire with multiple nobles rising. 'Estates in conquered territory!' The warrior tradition appeal resonates powerfully. Your directness seen as kingly strength. Don Íñigo: 'Those who take up the sword will be rewarded!' Even cautious nobles warm to the vision. Resistant houses sit isolated. Clear path to passage emerging.

ranges.label: Overwhelming Success - Complete Turnaround
ranges.summary: Your passionate defense transforms the room. 'This is the Reconquista spirit!' nobles shout. The Granada land promises ignite wild enthusiasm. 'We finish what our ancestors started!' Even skeptics rise in approval. Your challenge inspires rather than offends. Nobles compete to speak in favor. Cold reception completely forgotten.

tables.title: Cortes Response to 5% Tax Concession
tables.context: Diplomacy — After two challenging rolls, Juan makes a major strategic concession, lowering the tax from 8% to 5% (the original crusade tax rate) while keeping all the benefits (troop compensation and elimination of regular crown tax). He appeals to humility, partnership with nobles, and the principle that the crown belongs to God's glory, not his own.

ranges.label: Impossible Demand - Resistant Houses Reject Entirely
ranges.summary: The Baron de Medina's representative stands immediately: 'Any crusade tax is illegitimate!' But he is utterly isolated. The rest of the hall stares at him in disbelief. 'Sit down! The King just gave us everything!' someone shouts. This obstructionism backfires completely - these representatives now look like unreasonable rebels.

ranges.label: Minor Grumbling - Small Minority Still Resistant
ranges.summary: A handful of nobles, perhaps five or six, still look uncomfortable, muttering about precedent and permanent structures. The three resistant houses' representatives sit stone-faced. But they are utterly alone as the overwhelming majority of the hall has moved on.

ranges.label: Cautious Acceptance - Final Details Needed
ranges.summary: Most nobles nod approvingly, but Don Pedro de Velasco raises a hand requesting clarification on procedural matters - payment schedules, troop verification processes, formula for mixed forces. These are reasonable administrative questions, not opposition. The principle is accepted and passage is certain after brief discussion.

ranges.label: Positive - Clear Approval
ranges.summary: Solid applause breaks out across the hall. Don Rodrigo de Perea stands: 'Your Majesty has answered our concerns with grace and wisdom. At five percent with compensation, the mathematics work fairly for all.' Multiple nobles rise to voice agreement. Don García de Mendoza: 'This is justice!' The resistant houses' representatives sit isolated. Passage virtually assured.

ranges.label: Good Success - Strong Support
ranges.summary: The hall erupts in appreciative applause. 'Five percent!' voices call out. 'The King listens!' Don Íñigo the Elder: 'This is how a wise king rules—with his nobles, not over them!' Don Fernando de Guzmán stands: 'Your Majesty has transformed this from burden to opportunity.' Multiple nobles rise to endorse. The three resistant houses' representatives look increasingly isolated and foolish.

ranges.label: Great Success - Enthusiastic Endorsement
ranges.summary: The atmosphere transforms completely. Nobles surge to their feet applauding. 'The King honors us!' Don Rodrigo calculates aloud: 'At five percent, my estate pays 7,500, receives perhaps 10,800 for thirty men—I profit 3,300 maravedís while serving the crusade!' Others work similar calculations, faces lighting up. 'This rewards service perfectly!' Multiple nobles call to vote immediately.

ranges.label: Overwhelming Success - Near Unanimous
ranges.summary: The Cortes rises to its feet as one in sustained applause. 'WISDOM! JUSTICE!' voices ring out. Don Íñigo: 'You have given us everything we asked and more!' Nobles compete to praise your flexibility and wisdom. Even relatives of the condemned sit silent, unable to defend their masters' position. Multiple nobles pledge immediate payment and support.

ranges.label: Triumphant Moment - Acclamation
ranges.summary: The hall erupts in cheering with nobles rushing forward to pledge support. 'To the King! To Granada! To December 1433!' Don García de Mendoza, tears in his eyes, speaks of true kingship. The mathematics spread like wildfire—nobles realizing they'll actually profit. Multiple nobles call for immediate vote by acclamation. Resistant houses' representatives look stunned.

ranges.label: Legendary Success - Historic Unity
ranges.summary: Your concession creates a moment of profound kingdom unity. The entire Cortes erupts in simultaneous cheering and applause. Nobles embrace each other, celebrating. Don Rodrigo: 'Your Majesty has united this kingdom through wisdom!' Cardinal Capranica writes furiously, clearly impressed. Archbishop Gutiérrez declares: 'God's grace is upon this assembly!' This will be remembered as the moment Juan II transformed Castilian governance.

ranges.label: Transcendent Moment - The Cortes Transformed
ranges.summary: Something extraordinary happens. The combination of your earlier humility, voluntary surrender of power, and now this generous concession creates an almost spiritual experience. Nobles weep openly. Don Íñigo falls to his knees: 'This is the king we have prayed for!' The entire Cortes spontaneously begins singing 'Te Deum Laudamus.' Your vision of singing it together in Granada 1433 has begun here, now. This transcends politics and becomes a sacred covenant between king and kingdom.

tables.title: Cortes Response to Excommunication Announcements
tables.context: Religion/Intrigue — Juan announces the excommunication and land forfeiture of Count of Niebla, Baron de Medina, and Don García de Sotomayor for violent resistance against crown tax assessors and destruction of papal documents. He presents three formal excommunication bulls prepared by Cardinal Capranica and threatens military action. This is a harsh punishment designed to demonstrate that violence against royal authority has severe consequences.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Backfire - Defensive Solidarity
ranges.summary: Multiple nobles surge to their feet in outrage. 'This is tyranny!' Several relatives of condemned houses stand in support. Fear ripples through Category B nobles. 'We could be next!' Even some loyalists look uncomfortable with severity. The hall divides sharply. Juan may have created more enemies than he punished.

ranges.label: Serious Failure - Sympathy for the Condemned
ranges.summary: The Baron de Medina's representative stands trembling with rage: 'You destroy us for defending our own lands? This is not justice!' Others rise in support. 'Where does this authority end?' Fear of precedent spreads. Don Fernando de Guzmán looks deeply troubled. The 'cancer' language offends even neutrals.

ranges.label: Failure - Shocked Opposition
ranges.summary: Heavy silence follows, then uncomfortable murmuring. Many nobles look genuinely shocked by the severity of excommunication AND land forfeiture AND military threat combined. Sympathy spreads: 'Violence was wrong, but this seems extreme.' Don Pedro de Velasco speaks carefully: 'Your Majesty, perhaps trial before sentence?' Multiple nobles nod.

ranges.label: Poor - Divided and Fearful
ranges.summary: The hall splits visibly. Loyal houses nod grimly - Don Íñigo: 'Justice must be done.' But many others look uncomfortable. The public humiliation troubles them. 'Brought before court to determine sentence'—does that mean execution? Category B nobles exchange worried glances. Some whisper: 'What if they come for us next?'

ranges.label: Mixed - Grim Acceptance
ranges.summary: Silence follows—not hostile, but heavy. Most nobles recognize the offenses were serious. Don Rodrigo de Perea nods slowly: 'Violence against crown officials cannot stand.' But the severity troubles many. The three representatives sit pale and silent. Their allies look torn between loyalty and self-preservation. Category B nobles relieved they weren't named but nervous about precedent. The justice is accepted, but atmosphere is tense rather than supportive.

ranges.label: Modest Success - Grim Support
ranges.summary: After long silence, Don Íñigo the Elder stands. 'His Majesty is right. These offenses cannot stand.' Scattered, serious applause follows—not celebratory, but acknowledging necessity. 'They beat assessors—what did they expect?' The hall is sobered but not divided. Category B nobles look relieved they weren't included.

ranges.label: Success - Clear Support for Justice
ranges.summary: Multiple nobles rise as Juan finishes. 'Justice!' Don Fernando de Guzmán: 'Those who raise hands against the king's men cannot be tolerated!' Solid applause spreads—firm and serious. The selective targeting is noted approvingly: 'Only three—those who committed actual violence.' Category B nobles visibly relieved. Don Pedro: 'Your Majesty protects us all by protecting crown officials.' Severity accepted as necessary for order.

ranges.label: Good Success - Strong Approval
ranges.summary: The hall responds with grave but solid support. Don Íñigo: 'JUSTICE MUST BE DONE!' Multiple nobles stand: 'They beat your assessors, burned papal seals—this is rebellion!' Category B nobles clearly relieved they're distinguished from violent offenders. The three representatives sit alone and abandoned. 'Your Majesty protects those who fulfill their duties,' someone calls. Strong support for both the justice and the message.

ranges.label: Great Success - Overwhelming Support
ranges.summary: The hall erupts in approval. 'This is justice!' Don Rodrigo stands: 'Your Majesty protects us all! If assessors can be beaten with impunity, law means nothing!' Multiple nobles rise with strong voices. The selective targeting praised: 'Only those who committed violence—this is proportional justice.' Even relatives of the condemned sit silent, unable to defend the indefensible. Category B nobles grateful they were spared.

ranges.label: Triumphant - United in Justice
ranges.summary: The Cortes rises almost as one. 'JUSTICE! FOR THE CROWN! FOR THE CRUSADE!' The clarity of the offenses and proportionality create powerful support. Don Íñigo: 'Three houses chose rebellion—let their example teach us all!' Even the resistant houses' representatives sit unable to protest—the crimes too clear, the isolation too complete. This becomes a defining moment of the young king who balances partnership with strength.

ranges.label: Legendary - Fear and Respect Combined
ranges.summary: Your words create a moment of unified justice. The entire Cortes stands: 'JUSTICE BEFORE GOD!' Some nobles weep at the rightness of it. The three representatives sit broken, their masters' reputations destroyed. Category B nobles literally prostrate themselves: 'We will pay immediately, Your Majesty!' This moment will echo through Castilian history—the day nobility learned that violence against crown authority brings destruction.

tables.title: Cortes Response to Crown Marshals Explanation with Mercy for Baron de Medina
tables.context: Diplomacy/Religion — Juan addresses the procedural concerns about the three Crown Marshals by having Archbishop Gutiérrez read the complete Crown Marshal decree outlining three-stage procedure (mediation, warning, enforcement), specific powers and limitations, and compensation. Juan also addresses the Baron de Medina's fate by invoking Isabel's prayers for mercy and offering a trial with noble input rather than immediate execution.

ranges.label: Still Wary - Procedural Concerns Remain
ranges.summary: Don Pedro de Velasco stands again asking for specifics: 'What exactly are the Crown Marshals' powers? Can they impose fines? Arrest nobles? Seize property?' Others nod wanting clarification. The question about Baron de Medina's trial remains unanswered. The reassurance helps but specifics are needed before full commitment.

ranges.label: Cautious - Need More Details
ranges.summary: The reassurance that 'no one else is under investigation' causes visible relief—Don García de Guzmán's shoulders sag slightly. But questions persist about specific Marshal authorities and appeal processes. The systematic approach is appreciated but vagueness troubles them. Nobles want to support this but need clarity first.

ranges.label: Mixed Positive - Relief Emerging
ranges.summary: 'No one else under investigation'—these words ripple through the hall with palpable relief. Multiple nobles visibly relax. Don Fernando de Guzmán: 'Your Majesty provides both justice and clear procedure. This shows wisdom.' But practical questions remain: 'Can you explain the Marshals' specific authorities?' The systematic approach appeals—much better than arbitrary royal anger—but atmosphere is warming but not yet enthusiastic.

ranges.label: Modest Success - Clear Relief
ranges.summary: The mood shifts noticeably. 'No one else under investigation!' The reassurance spreads like a wave. Don García de Guzmán looks genuinely relieved. The Crown Marshal framework is welcomed: 'Clear procedures prevent misunderstandings!' Several nobles nod approvingly at the three figures. The religious framing—'crown belongs to God'—resonates. Don Rodrigo: 'Your Majesty balances strength with fairness.' Tension easing, still somber but accepting.

ranges.label: Success - Strong Support for Framework
ranges.summary: The reassurance transforms the atmosphere. Audible sighs of relief sweep the hall. The Crown Marshal system is embraced: 'This is what we needed—clear process!' Don Pedro: 'This framework prevents both noble obstruction AND royal overreach. Well conceived.' Multiple nobles stand in support. The three Marshals are viewed positively—protectors of order, not instruments of tyranny. Partnership feeling from yesterday begins returning.

ranges.label: Good Success - Enthusiastic Support
ranges.summary: 'No one else under investigation!' Immediate, visible transformation with applause. 'His Majesty punishes violence but provides justice for all else!' The Crown Marshal system is celebrated as brilliant: 'Clear authority, incorruptible men, defined procedures!' Even previously worried nobles now look satisfied. The religious framing restores partnership tone. The three Marshals are viewed as guarantors of fairness.

ranges.label: Great Success - Relief and Renewed Partnership
ranges.summary: The hall erupts in relieved applause. 'Only violence is punished—disagreement is addressed through proper channels!' The Crown Marshal framework is celebrated. Don Fernando: 'Your Majesty could have ruled by fear—instead you provide clear justice and fair procedure. This is true kingship!' Multiple nobles rise in support of the Marshals. Yesterday's warmth returns fully. Even Category B nobles look comfortable.

ranges.label: Overwhelming Success - System Embraced
ranges.summary: The Cortes transforms from somber to energized. 'This is governance as it should be!' Relief at no further investigations causes jubilation. The Crown Marshal system is praised as revolutionary: 'Clear procedures, fair process, strength where needed!' Multiple nobles want to meet the Marshals personally. The partnership from yesterday is fully restored. The three representatives sit forgotten.

ranges.label: Triumphant - Perfect Balance Achieved
ranges.summary: Your speech creates a moment of profound realization. The nobility sees the complete picture: yesterday's partnership + today's necessary punishment + tomorrow's clear procedures = ideal governance. 'He rules WITH us, punishes only violence, and provides fair process for everything else!' Even relatives of the condemned recognize the justice.

ranges.label: Legendary - The New Castilian Order
ranges.summary: Something transcendent occurs. The nobility realizes they're witnessing the birth of modern governance—partnership, clear law, systematic enforcement, proportional justice. The Crown Marshals aren't just enforcers, they're symbols of the new order where everyone knows the rules and consequences. Even the three condemned representatives stand and bow—recognizing that their masters' destruction serves a greater good. This moment will be studied for centuries.

tables.title: Cortes Response to Eternal Crusade Vision
tables.context: Diplomacy/Religion — Juan concludes the Cortes with an inspiring vision of an 'eternal crusade' that will continue beyond Granada, expanding Christian conquest to new lands and shores, distributing new estates and titles to ambitious nobles, and providing perpetual opportunity for glory and service. He frames this as fulfilling Castile's warrior tradition and ensuring the kingdom never lacks purpose or prosperity.

ranges.label: Alarm - 'Eternal War?'
ranges.summary: Silence follows Juan's words, then uncomfortable shifting. An older noble stands: 'Your Majesty... eternal crusade? Some of us wish to see our grandchildren grow, tend our estates in peace.' Others nod—the word 'eternal' troubles them deeply. 'Where would this even be? Africa? The Atlantic?' The vagueness increases alarm that Juan is condemning Castile to perpetual warfare.

ranges.label: Skeptical - Exhaustion and Doubt
ranges.summary: Tepid response with many nobles looking simply tired at the prospect. 'We've been in the field eight months,' someone mutters. 'I need to return to my estates.' The vision is too abstract, too distant. 'First let us actually take Granada,' Don Pedro says carefully, 'then discuss what comes after.' Morning's heavy business has drained enthusiasm for grand visions.

ranges.label: Mixed - Divided Response
ranges.summary: The hall splits noticeably. Younger nobles lean forward with interest—'New lands! New opportunities!' But older nobles and those exhausted from the campaign look doubtful. 'Eternal crusade sounds... expensive,' someone says. Don Rodrigo: 'An inspiring vision, Your Majesty, but could you clarify the destination? Africa? How does this align with Portuguese interests?' The vagueness creates uncertainty.

ranges.label: Cautious Interest - Need Details
ranges.summary: 'New territories...' Nobles begin discussing among themselves. Some clearly intrigued by land opportunities, others uncertain. Don Fernando stands: 'Your Majesty's vision is ambitious. But we would benefit from more specific details. Africa? Or elsewhere?' The appeal to warrior tradition resonates somewhat, but after the morning's heavy business, they're not ready for grand enthusiasm.

ranges.label: Modest Positive - Guarded Enthusiasm
ranges.summary: The vision begins taking hold. Multiple younger nobles sit forward—'Opportunity for our sons!' 'More estates to distribute!' The appeal to Castile's warrior heritage resonates. Don Íñigo nods slowly: 'Our kingdom was forged in crusade. Perhaps that should continue.' But many remain cautious—exhausted, worried about costs, uncertain about destination. 'Let us first complete Granada,' Don Luis suggests, 'then plan systematically.'

ranges.label: Success - Growing Interest
ranges.summary: The eternal crusade concept catches fire with younger nobles. 'This is our purpose!' Several stand: 'We were raised for conquest—why stop at Granada?' The land opportunity appeals broadly—even cautious nobles recognize distributing new territories solves succession problems. Don Fernando: 'His Majesty offers us continued purpose and prosperity!' Older nobles still reserved but warming. 'After Granada, we discuss specifics,' one says, 'but the vision has merit.'

ranges.label: Good Success - Strong Appeal
ranges.summary: The hall responds with genuine enthusiasm. 'This is what Castile was meant for!' The warrior nobility sees the appeal—purpose beyond Granada, opportunities for their sons, expansion of Christian kingdoms. Don Íñigo stands: 'The Reconquista spirit shouldn't end at the Mediterranean!' Multiple nobles call out support. Even exhausted nobles see the appeal of continued purpose. Excitement building as nobles consider implications.

ranges.label: Great Success - Inspiring Vision
ranges.summary: The Cortes rises in waves of applause. 'ETERNAL CRUSADE!' Young nobles shout with enthusiasm. The vision of endless opportunity, continued glory, spreading Christianity ignites genuine passion. Don Rodrigo: 'This solves everything—what to do with our armies, how to provide for younger sons!' Even older nobles warm to it: 'Perhaps our grandchildren will conquer Africa!' The hall celebrates ending the Cortes on this high note.

ranges.label: Overwhelming Success - The Vision Takes Hold
ranges.summary: Your speech electrifies the assembly. Nobles leap to their feet cheering. 'THIS IS OUR DESTINY!' The eternal crusade concept resonates profoundly with warrior nobility culture. 'Why should crusade end? Christianity should expand forever!' Young nobles nearly weeping with excitement: 'Glory! Land! Purpose!' Even exhausted older nobles caught up: 'Our kingdom will never fade if we never stop expanding!'

ranges.label: Legendary - A New Castilian Identity
ranges.summary: Something transcendent happens. Your words don't just inspire—they redefine what Castile IS. The eternal crusade becomes not just military policy but national identity. Nobles embrace it as sacred purpose: 'We are not just a kingdom, we are the sword of Christ!' The practical and spiritual merge perfectly. This speech will be remembered for centuries as the moment Castile transformed into an expansionist crusader state. Songs written, oaths sworn, banners raised.

tables.title: Isabel's Childbirth - Outcome Determination
tables.context: Chaos — Isabel goes into labor after weeks of pregnancy. This d100 roll determines the severity of complications and outcome for both mother and child during the medieval childbirth.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Tragedy
ranges.summary: Severe complications including hemorrhaging or impossible fetal positioning result in maternal death despite efforts. Baby's survival uncertain. Kingdom plunged into mourning.

ranges.label: Disaster - Stillbirth
ranges.summary: Baby born not breathing and cannot be revived, possibly from cord around neck or death in utero. Isabel survives but traumatized and without heir.

ranges.label: Severe Crisis - Both Survive Barely
ranges.summary: Breech birth with catastrophic hemorrhaging and desperate struggle by physicians. Baby born blue, not breathing at first but revived with difficulty. Both survive but Isabel needs months to recover with permanent health impacts possible.

ranges.label: Major Complications - Dangerous But Survivable
ranges.summary: Extremely difficult 24+ hour labor with severe tearing and significant blood loss. Baby stuck, requires forceful manipulation. Both survive but Isabel in severe pain for weeks with high infection risk.

ranges.label: Difficult Medieval Birth - Standard Suffering
ranges.summary: Long 16-20 hour painful labor with considerable tearing and moderate blood loss. Baby positioned awkwardly. Both survive; Isabel needs 4-6 weeks recovery before moving normally.

ranges.label: Hard Labor - Typical First Birth
ranges.summary: Painful 12-16 hour labor with some tearing and manageable blood loss. Baby large or positioned slightly awkwardly. Both healthy; Isabel needs 3-4 weeks to recover strength.

ranges.label: Manageable Birth - Within Expected Range
ranges.summary: 8-12 hours labor with moderate tearing and normal blood loss. Baby delivered without extraordinary measures. Both healthy; Isabel needs 2-3 weeks recovery.

ranges.label: Relatively Smooth - Better Than Average
ranges.summary: 6-8 hours labor with minimal tearing and controlled blood loss. Baby positioned well, delivery uncomplicated. Both very healthy; Isabel recovering remarkably fast.

ranges.label: Easy Birth For The Era
ranges.summary: 4-6 hours labor with very little tearing and minimal blood loss. Baby positioned perfectly. Both completely healthy; Isabel recovering quickly.

ranges.label: Remarkably Quick - Almost Unnaturally Smooth
ranges.summary: Less than 2 hours from first real contraction to birth with barely any tearing or blood loss. Baby born pink and screaming immediately. Both perfectly healthy.

ranges.label: Miraculous - Divine Favor
ranges.summary: Less than 2 hours labor with virtually no tearing or blood loss. Baby born pink and screaming. Isabel energized rather than exhausted. Everyone present certain they witnessed a miracle.

tables.title: Baby's Gender Determination
tables.context: Chaos — The gender of Juan and Isabel's child is determined. No medieval method could predict this before birth.

ranges.label: Daughter
ranges.summary: A girl is born. Healthy enough given the difficult birth. Will need a male heir eventually, but she lives and is perfect.

ranges.label: Twins - Boy and Girl
ranges.summary: Physicians missed twins during pregnancy. Both weak from ordeal but alive. A son and daughter born.

ranges.label: Son
ranges.summary: A boy is born—heir to Castile. Succession secured if he survives infancy. Political stability for the kingdom.

tables.title: Newborn's Health After Traumatic Breech Birth
tables.context: Chaos — The baby suffered severe oxygen deprivation during the difficult breech delivery. This roll determines long-term health impacts and survival prospects.

ranges.label: Dies Within Hours
ranges.summary: Too much damage from oxygen deprivation and trauma. Never begins breathing properly. Stops breathing within 6-12 hours. Nothing physicians can do.

ranges.label: Dies Within Days
ranges.summary: Breathing remains dangerously weak. Cannot feed or suckle. Develops fever or seizures from birth trauma. Passes away within 3-5 days.

ranges.label: Severe Permanent Damage - Will Not Survive Infancy
ranges.summary: Significant brain damage from oxygen deprivation evident immediately with constant seizures. Cannot feed properly. Will not live past a few months.

ranges.label: Severe Disabilities - May Survive But Profoundly Impaired
ranges.summary: Brain damage from lack of oxygen causing seizures and poor muscle tone with severely delayed development. May live but severely disabled if survives.

ranges.label: Moderate Disabilities - Physical Impairments
ranges.summary: Erb's palsy causing arm/shoulder nerve damage or broken collarbone that heals with weakness. Mentally sound but physical limitations affect marriage prospects.

ranges.label: Mild Complications - Chronic Weakness
ranges.summary: Breathing problems persist for months with frequent childhood illnesses and slow weight gain. May outgrow it or remain frail and sickly with higher mortality risk.

ranges.label: Weak Start But Likely to Improve
ranges.summary: Breathing weak for first weeks but gradually strengthens. Difficulty feeding initially but learns to nurse. Small and fragile but gaining strength slowly.

ranges.label: Surprisingly Resilient - Minor Issues Only
ranges.summary: Despite traumatic birth, breathing improves within hours. Feeds adequately and tired easily at first. Small bruising heals quickly. Steady improvement expected.

ranges.label: Healthy Despite Ordeal - Good Recovery
ranges.summary: Breathing stabilizes within 12 hours. Feeds well and gaining strength rapidly. No apparent lasting damage from oxygen deprivation. Small and tired but fundamentally healthy.

ranges.label: Remarkably Healthy - Minimal Impact
ranges.summary: Breathing normalizes within hours. Feeds vigorously with strong cry by second day. No signs of brain damage or physical trauma. Just small and needs monitoring but essentially healthy.

ranges.label: Miraculously Unscathed - Perfect Health
ranges.summary: Despite horrific birth, shows no ill effects whatsoever. Breathing strong, feeding perfectly, no damage from the ordeal. Physicians amazed and call it divine protection. Will grow into completely healthy child.

tables.title: Isabel's Recovery from Severe Childbirth Trauma
tables.context: Chaos — Isabel suffered a catastrophic breech birth with severe hemorrhaging and infection. This roll determines her recovery trajectory and long-term health impacts.

ranges.label: Death Within Days - Childbed Fever
ranges.summary: Infection sets in within 24-48 hours. High fever and delirium. Puerperal sepsis spreads rapidly. Medieval medicine powerless. Dies within 3-5 days of birth.

ranges.label: Death Within Two Weeks - Complications
ranges.summary: Secondary hemorrhaging or slow infection develops. Weakened state prevents recovery. Fever and weakness lead to gradual decline. Dies within 10-14 days.

ranges.label: Survives But Gravely Ill - Months of Crisis
ranges.summary: Severe infection that doesn't quite kill her. Fever comes and goes for months. Barely able to leave bed for 8-12 weeks. Likely permanent damage and chronic pain. Future pregnancies very dangerous.

ranges.label: Serious Infection - Long Recovery, Permanent Effects
ranges.summary: Childbed fever develops but body fights it off. Bedridden 6-8 weeks with fever, pain, extreme weakness. Survives with lasting damage, chronic pelvic pain, and difficulty walking initially.

ranges.label: Moderate Infection - Difficult Recovery
ranges.summary: Low-grade infection manageable but persistent. Bedridden 4-6 weeks with fever, exhaustion, and slow healing. Eventually recovers with lasting weakness or pain. Future pregnancies risky but possible.

ranges.label: Severe Weakness - No Infection But Slow Recovery
ranges.summary: No infection but massive blood loss takes toll. Bedridden 3-4 weeks, extremely weak. Cannot walk unassisted for weeks. Takes 3-4 months to regain normal strength but can have more children.

ranges.label: Weak But Improving - Standard Difficult Recovery
ranges.summary: No major infection, just severe trauma and blood loss. Bedridden 2-3 weeks. Weak and tired for months with gradual improvement. Takes 2-3 months to move normally.

ranges.label: Painful Recovery - Improving Steadily
ranges.summary: Healing properly but extensive tearing causes pain. Out of bed after 10-14 days but moving carefully. Pain lasts 6-8 weeks. Strength returns over 2 months with eventual full recovery.

ranges.label: Difficult But Normal Recovery
ranges.summary: Typical post-traumatic birth recovery for the era. Out of bed after a week, moving slowly. Pain and exhaustion for 4-6 weeks. Full recovery expected within 2-3 months.

ranges.label: Better Than Expected - Good Recovery
ranges.summary: Given severity of birth, recovering well. Out of bed after 5-7 days. Tired and sore but improving daily. Pain manageable. Full recovery within 6-8 weeks.

ranges.label: Remarkably Resilient - Quick Recovery
ranges.summary: Despite blood loss, body bounces back. Out of bed after 3-4 days carefully. Tired but not severely weakened. Moderate pain decreasing. Full recovery within 4-6 weeks.

ranges.label: Miraculous Recovery - Both Mother and Child Blessed
ranges.summary: Against all odds and medical expectation, recovers rapidly. Out of bed within days, walking within a week. Exhausted but not debilitated. Full recovery within 3-4 weeks. Physicians call it a miracle.

tables.title: Don García de Sotomayor's Response to Crown Marshal's Ultimatum
tables.context: Intrigue — Don García de Sotomayor, a condemned noble from the Cortes, is fortified in his Extremadura castle. Crown Marshal Don Rodrigo de Perea arrives with 50 men-at-arms to demand he surrender himself for trial in Toledo or face siege.

ranges.label: Open Violent Rebellion - Declares War
ranges.summary: Refuses marshal entry and shouts defiance from walls. Declares Juan II a tyrant and Cortes invalid. Sends messengers declaring open rebellion. Begins raiding crown lands. Full military rebellion requiring immediate armed response.

ranges.label: Defiant Rejection - Fortified Resistance
ranges.summary: Refuses to surrender and rejects crown authority with 'Come take me if you dare.' Allows marshal safe departure but makes clear he'll resist siege. Prepares for war believing he can hold out.

ranges.label: Stalling - Playing for Time
ranges.summary: Receives marshal but gives no clear answer. Requests weeks to settle affairs before coming to Toledo. Clearly stalling while hoping support materializes. Testing if crown will accept delay or act immediately.

ranges.label: Conditional Surrender Offer
ranges.summary: Willing to come to Toledo but only with guarantees of safe conduct and specific sentence. Demands crusade service, not execution. Attempts to negotiate despite being told there are no negotiations.

ranges.label: Reluctant Compliance - Sees No Alternative
ranges.summary: Realizes no support is coming from other nobles and castle cannot hold indefinitely against full royal army. Agrees to surrender person and come to Toledo. Bitter and resentful but pragmatic.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Surrender - Seeking Best Outcome
ranges.summary: Accepts that resistance is futile. Hopes trial and contrition might earn crusade service. Cooperates with marshal's custody. Not happy but not defiant.

ranges.label: Penitent Surrender - Seeking Redemption
ranges.summary: Realizes magnitude of his error. Genuinely repentant. Begs for mercy and opportunity to serve in crusade. Cooperates fully with marshal.

ranges.label: Complete Capitulation - Immediate Submission
ranges.summary: Surrenders immediately upon marshal's arrival. Fully cooperative with no resistance. Publicly acknowledges guilt. Ready to face whatever judgment comes.

ranges.label: Unexpected Ally Pressure
ranges.summary: One or more significant nobles send messages supporting the crown and pressure Sotomayor to submit peacefully. He surrenders to avoid isolation. Realizes any hope of support was fantasy.

ranges.label: Death or Incapacitation Before Response
ranges.summary: Dies of sudden illness, accident, or possible suicide before marshal arrives. Or severe illness makes resistance impossible. Heirs must decide whether to continue resistance.

tables.title: Baron de Medina's Response to Crown Marshal's Summons
tables.context: Intrigue — Baron de Medina has already surrendered his estates but has been publicly complaining about 'royal tyranny' and stirring resentment. Crown Marshal Don García Fernández Manrique arrives with 50 men-at-arms to summon him to Toledo for trial.

ranges.label: Bitter Words Become Action - Attempts Flight
ranges.summary: Realizes summons means possible execution. Flees before marshal arrives or during the night. Attempts to reach Aragon, Portugal, or France. His flight confirms guilt in many eyes.

ranges.label: Defiant Refusal - Barricades Himself
ranges.summary: His bitter rhetoric becomes action. Refuses to surrender person and fortifies minor estate. Not strong enough to resist long but will try. 'I've already given you my lands, you won't have my life!'

ranges.label: Rallies Support - Tries to Create Coalition
ranges.summary: Uses complaints about tyranny to gather allies. Attempts to convince other resentful nobles to stand with him. 'If we don't resist together, we'll all fall separately.' Success depends on finding support.

ranges.label: Negotiating Surrender - Wants Guarantees
ranges.summary: Will come to Toledo but demands assurances against execution. Tries to extract concessions despite having no leverage. Will surrender if gets any assurance.

ranges.label: Bitter Compliance - Comes Under Protest
ranges.summary: Submits to summons but makes scene about it. Loud complaints as taken into custody about 'royal tyranny trampling ancient rights.' Theater for other nobles watching.

ranges.label: Reluctant Submission - Accepts Fate
ranges.summary: Realizes his complaints won't save him. Comes quietly when marshal arrives. Still bitter but not making more trouble. Hopes trial might give him chance to argue his case.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Cooperation - Seeking Best Outcome
ranges.summary: Decides compliance is his best strategy now. Cooperates with marshal without drama. Hopes contrition at trial earns mercy.

ranges.label: Genuine Contrition - Regrets His Bitterness
ranges.summary: Realizes his public complaints made everything worse. Genuinely repentant. Apologizes to marshal for previous rhetoric. Hopes penitent attitude helps at trial.

ranges.label: Complete Capitulation - Begs for Mercy
ranges.summary: Immediately submits when marshal arrives. Publicly recants all complaints about tyranny. Begs for opportunity to prove loyalty in crusade. Full cooperation.

ranges.label: Unexpected Turn - Support or Incapacitation
ranges.summary: Other nobles publicly defend him and pressure crown for mercy, or falls seriously ill before marshal arrives. Situation becomes more complicated than simple arrest.

tables.title: Count of Niebla's Response to Crown Marshal's Ultimatum
tables.context: Intrigue — Count of Niebla has been negotiating for reduced penalties after the Cortes condemnation. Crown Marshal Don Pedro Fernández de Velasco arrives with 50 men-at-arms to deliver non-negotiable ultimatum: surrender yourself for trial or become an outlaw.

ranges.label: Negotiation Rejected - Violent Defiance
ranges.summary: Interprets 'no negotiation' as death sentence. Fortifies main castle and prepares for siege. Declares he'd rather die fighting than be executed. Raises what forces he can. Full military resistance.

ranges.label: Desperate Flight - Abandons Everything
ranges.summary: Realizes he has no leverage and no hope. Flees with family before marshal arrives. Attempts to reach Portugal or Aragon. Leaves estates and properties behind.

ranges.label: One More Attempt - Refuses Without New Terms
ranges.summary: Still trying to negotiate despite clear message. Sends new emissaries with modified offers. Won't accept 'submit to judgment' without guarantees. Forces crown to accept terms or besiege.

ranges.label: Stalling Tactics - Playing for Time
ranges.summary: Gives no definitive answer to marshal. Makes excuses about settling affairs. Hoping Isabel's death or political change rescues him. Testing crown's patience.

ranges.label: Conditional Surrender - Final Bargaining
ranges.summary: Will come to Toledo IF crown guarantees trial not execution. Wants specific promise he can argue his case. Seeking any small concession to save face.

ranges.label: Resigned Compliance - Accepts Inevitable
ranges.summary: Realizes negotiation has failed. No leverage, no support from other nobles. Agrees to surrender and come to Toledo. Bitter but pragmatic.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Surrender - Seeking Best Outcome
ranges.summary: Accepts that compliance is his only path forward. Cooperates with marshal's custody. Hopes peaceful surrender earns consideration. Still wants to argue his case at trial.

ranges.label: Contrite Surrender - Genuine Repentance
ranges.summary: Realizes attempts to bargain were errors. Genuinely apologetic. Cooperates fully. Seeks redemption through crusade service.

ranges.label: Immediate Capitulation - Complete Submission
ranges.summary: Surrenders immediately when marshal arrives. Full cooperation with no resistance. Acknowledges justice of Cortes' judgment. Ready to accept whatever sentence comes.

ranges.label: Pays Everything - Offers Full Restitution
ranges.summary: Immediately pays all back taxes owed and surrenders all properties without argument. Volunteers to serve in crusade at own expense. Hoping generosity earns mercy.

ranges.label: Unexpected Development
ranges.summary: Influential ally intervenes on his behalf, discovers evidence that reduces his guilt, or serious illness/death occurs before marshal arrives. Situation becomes more complicated.

tables.title: Council Response to Juan's Legal Question on Basel's Authority
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan asks whether the Council of Basel has a legal right to exist based on the decrees of the Council of Constance (Haec Sancta and Frequens). The bishops have been debating the legality and legitimacy of Basel's convocation.

ranges.label: Hostile Resistance
ranges.summary: Bishop de Ávila feels cornered and reacts defensively, calling Juan's question an attempt to legitimize rebellion. Several conservative bishops voice agreement, and the mood turns tense as they see Juan as too sympathetic to Basel's position.

ranges.label: Grudging Concession with Resentment
ranges.summary: The conservatives are clearly unhappy but cannot escape the logical force of the legal argument. They admit Basel was called by proper authority but insist this changes nothing about their current rebellion. The admission comes grudgingly and several bishops shift uncomfortably.

ranges.label: Divided Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: The moderates nod at Juan's wisdom in separating the legal question from the policy question. De Cartagena concedes Basel has legal right to exist per Frequens, but conservatives immediately push back on whether Basel has the right to defy papal dissolution. The council is split but the discussion has moved forward.

ranges.label: Respectful Consideration
ranges.summary: Archbishop Gutiérrez nods approvingly at Juan's methodical approach. Even Bishop de Ávila responds more calmly and concedes the legal point, though objecting to Basel's subsequent defiance. The conservatives respect Juan's careful reasoning even as they prepare counter-arguments. The mood remains serious but productive.

ranges.label: Strong Approval
ranges.summary: The Archbishop smiles slightly and Juan earns significant respect for his logical approach. Even Bishop de Isorna acknowledges the legal point is sound. Conservatives shift from defensive to thoughtful, focusing their concerns on Basel's defiance rather than its right to exist. The council feels honored that their king thinks so deeply about these matters.

ranges.label: Commanding Respect
ranges.summary: A moment of silence follows Juan's question as several bishops exchange glances of genuine respect. The Archbishop publicly acknowledges Juan's wisdom and even Bishop de Ávila concedes the legal point entirely. Juan has elevated the entire discussion and earned the council's deep respect. They see him as a worthy king engaging seriously with crucial questions.

tables.title: Council Response to Juan's Public Confession of Sin
tables.context: Personal/Persuasion — Juan publicly confesses his own temptation to misuse crusade funds for his military academy, crediting Cardinal Capranica with preventing him from committing this sin. He uses this confession to illustrate the need for oversight mechanisms even for good Christian rulers.

ranges.label: Cynical Reception
ranges.summary: Bishop de Isorna's eyes narrow and several bishops exchange glances suggesting they see this as calculated theater. The moment falls flat as they perceive it as rhetorical manipulation rather than genuine piety.

ranges.label: Uncomfortable Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: The bishops shift uneasily during and after the prayer. When Juan rises, there is uncertain murmuring. The bishops respect his humility but seem uncomfortable with the public vulnerability from their king, as if they feel judged by comparison or unsure how to respond.

ranges.label: Respectful But Reserved
ranges.summary: Several bishops murmur 'Amen' after the prayer. Archbishop Gutiérrez nods gravely and acknowledges Juan's 'commendable self-examination.' The bishops appreciate the sentiment but aren't deeply moved, and the discussion continues without transformative impact.

ranges.label: Genuine Appreciation
ranges.summary: Several bishops cross themselves and say 'Amen' with feeling. Bishop de Cartagena looks at Juan with evident respect, noting his true humility. The Abbott of Valladolid nods slowly, clearly moved. Even some conservatives seem touched by Juan's vulnerability. His point about oversight is well-made through personal example and the mood softens noticeably.

ranges.label: Moved Response
ranges.summary: A profound silence follows the prayer. When Juan rises, Bishop de Cartagena has tears in his eyes. The Abbott stands, his aged voice thick with emotion, saying he has never witnessed such humility from a monarch. Several bishops look genuinely affected and the demonstration of accountability has deeply impressed them.

ranges.label: Powerful Impact
ranges.summary: As Juan prays, several bishops bow their heads and quiet weeping is heard. When he finishes, even conservative Bishop de Ávila stands and kneels beside him, confessing his own struggles with protecting unworthy priests. Half the bishops are on their knees and the whole dynamic of the council has shifted into genuine spiritual reckoning.

ranges.label: Transformative Moment
ranges.summary: As Juan prays, Archbishop Gutiérrez slowly rises and kneels beside him. One by one, even the stern conservatives follow. By the time Juan says 'Amen,' every man in the chamber is on his knees. The Abbott weeps openly and Bishop de Isorna's voice breaks as he confesses his own sins. The room experiences collective spiritual transformation.

ranges.label: Profound Transformation
ranges.summary: The council becomes a moment of collective confession and genuine spiritual transformation. When the men finally rise, they look at Juan—and at each other—with new eyes. The council has moved from a fractious political discussion to a profound moment of mutual vulnerability and spiritual reckoning.

tables.title: Sultan Yusuf III's Winter/Spring 1432 Strategic Response
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Sultan of Granada facing military collapse must decide strategy after losing most of eastern and western territories. This roll determines his approach to the coming Castilian assault.

ranges.label: Complete Internal Collapse
ranges.summary: Palace coup overthrows Yusuf III during winter; civil war erupts between war and peace factions; multiple surrender offers from competing authorities; Granada defeats itself before Juan arrives.

ranges.label: Demoralized Defensive Posture
ranges.summary: Yusuf recognizes hopelessness and pulls all remaining forces into Granada city; abandons outlying fortresses without resistance; attempts only half-hearted diplomatic feelers; garrison commanders instructed to surrender when pressed.

ranges.label: Competent But Hopeless Defense
ranges.summary: Yusuf consolidates remaining forces intelligently, fortifies Granada city, garrisons ordered to resist then seek terms; some raiding to harass Castilians; each fortress requires 1-3 week siege; outcome still inevitable but costly.

ranges.label: Effective Delaying Strategy
ranges.summary: Yusuf plays for time brilliantly with diplomatic missions, simultaneous guerrilla warfare; remaining fortresses conduct aggressive raids on supply lines; exploits any delays or logistical problems; creates 2-3 month delay minimum with real tactical successes.

ranges.label: Desperate But Effective Military Gambit
ranges.summary: Yusuf concentrates all forces for surprise offensive against weakest Castilian garrison; winter attack catches Christians off-guard; takes back one fortress or inflicts 500-1,000 casualties; delays campaign but outcome still inevitable.

ranges.label: Brilliant Defensive Strategy With External Support
ranges.summary: Yusuf's diplomacy bears fruit; Morocco sends 3,000-4,000 additional troops and/or Aragonese/converso saboteurs provide aid; creates serious military challenge; campaign takes 6+ months with significant casualties; possible negotiated settlement rather than total conquest.

ranges.label: Masterstroke - Internal Castilian Problems Exploited
ranges.summary: Yusuf's agents successfully bribe/convince Castilian nobles to withdraw and/or arrange assassination attempt on key commander; creates crisis in crusade coalition; campaign paralyzed; outcome genuinely uncertain.

ranges.label: The Unthinkable - Game-Changing Development
ranges.summary: Multiple factors combine in Granada's favor: major Moroccan commitment (5,000+ troops) AND Aragonese intervention AND Castilian internal crisis AND Juan's personal crisis; crusade collapses or delayed years; Granada survives as tributary.

tables.title: Baron Alfonso de Guzmán's Response to Juan's Personal Appeal at Sanlúcar
tables.context: Persuasion Roll — Juan rides personally to Sanlúcar with only 200 men to convince rebel Baron to open his gates peacefully. This roll determines how the Baron responds to Juan's appeal to shared purpose and mercy.

ranges.label: Hostile Defiance
ranges.summary: Baron's pride is wounded; Juan's presence and reasonable words don't move him; hardened by anger about 'bureaucratic' marshals; declares he will die before submitting; threatens to fight to the death with resistance hopeless.

ranges.label: Defensive Resistance
ranges.summary: Baron acknowledges Juan's gesture and the military reality but focuses on the injustice he felt about taxation and how marshals treated him; wounded pride keeps him resistant; willing to negotiate if terms address his concerns and allow him to save face.

ranges.label: Conflicted
ranges.summary: Baron is torn between pride and pragmatism; acknowledges Juan's reasonable words and mercy shown; questions whether submission means humiliation or if he can maintain some honor; needs reassurance to overcome defensive position.

ranges.label: Receptive But Concerned
ranges.summary: Juan's personal appeal resonates strongly; Baron sees his own foolishness with painful clarity; recognizes crusade is just and his defiance unjustified; struggles with financial burden but success factors dominating; needs reassurance about treatment.

ranges.label: Willing Submission
ranges.summary: Baron recognizes the situation is hopeless and Juan's offer of mercy is genuine; drops to knee and submits fully; agrees to pay tax and swear renewed fealty; might ask for treatment as mercifully as possible but doesn't resist the outcome.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Capitulation
ranges.summary: Baron capitulates completely and emotionally; grateful that Juan came personally before destroying him; submits immediately and offers to actively serve in the crusade; becomes an asset rather than enemy; offers to help convince other nobles.

tables.title: Fortress's Response to Baron Alfonso's Truce Approach at Niebla
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Baron rides toward Niebla fortress under white flag to convince his cousin Count Diego to negotiate. This roll determines how the defenders respond to the approach of a herald under formal truce.

ranges.label: Violent Panic - Crossbows Fire
ranges.summary: Sentries panic or misinterpret intent and fire crossbow bolts; warning shots become aimed shots in confusion; Baron may be wounded or horse killed; eventually Count Diego's voice stops firing but damage is done; creates crisis and makes negotiation impossible.

ranges.label: Hostile Refusal - No Violence But Complete Rejection
ranges.summary: Guards recognize Baron but refuse to let him approach; Count Diego appears on walls shouting defiance; refuses all communication and sealed gates; violent rejection but no actual shooting or assassination attempt.

ranges.label: Suspicious Standoff - They Listen But Don't Commit
ranges.summary: Guards challenge Baron at distance to state business; castellan appears on walls; brief shouted conversation about Sanlúcar; castellan says he'll consult Count but gives no promises; door opened slightly but no commitment.

ranges.label: Cautious Interest - Request for Formal Parley
ranges.summary: Guards hold fire and send for castellan; Rodrigo appears and is shocked about Sanlúcar; internal commotion visible as people argue on walls; offers formal parley tomorrow at dawn with Count Diego willing to listen.

ranges.label: Positive Response - Younger Brother Luis Emerges
ranges.summary: Luis de Guzmán (Count's younger brother) emerges quickly, grateful, and eager to help convince his brother; has been trying to talk sense all winter; offers to arrange meeting tonight; clearly working to convince Diego to submit.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Reception - Castellan Takes Control
ranges.summary: Castellan Rodrigo recognizes Baron immediately and welcomes him; gates partially open and he embraces Baron; after hearing story agrees Count should listen; Luis appears with support; clear internal faction supporting negotiation gaining strength.

ranges.label: Immediate Capitulation - Internal Coup
ranges.summary: Luis and Rodrigo see opportunity and act decisively; gates open fully and Luis emerges with knights offering immediate submission; reveals half the garrison wants to submit; Count Diego effectively overthrown by his own brother and castellan; fortress surrenders without fight.

tables.title: Baron Alfonso de Guzmán Under Crossbow Fire at Niebla
tables.context: Chaos Roll — After initial crossbow panic that forced Baron to halt, we determine what actually happens to him under the volley of arrows. This roll determines his fate and whether he survives the attack.

ranges.label: Fatal Strike - Baron Killed
ranges.summary: Multiple bolts strike Baron in neck/chest/face with lethal wounds; falls from horse mortally wounded; dies within minutes; horse bolts back to lines; catastrophic outcome creating undeniable treason charge against Count Diego.

ranges.label: Critical Wound - Baron Seriously Injured
ranges.summary: Bolt penetrates shoulder, side or leg causing serious bleeding; Baron reels in saddle barely stays mounted; manages to retreat but collapses at friendly lines; survives but weeks/months recovery; attempted murder under truce flag proven.

ranges.label: Significant Wound - Baron Injured But Functional
ranges.summary: Bolt grazes Baron's arm/leg/side causing painful wound and bleeding but not life-threatening; retreats under continued fire; reaches friendly lines with visible proof of attack; wounded but will recover in days/weeks.

ranges.label: Horse Struck - Baron Unhorsed But Uninjured
ranges.summary: Bolts miss Baron but strike his horse; horse rears/collapses and throws Baron; Baron hits ground hard stunned but physically unharmed; must scramble back on foot while bolts fly; dramatic rescue by cavalry needed.

ranges.label: Near Misses - Baron Retreats Under Fire
ranges.summary: Multiple bolts fly very close; one strikes shield another strikes saddle; horse panics from ground strikes; Baron wheels and gallops back in harrowing retreat; uninjured but badly shaken; clear assassination attempt evident.

ranges.label: Warning Shots - Deliberately Missing
ranges.summary: Crossbows fire but bolts land short or wide showing intentional warning pattern; 'Stay back!' shouted from walls; Baron recognizes warning nature and retreats cautiously; hostile but not murderous; unclear if Count ordered it.

ranges.label: Confusion and Cease Fire
ranges.summary: Initial panicked shots fired (2-3 bolts) all missing; shouting erupts from fortress walls immediately; officer's voice commands 'CEASE FIRE! Cease fire, you fools!'; shooting stops immediately showing someone took control; possible parley still viable.

ranges.label: Single Shot Then Intervention
ranges.summary: One nervous sentry fires single bolt that misses wildly; immediate shouting from walls ordering ceasefire; castellan's voice roaring 'Do NOT shoot the Baron!'; gates open slightly with officer emerging waving apologies; clear shooter acted alone and was immediately countermanded.

tables.title: Count Diego de Guzmán's Response to Juan's Personal Appeal at Niebla
tables.context: Persuasion Roll — Juan rides to Niebla after successful parley at Sanlúcar and makes direct appeal to Count Diego. Juan clearly explains the 5% tax (not 8%), offers reasonable terms, and has Baron Alfonso testify. This roll determines how Diego responds.

ranges.label: Explosive Rage - Complete Breakdown
ranges.summary: Juan's reasonable questions trigger complete rage; Diego's face flushes red; hand moves to sword; becomes uncontrollable shouting about tyranny and ancient lineage; success factors completely drowned by wounded pride; negotiation impossible.

ranges.label: Hostile Defiance
ranges.summary: Diego's face is stone; laughs bitterly; dismisses Juan's presence and Baron's example; focuses on unjust taxation and being treated like criminal; acknowledges military reality but refuses to submit based on principle; will resist.

ranges.label: Defensive Justification
ranges.summary: Diego responds with controlled anger and justified grievances about tax burden, disrespectful marshals, excommunication without hearing; embarrassed about shooting but defensive; acknowledges Juan's presence and Baron's submission but focuses on perceived injustices; might negotiate if terms address concerns.

ranges.label: Conflicted Struggle
ranges.summary: Diego's emotions war visibly; admits to starting with tax grievance but acknowledges getting in too deep; sees military reality but can't overcome pride; trapped between submission and death; needs way to submit while preserving dignity.

ranges.label: Strained Receptivity
ranges.summary: Diego is exhausted and strained; acknowledges all points as true but struggle with pride; recognizes Juan's mercy and military reality; asks clear question about what surrender means; very receptive and needs only reassurance about treatment.

ranges.label: Willing Submission
ranges.summary: Diego's shoulders slump; acknowledges all of Juan's points as true; admits to pride and foolishness; submits fully and completely; offers to accept penalties; swears to serve faithfully; asks only for chance to prove it like Baron Alfonso.

ranges.label: Emotional Capitulation
ranges.summary: Diego drops to knees emotionally moved; weeps openly; pulls off sword belt in submission; thanks Juan for chance to make right; offers enhanced payments as penance; opens fortress gates voluntarily; becomes grateful and eager to serve.

tables.title: Count Diego de Guzmán's Reaction to Juan's Specific Terms Offering Title Transfer
tables.context: Persuasion Roll — After the initial defensive justification, Juan offers very specific and fair terms: 5% tax (not 8%), title passes to son (family keeps lands), son becomes Count, taxation was misunderstanding. This roll determines if Diego can accept losing his title even with other mercy.

ranges.label: Explosive Rejection
ranges.summary: Diego's face goes red when hearing he must surrender title; explodes in rage about humiliation; refuses terms completely; storms back to fortress; declares he'd rather die Count Diego than live as nothing; no submission possible; siege must proceed.

ranges.label: Bitter Refusal
ranges.summary: Diego acknowledges tax clarification but fixates on title loss; argues stripping him is calculated humiliation; refuses terms and will resist; sees it as worse than death to lose identity as Count.

ranges.label: Conflicted Resistance
ranges.summary: Diego sees tax terms are fair but struggles intensely with title loss; views being Count as his identity; can't accept becoming nothing in his own home; doesn't refuse outright but can't accept; asks for time to consider.

ranges.label: Painful Consideration
ranges.summary: Diego torn between justice of terms and loss of title; understands offer is fair but hurt cuts deep; acknowledges difficulty but doesn't commit either way; needs further persuasion or reassurance.

ranges.label: Reluctant Acceptance
ranges.summary: Diego nods with visible pain that this is fair but struggles with title loss; agrees to terms with evident pain; will submit but clearly wounded by having to transfer title to son.

ranges.label: Acceptance With Dignity
ranges.summary: Diego takes long moment then nods with visible effort at self-control; accepts terms as fair; acknowledges he deserves consequences; submits willingly with some grace despite pain.

ranges.label: Genuine Submission
ranges.summary: Diego relieved despite title loss; acknowledges it's appropriate punishment for rebellion; sees justice in terms; grateful family keeps lands and he can be absolved; submits willingly.

ranges.label: Grateful Acceptance
ranges.summary: Diego overwhelmed with relief; grateful family not totally ruined; accepts title loss gracefully; acknowledges son will do better as Count; accepts terms with genuine gratitude.

tables.title: Bombardment Effectiveness at Creating Breach in Niebla's Walls
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Juan orders bombardment of Niebla fortress's northeastern wall section with five bombards. This roll determines how effective the medieval siege artillery is at creating a practical breach for assault.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure
ranges.summary: Multiple guns malfunction on first day; one bombard explodes killing crew; powder quality issues discovered; minimal wall damage despite days of firing; timeline extends to 2+ weeks; significant artillery crew casualties.

ranges.label: Poor Performance
ranges.summary: Guns fire inconsistently with accuracy problems and many missed shots; wall proves more resilient than expected; after 5-6 days produces small barely practical breach; defenders repair nightly; requires 7-10 days total with higher ammunition use.

ranges.label: Slow But Steady Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment proceeds methodically with no major malfunctions; wall damaged gradually over 5 days; defenders falling behind on repairs; by day 6-7 practical breach created; adequate for assault but will be contested; expected timeline.

ranges.label: Solid Effectiveness
ranges.summary: Guns perform well with good crew coordination; concentrated fire effective; wall damage accumulates steadily; after 4 days significant breach opened; defenders struggling to maintain repairs; by day 5 breach wide enough for assault.

ranges.label: Highly Effective Bombardment
ranges.summary: Excellent gun performance with superior targeting and minimal wasted shots; wall section proves vulnerable; after 3 days major breach created; defenders abandon repair attempts; by day 4 wide breach with rubble ramp formed easy for assault troops; better than expected.

ranges.label: Devastating Bombardment
ranges.summary: All five guns firing in perfect coordination; wall section collapses dramatically; after 2-3 days massive breach with partial wall collapse; rubble creates assault ramp; defenders demoralized; secondary damage to town buildings; fortress position untenable.

ranges.label: Spectacular Success With Complications
ranges.summary: Wall destroyed in 1-2 days intensive fire; massive breach with multiple entry points; but collapse damages adjacent town buildings causing 10-30 civilian casualties; refugees fleeing fortress; breach excellent but political complications.

ranges.label: Perfect Bombardment With Internal Collapse
ranges.summary: Wall destroyed in 1-2 days; massive breach demoralizes garrison; internal mutiny occurs and garrison refuses to defend breach; white flags appear on walls; fortress capitulates before assault needed; town and garrison preserved.

tables.title: Fortress Response to Juan's Safe Passage Offer at Niebla
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Juan orders herald to offer safe passage to anyone (townspeople, garrison, servants) willing to leave Niebla fortress. Only Count Diego is the target of the king's wrath. This roll determines how many people accept the offer and evacuate.

ranges.label: Count Diego's Tyranny - Executions
ranges.summary: Count Diego goes mad with rage; orders gates sealed; executes anyone attempting to leave as examples (2-5 killed); garrison terrorized into compliance through fear; no one dares leave; creates absolute horror inside fortress.

ranges.label: Lockdown - No Movement Allowed
ranges.summary: Count Diego orders all gates barred and no one permitted to leave; guards prevent evacuation attempts; townspeople confined to homes under guard; garrison confined to posts; minimal evacuation with only 5-10 people managing to escape.

ranges.label: Trickle Exodus - Some Brave Souls Leave
ranges.summary: Count Diego threatens but doesn't execute; 50-100 townspeople brave enough to leave mostly women/children/elderly; handful of garrison soldiers desert (10-20); Count rages but can't stop all without losing control; majority stay out of fear.

ranges.label: Significant Departure - Garrison Splits
ranges.summary: Count Diego losing control; 200-400 townspeople evacuate over hours; 30-50 garrison soldiers desert openly; Count can't stop flow without civil war inside walls; remaining garrison (~150) mostly household troops; substantially weakened.

ranges.label: Mass Civilian Exodus - Garrison Wavers
ranges.summary: Townspeople rush for exits in large numbers; 800-1,000 civilians (over half) evacuate; 50-80 garrison soldiers desert; Count Diego powerless to stop it; streets half-empty when assault comes; significantly easier assault.

ranges.label: Near-Total Evacuation - Only Diehards Remain
ranges.summary: Floodgates open and nearly everyone leaves; 1,200+ townspeople evacuate (80% of population); 100+ garrison soldiers desert; only Count's household troops remain (~50-80 men); town essentially abandoned; skeleton defense.

ranges.label: Garrison Mutiny - Officers Defect
