ranges.summary: Senior officers approach herald with surrender offer; garrison soldiers evacuate en masse (150+ troops); townspeople flood out (1,400+ civilians); Count Diego confined or restrained by own men; only 20-30 absolute loyalists remain with Count; fortress essentially surrendered except Count's retainers.

ranges.label: Complete Capitulation - Count Overthrown
ranges.summary: Castellan Rodrigo and brother Luis lead coup to relieve Count Diego of command for madness; gates thrown open and white flags raised; entire garrison marches out in formation to surrender honorably; townspeople evacuate safely; Count Diego detained and presented to king.

tables.title: Count Diego's Response to Juan's Challenge
tables.context: Chaos Roll — After a week of successful siege at Niebla's inner keep, Juan shouts a direct challenge to the mad Count Diego, calling him to face his doom. The garrison has been silent for hours after the bombardment, and Juan wants to know their state of mind and how they'll respond to his psychological pressure.

ranges.label: Complete Breakdown
ranges.summary: Diego suffers total psychological collapse, screaming incoherently and destroying the keep's interior. His banner is torn down from inside, and his own men try to restrain him. Complete loss of command and sanity.

ranges.label: Suicidal Defiance
ranges.summary: Diego appears at an arrow slit screaming defiance, declaring he'll kill ten Castilian soldiers before dying. His knights shout war cries behind him—the garrison is committed to a suicidal death-or-glory last stand.

ranges.label: Hostage Desperation
ranges.summary: A knight appears threatening to execute mutineers (Luis and others) if Juan storms the keep. Diego has seized the traitors and uses them as leverage in a desperate bargaining attempt from a cornered position.

ranges.label: Religious Madness
ranges.summary: Diego appears holding a crucifix, citing biblical passages about martyrdom and divine judgment. His madness has taken a religious turn—he's convinced this is God's test and his knights are now praying, believing themselves to be martyrs.

ranges.label: Defiant Silence
ranges.summary: Complete silence from the keep. No response at all to Juan's challenge—either Diego refuses to dignify it or his knights have silenced him. The uncertainty is maddening and the silence itself is terrifying to the troops.

ranges.label: Negotiation Attempt (By Knights)
ranges.summary: Not Diego, but senior knights appear requesting time to reason with their mad lord. The household is fracturing—some want to live while others remain loyal to their count's suicidal stance.

ranges.label: Conditional Surrender Offer
ranges.summary: Diego offers to surrender the keep if Juan allows him to keep the Count title (though losing lands and taxes). His obsession with the title remains absolute even as everything else falls apart.

ranges.label: Challenge Accepted (With Conditions)
ranges.summary: Diego accepts single combat but demands his champion fight instead of Juan directly, seeing it as either below the king or sacrilegious. He's found a thread of honor to cling to and won't fight the king personally.

ranges.label: Challenge Accepted (Directly)
ranges.summary: Diego appears in full armor challenging Juan to personal combat on the battlement, his voice almost sane despite the madness. This crystallizes into something coherent—single combat as a path to honorable death.

ranges.label: Surrender with Dignity Request
ranges.summary: Diego, haggard but clearer, agrees to surrender if allowed to walk out with his banner, armor, and sword. A moment of sanity pierces the madness as he seeks ceremony and dignity in defeat.

ranges.label: The Knights Mutiny
ranges.summary: The garrison itself rises up and drags Diego out, bound and struggling. 'Forgive us, Your Majesty! He's mad!' The household completely breaks, surrendering their own lord to save themselves.

ranges.label: Unexpected Honor
ranges.summary: Diego appears in full armor, clear-eyed and calm, raising his sword in salute. He acknowledges defeat and surrenders the keep, asking only to die with steel in hand rather than on the executioner's block—genuine nobility breaking through.

tables.title: Juan's Speech to Assault Troops - Fierce Commitment
tables.context: Persuasion Roll — After the mad count refuses all attempts at negotiation, Juan addresses 500 assault troops before storming the keep. He must inspire them to charge through a breach against desperate, cornered men. The troops are exhausted from months of campaigning but have just witnessed Juan's personal courage.

ranges.label: Exhaustion Dominates
ranges.summary: Your words are heard but men's faces remain tired and drawn. The fear doesn't vanish but is managed, controlled. Men cross themselves, think of bloody room-to-room fighting. Mostly just resigned—they'll do their duty but reluctantly.

ranges.label: Grim Resignation
ranges.summary: Silent nods and tight jaws. Your comparison to the mad count makes them think Granada will fight to the death like Diego did. Fear converts to dread at what more weeks of fighting will mean. Professional acceptance of duty, nothing more.

ranges.label: War-Weary Acceptance
ranges.summary: Mixed reactions—some straighten at the historical moment, others look sick at thoughts of more fighting. Veterans seem steadier than younger troops. Uneven resolve: some truly ready, some forcing themselves. Captains work to bolster the uncertain.

ranges.label: Mixed Resolve
ranges.summary: Your speech creates visible division. Some men who've fought beside you straighten and grip weapons tighter, but others look sick and pale. One young soldier vomits from fear. The unit is patchwork—some genuinely ready, some barely holding together.

ranges.label: Professional Acceptance
ranges.summary: Steady nods throughout. Your framing works—they see the necessity and inevitability. Fear is still there but managed and controlled. When you ask 'Are you with me?' you get firm 'Aye!' responses. Not enthusiastic but solid.

ranges.label: Rising Determination
ranges.summary: Your words strike home. Men stand straighter. Fear doesn't vanish but becomes bearable because of your presence. 'Kill the count and let the killing stop' gets dark chuckles. Veterans encourage younger soldiers. 'With you, Your Majesty! To the end!' they chorus.

ranges.label: Inspired Confidence
ranges.summary: Your leadership transforms the moment. Yes, it will be bloody—they know and accept it—but you're GOING WITH THEM. 'We will end this' becomes a rallying cry. Men pound swords against shields. Fear converts to focused aggression. They roar approval.

ranges.label: Fierce Commitment
ranges.summary: Your speech ignites something powerful. Success factors overwhelm the fear—your courage, the justice of the cause, the religious framing combine explosively. Men roar approval and pound shields. 'Kill the count and let the killing stop!' becomes a chant. They're absolutely WITH you.

ranges.label: Legendary Moment
ranges.summary: Your words strike like divine inspiration. These men have followed you through the entire crusade and now see their king preparing to lead them personally into danger. The roar shakes the walls. Men weep and shout simultaneously. This becomes a story told for generations.

tables.title: Siege of Íllora - First Week Bombardment
tables.context: Chaos Roll — After a successful cannon shot on Niebla's keep gate, Juan orders the bombardment of Íllora's outer walls. The garrison has 600-800 troops and refuses surrender, forcing a grinding siege. This roll determines how effectively the artillery performs and what complications arise during the initial bombardment phase.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Disaster
ranges.summary: A bombard barrel explodes catastrophically on Day 2, killing master gunner Pietro and 8 crew members, wounding a dozen more. A second bombard's carriage is destroyed. You're down to 3 operational guns. Bombardment effectiveness drops 60%. Garrison morale soars. Siege becomes months-long.

ranges.label: Major Setback - Successful Sortie
ranges.summary: Day 4: 400 Moorish troops sortie at dawn and strike hard at your artillery positions. One bombard is badly damaged despite protective measures. Powder stores are set ablaze. 45 of your men killed, 80 wounded. You lose a week of progress and significant supplies.

ranges.label: Serious Complications
ranges.summary: Heavy rains begin on Day 3, turning siege works to mud. Bombardment slows to half-rate. Day 5: Small sortie kills 18 men and damages supplies. Disease begins appearing. By week's end: minimal wall damage, 25 dead from combat and illness. Another week needed minimum.

ranges.label: Difficult Progress
ranges.summary: Bombardment effective but slow. Garrison makes effective repairs each night, undoing daily progress. Day 5: Small sortie (80 men) harasses positions, kills 12. By week's end: serious damage but no breach yet. Casualties: 20 dead, 35 wounded. Need 3-4 more days of bombardment.

ranges.label: Grinding Siege Warfare
ranges.summary: Standard difficult siege. Bombardment creates steady damage. Defenders repair at night but can't keep up. Two small sorties cause 15 dead, 28 wounded total. Incendiary arrows threaten powder stores but protective measures work. By week's end: breach developing but not assault-ready. Need 3-4 more days.

ranges.label: Steady But Unspectacular
ranges.summary: Professional operations proceeding normally. One sortie (Day 4) is spotted early and driven back with minimal casualties (6 dead, 10 wounded). Protective measures around artillery working. By week's end: clear breach forming, maybe 15 feet wide. Need two more days of bombardment.

ranges.label: Effective Operations
ranges.summary: Your protective measures and experienced crews make the difference. Day 5 sortie is crushed—they lose 35 men, you lose 8. Wall damage accumulates faster than they can repair. Deserters provide intelligence (3 men). By week's end: breach 20 feet wide, assault-ready with one more day. Casualties: 10 dead, 18 wounded.

ranges.label: Strong Progress
ranges.summary: Excellent bombardment effectiveness. Pietro's crews work like a machine and exploit wall's structural weaknesses brilliantly. Day 4: Major section collapses—30-foot breach opens. Garrison sortie on Day 5 is slaughtered (50 Moorish dead, 5 Castilian). Deserters increase (8 men). By week's end: breach fully assault-ready, 35 feet wide. Minimal casualties: 7 dead, 12 wounded.

ranges.label: Rapid Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Everything goes right. Wall proves weaker than expected. Day 3: Major collapse creates 25-foot breach. Day 5: Follow-up bombardment widens to 40 feet. Garrison morale cracking—no effective sorties. Deserters (15 men) provide detailed intelligence. Zero artillery damage. By week's end: assault-ready breach. Casualties: 4 dead, 8 wounded.

ranges.label: Garrison Weakening
ranges.summary: Not just bombardment success but psychological warfare working. Deserters (25+ men) streaming out at night reporting mutiny attempts and terrible morale. Day 4: Major breach, Day 6: widened dramatically. Half-hearted sortie easily repulsed. By week's end: 45-foot breach, garrison probably ready to negotiate. Casualties: 3 dead, 6 wounded.

ranges.label: Near-Collapse
ranges.summary: Spectacular effectiveness. Day 3: 60-foot breach appears. Deserters flood out (40+ men). Internal mutiny visible, commander barely in control. No sorties attempted. Bombardment shifts to castle, damaging towers. White flags briefly appear on Day 6. By week's end: massive breach, garrison on verge of surrender. Casualties: 2 dead, 3 wounded.

ranges.label: Unexpected Surrender
ranges.summary: Day 5: White flags appear on the walls. Garrison commander sends negotiators: 'We cannot win. Let us discuss terms before more blood is shed.' Bombardment proved devastating, garrison demoralized. Breach is ready but unnecessary. Fortress surrenders after five days. Zero combat casualties. Íllora falls without assault.

tables.title: Juan's Offer of Mercy at Íllora - Qaid Hamza's Response
tables.context: Persuasion Roll — Juan approaches Íllora's keep under flag of truce in white armor, offering terms. He acknowledges the garrison's honor while laying out the military reality: the breach is assault-ready, bombardment was devastating, and further resistance is futile. He offers merciful terms but also makes clear the alternative is storming the breach.

ranges.label: Offended Rejection
ranges.summary: The humor lands badly. Hamza's face hardens—he feels mocked by Juan's 'fight again' comment. Though your terms sound good and reputation for mercy is known, the ending feels dismissive of their honor. 'We will defend this fortress.' Your offer fails due to wounded pride.

ranges.label: Rigid Honor Refusal
ranges.summary: Hamza acknowledges your values and reputation, but military honor demands resistance. He's sworn oaths to Sultan Yusuf and cannot break faith, no matter the cost. 'I will die at my post, Your Majesty.' Immovable despite good terms.

ranges.label: Suspicious Resistance
ranges.summary: Hamza hears the terms but his decades of war make him deeply suspicious. 'Words are easy before gates open. Actions after matter.' He's seen too many Christian promises broken. Cannot risk his people on assurances, however sincere they sound. Refuses to surrender despite the hopelessness.

ranges.label: Deeply Conflicted
ranges.summary: Hamza is torn—the terms are good, your reputation suggests honesty—but duty and fear of betrayal pull him toward resistance. He needs time to pray and think. Not rejection but paralysis. Conflicted between obligations.

ranges.label: Cautious Opening
ranges.summary: Your approach slightly disarms him. The humor catches him off-guard—a slight smile. 'Fight again as allies rather than enemies?' Your honesty about God's children and avoiding unnecessary killing creates an opening. He wants assurances but is willing to negotiate.

ranges.label: Growing Respect and Consideration
ranges.summary: Hamza is moved by mention of your wife praying for Muslims. He acknowledges your character. He's inclined to accept and will speak with his men tonight, likely agreeing by dawn. Your actions match your words at other fortresses.

ranges.label: Strong Acceptance
ranges.summary: The humor works and disarms him. 'Fight again? Perhaps.' Hamza relaxes and sees that you offer good terms for an honorable exit. He accepts after two days to organize departure. Fortress surrenders peacefully.

ranges.label: Grateful Relief
ranges.summary: Your wife's prayers move Hamza deeply. No Christian has ever shown such mercy toward Muslims. He accepts immediately—terms are better than he deserves. 'You've proven honor and mercy exist even in war.' Surrenders the fortress.

ranges.label: Immediate Acceptance with Emotion
ranges.summary: Hamza steps forward to clasp your hand. 'You are unlike any Christian commander I've faced.' Gates open within the hour. Garrison surrenders immediately. Hamza asks to remain as your vassal—extraordinary transformation.

ranges.label: Transformation and Alliance
ranges.summary: Something extraordinary happens. Hamza laughs at the humor about fighting again. 'Or perhaps not fight at all—perhaps serve together.' He offers to stay as a Muslim commander holding a Christian king's fortress, seeing a new way forward.

tables.title: Assault on Íllora Town - Military Outcome
tables.context: Chaos Roll — After Hamza refuses Juan's merciful terms, the assault begins with pre-dawn bombardment followed by 500 troops storming through the 40-foot breach. The defenders have prepared internal barricades and are desperate, having rejected any chance of honorable surrender.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure
ranges.summary: Assault goes disastrously wrong. Defenders prepared the breach better than expected with fire, oil, and collapsing rubble traps. First wave devastated. Panic spreads. Moorish sortie from secondary gate hits flanks. 150-200 Castilian dead, 250+ wounded. Garrison holds firm. Need weeks more siege work.

ranges.label: Severe Setback
ranges.summary: Breach assault bogs down in brutal fighting. Defenders have layered barricades. Your troops fight for every foot in chokepoint. Casualties mount quickly. After 3 hours, you control the breach but haven't broken into town. 100-130 dead, 180-220 wounded. Garrison still fighting effectively. Another assault needed tomorrow.

ranges.label: Heavy Casualties - Slow Progress
ranges.summary: Assault succeeds but at terrible cost. Defenders fight desperately at every barricade. Room-to-room combat in the town is nightmarish. Takes until mid-afternoon to secure town walls. Garrison retreats to castle with 400 men still fighting. 80-100 dead, 150-180 wounded. Now face castle siege with exhausted forces.

ranges.label: Difficult Urban Combat
ranges.summary: Breach stormed successfully after fierce fighting. Town combat is brutal—defenders contest every street and building. Some surrender when cornered, others fight to death. By evening you control the town. 60-75 dead, 120-140 wounded. Garrison retreats to castle. Grim victory.

ranges.label: Hard-Fought Success
ranges.summary: Standard difficult assault. Breach fighting intense but numbers tell. Town secured by afternoon through methodical clearing. Defenders split—some surrender when offered quarter, others fight on. Garrison retreats to castle with 200-250 loyalists. 45-55 dead, 90-110 wounded. Solid military success.

ranges.label: Professional Assault
ranges.summary: Well-executed attack. Bombardment disrupts defenders effectively. Breach taken in two hours. Town clearing proceeds methodically—discipline holds, quarter offered, many accept. Hamza retreats to castle with 150 loyalists. 30-40 dead, 60-80 wounded. Town secured, civilians mostly protected.

ranges.label: Effective Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Excellent assault execution. Pre-dawn bombardment devastates positions. First wave takes breach with minimal resistance. Town fighting sees substantial surrenders—250+ garrison troops lay down arms. Hamza and 100 hardliners barricade in castle. 20-28 dead, 45-60 wounded. Strong success.

ranges.label: Garrison Fracturing
ranges.summary: Assault begins, garrison cohesion breaks immediately. Whole sections surrender as you enter. Hamza and 60 loyalists fight running battle to castle. 400+ garrison troops surrender throughout the morning. Fighting brief and localized. 12-18 dead, 30-40 wounded. Town secured by noon with minimal damage.

ranges.label: Rapid Collapse
ranges.summary: White flags appear before assault fully begins. Officers override Hamza's decision. Young captain leads surrender. Hamza and 30-40 diehards barricade in castle tower. Rest of garrison surrenders en masse. 5-8 dead from brief fighting, 10-15 wounded. Excellent success.

ranges.label: Last-Minute Surrender
ranges.summary: Gates open at dawn before bombardment. Senior officer emerges with white flag. 'Commander Hamza was overruled. We surrender.' Garrison mutinied overnight. Zero assault casualties. Complete peaceful surrender. Total strategic success.

ranges.label: Hamza's Change of Heart
ranges.summary: Hour before dawn, Hamza requests parley. Emerges alone saying his mistrust was sin and God showed him through a dream that Juan truly is different. Full peaceful surrender. Hamza repentant. Miraculous resolution.

tables.title: Siege of Íllora Castle - bombardment and Garrison Response
tables.context: Chaos Roll — After the costly assault on the town (87 dead), 400 garrison troops under Hamza have retreated to the castle. Juan orders bombardment without offering new terms first. This roll determines how the castle siege unfolds, how long bombardment takes, and how internal division leads to surrender or prolonged fighting.

ranges.label: Hamza's Final Stand
ranges.summary: Castle proves incredibly resilient. Three days bombardment creates only minor damage. Day 4: Hamza leads 200-man suicidal sortie. 45 Castilian troops killed before sortie annihilated. Hamza dies fighting. Remaining garrison surrenders. 60+ dead, 80+ wounded. Week-long brutal siege.

ranges.label: Protracted Resistance
ranges.summary: Castle tougher than expected. Five days bombardment to create marginal breach. Internal divisions persist but Hamza maintains control through executions of 'defeatists.' Day 6: Storm castle—35 more dead, 150+ defenders killed. Hamza dies in fighting. 50 dead, 70 wounded. Pyrrhic victory.

ranges.label: Difficult Siege
ranges.summary: Four days bombardment. Walls crack slowly. Internal arguments heard nightly with visible scuffles. Day 4: Major breach opens. Officers imprison Hamza and surrender. Bombardment killed 15 civilians in collapse. 8 dead from harassing fire. Week lost but officers finally act.

ranges.label: Grinding Siege
ranges.summary: Three days steady bombardment. Walls show serious damage. Internal discord intensifies—two mutiny attempts observed. Day 3 evening: Major wall collapse creates breach. Night before assault, officers overthrow Hamza (imprisoned, not killed). Surrender at dawn Day 4. 10 civilians dead from bombardment. 5 dead from harassing arrows. Four days lost.

ranges.label: Slow Crumbling
ranges.summary: Two days bombardment creates significant damage. Internal divisions visible daily. Day 2: 60 soldiers lower themselves on ropes and surrender. Day 3: Officers arrest Hamza and negotiate surrender. 340 troops surrender. 3 dead from harassing fire. Three days lost, clean resolution.

ranges.label: Effective Pressure
ranges.summary: Bombardment effective. Day 1: Significant damage. That night: Major internal confrontation with fighting inside. Day 2: Officers present Hamza in chains—'He would have killed us all.' Castle moderately damaged, garrison intact (395 troops). 2 dead from arrows. Two days lost. Good outcome.

ranges.label: Rapid Resolution
ranges.summary: First bombardment volley causes spectacular damage. Wall section proves weaker, major crack appears. By mid-morning: serious crisis. Gates open, white flags everywhere. Officers drag Hamza out in chains. Immediate complete surrender. Castle minimally damaged. Zero additional casualties. One day. Excellent outcome.

ranges.label: Quick Collapse
ranges.summary: First volley causes major damage—wall section unexpected weak. Immediate crisis inside. By mid-morning: gates open, white flags. Officers emerge with white flags. Immediate complete surrender. Castle minimally damaged. Zero additional casualties. One day. Excellent outcome.

ranges.label: Overnight Mutiny
ranges.summary: At 3 AM, before bombardment at dawn, gates open. Officers emerge with white flags and Hamza as prisoner. 'We imprisoned our commander after midnight. We will not repeat the slaughter.' Complete overnight mutiny. Zero bombardment needed. Zero additional casualties. Immediate surrender. Outstanding success.

ranges.label: Hamza Overthrown at Midnight
ranges.summary: Shortly after midnight, delegation approaches under white flag. Officers have voted unanimously to remove Hamza. 'We surrender and request the terms you offered yesterday.' Internal revolution within hours. Zero bombardment. Zero additional casualties. Complete peaceful resolution.

ranges.label: Hamza's Revelation
ranges.summary: 2 AM: Messenger requests immediate parley. At dawn, gates open—Hamza emerges unarmed, falls to knees. 'God showed me my sin. I surrender everything. Please show the mercy I should have accepted.' Completely broken and repentant. Zero additional casualties. Miraculous transformation.

tables.title: Moclín Garrison Response to Juan's Surrender Offer
tables.context: Persuasion Roll — Juan rides to Moclín under flag of truce and shouts an offer of terms to the garrison. They have just heard news of Íllora's fate 4 days earlier: bombardment, breach, costly assault, followed by mercy. Commander Rahman al-Zagal is a professional veteran who can calculate military reality.

ranges.label: Hostile Rejection
ranges.summary: Long silence, then arrows at the ground—not at Juan but clear message. 'We are sworn to Sultan Yusuf! We will not surrender!' Facts acknowledged but fear and duty dominate. 'Come with your bombards if you will!' Defiant response. Siege continues without negotiation.

ranges.label: Suspicious Refusal
ranges.summary: Gates remain closed. After tense wait: 'Fine words, King of Castile, but we've heard Christian promises before.' They acknowledge Íllora but mistrust wins. 'If you want Moclín, take it by force.' Not hostile, but firm refusal. Requires siege.

ranges.label: Conflicted Paralysis
ranges.summary: Clear internal debate on walls. Finally: 'Your Majesty, we need time to discuss. Give us until morning.' Torn between facts and duty. Cannot decide immediately. Internal divisions visible. May need more pressure or time.

ranges.label: Cautious Consideration
ranges.summary: After pause: 'Your Majesty honors us. We heard what happened at Íllora. We know your reputation.' Professional acknowledgment. 'But we have duties and oaths. What exactly do you offer? How do we know the terms will hold?' Listening but wary. Ready to negotiate.

ranges.label: Serious Negotiation
ranges.summary: Gate opens partially. Officer emerges with guards at respectful distance. 'Your Majesty, we saw your bombards break Íllora's walls. We know Commander Hamza refused and paid the price.' Acknowledging reality. 'If you offer the same terms we are willing to discuss surrender seriously. We need assurances, time to organize. Our commander wishes to negotiate properly.'

ranges.label: Strong Momentum
ranges.summary: Quicker response. Gate opens, delegation of three officers emerges. Lead officer salutes respectfully. 'Your Majesty, we are soldiers. We can see reality.' Acknowledges siege, bombardment arriving in days, what happened at Íllora. 'If you guarantee safety, honor, choice to stay or leave—we believe we can accept.'

ranges.label: Eager Acceptance
ranges.summary: Gates open within minutes. Commander Rahman himself emerges with full delegation, removes helmet respectfully. 'Your Majesty, you do us honor.' Acknowledges everything about Íllora. 'We cannot win. If you offer the same terms—we accept. Moclín is yours.'

ranges.label: Grateful Relief
ranges.summary: Immediate response. Gates swing open, garrison commander rides out with obvious relief. 'Your Majesty! Thank God you've come!' Nearly stammering with relief. 'We feared this siege. The bombards arriving eventually. You offer surrender with honor? We accept! Please, let us avoid what Íllora suffered.'

ranges.label: Immediate Enthusiastic Surrender
ranges.summary: White flags on every tower before Juan finishes speaking. Gates thrown wide open. Commander Rahman and officer corps rush out, many smiling with relief. 'Your Majesty! We surrender! Completely!' Rahman laughs. 'You saved us the trouble of sending envoys. Íllora taught us everything. You're merciful and keep your word.'

tables.title: Moclín Garrison Response to Initial Terms
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan II personally visits Moclín's gates to offer surrender terms after the costly siege of Íllora. The garrison must decide whether to open negotiations or maintain defiance.
tables.outcome_label: Substantive Dialogue - Both Sides Engaging Honestly

ranges.label: Hostile Rejection
ranges.summary: Garrison refuses engagement and fires warning arrows. Hardline commander dominates and fears that precedent from Íllora (harder terms after refusal) will repeat. Negotiation impossible.

ranges.label: Fearful Resistance
ranges.summary: Officers appear and ask questions but deep concerns prevent acceptance. They acknowledge generous terms but fear economic pressure, vague timelines, and lack of legal protections for property and courts.

ranges.label: Cautious Negotiation
ranges.summary: Officers engage constructively, acknowledging military reality but requesting specifics on Christian rule, Islamic courts, mosque protections, and prisoner release timelines before considering surrender.

ranges.label: Substantive Dialogue
ranges.summary: Rahman al-Zagal and officers engage seriously, acknowledging Juan's honor and military dominance. They raise specific concerns about property law, mosque conversion, and prisoner timelines that can be negotiated.

ranges.label: Positive Momentum
ranges.summary: Officers are impressed by Juan's personal approach and acknowledge military reality. They request written charter guaranteeing Islamic religious and property rights, and clearer prisoner release definition.

ranges.label: Strong Agreement
ranges.summary: Officers demonstrate respect and willingness to finalize details. They acknowledge military reality and request written guarantees with royal seal, plus timeline for prisoner release.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Acceptance
ranges.summary: Commander al-Zagal steps forward and bows, accepting terms completely. Even without written additions, Juan's demonstrated honor at Íllora convinces them to surrender.

tables.title: Moclín Final Surrender Decision
tables.context: Diplomacy — After revealing the papal bull, consulting clergy on mosque compromise, and offering two friars as permanent witnesses to enforce terms, Juan presents his final offer on Christian rule and Muslim protections.

ranges.label: Rejection - Pride and Fear Win
ranges.summary: Despite Juan's concessions, the garrison rejects terms. Main mosque conversion and Christian law governance prove too psychologically difficult despite military reality favoring surrender.

ranges.label: Painful Rejection
ranges.summary: Officers acknowledge Juan's genuine concessions but cannot accept the mosque's conversion, Christian legal dominance, and religious minority status. Cultural death feels equivalent to physical death.

ranges.label: Divided Garrison
ranges.summary: Garrison splits internally. Approximately half accept terms seeing military reality and valuing life; half refuse, unable to accept mosque conversion. Officers request until morning to unify garrison or separate factions.

ranges.label: Reluctant Acceptance
ranges.summary: After internal struggle, military reality wins over pride. Officers accept that living under Christian law with limited freedom is better than death, though acknowledging the bitterness of the terms.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Acceptance
ranges.summary: Officers pragmatically accept fair terms, acknowledging Juan's consultation with clergy, permanent witnesses, and religious protections show genuine respect despite inherent unfairness of Christian rule.

ranges.label: Relieved Acceptance
ranges.summary: Officers accept with visible relief and gratitude. Juan's fair negotiation, permanent friars, prayer space permission, and prisoner timeline go far beyond expectations and earn respect.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Acceptance
ranges.summary: Commander al-Zagal accepts completely and with genuine gratitude. Juan's consultation with clergy, finding middle ground, and offering permanent guarantors shows extraordinary leadership worthy of respect.

ranges.label: Immediate Surrender with Honor
ranges.summary: Gates open immediately and garrison surrenders at once. Commander and officers express deep gratitude for Juan's diplomatic wisdom and offer immediate feast together to seal the agreement.

tables.title: March to Alhama and Bombard Deployment
tables.context: Chaos — The army marches 25 miles southeast through mountain terrain to Alhama with 5 bombards. Success depends on terrain difficulty, weather, guerrilla interference, artillery transport issues, and enemy preparedness.

ranges.label: Catastrophic March
ranges.summary: Major guerrilla ambush in mountain passes inflicts 80-120 casualties. One bombard damaged beyond repair. Arrival delayed 4-5 days, allowing enemy full preparation.

ranges.label: Severe Difficulties
ranges.summary: Heavy harassment throughout march causes 40-60 casualties. One bombard damaged, requiring 3-4 day repairs. Supply disruption delays arrival 2-3 days with poor artillery positioning available.

ranges.label: Significant Problems
ranges.summary: Constant skirmishing and difficult terrain cause 20-35 casualties. Artillery transport slowed significantly. Arrival delayed 1-2 days. Enemy fully alert with suboptimal bombard positions.

ranges.label: Minor Complications
ranges.summary: Light guerrilla harassment and terrain challenges cause 10-18 casualties. March takes full two days as planned but exhausts troops. Adequate but not ideal bombard positions found.

ranges.label: Standard March
ranges.summary: Light skirmishing and manageable terrain cause 5-10 casualties. Arrival evening April 20 as planned. Good bombard positions within 300-350 yards, ready to offer terms April 21.

ranges.label: Smooth Operation
ranges.summary: Minimal resistance and good weather with only 2-5 casualties from accidents. Excellent bombard positions within 250-300 yards found, allowing morning terms offer.

ranges.label: Very Successful March
ranges.summary: Fast movement with no significant resistance produces 0-2 casualties. Arrival with troops fresh. Perfect bombard positions within 200-250 yards. Garrison visibly shaken by professional deployment.

ranges.label: Exceptional Execution
ranges.summary: Rapid march through mountains with complete surprise on speed and ideal conditions produces no casualties. Early afternoon April 20 arrival with troops enthusiastic. Perfect artillery positions within 200 yards identified with garrison clearly frightened.

ranges.label: Outstanding Success
ranges.summary: Lightning fast march avoiding all resistance and enjoying ideal conditions produces no casualties. Early April 20 arrival with perfect positions within 150-200 yards. Garrison demoralized and already discussing surrender.

ranges.label: Spectacular Achievement
ranges.summary: Everything perfect—fastest possible march with zero resistance and ideal conditions. Early afternoon April 20 arrival with perfect positions within 150 yards of weakest wall. Garrison panicking before terms even offered.

tables.title: Alhama Initial Response to Terms Offer
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan appears before Alhama's gates in white armor on horseback, announcing he offers terms and asking for honest negotiation rather than bloodshed.

ranges.label: Hostile Rejection
ranges.summary: Officers appear briefly and fire warning arrows near Juan. Garrison refuses engagement, hardliners in control. Juan's show of force not yet decisive in overcoming pride and fear of Sultan.

ranges.label: Defiant Silence
ranges.summary: Long silence followed by officer inquiry about terms. Internal garrison division evident. Some want to negotiate, hardliners refuse. No commitment to negotiation yet.

ranges.label: Cautious Inquiry
ranges.summary: Senior officer appears with interpreters and asks specific questions from distance about Íllora and Moclín. Not committing to negotiate, just gathering information about Juan's reputation and military events.

ranges.label: Serious Consideration
ranges.summary: Gates remain closed but communication opens. Officer acknowledges impressive army arrival and requests time to discuss among garrison leadership, promising either negotiation or preparation for defense.

ranges.label: Willing to Negotiate
ranges.summary: Commander appears quickly on wall showing professional respect. Acknowledges military reality of Juan's army and requests detailed terms before considering opening gates.

ranges.label: Eager for Terms
ranges.summary: Commander appears quickly with officers, recognizing the bombards from Íllora and expressing relief that terms are offered. Shows understanding of military reality and willingness to discuss seriously.

ranges.label: Ready to Surrender
ranges.summary: Gates open partially within minutes. Commander and officers approach under truce flag with visible relief. Immediately willing to hear terms and likely to accept if fair.

ranges.label: Immediate Acceptance
ranges.summary: Gates open and commander announces surrender on walls. Requests immediate discussion of formal terms. Garrison united in accepting Juan's offer of mercy.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Capitulation
ranges.summary: Gates swing open fully and entire officer corps emerges. Commander kneels to Juan, expressing that his arrival and reputation prove honor. Immediate surrender requested.

tables.title: Alhama Response to Personal Parley Invitation
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan dismounts his horse before Alhama's gates, showing vulnerability and invoking both faiths' sacred military tradition of truces, asking officers to come down for face-to-face negotiation.

ranges.label: Refusal - Stay on Walls
ranges.summary: Officers refuse to come down, citing need to answer questions first before committing to face-to-face parley. Gates remain shut with visible internal disagreement about negotiation itself.

ranges.label: Cautious Counter-Offer
ranges.summary: Officers clearly want to negotiate after Juan's gesture but request he answer their questions from current positions first. If his answers satisfy them about Íllora/Moclín, they will then come down.

ranges.label: Conditional Agreement
ranges.summary: Officers accept meeting with conditions: Juan remains in place, they come with armed guards. Meeting occurs between positions with maintained safety protocols.

ranges.label: Respectful Acceptance
ranges.summary: Gates open slightly and officers emerge, approaching to 30 yards. They accept Juan's invitation with respect for his gesture, ready for serious conversation.

ranges.label: Immediate Acceptance
ranges.summary: Brief discussion on walls, then gates open. Commander and officers emerge and approach directly, bowing in respect for Juan's courageous dismounting.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Response
ranges.summary: Gates open immediately and entire officer corps emerges visibly moved. Commander kneels briefly in respect, expressing that Juan's action demonstrates true leadership worthy of trust.

tables.title: Alhama Response to Commander Martín's Testimony
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan brings Commander Martín (formerly Yusuf ibn Rashid, legendary Granada officer who converted to Christianity) to speak truthfully about Íllora, Moclín, and living under Christian rule after his conversion.

ranges.label: Stubborn Refusal
ranges.summary: Officers recognize Martín but internal hardline faction prevents coming down. They acknowledge his testimony but garrison politics paralyze decision. Request to return next morning for answer.

ranges.label: Cautious Delay
ranges.summary: Martín's testimony carries weight and Juan's logic seems sound, but officers request time to discuss overnight. Clearly some convinced, others need persuasion. Promise decision at dawn.

ranges.label: Internal Debate Visible
ranges.summary: Heated argument on walls with officers divided. Some convinced by Martín's testimony, others fearful. Request one hour to settle internal arguments, then commit to either negotiation or clear refusal.

ranges.label: Reluctant Acceptance
ranges.summary: Extended conference with Martín's testimony clearly impacting garrison. Officers emerge willing to come down and negotiate, though showing obvious reluctance about terms.

ranges.label: Respectful Agreement
ranges.summary: Brief discussion then gates open. Officers emerge respecting Martín's testimony and ready to negotiate seriously with Juan as soldiers who understand military reality.

ranges.label: Eager Response
ranges.summary: Gates open quickly, Martín's testimony decisive. Commander and full staff emerge eager to hear terms, ready to accept if fair like Moclín's surrender.

ranges.label: Immediate Capitulation
ranges.summary: Gates swing open at once. Entire garrison leadership surrenders immediately, moved by Martín's testimony and its proof of Juan's honor. Request immediate agreement drafting.

tables.title: Alhama Final Decision After Night Deliberation
tables.context: Persuasion — After night of internal garrison debate about Martín's testimony and Juan's demonstrated honor, officers must decide whether to surrender or defend. Juan emphasizes military reality, shows respect through Isabel's ribbon, and promises family protection advocacy.
tables.outcome_label: Ready to Negotiate - Need Final Assurances

ranges.label: Defiant Rejection
ranges.summary: Hardliners won internal debate despite being moved by Martín's testimony. Fear of Sultan's punishment and religious duty dominate. Garrison united in refusal to negotiate.

ranges.label: Painful Refusal
ranges.summary: Officers acknowledge Juan's honor and military reality but cannot overcome fear that Sultan will punish families for 'cowardly' surrender. Logic rejected for family safety concerns.

ranges.label: Conditional Willingness
ranges.summary: Officers want to surrender but need face-saving resistance first. They request Juan allow them to defend for some days before negotiating surrender, to prove they fought with honor.

ranges.label: Divided Garrison
ranges.summary: Garrison fractures: approximately half want immediate surrender, half refuse. Officers offer Juan the choice: accept those who surrender now, besiege smaller resisters.

ranges.label: Ready to Negotiate
ranges.summary: Officers emerge ready to surrender but raise specific concern: families in Granada city will face Sultan's punishment if they surrender without fighting. Request assurance about family protection in Granada.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Acceptance
ranges.summary: Officers accept completely, moved by Juan's emotional connection to family through Isabel's ribbon. Request same Moclín terms with family protection advocacy added.

ranges.label: Immediate Complete Surrender
ranges.summary: Garrison opens gates at dawn before Juan arrives. Officers surrender completely with gratitude, some requesting to hear more from Martín about his faith transformation.

tables.title: Alhama Final Decision - Response to Ultimatum
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan delivers final ultimatum: accept terms or face bombardment. He emphasizes Sultan's injustice in using families as hostages and calls on officers to fight on side of justice rather than evil.

ranges.label: Defiant Refusal
ranges.summary: Officers refuse clearly. Moral arguments acknowledged but fear for families too powerful. Will defend Alhama despite knowing it's futile.

ranges.label: Painful Rejection
ranges.summary: Officers understand Juan's logic and morality but cannot accept terms leaving families vulnerable. Will fight despite military reality.

ranges.label: Agonized Refusal
ranges.summary: Long silence and visible internal struggle. Officers acknowledge Juan is right about Sultan's evil, acknowledge logic of surrender, but family loyalty overrides. Request honorable siege rather than slaughter.

ranges.label: Split Decision
ranges.summary: Garrison fractures: some accept surrender, others refuse. Officers allow those who surrender to depart safely while hardliners defend. Two-stage siege negotiation.

ranges.label: Reluctant Acceptance
ranges.summary: Juan's exposure of Sultan's injustice and family hostage system convinces officers. They accept terms despite fear, trusting Juan's honor and future family negotiations.

ranges.label: Resolved Agreement
ranges.summary: Officers clearly decide Sultan's tyranny is unjust and unworthy of defense. They accept surrender with clear decision, trusting Juan's demonstrated honor.

ranges.label: Strong Acceptance
ranges.summary: Officers demonstrate strong acceptance, trusting Juan's concern for families more than Sultan's promises. Relief mixed with remaining fear, but decision is solid.

ranges.label: Determined Surrender
ranges.summary: Officers surrender completely, recognizing fighting doesn't protect families but surrendering to Juan does. Some offer to serve Juan against Sultan.

ranges.label: Complete Commitment
ranges.summary: Officers not only surrender but express conviction that Sultan is evil and commit to helping defeat him. Some families to be protected under Juan's rule.

tables.title: Alhama Bombardment - Breach Creation
tables.context: Siege Operations — Five bombards positioned at 180 yards from western wall of Alhama fortress attempt to create a breach for assault. The bombardment began April 21 with twenty-three shots that first day.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Setback
ranges.summary: Major gun malfunction cracks one bombard barrel, killing 3 crew and injuring 5 more, requiring 8-10 day replacement delay. Morale shaken, timeline extends to 4+ weeks for breach.

ranges.label: Severe Complications
ranges.summary: Poor powder batch causes misfires, unseasonable rain disrupts operations for 5 days, garrison sortie damages one gun carriage. 15-20 additional casualties from sortie, timeline 3.5-4 weeks.

ranges.label: Significant Delays
ranges.summary: Wall construction proves exceptionally solid with thick rubble core and well-maintained mortar. Progress frustratingly slow despite bombardment. Timeline 3-3.5 weeks to breach.

ranges.label: Below Expectations
ranges.summary: Solid walls with competent defender repairs. Professional but unremarkable progress with occasional weather delays. Pietro frustrated but professional. Timeline 2.5-3 weeks.

ranges.label: Standard Siege Progress
ranges.summary: Walls crack and crumble at expected pace. Defenders repair at night but bombardment outpaces them. Professional execution on both sides. Timeline 2-2.5 weeks.

ranges.label: Better Than Expected
ranges.summary: Wall section shows signs of older construction with degraded mortar over decades. Pietro identifies weakness and concentrates fire effectively. Minor structural failure accelerates progress. Timeline 1.5-2 weeks.

ranges.label: Strong Progress
ranges.summary: Excellent crew performance and ideal weather. Defenders demoralized after early wall damage. One section collapses cleanly after 10 days creating partial breach, second breach point developing. Timeline 10-14 days.

ranges.label: Exceptional Execution
ranges.summary: Pietro discovers critical weakness in wall foundation from old earthquake damage or poor repair. Concentrated bombardment causes cascading failures with major collapse by day 8. Garrison realizes futility immediately. Timeline 8-10 days.

ranges.label: Rapid Collapse
ranges.summary: Wall construction fundamentally flawed with water damage or different stone quality. First major breach by day 6-7, garrison sends negotiators before assault becomes necessary. Timeline 6-8 days, possible surrender before assault.

ranges.label: Spectacular Breach
ranges.summary: Multiple structural weaknesses compound cascading into collapse. First bombardment day reveals serious problems, by day 4-5 entire 40+ foot section collapses. Garrison immediately requests terms. Timeline 4-5 days, surrender without assault.

ranges.label: Miraculous Fortune
ranges.summary: Wall has critical hidden flaw from underground water erosion or ancient defect. First day bombardment triggers chain reaction with massive collapse by day 2-3 creating multiple breach points. Timeline 2-3 days, immediate surrender discussions.

tables.title: Alhama Garrison Response to Negotiation Offer
tables.context: Diplomacy — Commander Martín approaches under flag of truce after 10 days of bombardment and first major breach. Garrison commanders have already explained their family hostage situation but are being offered another chance to negotiate terms.

ranges.label: Absolute Refusal
ranges.summary: Officers refuse to even meet, shout from walls that they must fight to the end. Family fear calcified into desperate determination. No negotiation possible until after at least one assault repulsed or garrison breaks.

ranges.label: Not Yet - Need More
ranges.summary: Officers meet Martín but apologetically state 10 days of bombardment insufficient to show proper resistance. They must attempt to defend breach once before negotiating. They need blood spilled in combat to justify surrender to Sultan.

ranges.label: Need Visible Desperation
ranges.summary: Officers want two more days of bombardment to make breach overwhelming and surrender look inevitable rather than chosen. They need military situation so hopeless even Sultan must accept they had no choice.

ranges.label: Cautious Opening
ranges.summary: Officers willing to talk but deeply anxious about families. They request guarantees: prisoner exchange for families or safety assurances. Want to negotiate but need something protecting loved ones before committing.

ranges.label: Ready to Discuss Seriously
ranges.summary: Officers agree to formal negotiation as breach demonstrates they resisted properly. Will meet tomorrow at dawn and need details about surrender timing and civilian protections. Professional and pragmatic but still worried.

ranges.label: Relief and Readiness
ranges.summary: Officers clearly relieved Juan offered terms after seeing breach. Ready to negotiate immediately as breach makes their position clear to anyone observing. Want to work out surrender details quickly while protecting families and men's lives.

ranges.label: Grateful Acceptance
ranges.summary: Officers practically thank Martín, expressing hope for Juan's mercy which is well-known. Ready to surrender under same terms offered before with safe conduct and choice to stay or leave. Want to finalize quickly to prevent more damage.

ranges.label: Immediate Willingness
ranges.summary: Officers send word within the hour requesting formal parley tomorrow morning with written terms. Prepared to open gates within two days if terms acceptable. Breach proves resistance, now must live with honor. Professional eagerness to conclude.

ranges.label: Desperate Eagerness
ranges.summary: Senior officers come to walls immediately requesting audience tonight if possible. Breach broken morale, mutiny or chaos threatening. Beg to surrender soon and accept previously offered terms. Fear of losing control of garrison.

ranges.label: Crisis Point
ranges.summary: Officers emerge from gates within two hours requesting immediate audience with Juan. Breach shattered men's will, some planning to flee while others prepare to fight to death. Garrison losing cohesion. Must surrender tomorrow to maintain order and dignity.

tables.title: Sultan Yusuf IV's Strategic Response to Encirclement
tables.context: Intrigue — Sultan faces imminent complete encirclement with multiple fortresses fallen or surrendering, his hostage system exposed as tyrannical, and Castilian forces preparing three-pronged final offensive. Must choose how to respond strategically.

ranges.label: Desperate Field Battle
ranges.summary: Sultan gathers 8,000-9,000 troops and marches out to meet Juan's army before Iznalloz to break Castilian forces in open battle. Catastrophic odds but driven by desperation and refusal to accept inevitable defeat.

ranges.label: Assassination Attempt
ranges.summary: Sultan dispatches 3-5 elite assassins to infiltrate Castilian camp and kill Juan, Álvaro, or key commanders. Extremely risky gambit—success throws crusade into chaos, failure provides moral justification and enrages forces.

ranges.label: Fanatic Resistance Call
ranges.summary: Sultan issues religious proclamation calling for jihad and fanatic resistance with paradise promised to defenders. Orders execution of family members of officers who negotiated. Doubles down on hostage system despite exposure. Brutal but potentially stiffens short-term resistance.

ranges.label: Aggressive Guerrilla Campaign
ranges.summary: Sultan organizes systematic guerrilla warfare with 1,500-2,000 light cavalry to raid supply lines, harass siege camps, and attack foraging parties. Can't prevent encirclement but makes every operation costly and slow. Professional response insufficient to change strategic outcome.

ranges.label: Desperate Diplomatic Appeal
ranges.summary: Sultan sends urgent embassies to Morocco, Tunis, Egypt begging substantial military aid while offering territorial concessions and political alliances. Realistic chance of promises but actual aid unlikely to arrive in time.

ranges.label: Fortify and Delay
ranges.summary: Sultan abandons outlying fortresses, concentrates all forces in Granada city itself. Stockpiles food aggressively and fortifies walls further. Banks on expensive siege exhausting Castilian will and losing momentum. Passive but rational response.

ranges.label: Cautious Diplomatic Feelers
ranges.summary: Sultan sends unofficial envoy to test what short of complete conquest Juan would accept. Explores vassalage, tribute, or limited territory retention possibilities without committing. Pragmatic hedging keeping options open.

ranges.label: Conditional Negotiation Offer
ranges.summary: Sultan sends formal embassy proposing negotiations with willingness to discuss vassalage or territorial concessions but insists on preserving Granada city itself and his rule. Offers substantial tribute and acknowledgment of Castilian suzerainty.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Peace Overture
ranges.summary: Sultan recognizes military situation hopeless and sends high-ranking embassy offering serious negotiation for honorable surrender. Willing to discuss vassalage with autonomy, guaranteed dynasty rule, protection for Granada's Muslims, reasonable tribute.

ranges.label: Dynastic Preservation Bid
ranges.summary: Sultan offers to abdicate in favor of family member more acceptable to Castile if it preserves Nasrid dynasty in some form. Proposes son or brother rule as Castilian vassal with Granada as reduced autonomous emirate. Complete pragmatism accepting military defeat.

ranges.label: Full Surrender Negotiation
ranges.summary: Sultan sends embassy proposing complete surrender: he abdicates, leaves for Morocco with wealth and family, Granada peacefully transfers to Castilian control. Offers civilian protections in exchange for safe exile. Wants to end war before starvation makes terms worse.

ranges.label: Desperate Abdication
ranges.summary: Sultan recognizes position hopeless and he personally discredited from hostage system. Abdicates immediately and flees to Morocco, leaving Granada's ruling council to negotiate surrender. Cowardly but pragmatic for personal survival, ends war quickly.

ranges.label: Internal Coup
ranges.summary: Granada's nobles and garrison commanders stage internal coup against Sultan, arrest or kill Yusuf, install new ruler or council. Send immediate peace embassy: 'We removed the obstacle to peace. Wish to negotiate Granada's future on better terms.'

tables.title: Three-Pronged June Offensive Success
tables.context: Military — Three simultaneous operations (coastal ports with Infante Juan, Montefrío siege with 5,000 troops, Iznalloz bombardment with main army) while Sultan launches aggressive guerrilla campaign with 1,500-2,000 light cavalry raiding supply lines.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Setbacks
ranges.summary: Guerrilla campaign devastates operations with major supply convoys destroyed, multiple camps raided with 200+ dead and 100-150 wounded, one bombard damaged beyond field repair in attack. Coastal force bogged down at Motril for 3+ weeks, Montefrío operations stalled, Iznalloz barely begun. Timeline extends to August, morale severely damaged, strategic plan jeopardized.

ranges.label: Severe Complications
ranges.summary: Guerrillas inflict serious damage across fronts with major supply convoys destroyed, 100-150 casualties from raids. One operation suffers major setback requiring reinforcement. Iznalloz siege proceeds slowly. By month's end only 1 of 3 objectives achieved. Encirclement incomplete. Sultan's strategy working better than expected.

ranges.label: Significant Delays
ranges.summary: Guerrilla harassment causes persistent problems with supply raids forcing stronger escorts and slowing operations. 60-80 casualties from skirmishes. All three operations proceed but 10-14 days behind schedule. Motril falls but Salobreña resists. Montefrío under siege but not fallen. Encirclement delayed to July.

ranges.label: Mixed Results
ranges.summary: Operations proceed with moderate guerrilla interference. 40-50 casualties from raids. Coastal force takes Motril, besieging Salobreña. Montefrío under serious pressure. Iznalloz bombardment underway. Timeline slips 5-7 days but generally on track. Two objectives partially complete by month's end.

ranges.label: Standard Progress Despite Harassment
ranges.summary: Guerrillas harass but don't significantly disrupt operations. 25-35 casualties from skirmishes. Motril falls within 10 days, Montefrío walls breached by month's end. Iznalloz bombardment ahead of schedule. Timeline roughly maintained. Encirclement 75% complete by early July. Professional execution overcomes harassment.

ranges.label: Strong Execution
ranges.summary: Operations execute efficiently with cavalry screens effectively countering raiders. 15-25 casualties from minor skirmishes. Motril secured quickly, Salobreña breached, Montefrío near surrender, Iznalloz bombardment ahead of schedule. Encirclement essentially achieved by late June.

ranges.label: Excellent Coordination
ranges.summary: All three operations execute smoothly with aggressive counter-guerrilla operations limiting raiding effectiveness. 10-15 casualties. Motril secured in 8 days, Salobreña negotiates surrender, Montefrío falls after bombardment, Iznalloz under heavy pressure. Encirclement complete by late June.

ranges.label: Exceptional Performance
ranges.summary: Sultan's guerrilla force intercepted and destroyed in major engagement with 50+ enemy casualties. All operations unhindered with negligible casualties (5-10). Motril surrenders after show of force, Salobreña falls mid-June, Montefrío negotiates immediate surrender. Iznalloz garrison sees pattern and requests terms. All objectives achieved by June 25.

ranges.label: Devastating Success
ranges.summary: Guerrilla force destroyed in ambush with 150+ casualties and remnants fleeing. All fortresses fall with minimal resistance as garrisons recognize futility. Zero significant Castilian casualties. All objectives achieved by June 20. Completely encircled with massive army ready for systematic raiding. Historical achievement.

ranges.label: Miraculous Triumph
ranges.summary: Perfect military coordination with complete enemy collapse. Guerrilla force destroyed completely. All fortresses surrender immediately upon seeing overwhelming force. Zero casualties. All objectives achieved by June 15. Granada completely encircled with massive army in perfect fighting condition. Morale soaring. Historical masterpiece.

tables.title: Army Morale Response to King's Speech
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan addresses 22,000 troops assembled on plain outside Iznalloz before marching on Granada. Speech acknowledges their sacrifices and hardships while expressing confidence in inevitable victory and proximity to final objective.

ranges.label: Severe Morale Crisis
ranges.summary: Speech falls completely flat with men hearing only 'may take some time' and 'tired.' Grumbling spreads immediately through ranks. Some veterans openly question Granada's capture. Desertion that night: 40+ men. Officers report units questioning campaign. Dangerous morale crisis.

ranges.label: Poor Reception
ranges.summary: Tepid response with scattered applause only. Men look weary and unconvinced. Acknowledge hardship but hear little inspiration. Low morale persists. Some desertion expected (10-15). Army will march but without enthusiasm or confidence.

ranges.label: Disappointing Response
ranges.summary: Polite but unenthusiastic reception with scattered and brief applause. Veterans appreciate honesty but aren't inspired. New recruits uncertain. Morale neither improves nor worsens. Army will do duty but without conviction.

ranges.label: Mixed Reception
ranges.summary: Half respond well, half remain weary. Veterans appreciate realism and honesty. New troops less certain. Moderate applause from crusader contingents. Some unit morale improves, others unchanged. Sufficient for march but not inspiring greatness.

ranges.label: Adequate Response
ranges.summary: Solid reception as men appreciate acknowledgment of sacrifices and honest assessment of challenges. Decent applause and cheering. 'The worst is behind us' resonates with veterans. Morale improves modestly. Army ready to march with reasonable confidence.

ranges.label: Good Reception
ranges.summary: Strong response from most of army. 'Victory is near' and 'only a matter of time' land well. Veterans cheer at 'we have won every battle.' Good applause and sustained cheering. Morale notably improved. Army eager to march on Granada.

ranges.label: Strong Enthusiasm
ranges.summary: Excellent reception as message resonates deeply. Men roar approval at 'we have won every battle.' 'Soldiers of Christ' triggers religious fervor. Prolonged cheering and applause. Officers report dramatic morale shift. Energy and determination evident throughout ranks.

ranges.label: Powerful Impact
ranges.summary: Speech electrifies army and men roar approval at 'we have won every battle.' Honest acknowledgment combined with confident victory creates powerful connection. Prolonged cheering, religious enthusiasm, even weary troops stand straighter. Officers report dramatic transformation. Morale transforms to determined crusading force.

ranges.label: Inspiring Triumph
ranges.summary: Speech creates surge of conviction and purpose. Army explodes in sustained cheering and religious fervor. Veterans pound shields, crusaders sing hymns, even weary stand straighter. Combination of acknowledgment and purpose resonates perfectly. Exhausted army becomes crusading force with renewed purpose and faith.

ranges.label: Legendary Moment
ranges.summary: Perfect pitch achieving instant legend status. Speech acknowledges sacrifice while inspiring confidence, religious conviction meeting military reality. Army erupts with fervent cheering lasting minutes. Men weeping with emotion. Religious enthusiasm borders ecstatic. Unshakeable morale created. Historical moment of transformative leadership.

tables.title: Granada Blockade Establishment & Initial Raiding
tables.context: Military — March from Iznalloz to Granada (20 miles), establish fortified camp within sight of main gate, deploy 5,500+ cavalry for systematic interdiction of supply routes and raiding campaign devastation. Timeline: approximately 3-4 weeks of operations.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Disaster
ranges.summary: March ambushed in mountain pass by massed Granada sortie (2,000+ troops). Surprise attack in confined terrain causes panic with 150+ killed and baggage train overrun. Army forced to retreat to Iznalloz. Camp establishment fails completely. Sultan emboldened. Morale collapses. Strategic catastrophe.

ranges.label: Severe Setbacks
ranges.summary: Multiple disasters compound with initial positioning contested (100+ casualties), major night raid destroying supplies and killing 60+ men, disease outbreak in crowded conditions (80+ sick). Only weak blockade established. Granada resupplying successfully. 250+ total casualties. Strategy failing.

ranges.label: Major Complications
ranges.summary: Camp establishment heavily contested (70+ casualties) with multiple Granada sorties disrupting construction. Cavalry raids meet strong resistance with 30+ dead in ambushes. Disease problems in summer heat (50+ sick). Weak blockade but Granada getting supplies through mountain routes. 180+ casualties.

ranges.label: Significant Difficulties
ranges.summary: Camp established but at high cost (50+ casualties). Granada garrison aggressive, launching sorties every few days. Cavalry raiding produces mixed results—some convoys intercepted, others reach city. Several ambushes with 20-25 cavalry casualties. Heat and disease affecting troops. Blockade porous. 120+ casualties. Strategy proceeding with major challenges.

ranges.label: Mixed Results
ranges.summary: Camp established after moderate fighting (30-40 casualties). Granada contests positioning but Castilian numbers prevail. Cavalry raiding intercepts some supply attempts while Granada cavalry contests effectively. 15-20 casualties from engagements. Partial blockade with mountain paths still used. 80-100 casualties. Some progress but incomplete control.

ranges.label: Moderate Success
ranges.summary: Camp solidly established after initial skirmishing (20-30 casualties). Cavalry raiding intercepts majority of supply convoys. Granada's cavalry contests but generally driven back. Successful raids burn mills and fields. Blockade reasonably effective though not complete. 50-70 casualties. Granada's supply worsening.

ranges.label: Good Execution
ranges.summary: Camp established efficiently (15-25 casualties). Strong fortifications completed within week. Cavalry raiding highly effective with most supply routes interdicted. Granada's cavalry forced defensive. Systematic burning of nearby resources. Effective blockade with multiple screens. 30-45 casualties. Strategy working well.

ranges.label: Strong Performance
ranges.summary: Professional camp establishment (10-15 casualties). Excellent fortifications completed quickly. Cavalry raiding dominates with Granada riders avoiding engagement. Multiple convoys intercepted and destroyed. Systematic devastation of surrounding area. Tight blockade with overlapping screens. 20-30 casualties. Highly effective.

ranges.label: Excellent Campaign
ranges.summary: Masterful execution with camp established minimal resistance (5-10 casualties). Perfect positioning and fortification. Cavalry raiding crushes opposition with Granada suffering 50+ casualties and withdrawing to walls. Complete interdiction and systematic burning. Demoralized garrison. 10-20 casualties. Outstanding results.

ranges.label: Devastating Effectiveness
ranges.summary: Perfect military operation with camp established unopposed. Cavalry raiding annihilates Granada cavalry (80+ casualties) with remnants fleeing to city. Complete blockade and systematic devastation. Visible panic in city. Some garrison desertions. Negligible casualties. Strategic masterpiece.

ranges.label: Total Domination
ranges.summary: Historical achievement with Granada garrison barely contesting. Camp established like military parade. Cavalry operations annihilate enemy riders (100+ casualties, force broken). Absolute blockade with complete control. Visible panic and garrison unrest. Sultan's authority shaken. Zero casualties. Granada's position critical. Possible immediate surrender.

tables.title: Iznalloz Fall & Granada Positioning Operations
tables.context: Military — Final bombardment phase of Iznalloz fortress with four operational bombards, immediate march to Granada city positioning (~23,000 troops), initial positioning and raiding around capital with peripheral operations (southern watchtowers, coastal ports) commencing.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Disaster
ranges.summary: Iznalloz garrison launches desperate sortie during bombardment, overruns gun position, destroys two bombards and kills 80+ troops including Pietro Calabrese. Siege collapses into chaos. Retreat necessary to regroup. Granada march delayed weeks. Sultan emboldened. Strategic timeline ruined. 150+ casualties.

ranges.label: Severe Setbacks
ranges.summary: Iznalloz resists stubbornly for 3+ additional weeks. One bombard damaged in sortie. March harassed heavily with 60+ casualties. Arrival disorganized with Sultan sorties aggressively causing 40+ casualties. Operations delayed into August. 180+ total casualties. Momentum lost.

ranges.label: Major Complications
ranges.summary: Iznalloz requires full additional two weeks bombardment with garrison resisting until assault necessary (50+ casualties). March faces persistent harassment (30-40 casualties). Positioning contested by Granada sorties. Initial raiding ineffective. 120+ casualties. Strategy proceeding badly delayed.

ranges.label: Significant Delays
ranges.summary: Iznalloz walls breached but garrison negotiates for week before surrendering (mid to late July). March faces moderate guerrilla activity (20-25 casualties). Positioning takes 4-5 days with skirmishing. Initial raiding meets stiff resistance. Army fully positioned late July behind schedule. 60-80 casualties.

ranges.label: Mixed Results
ranges.summary: Iznalloz breaches July 16-18, surrenders after brief negotiation. March proceeds with minor harassment (10-15 casualties). Positioning takes three days with scattered skirmishes. Initial raiding burns some fields but faces resistance. Army surrounds Granada by July 24-25. 35-50 casualties. Acceptable execution.

ranges.label: Solid Execution
ranges.summary: Iznalloz breaches July 15-16 with garrison requesting terms immediately. Falls by July 18. March proceeds smoothly (5-10 casualties). Positioning completed in two days. Initial aggressive raiding destroys fields. Army surrounds Granada by July 22-23. 20-30 casualties. Excellent coordination.

ranges.label: Strong Performance
ranges.summary: Iznalloz breaches July 14, garrison recognizes futility July 15-16. Rapid march (July 17-20) faces negligible resistance. Professional positioning in 36 hours. Immediate aggressive raiding destroys mills and fields. Psychological impact evident. Army positioned July 21. 10-15 casualties.

ranges.label: Excellent Execution
ranges.summary: Iznalloz garrison sees Montefrío example and requests terms before final breach (July 13-14). Falls July 15 with minimal casualties. Lightning march reaches Granada July 18-19, complete surprise. Positioning flawlessly executed. Immediate devastating raiding. Granada garrison stunned. 5-10 casualties.

ranges.label: Exceptional Campaign
ranges.summary: Iznalloz surrenders July 12-13 with zero assault casualties. Lightning march reaches Granada July 16-17 completely unexpected. Professional positioning like military textbook. Massive raids destroy visible resources. Granada's population watches in terror. Army positioned July 18-19. 3-5 casualties.

ranges.label: Devastating Shock
ranges.summary: Iznalloz surrenders July 11-12 without resistance. Extremely rapid march reaches Granada July 15-16 before Sultan realizes Iznalloz fallen. Perfect positioning execution. Systematic raiding with no resistance. Garrison demoralized. Zero significant casualties. Army positioned July 17 perfectly.

ranges.label: Strategic Masterpiece
ranges.summary: Iznalloz surrenders July 10-11 upon seeing preparations. Forced march reaches Granada July 14-15. Sultan completely unprepared. Professional flawless positioning with such speed Granada garrison cannot respond. Immediate devastating raids. City in shock with visible panic. Army positioned July 16. Zero casualties. Historical achievement.

tables.title: Defensive Consolidation Strategy - Camp Fortification
tables.context: Military — Shift to larger cavalry formations (500-800 riders), fortified camp construction with elevated crossbow platforms and strengthened defenses, more defensive patient posture. Timeline: approximately 2 weeks of consolidation operations.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Attack
ranges.summary: Sultan launches massive coordinated sortie (3,000+ troops) targeting camp during construction phase. Overruns one section, destroys platforms under construction. 80+ killed with major chaos. Construction set back week+. Strategy appears failed. Major morale crisis.

ranges.label: Major Disaster
ranges.summary: Large sortie (1,500+ troops) catches construction crews exposed, killing 50+. Destroys completed platforms and burns supplies. Disease outbreak compounds (40+ sick). Cavalry formation ambushed successfully (20+ dead). Construction badly delayed. 90+ casualties. Strategy failing.

ranges.label: Serious Setbacks
ranges.summary: Multiple problems: sortie kills 30+ during construction, disease spreads (30+ sick), cavalry ambushed (15+ casualties). Platform construction behind schedule. Granada supplies flowing due to reduced raiding. 70+ casualties. Limited progress.

ranges.label: Significant Complications
ranges.summary: Construction proceeds slowly due to harassment (20+ casualties from raids/skirmishes). Disease affects 20+ troops. Cavalry cautious but less effective. Granada moderately resupplying. Only 50-60% of planned platforms completed. 50+ casualties. Partial success.

ranges.label: Mixed Results
ranges.summary: Construction achieves 60-70% with some platforms completed and defenses improved but not finished. Minor raids and skirmishes (15-25 casualties). Disease manageable (10-15 sick). Cavalry intercepts some supplies. 40-50 casualties. Modest progress but incomplete.

ranges.label: Adequate Progress
ranges.summary: Construction proceeds reasonably well with 6-8 platforms completed and earthworks strengthened. Occasional skirmishing (10-20 casualties). Larger cavalry formations deter attacks. Disease minor (5-10 sick). Camp noticeably more defensible. 25-35 casualties. Strategy working.

ranges.label: Good Execution
ranges.summary: Construction efficient with 8-10 platforms completed and camp significantly improved. Minimal combat casualties (8-15). Larger cavalry formations avoid ambushes while maintaining presence. Disease minimal. Granada makes fewer sorties. Visible transformation intimidates garrison. 15-25 casualties. Solid progress.

ranges.label: Strong Performance
ranges.summary: Excellent construction progress with 10+ platforms operational and camp impressively fortified. Very low casualties (5-10). Cavalry dominates without engagement. Disease controlled. Granada stops sorties appearing intimidated. Morale improves seeing tangible progress. 10-15 casualties. Strategy very effective.

ranges.label: Excellent Results
ranges.summary: All planned fortifications completed ahead of schedule. Minimal casualties (3-8). Cavalry operates freely with Granada's withdrawn to walls. Disease avoided entirely. Camp transformed into impressive fortress. Visible garrison demoralization. Negligible casualties. Outstanding execution.

ranges.label: Exceptional Success
ranges.summary: Perfect execution with all fortifications completed in 10 days. Zero significant casualties (1-3 minor injuries). Granada cavalry withdrawn to walls. Construction intimidates garrison with visible demoralization. Some deserters report morale collapsing. Camp now fortress. Strategic masterpiece.

ranges.label: Strategic Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Flawless two weeks with perfect fortification completion. Zero casualties. Granada garrison so intimidated Sultan sends unofficial envoy testing surrender terms. Visible panic in city. Construction message clear: 'We're staying until you starve.' Possible early negotiations. Historical demonstration of strategic patience.

tables.title: Sultan Yusuf IV's Response to Juan's Surrender Demand
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan approaches Granada under flag of truce in white armor with crusaders and reliquaries, dismounts, and makes a respectful appeal for surrender offering 50,000 florins compensation and dignified terms. The Sultan must decide how to respond to this unprecedented diplomatic gesture.

ranges.label: Outright Rejection
ranges.summary: Gates remain closed with no response or insulting dismissal; Sultan rejects offer out of hand.

ranges.label: Defiant Refusal
ranges.summary: Formal rejection speech from walls rallying city to continued resistance; Sultan uses rejection as propaganda.

ranges.label: Evasive Delay
ranges.summary: Sultan requests time to consider and sends low-ranking official to stall; avoids commitment either way.

ranges.label: Cautious Opening
ranges.summary: Sultan sends senior envoy (Qaid Ibrahim al-Farsi) to discuss preliminaries without committing himself; tests sincerity of offer.

ranges.label: Serious Negotiation
ranges.summary: High-ranking delegation with real authority to discuss substantive terms arrives; Sultan shows genuine interest.

ranges.label: Respectful Engagement
ranges.summary: Sultan sends closest advisors with clear intent to negotiate formal surrender; demonstrates serious commitment.

ranges.label: Personal Response
ranges.summary: Sultan appears on walls himself to engage directly; honors Juan's gesture with personal acknowledgment.

ranges.label: Unprecedented Opening
ranges.summary: Sultan rides out personally under truce to negotiate face-to-face; indicates willingness to surrender immediately.

tables.title: Qaid Ibrahim's Reaction to Juan's Surrender Terms
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan has offered the Sultan clear terms: abdication and exile with 50,000 florin compensation, no forced conversions, garrison can leave in peace. Qaid Ibrahim al-Farsi hears this proposal as the Sultan's envoy and must evaluate whether to recommend acceptance or rejection.

ranges.label: Insulted
ranges.summary: Ibrahim takes terms as insulting to the Sultan's honor; returns angrily and advises rejection, viewing compensation as reducing a kingdom to a business transaction.

ranges.label: Deeply Skeptical
ranges.summary: Doubts Juan's sincerity; reports terms neutrally but recommends caution and refusal; fears hidden clauses or betrayal.

ranges.label: Conflicted
ranges.summary: Recognizes pragmatism but fears Sultan's pride and court reaction; gives neutral report without strong recommendation.

ranges.label: Thoughtfully Receptive
ranges.summary: Sees generosity in offer; reports fairly without pushing strongly for acceptance or rejection; lets Sultan decide.

ranges.label: Impressed
ranges.summary: Acknowledges unprecedented generosity of terms; reports positively to Sultan; suggests serious consideration.

ranges.label: Strongly Supportive
ranges.summary: Believes terms should be accepted; will advocate actively to Sultan for surrender; emphasizes mercy aspect.

ranges.label: Deeply Moved
ranges.summary: Profoundly affected by Juan's offer; becomes passionate advocate for acceptance; will push Sultan hard toward surrender.

ranges.label: Converted Advocate
ranges.summary: Completely convinced of necessity to accept; pledges to persuade Sultan personally; may help overcome court resistance.

tables.title: Sultan Yusuf IV's Actual Decision on Surrender Terms
tables.context: Diplomacy — Qaid Ibrahim has returned from Juan's camp insulted and recommending rejection. Now Sultan Yusuf must decide whether to accept the generous terms (50,000 florins, dignified exile, population spared starvation) or reject them and continue the siege despite mathematical inevitability of defeat.

ranges.label: Furious Rejection
ranges.summary: Sends formal defiant response; rallies city for total resistance; ignites religious fervor for fighting to the end.

ranges.label: Dignified Refusal
ranges.summary: Polite but firm rejection; accepts that war will continue until starvation or total defeat; prepares garrison psychologically.

ranges.label: Silent Defiance
ranges.summary: Makes no response at all; lets Ibrahim's angry reaction stand as answer; retreats into paralysis and avoids decision.

ranges.label: Prolonged Deliberation
ranges.summary: Internal debates rage for days or weeks with no decision; court factions argue endlessly; Sultan paralyzed by indecision.

ranges.label: Cautious Counter-Offer
ranges.summary: Sends different envoy with modified terms or counter-proposals; seeks better financial settlement or territorial concessions.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Consideration
ranges.summary: Privately inclined to accept but needs better framing or additional assurances; seeks compromise that preserves some dignity.

ranges.label: Split Decision
