ranges.summary: Sultan personally wants to accept but court and nobles block him; internal political crisis prevents surrender decision.

ranges.label: Reluctant Acceptance
ranges.summary: Agrees to terms despite significant internal opposition; yields to mathematical reality but with visible reluctance.

ranges.label: Pragmatic Surrender
ranges.summary: Accepts quickly, recognizing inevitable mathematics; ends paralysis through decisive action to spare population.

tables.title: Sortie Opening Phase Success
tables.context: Military — Garrison commanders launch desperate unauthorized sortie on October 16 without full Sultan approval, hoping to disrupt Castilian operations or prove their strength. The sortie was detected before leaving the gates, losing the element of surprise completely. This table determines how the initial combat develops.

ranges.label: Suicide Charge Broken
ranges.summary: Shattered before reaching earthworks; approximately 800+ Granada casualties with minimal Castilian losses; complete rout.

ranges.label: Brave But Futile
ranges.summary: Reaches earthworks but is quickly repulsed; 500-600 Granada casualties versus 50-100 Castilian; desperate but unsuccessful.

ranges.label: Desperate Fighting
ranges.summary: Brief fierce combat at ramparts; 400-500 Granada casualties versus 100-200 Castilian; neither side gains clear advantage.

ranges.label: Penetration Attempt
ranges.summary: Breaches through at one point before Castilian counterattack restores line; 350-450 Granada casualties versus 150-250 Castilian.

ranges.label: Serious Threat
ranges.summary: Multiple breaches in Castilian defenses; hard fighting for several hours; 300-400 Granada casualties versus 250-400 Castilian.

ranges.label: Dangerous Assault
ranges.summary: Nearly overruns section of camp; reaches supply areas; 250-350 Granada casualties versus 400-600 Castilian before being pushed back.

ranges.label: Critical Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Penetrates deeply toward command area; threatens Juan's position; 200-300 Granada casualties versus 600-800+ Castilian in vicious fighting.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Breach
ranges.summary: Elite assassination team breaks through defenses; Juan's personal safety directly threatened; battle becomes desperate close-quarters combat.

tables.title: Granada's Response to Post-Sortie Crisis
tables.context: Intrigue — The catastrophic sortie failure has devastated Granada's garrison, killing 800+ soldiers and shattering morale. The October planting season has been completely missed, making the 1433 harvest impossible. Food stores now face critical depletion within 2-4 months. The Sultan's paralysis and incompetence are fully exposed. Some faction must act or Granada will face starvation.

ranges.label: Deepening Paralysis
ranges.summary: Sultan retreats into denial; city descends into despair; no action taken; continued silent watching as doom approaches.

ranges.label: Religious Radicalization
ranges.summary: Hardline imams seize narrative and declare martyrdom over surrender; mobilize population for total resistance to the end.

ranges.label: Desperate Second Sortie
ranges.summary: Another unauthorized attack by garrison units refusing to accept waiting for starvation; likely as futile as the first.

ranges.label: Secret Peace Faction
ranges.summary: Nobles and merchants send covert envoys to Juan without Sultan's knowledge; attempt private negotiations bypassing court.

ranges.label: Internal Coup
ranges.summary: Pragmatic faction overthrows Sultan to negotiate surrender; eliminates paralyzed leader to prevent starvation.

ranges.label: Sultan Finally Acts
ranges.summary: Yusuf sends formal envoys after sortie disaster shocks him into reality; begins serious negotiations for terms.

ranges.label: Mass Desertion Begins
ranges.summary: Garrison soldiers begin fleeing to Castilian lines in small groups; see no hope and seek mercy from enemy.

ranges.label: Popular Uprising
ranges.summary: Citizens riot demanding surrender; force Sultan's hand through popular pressure; water riots or bread riots force negotiation.

ranges.label: Unconditional Surrender
ranges.summary: Sultan offers complete capitulation on all of Juan's terms; ends paralysis decisively; sends Vizier Ahmad with formal surrender document.

tables.title: Response of Outlying Territories to Granada's Surrender
tables.context: Military/Diplomacy — After Sultan Yusuf IV's surrender of Granada, Juan must determine how remaining fortified territories (especially Almería) will respond to news of the capital's fall and the Sultan's flight.

ranges.label: Significant Resistance
ranges.summary: Almería's garrison commander refuses initial surrender demand and declares he doesn't recognize the Sultan's authority. Requires demonstration of force and 2-3 weeks of negotiation before eventually surrendering; minor casualties possible (50-100 total). Other territories follow Almería's lead in delaying.

ranges.label: Prolonged Negotiation
ranges.summary: Almería commander is skeptical and demands additional guarantees, sending representatives to Granada to verify Sultan's status. 2-3 weeks of diplomatic back-and-forth before honorable surrender without violence. Some watchtowers hold out waiting for Almería's decision.

ranges.label: Cautious Compliance
ranges.summary: Most territories surrender within 2 weeks; Almería requests clarification but complies. One or two remote watchtowers don't receive message promptly and require follow-up delegation in early December. Surrenders are orderly but reluctant. Process complete by early December.

ranges.label: Smooth Surrender
ranges.summary: All major territories surrender within 10 days; Almería's commander recognizes futility immediately. Mixed delegations well-received; Muslim qadis' presence crucial to legitimacy. Minor fortresses and watchtowers follow without incident; 200-300 garrison troops request conversion and employment.

ranges.label: Very Smooth Transition
ranges.summary: Territories surrender rapidly within one week; Almería's garrison sends delegation to Granada pledging loyalty. Widespread conversions among garrison troops (400-500 men); Muslim officials praise Juan's mercy. Even stubborn holdouts moved by reports of honorable treatment.

ranges.label: Exemplary Conduct
ranges.summary: All territories surrender within one week in formal ceremonies. Mass conversions (600-800 garrison troops). Muslim scholars praise Juan's justice throughout Granada; several watchtower commanders journey personally to swear fealty. Becomes model referenced in future conquests.

ranges.label: Remarkable Diplomatic Triumph
ranges.summary: Territories compete to surrender first and most honorably; Almería sends advance delegation expressing gratitude for terms. Mass conversions (600-800 troops); Muslim scholars write of Juan's mercy; several wealthy Muslim merchants offer loans to prevent famine. Sets precedent resonating for decades.

tables.title: Journey from Granada to Toledo
tables.context: Travel — Juan departs Granada with 100-man guard for the 9-day journey to Toledo to reunite with Isabel, who has waited through his 18-month absence. November weather and road conditions may complicate the journey.

ranges.label: Serious Complications
ranges.summary: Severe winter storm on days 3-4 forces 2-3 day shelter in roadside monastery; minor injuries from cold exposure (3-4 guards with frostbite). Arrival delayed to November 28-29. Alternatively, serious illness strikes Juan from campaign exhaustion, requiring extended rest stops.

ranges.label: Significant Delays
ranges.summary: Heavy rain and muddy roads slow progress; river crossing becomes dangerous, requiring 1-2 day wait for waters to recede. One full day lost to weather; arrival delayed to November 26-27. Guard exhausted but no casualties. Alternatively, encounter large group of displaced refugees requiring assistance (1-2 day delay).

ranges.label: Minor Complications
ranges.summary: Unseasonable cold but manageable; roads muddy in sections slowing pace. One horse goes lame requiring replacement. Arrive November 25-26 (1 day late). Minor encounter with desperate bandits easily dispersed; no casualties.

ranges.label: Routine Journey
ranges.summary: Weather cool but clear; roads in reasonable condition. Steady pace maintained; arrive November 25 as predicted. No incidents of note; guard performs professionally and uneventfully.

ranges.label: Smooth Journey
ranges.summary: Good weather holds; roads surprisingly good for November. Make excellent time; arrive November 24 (one day early). Villages along route celebrate as Juan passes; news of Granada's fall received with joy.

ranges.label: Very Smooth Journey
ranges.summary: Exceptional November weather; clear skies and crisp conditions. Roads dry and firm; arrive November 23 (two days early). Enthusiastic welcomes in every town; local nobles ride out to congratulate. Gifts of food and wine from grateful villages.

ranges.label: Triumphant Progress
ranges.summary: Perfect traveling weather; crowds line roads shouting 'The Conqueror of Granada!'; church bells ring at every town. Arrive November 22 (three days early) with swelling entourage. Several minor nobles request audience to swear loyalty.

ranges.label: Remarkable Homecoming
ranges.summary: Journey becomes spontaneous victory procession; every village erupts in celebration; crowds throw flowers. Priests bless Juan from church steps; veterans of campaign join escort. Arrive November 21 (four days early) to massive Toledo celebration. Isabel waiting at cathedral steps; city declares impromptu festival.

tables.title: Upstream Ford Crossing and Journey Continuation
tables.context: Travel — After forced delay at monastery due to flooded main ford, Juan's column attempts safer upstream crossing on November 22 before completing the journey to Toledo.

ranges.label: Serious Complications
ranges.summary: Upstream ford also flooded; requires even longer detour adding 2+ days. More guards fall ill (4-5 men with fever); forced to leave them at another monastery. Arrive Toledo December 2-3 significantly delayed. Alternatively, accident at crossing (horse injury, supply loss).

ranges.label: Further Delays
ranges.summary: Upstream crossing difficult but passable; takes most of day to get everyone across safely. One more day lost to careful crossing; weather turns cold with light snow beginning. Arrive Toledo November 29-30; two more guards develop mild illness.

ranges.label: Continued Struggles
ranges.summary: Crossing successful but time-consuming; weather remains poor with more rain or cold. Roads still muddy; make slow but steady progress. Arrive Toledo November 28-29; men tired but no additional casualties.

ranges.label: Manageable Crossing
ranges.summary: Upstream ford as expected—safer than main crossing. Successfully cross by afternoon of November 22; resume journey with one full day lost total. Weather cool but stable. Arrive Toledo November 27; no further complications.

ranges.label: Successful Crossing
ranges.summary: Ford much safer than anticipated; cross smoothly with no incidents and make good time after crossing. Weather improves—cold but clear. Arrive Toledo November 26; men grateful for Juan's caution and morale recovering.

ranges.label: Smooth Continuation
ranges.summary: Excellent crossing conditions; river receded more than expected. Resume normal pace; clear weather holds. Arrive Toledo November 25 (original timeline!). Despite delays, arrive exactly when predicted; men impressed by Juan's judgment.

ranges.label: Very Smooth
ranges.summary: Ford crossing easy and quick; roads improve and Juan's forces make up lost time. Weather turns pleasant—crisp and clear. Arrive Toledo November 24 (only one day late despite complications). Growing celebrations as the column approaches capital.

ranges.label: Excellent Recovery
ranges.summary: Perfect crossing conditions; push hard after crossing, making excellent time. Arrive Toledo November 23 (two days late but impressive recovery). Men energized by proximity to home; Isabel receives word of approach; story of cautious river crossing becomes example of wise leadership.

ranges.label: Remarkable Fortune
ranges.summary: Upstream ford perfect; cross in record time. Weather breaks completely—beautiful late November days. Make extraordinary time on improved roads. Arrive Toledo November 22 (incredibly, only one day late!). Men see it as divine favor for virtuous decision; story becomes parable: 'The king who chose wisdom over haste.'

tables.title: Isabel's Reaction to Renewed Marital Intimacy and Duty
tables.context: Personal/Intrigue — On the morning after their reunion evening, Juan initiates physical intimacy with Isabel, framing it as duty to produce heirs. Given Isabel's near-fatal childbirth trauma (10 months prior) and Juan's promise of 'time,' this tests her emotional resilience and acceptance of her role.

ranges.label: Profound Betrayal and Breakdown
ranges.summary: Isabel goes silent and withdraws completely, saying 'You promised me time.' Begins crying silently; refuses to look at Juan. Spends the rest of day in chapel; deep damage to trust. She'll submit to duty going forward but something breaks between them emotionally.

ranges.label: Hurt and Withdrawn
ranges.summary: Complies without resistance but without warmth; calls Juan 'Your Majesty' using formal address; gets dressed quickly and won't meet his eyes. Withdraws emotionally for several days; performs duties but the closeness from last night is gone.

ranges.label: Conflicted Compliance
ranges.summary: Participates but Juan feels her tension; afterward lies still with hand on stomach, clearly worried. States 'I hope if I am with child again, it will be easier this time' with trembling voice. Tries to hide tears; accepts duty but can't hide the fear.

ranges.label: Dutiful Acceptance with Reservation
ranges.summary: Responds without protest; afterward says 'I understand we have responsibilities.' Notes 'I wish duty and love didn't have to feel so separate.' Accepts role but mourns loss of intimacy; needs reassurance that Juan loves her as Isabel, not just values her as queen.

ranges.label: Mature but Resigned Acceptance
ranges.summary: Participates with some warmth despite visible apprehension; says 'You're right. We had our evening. Now we must do what's required.' Shows resignation to medieval reality rather than joy. Touches stomach: 'If God wills another child, I pray for strength.'

ranges.label: Understanding Acceptance
ranges.summary: Some initial tension but softens during intimacy. Afterward rests against Juan, saying 'I understand. The kingdom needs heirs' and 'I'm still afraid. But I trust you. And I trust God.' Manages genuine if nervous smile. Asks Juan to hold her. Shows mature understanding that 'Yesterday was a gift. Today is reality.'

ranges.label: Graceful Acceptance with Faith
ranges.summary: Responds with warmth despite underlying nervousness. Says 'We are king and queen, but we're also husband and wife. Both things can be true.' Takes Juan's hand and places it on her heart: 'I'm afraid. But I'm also yours.' Shows extraordinary maturity for age 16.

ranges.label: Remarkable Grace and Partnership
ranges.summary: Meets Juan with genuine warmth and intimacy. Afterward says 'Yesterday was for us. Today is for the kingdom. I understand both.' Demonstrates that 'My burden is bearing children; yours is bearing the weight of the realm. Let's carry them together.' Asks Juan to promise he'll be there when the time comes.

tables.title: Crusader Recruitment Over 21-Month Campaign
tables.context: Military — Assessing how many crusaders joined the Granada campaign between March 1431 and November 1432, accounting for recruitment success, leadership standards, and combat casualties.

ranges.label: Limited Growth - Organizational Caps Applied
ranges.summary: Commanders deliberately limited recruitment after ~800-900 total. Fray Hernando insisted on maintaining spiritual character: 'We are crusaders, not a mercenary company.' Combat casualties: ~80-120 killed/wounded over 21 months. Result: 750-850 crusaders by November 1432, with quality very high and cohesion excellent.

ranges.label: Modest Growth - Commitment Scared Many Off
ranges.summary: Steady trickle of recruits but absolute commitment requirement deterred most applicants. News spread but years-long service proposition was unattractive. Standards remained high, many rejected. Combat casualties: ~100-140 killed/wounded. Result: 900-1,200 crusaders by November 1432.

ranges.label: Moderate Growth - Balanced Recruitment
ranges.summary: Success attracted recruits, standards filtered them, commitment limited numbers. Three major waves: after Málaga (June 1431), after Loja (September 1431), after Granada surrender (November 1432). Combat casualties: ~120-160 killed/wounded. Result: 1,300-1,700 crusaders by November 1432.

ranges.label: Strong Growth - Success Overcame Hesitation
ranges.summary: News of Granada's conquest spread rapidly through Italy, France. Sacred relics' reputation grew with miraculous reports. Some families pooled resources to send younger sons. Combat casualties: ~140-180 killed/wounded. Result: 1,800-2,300 crusaders by November 1432.

ranges.label: Very Strong Growth - Crusade Fever
ranges.summary: Spectacular success created genuine crusade enthusiasm across Christendom. Italian cities sent contingents (Florence, Genoa, Venice). French knights arrived seeking glory. Commanders accepted more but maintained standards. Combat casualties: ~160-200 killed/wounded. Result: 2,400-2,900 crusaders by November 1432.

ranges.label: Exceptional Growth - Wave of Faith and Glory
ranges.summary: News reached Germany, Poland, even England. Multiple contingents from across Christendom arrived. Some commanders worried about maintaining character. Combat casualties: ~180-220 killed/wounded. Result: 3,000-3,500 crusaders by November 1432.

ranges.label: Extraordinary Growth - Crusade Becomes Legend
ranges.summary: Granada's fall triggered genuine crusade movement across Christendom. Pope's envoys actively recruiting. French and German princes sent knights. Commanders struggled to process volunteers and relaxed some standards. Combat casualties: ~200-250 killed/wounded. Result: 3,500-4,200 crusaders by November 1432.

tables.title: Basel Council Response to Castilian Positions
tables.context: Diplomacy — Determining the Council of Basel's reception and adoption of Castile's theological and political positions since the delegation's arrival in April 1432, measuring diplomatic influence and respect gained.

ranges.label: Dismissed and Ignored
ranges.summary: Castilian positions received politely but had no real influence. Major powers dominated discussions, Iberian delegation marginalized. Hussite negotiations collapsed. Pope-Council split became complete schism. Request that Castile choose a side. No adoption of Castilian positions on any issue.

ranges.label: Minimal Influence
ranges.summary: Castilian delegation heard respectfully but positions not adopted. Basel politics dominated by factional conflict. Moderates couldn't bridge divide. Hussite negotiations stalled. Correspondence polite but notes limited impact. Request for clarification on military commitments. Perhaps one minor suggestion incorporated.

ranges.label: Limited But Respectful Engagement
ranges.summary: Castilian positions noted and referenced in debates. Bishop Alfonso's address praised for theological sophistication. But Council too divided for Castilian moderation to gain traction. Hussite negotiations delicate. Request for continued engagement and possible military support. Castile seen as honest but relatively powerless broker.

ranges.label: Moderate Influence - Respected Voice
ranges.summary: Castilian delegation gained respect as principled moderate faction. Cardinal Cesarini and moderates cite Castilian positions approvingly. Some Castilian arguments incorporated into Council decrees on reform. Hussite negotiations progressing partially due to Castilian example. Correspondence warm with appreciation for balanced approach. Request for concrete details on Constantinople assistance now Granada complete. Castile asked to mediate between papal and conciliar factions. 2-3 Castilian positions partially adopted.

ranges.label: Significant Influence - Key Moderate Voice
ranges.summary: Castilian delegation became important moderate faction bridging extremes. Cardinal Cesarini privately consults Fray Hernando on difficult issues. Castilian positions on reform cited frequently. Hussite negotiations advanced significantly, some Articles partially resolved. Urgent request for Constantinople military support with specific Byzantine embassy. Request that Juan II personally attend Basel. 3-5 Castilian positions substantially adopted.

ranges.label: Major Influence - Castile as Example
ranges.summary: 'The kingdom that won its crusade' became rallying cry for reform faction. Castilian model of accountability with church oversight adopted as reform template. Fray Hernando's arguments cited in official documents. Hussite negotiations breakthrough: moderate Articles accepted. Pope-Council relations stabilized due to moderate voices. Multiple requests: Constantinople support, possible Bohemia mission, Juan II's personal attendance. 5-7 Castilian positions substantially incorporated. Basel offers Juan II 'Defender of the Faith' title.

ranges.label: Extraordinary Influence - Castilian Model Adopted
ranges.summary: Castile's balanced approach became Council's official position on papal-conciliar relations. Bishop Alfonso's framework adopted for Hussite resolution. Breakthrough in negotiations: Prague Compactata signed based partly on Castilian positions. Pope and Council reached compromise influenced by Castilian mediation. Formal invitation for Juan II as honored guest and speaker. Request for military assistance to Constantinople with Castilian command. 7-10 Castilian positions form core of Council reform agenda.

ranges.label: Transformative Influence - Castilian Renaissance
ranges.summary: Castile's success triggered fundamental rethinking of church reform and crusading. Council united around Castilian model of strong authority with accountability. Hussite conflict resolved through Prague Compactata based substantially on Castilian positions. Pope-Council reconciliation achieved with Castilian delegation as key mediators. Cardinal Cesarini proposes Juan II as supreme commander of united Christian forces. Castilian positions form foundation of entire reform program. Discussion of Juan II as possible future Holy Roman Emperor candidate.

tables.title: Royal Military Academy Nine-Month Progress Assessment
tables.context: Military — Evaluating the Royal Military Academy's success in synthesizing European military knowledge and training officers over 9 months (March-November 1432) with world-class faculty including János Hunyadi and Francesco Sforza.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure - Collapsed
ranges.summary: Irreconcilable conflicts between faculty nationalities caused complete breakdown. Hunyadi and Sforza had major falling out over doctrine. Language barriers proved insurmountable. Students learned contradictory lessons. Several faculty quit in frustration. No coherent doctrine produced. Waste of 32,500 florins investment. Institution needs complete restructuring or abandonment.

ranges.label: Serious Problems - Barely Functional
ranges.summary: Significant faculty conflicts slowed progress substantially. Language barriers proved major obstacle to communication. Competing doctrines never properly synthesized. Students received fragmented education from multiple incompatible sources. Partial tactical manual produced but incoherent. Perhaps 5-8 adequately trained officers. Needs major reforms to be useful.

ranges.label: Disappointing Results - Underperforming
ranges.summary: Faculty eventually found working rhythm but very slowly. Significant time lost to organizational conflicts. Modest synthesis achieved but limited depth. Students received inconsistent education. Some useful tactics documented. Perhaps 10 adequately trained junior officers. Foundation exists but shaky. Not clearly worth the investment yet.

ranges.label: Solid Foundation - Meeting Expectations
ranges.summary: After initial friction, experts found workable collaboration. János Hunyadi emerged as respected coordinator for anti-Ottoman doctrine. Practical synthesis: not revolutionary but genuinely useful. Combined Hungarian mobility, German shock, Italian engineering, Spanish frontier experience. 15 well-trained junior officers ready for command. Comprehensive tactical manual produced covering cavalry, infantry, artillery integration. Students grasp combined-arms principles. Ongoing curriculum established. Foundation for permanent officer corps proved viable.

ranges.label: Strong Performance - Exceeding Expectations
ranges.summary: Faculty collaboration excellent after brief adjustment. Hunyadi's leadership effectively unified diverse experts. High-quality synthesis of European military knowledge. Anti-Ottoman doctrine particularly well developed. 15 excellently trained junior officers plus 30-40 additional students enrolled mid-year. Detailed tactical manuals for multiple scenarios. Students conducting independent tactical analysis. Some minor innovations beyond mere synthesis. Investment clearly justified.

ranges.label: Excellent Results - Major Success
ranges.summary: Faculty formed genuine collaborative community with genuine breakthrough synthesis. Hungarian-Italian-German-French-Spanish integration produced innovative anti-Ottoman tactics. 15 outstanding junior officers plus 40 more in training. Comprehensive doctrine covering cavalry, infantry, artillery, logistics, intelligence, siege warfare. Students demonstrating advanced understanding. Several innovations tested in training. Foreign kingdoms showing interest. Academy becoming renowned across Europe.

ranges.label: Extraordinary Achievement - Revolutionary
ranges.summary: Faculty collaboration produced genuine innovations beyond documentation of existing tactics. Comprehensive anti-Ottoman warfare doctrine synthesized from all traditions. Tactical breakthroughs in combined-arms coordination. 15 brilliant junior officers plus 50 more in advanced training. Complete curriculum from strategic to tactical levels. Student treatises gaining European attention. Several innovations adopted by Castilian forces. Foreign military observers requesting study. Hunyadi: 'Finest military education institution in Christendom.'

ranges.label: Transformative Success - Historic Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Academy achieved seemingly impossible: true European military synthesis. Revolutionary anti-Ottoman doctrine combining best Christian traditions. Tactical innovations that will change European warfare. 15 exceptionally trained officers already commanding units plus 60 in advanced training. Complete military education system from basic to advanced. Students developing original strategic thinking, not just learning doctrine. Foreign kingdoms sending students and paying for military knowledge. Doctrine adopted across Christendom. Academy establishing branches in other cities. Permanent transformation of Castilian military power.

tables.title: Sierra Nevada Fortress Commanders' Response to Summons
tables.context: Military/Diplomacy — Determining how the remaining Muslim fortress commanders in the Sierra Nevada respond to Don García's invitation to come to Granada on March 5th, 1433, to swear fealty and receive position confirmations under Christian rule.
tables.outcome_label: Significant Influence - Mostly Compliant With Some Caution

ranges.label: Unified Defiance
ranges.summary: All eight commanders refuse summons and declare resistance to the death. Have spent winter fortifying positions and stockpiling supplies. Religious/honor motivations dominate rational calculation. Don García must reduce fortresses by force requiring 2-4 months of siege operations with 50-150 Christian casualties. Cost: 15,000-25,000 florins. May delay Te Deum or proceed with sieges afterward.

ranges.label: Mixed Response - Significant Resistance
ranges.summary: 5 commanders accept summons and come to Granada. 3 commanders refuse (two citing religious reasons, one claiming fortress too remote). Those who refuse are well-supplied hardliners prepared for siege. Those who accept provide intelligence. Partial success but 1-2 month campaign still required. Moderate casualties: 30-80 troops. Cost: 8,000-15,000 florins. Can likely complete before Te Deum.

ranges.label: Mostly Compliant - Minor Resistance
ranges.summary: 6-7 commanders accept summons and travel to Granada. 1-2 commanders don't respond initially (communication issues or reluctance). Don García sends second delegation with ultimatum. Holdouts either comply after second contact or prove to be minor fortresses that can be bypassed. Minimal military action required, perhaps one small fortress. Light casualties: 10-20 troops if any. Cost: 2,000-5,000 florins. Resolved well before Te Deum.

ranges.label: Full Compliance - Cautious
ranges.summary: All eight commanders accept summons and arrive in Granada between late February and early March 1433. Cautious and wary but recognize reality of Christian victory. Some bring families as gesture of good faith. Negotiations proceed carefully but successfully. All swear fealty by mid-March. Most retain positions under Christian supervision. Some accept compensation and depart. No military action required. Major success demonstrating legitimacy of Christian governance.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Compliance
ranges.summary: All eight commanders eagerly accept summons. Several arrive early before March 5th assembly. Pragmatic calculation: better to cooperate and retain authority than lose everything. Some bring valuable intelligence or offer service. A few request baptism or show interest in conversion. Smooth integration into governance structure. Don García uses as examples to other Muslim populations. Strengthens Christian authority significantly. No military action needed.

ranges.label: Proactive Submission
ranges.summary: Commanders don't wait for March assembly but begin arriving January/February on own initiative. Some send advance messages pledging loyalty. Competition among commanders to be first demonstrates genuine loyalty-seeking. Bring detailed intelligence about territories. Offer concrete assistance with tax collection, maintaining order, converting mosques. Several express interest in conversion (genuine or calculated). Don García uses as model for governance.

ranges.label: Unexpected Bonus
ranges.summary: Not only do all commanders submit eagerly but they bring additional Muslim nobles from their territories. Mass submission ceremony becomes major political event. Several convert to Christianity publicly. Offer to serve as intermediaries for Christian-Muslim relations. Provide detailed intelligence about resistance cells. One fortress commander particularly impressive—Juan may grant noble title. Propaganda windfall. Sets positive precedent for Muslim integration.

tables.title: Isabel's Pregnancy Conception Outcome
tables.context: Personal — Determining whether Queen Isabel becomes pregnant following her renewed intimate relations with King Juan II in late November 1432, accounting for her traumatic childbirth 10 months earlier, age (16-17), recovery status, and medical complications.

ranges.label: No Conception
ranges.summary: Internal damage from traumatic birth affecting fertility more than apparent. Nursing Catalina suppressing ovulation. Psychological anxiety affecting cycles. Simply normal variance—not every cycle results in conception. May take 6-12 months of trying before conception occurs. Physicians' 'very risky' warning was more serious than realized.

ranges.label: Delayed Conception
ranges.summary: Conceives within 2-4 months (February-April 1433). Body needed more recovery time than physicians realized. Early attempts unsuccessful due to nursing and stress. Once those factors diminish, natural fertility returns. Pregnancy confirmed spring 1433. Child born late 1433 or early 1434.

ranges.label: Conception Within 1-2 Months
ranges.summary: Conceives in December 1432 or January 1433. Body recovered well despite trauma despite trauma. Nursing not significantly suppressing fertility. Age and proven fertility overcome complications. Pregnancy confirmed by late February 1433. Child born autumn 1433.

ranges.label: Immediate Conception
ranges.summary: Conceives in late November/early December 1432. Optimal timing with ovulation cycle. Body fully recovered and fertility strong. Youth and health overcome previous complications. Pregnancy confirmed by late January 1433. Child born late summer/early autumn 1433.

ranges.label: Conception With Complications Ahead
ranges.summary: Conceives within 1-2 months. Initial pregnancy proceeds normally. However, internal damage creates risks: potential miscarriage (15-20% in first trimester), placental positioning issues possible, labor complications likely to recur. Will require careful medical monitoring. Physicians' warnings prove prescient.

ranges.label: Twins Conceived
ranges.summary: Fraternal twins conceived (occurs naturally ~1 in 80 births). Extremely dangerous given Isabel's medical history. Medieval survival rate for mother with twins after traumatic first birth: 50-60%. Physicians will be very concerned when discovered. Major medical crisis ahead. But if successful: solves succession dramatically.

tables.title: Ducal Response to Tax Ultimatum
tables.context: Intrigue — Two major Castilian nobles (Duke of Arévalo and Duke of Medina Sidonia) have received royal ultimatums from Crown Marshals: pay outstanding taxes within two months or be declared in rebellion. Juan rolled to determine their response.

ranges.label: Full Compliance
ranges.summary: The dukes pay all back taxes in full, appear in Toledo to personally explain delays, and acknowledge crown authority with possible additional gifts to demonstrate loyalty. They recognize the overwhelming strength of the crown's position.

ranges.label: Grudging Compliance with Conditions
ranges.summary: The dukes pay most or all of back taxes but request private audience rather than public appearance and ask for payment timeline (installments) rather than lump sum. They include letters explaining misunderstandings or administrative errors, complying but attempting to preserve dignity and negotiate terms.

ranges.label: Partial Compliance, Negotiation Attempt
ranges.summary: The dukes pay 50-75% of back taxes, offer to discuss remaining amounts, cite financial difficulties and propose payment timelines, and request Juan visit them rather than traveling to Toledo. They test royal boundaries on enforcement flexibility.

ranges.label: Defiance Without Open Rebellion
ranges.summary: The dukes refuse to pay or appear, send letters disputing the crown's authority to make such demands, claim taxes were already paid or don't apply to them, and don't raise armies but don't submit. They wait to see if Juan will actually enforce the ultimatum.

ranges.label: Open Defiance and Rebellion
ranges.summary: The dukes refuse all demands, raise troops defensively, send letters to other nobles seeking support for coalition resistance, and directly challenge royal authority. This requires military response from the crown.

tables.title: Alfonso's Response to Inheritance Timing Proposal
tables.context: Diplomacy — King Alfonso of Aragón considers whether to formalize the succession arrangement (making him Juan's heir if no son) immediately or wait until after the Rome mission to assess papal response on Naples support.
tables.outcome_label: Suggests Waiting with Clear Practical Reasoning

ranges.label: Wants to Formalize NOW
ranges.summary: Spiritual/emotional response overrides political caution. Alfonso sees the moment as sacred and doesn't want to lose it by waiting. Argues that when God shows you a glimpse of His kingdom, you don't ask Him to wait while you consult advisors.

ranges.label: Suggests Waiting but Clearly Torn
ranges.summary: Appreciates the proposal but worries Juan will doubt his commitment. Tries to explain both his desire to commit AND his political reasoning for patience, visibly wrestling with the conflict.

ranges.label: Suggests Waiting with Clear Practical Reasoning
ranges.summary: Appreciates being asked, explains political wisdom of sequencing. Proposes waiting until after Rome to understand papal response on Naples, arguing the order matters for both courts' acceptance and nobles' perception.

ranges.label: Defers to Juan's Judgment
ranges.summary: Trusts Juan's discernment and will follow his lead, having seen wisdom in his recent decisions beyond his years.

ranges.label: Proposes Creative Middle Path
ranges.summary: Suggests private sealed document now with minimal witnesses, delaying public formalization until after Rome. Balances immediate emotional commitment with strategic political timing.

tables.title: Response to Juan's Iberian Unity Vision
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan addresses the assembled Iberian monarchs (João of Portugal, Alfonso of Aragón, Infante Juan and Enrique of Navarre), proposing regular meetings and closer cooperation between their kingdoms based on the unity that conquered Granada.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Embrace
ranges.summary: João leads response warmly, all monarchs follow with genuine excitement. Immediate agreement to meet annually, formalize cooperation framework, create rotating councils. The moment crystallizes into shared commitment that transcends ceremony.

ranges.label: Warm but Measured
ranges.summary: Affirmation of the historic moment with appreciation for the vision, but practical reservations about frequency and formality. Support for the spirit without concrete commitments beyond vague promises.

ranges.label: Polite Agreement with Reservations
ranges.summary: Toast the sentiment and acknowledge historic significance, but one or two voices (perhaps advisors) note practical difficulties. Kings supportive but making no firm promises about future meetings.

ranges.label: Cool Reception
ranges.summary: Polite acknowledgment that kingdoms have always had separate interests. Someone notes practical difficulties. The unified feeling fractures slightly though no direct rejection occurs.

ranges.label: Awkward Moment
ranges.summary: Someone misreads Juan's intent as claiming leadership over Iberia. Brief tension before smoothing over, but the unified feeling is damaged and trust becomes strained.

tables.title: Morocco Delegation Six-Month Mission Outcome
tables.context: Espionage/Trade — Commander Martín de Alcalá and Fernando lead a delegation of 25 converted Muslim soldiers on a six-month intelligence and trade mission to establish permanent presence in Morocco, gather political intelligence about local power structures, and initiate trade networks. Roll determines overall mission success.

ranges.label: Catastrophic Failure
ranges.summary: Multiple delegates killed or imprisoned. One or two defected under pressure and revealed mission details. Freed prisoners testified they were 'apostates.' No trade established. Moroccan cities now actively hostile to Castile. 2-3 survivors fled back to Málaga with horror stories.

ranges.label: Significant Failure
ranges.summary: Hostile reception in 2 of 3 target cities. Several imprisoned or expelled, one killed in Salé. Religious authorities demanded conversion renunciation. Minimal intelligence gained. No trade relationships. 10-12 survivors returned, mission largely failed.

ranges.label: Partial Success/Mixed Results
ranges.summary: Tangier moderately receptive, established merchant presence. Tétouan hostile - delegates expelled. Salé dangerously uncertain with 2 delegates imprisoned then released. Some basic intelligence gathered about local power structures. Limited trade beginning. 15-18 delegates survived.

ranges.label: Moderate Success
ranges.summary: Established presence in Tangier and Tétouan (2 of 3 cities). Local merchants cautiously receptive to trade. Commander Martín's reputation and freed prisoners' testimony opened doors. Basic intelligence network functioning with reports on local governance and Marinid weakness confirmed. Small but growing trade in leather/wool for timber/iron. 20-22 delegates operating safely. Salé remains too hostile to approach.

ranges.label: Good Success
ranges.summary: Presence established in all three target cities. Commander Martín's 'honorable enemy' reputation from Granada preceded him. Freed prisoners' gratitude created goodwill. Trade networks forming, solid intelligence gathered on Marinid weakness and local governance structures. 23-24 delegates operating safely. Foundation laid for permanent presence.

ranges.label: Exceptional Success
ranges.summary: Warmly received in multiple cities beyond initial three targets. Trade flourishing with Castilian goods flowing through new networks. Detailed intelligence on political factions and power structures. Two local governors requested direct meetings with Juan. Secret correspondence established with major merchant houses. All 25 delegates safe. Request for additional personnel to expand operations.

tables.title: Random Complication on Eve of Te Deum
tables.context: Personal/Religion — The night before the Te Deum ceremony, a theological and political complication arises requiring Juan's immediate decision that affects the ceremony's meaning and precedent-setting implications.

ranges.label: Spiritual Crisis
ranges.summary: Vivid nightmare/vision of standing before God's throne, questioned about serving ambition rather than family. Wake in cold sweat wrestling with whether the four-month Rome absence honors God or serves pride.

ranges.label: Physical Illness
ranges.summary: Wake with severe fever and chills. Must decide: postpone ceremony (disappointing assembled kings) or push through while clearly unwell with risk of collapse during sacred moment.

ranges.label: Urgent Message from Toledo
ranges.summary: Fast courier arrives with message from Álvaro: Isabel showing pregnancy complications with bleeding. Not life-threatening yet but worrying. She insists you not return, but Álvaro thought you should know before ceremony begins.

ranges.label: Diplomatic Crisis
ranges.summary: Late night: a drunk Portuguese advisor insulted Aragonese delegation, near brawl prevented. Both sides now demanding apologies. Carefully built unity threatens to crack before ceremony even begins.

ranges.label: Crusader Morale Problem
ranges.summary: Andrea Vescovi, first crusader sworn, came to Captain Fernán in tears having profound doubts about taking Granada lands. 'We crusaded for Christ, not wealth.' Others may feel same. Potential morale issue before Rome journey.

ranges.label: Sacred Relic Security Breach
ranges.summary: Morning inspection reveals True Cross reliquary lock damaged with evidence of attempted opening overnight. Nothing stolen but sacred object violated. Security breach or attempted theft must be investigated immediately.

ranges.label: Commander Yahya's Family Crisis
ranges.summary: Commander Yahya ibn Nasir appears at dawn desperate. His family pressured by other Muslims to leave Granada after learning of his conversion. Calls him traitor. Begs protection before ceremony begins in hours.

ranges.label: Personal Doubts About Priorities
ranges.summary: Dream of Catalina grown, asking 'Why did Papa leave?' Crushing wave of doubt about four-month absence during her early childhood. These months will be lost forever, her infant memories will not include father.

ranges.label: Weather Catastrophe
ranges.summary: Massive overnight storm damaged cathedral roof with water pouring in. Ceremony technically possible but undignified. Must decide: proceed in damaged cathedral, postpone for repairs (days?), or relocate to less symbolic location.

ranges.label: Unexpected Visitor Request
ranges.summary: Sultan Muhammad IX (exiled former Granada ruler) appeared at gates overnight requesting private audience before ceremony. Wants 'one last conversation.' Request is ambiguous - could be genuine or trap.

ranges.label: Theological Challenge
ranges.summary: Archbishop brings urgent concern: Infante Juan (redeemed rebel) requested to carry the True Cross in procession as penance. Powerful redemptive symbolism, but some clergy object that former rebels shouldn't touch holiest relic. Sets precedent. Decision needed immediately before ceremony.

ranges.label: Assassination Warning
ranges.summary: Don García received intelligence overnight of rumored assassination plot during ceremony. Source uncertain, details vague. Decision needed: tighten security and risk insulting guest kings, or proceed normally and risk danger?

tables.title: Málaga to Rome Sea Voyage
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Juan embarks from Málaga with 800 crusaders, sacred relics (True Cross fragment and Santiago's bone), crusade treasury (~315,500 florins), and supplies for the Mediterranean crossing to Rome. The journey will take 9-15 days depending on weather and fortune.

ranges.label: CATASTROPHIC STORM
ranges.summary: Major Mediterranean storm hits mid-voyage, scattering 1-2 ships from fleet. Arrival delayed 10-12 days, with 8-15 men lost overboard and 30-40 seriously injured. Some equipment/supplies damaged though treasury and relics heavily protected.

ranges.label: SEVERE WEATHER
ranges.summary: Heavy storms force fleet to shelter at Sardinia or Corsica for 4-6 days. 2-4 men lost overboard, 10-15 injured, horses panic and sustain injuries. Arrival delayed 7-9 days, significantly disrupting Rome schedule.

ranges.label: BARBARY CORSAIR ENCOUNTER
ranges.summary: 3-4 corsair galleys attempt intercept but flee when recognizing superior Castilian strength. Brief skirmish with 1-3 casualties from crossbow exchange. Arrival delayed 1-2 days due to evasive maneuvering, but creates dramatic story for Rome.

ranges.label: DIFFICULT PASSAGE
ranges.summary: Contrary winds and choppy seas plague entire voyage. Many crusaders, including hardened veterans, become violently seasick. Fleet forced to tack repeatedly, taking inefficient route. Arrive 3-5 days late with no casualties but significantly affected morale—men eager for solid ground.

ranges.label: ADEQUATE JOURNEY
ranges.summary: Normal Mediterranean spring sailing with moderate winds and rough patches. Most crusaders manage seasickness. Fleet stops briefly at Sardinia/Corsica for supplies. Arrive 1-2 days late; minor incident of one broken leg and distressed horses, overall unremarkable passage.

ranges.label: GOOD SAILING
ranges.summary: Favorable winds for most of journey with experienced Genoese captains pleased with conditions. Crusaders handle seasickness well, adjusting quickly. Dolphins accompany fleet, seen as good omen. Arrive on schedule (9-10 days) with no casualties and intact supplies, morale high.

ranges.label: EXCELLENT VOYAGE
ranges.summary: Perfect Mediterranean spring weather with strong favorable winds and smooth seas. Arrival 1-2 days early. Many crusaders enjoy voyage and see it as adventure; Giovanni Rossi declares it proof of God's blessing. Ships make impressive formal arrival in formation.

ranges.label: REMARKABLE JOURNEY
ranges.summary: Exceptional sailing conditions throughout entire voyage. Genoese captains declare it 'best crossing in years.' Arrive 2-3 days early. Day 5 features massive dolphin pod escorting fleet for hours, interpreted as divine sign. Evening deck prayers become powerful bonding experience; crew arrives fresh and eager.

ranges.label: EXTRAORDINARY - DIVINE FAVOR
ranges.summary: Perfect weather entire voyage, arrival 3 days early. Day 4 dolphins escort fleet; Day 6 a white dove lands on ship's mast for hours, then flies toward Rome. Chaplains lead increasingly fervent prayers; even hardened Genoese sailors moved. Word reaches Rome through fishing boats about miraculous signs, creating significant anticipation.

ranges.label: MIRACULOUS
ranges.summary: All extraordinary signs present plus Day 7 shows exceptionally bright stars with crusaders reporting dreams of Santiago. Day 8 arrival at Ostia harbor coincides with church bells spontaneously ringing with no human involvement. Small crowds gather; Pope Eugenius IV hears reports within hours, setting extraordinary tone for entire visit.

ranges.label: ACTS OF GOD
ranges.summary: Journey becomes subject of future chronicles featuring perfect weather, dolphins, dove, dreams, spontaneous bells plus mysterious white-robed figure reported at ship's prow. Word spreads through Rome like wildfire; Pope Eugenius personally comes to greet Juan at Ostia. Thousands line route to St. Peter's; entire arrival becomes legendary proof of divine favor.

tables.title: Ostia to Rome March
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Juan leads 800 crusaders, the Guardian Company with sacred relics, and crusade treasury on the 15-mile march from Ostia to Rome (April 24, 1433). The city is politically divided between papal supporters and Colonna faction; the march's reception will reflect these tensions and set tone for diplomatic visit.

ranges.label: COLONNA AMBUSH ATTEMPT
ranges.summary: Colonna family launches 200+ armed retainers to block road, unaware of crusader force size. Brief violent clash kills 12-18 crusaders and 30-40 wounded, routing 40-60 Colonna fighters. Creates immediate crisis before reaching Rome; Pope Eugenius must choose between supporting Juan or avoiding civil war. Arrival becomes controversial rather than triumphant.

ranges.label: HOSTILE MOB CONFRONTATION
ranges.summary: Pro-Colonna/anti-foreign mob (300-500 people) blocks road with stones, insults, and clubs but no organized attack. Crusaders form defensive positions; standoff lasts 2-3 hours until papal troops arrive to disperse mob. 3-6 crusaders injured; several Romans killed when violence escalates. Arrival delayed half-day; tense atmosphere for papal meeting.

ranges.label: COLD RECEPTION
ranges.summary: March proceeds without violence but Romans notably unwelcoming—streets empty with people watching from windows, shops shutter as if facing invasion. Pro-Colonna supporters glare from corners; few priests cheer. Psychological warfare is clear: 'We don't want you here.' Cardinals note poor reception, weakening papal position.

ranges.label: MIXED RECEPTION - DIVIDED CITY
ranges.summary: Clear factional divide visible: papal supporter quarters burst with cheering, flowers, people kneeling as relics pass; Colonna/Basel supporter quarters show silence, shuttered windows, occasional insults and stones from windows (no serious injuries). Cardinals watch and take notes. Arrival becomes rallying point for both factions, giving visceral sense of Rome's deep divisions.

ranges.label: CAUTIOUS BUT PEACEFUL
ranges.summary: Romans wary but not hostile; crowds gather from curiosity more than enthusiasm. People point at white tabards and whisper about Granada. Few papal supporters cheer; most watch silently. No incidents or confrontations. Dignified march with respectful but non-celebratory reception; Pope's allies relieved and Colonna family doesn't interfere.

ranges.label: CURIOUS AND RESPECTFUL
ranges.summary: Growing crowds gather to watch impressive sight of 800 crusaders in white tabards. Word spreads quickly: 'The Reconquista King carrying the True Cross.' Crowds part respectfully, cross themselves as relic cases pass. Some elderly Romans weep remembering crusade stories. Giovanni Rossi leads prayers during march; cardinals watching take positive note.

ranges.label: WARM RECEPTION FROM PAPAL FACTION
ranges.summary: Papal supporters organize formal welcome with church bells ringing as Rome approaches. Crowds of clerics, monks, and loyalists line streets throwing flowers; people kneel as True Cross passes. Chants of 'Deus Vult!' and 'Viva il Papa!' echo. Colonna quarters remain quiet with no hostility. Sets positive tone for papal audience.

ranges.label: ENTHUSIASTIC WELCOME
ranges.summary: Massive crowds (10,000+) witness arrival; news of Granada conquest with sacred relics spreads widely. Streets lined with kneeling people, reaching out to touch crusaders' tabards. Spontaneous hymn-singing. Elderly cardinals weep from windows. Pope Eugenius sends word for immediate reception. Arrival becomes major morale boost for papal faction; Basel supporters forced to reassess.

ranges.label: TRIUMPHANT ENTRY
ranges.summary: Romans give crusader's welcome with 15,000-20,000 lining route from gates to Vatican. Continuous church bells, flowers, touching of tabards. Chants of 'Christus Vincit! Christus Regnat!' Giovanni Rossi carries banner with weeping crowds. Cardinals Orsini and others personally escort through streets. Colonna stays quiet—moment too powerful to oppose. Political momentum shifts toward Pope.

ranges.label: MIRACULOUS ATMOSPHERE
ranges.summary: As gates enter Rome, bells across entire city spontaneously ring with no human prompting. White dove circles column entire march, landing on True Cross relic case. Crowds fall to knees interpreting as divine sign. Mystical Roman woman declares 'Hand of God guides him.' Pope Eugenius comes personally to greet on steps. Arrival becomes legendary moment.

ranges.label: SIGNS AND WONDERS
ranges.summary: Dawn departure from Ostia unusually brilliant with three witnesses reporting white-robed figure ahead of column (no one found). During march, blind beggar suddenly cries 'I can see!' as relics pass; witnesses verify known blindness suddenly healed. Thousands line Rome streets; Pope comes out weeping, embraces Juan saying 'God has sent you in our hour of need.' Cardinals begin shifting positions.

ranges.label: THE RECONQUISTA KING ARRIVES
ranges.summary: Everything extraordinary from 91-95 plus extraordinary light effects during presentation to Pope at St. Peter's. Emperor Sigismund's representatives witness entry and send urgent dispatches. All Rome understands something momentous is occurring. Colonna family sends quiet message accepting papal strength while Juan is present. Basel faction deeply divided.

ranges.label: ACTS OF GOD - HISTORICAL MOMENT
ranges.summary: All signs from 96-98 plus shaft of light illuminates Juan, Pope, and relics on St. Peter's steps as thousands witness. Multiple witnesses report seeing Santiago walking Rome's walls that night. Three Basel-supporting cardinals publicly renounce conciliar supremacy. Colonna patriarch seeks reconciliation. Emperor Sigismund speeds journey hearing reports. Chronicles centuries later will call it transformative moment for Church.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV's Reaction to Juan's Reliquary Presentation
tables.context: Persuasion Roll — At St. Peter's steps, Juan presents the sacred relics, crusade bull, Sultan's surrender document, Archbishop's conversion testimony, white crusade banner, and treasury chests with full accounting. He kneels and declares Castile's swords available to the Church, requesting release from crusade oath. The Pope must balance his genuine gratitude with political pressures from Basel Council, Colonna family, and cautious cardinals.

ranges.label: POLITICAL CAUTION DOMINATES
ranges.summary: Pope publicly acknowledges Juan's extraordinary achievement but responds with formal distance. Mentions Basel's complexity and Emperor Sigismund's pending arrival, suggesting Pope sees complications rather than opportunity. While releasing Juan from oath, Pope shows no discussion of petitions or private audience. Cardinals note caution; Basel supporters are pleased; Colonna faction relaxes. Dismisses Juan diplomatically rather than embracing alliance.

ranges.label: GRATEFUL BUT GUARDED
ranges.summary: Pope's voice softens and he acknowledges Juan's faith honors Christ. He personally praises completion of Reconquista and offers private audience, suggesting warmth beneath political restraint. However, Pope avoids public commitments, maintains public restraint despite genuine personal emotion. Sets foundation for private negotiations about petitions but signals complicated Roman politics prevent bold public endorsement.

ranges.label: MOVED BUT CAUTIOUS
ranges.summary: Pope experiences genuine emotional response with tears and public release from oath 'with some warmth.' Openly declares Juan has 'strengthened the Church in our hour of need' and offers private audience clearly. However, still avoids strong public commitments or detailed pledges on petitions. Basel supporters concerned; papal supporters encouraged. Sets positive tone for private discussions.

ranges.label: DEEPLY GRATEFUL, POLITICALLY AWARE
ranges.summary: Pope publicly embraces Juan after presentation, his thin face wet with tears. Publicly endorses crusade completion as achievement and uses it to make subtle point about papal authority against Basel's claims. Opens substantial private discussions about petitions (Military Orders, Naples advocacy, Council situation). Hints at wanting continued alliance. Basel supporters unhappy but not in crisis; sets foundation for substantive negotiations. Pope personally moved but politically calculating.

ranges.label: PROVIDENTIAL TIMING
ranges.summary: Pope takes both Juan's hands, pulls him to feet. Publicly uses Juan's achievement as argument against Basel, noting today is feast of St. Fidelis (patron of fidelity). Declares papal authority, rightly exercised, accomplishes God's will. Pope sees strategic opportunity in Juan's arrival. Petitions likely favorable; alliance forming visibly. Basel supporters alarmed; Colonna faction concerned. Pope gains visible confidence from Juan's support.

ranges.label: DIVINE VINDICATION
ranges.summary: Pope's voice breaks emotionally as he recalls praying for a sign about Basel crisis. Sees Juan's arrival and crusade success as God's answer about papal authority's divine favor. Raises voice publicly: 'Did the Council of Basel conquer Granada?' Uses Juan explicitly against Basel's supremacy claims. Crowd erupts in cheers. Cardinals uncomfortable. Forms immediate strong alliance; petitions almost certainly granted.

ranges.label: TRANSFORMATION
ranges.summary: Pope falls to knees before Juan shocking the cardinals—admits he doubted whether God wanted him as Pope. Sees Juan's crusade success as answer to his doubts. Addresses cardinals publicly that papally-authorized crusades accomplish what council decrees cannot. Grants all petitions immediately on steps. Basel faction in crisis; Colonna alarmed. Pope transforms from doubtful to certain; relationship becomes intimate alliance rather than diplomatic arrangement.

ranges.label: LEGENDARY MOMENT
ranges.summary: As Pope reaches for Juan's hands, light breaks through clouds creating shaft of sunlight illuminating him, Juan, and sacred relics. Cardinal Orsini cries out; crowd gasps; cardinals kneel. Pope publicly states this proves papal authority, rightly exercised, accomplishes God's will. Uses light as divine judgment on Basel's claims. All petitions granted. Creates legendary moment witnessed by cardinals and thousands. Chronicles will record extraordinary event.

ranges.label: ACTS OF GOD - HISTORICAL WATERSHED
ranges.summary: Everything from 89-95 plus bells of St. Peter's ring spontaneously throughout Rome without human prompting. Entire plaza falls to knees. Pope weeps holding True Cross, proclaims God has rendered judgment on papal-conciliar conflict. Three Basel-supporting cardinals publicly renounce conciliar supremacy; Colonna patriarch seeks reconciliation. Emperor Sigismund writes 'God has rendered judgment.' Church politics fundamentally shifted by arrival and moment.

ranges.label: MIRACULOUS - DIVINE JUDGMENT
ranges.summary: Extraordinary light, spontaneous bells, kneeling crowd all occur as prophesied signs. Pope experiences complete spiritual transformation declaring papacy vindicated. Multiple visions reported across Rome. Church factions realign immediately. Basel Council enters crisis with Cesarini experiencing spiritual crisis. Colonna and Pope reconcile. Your arrival becomes watershed of papal-conciliar history. Centuries of chronicles describe this as pivotal moment.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV's Response to Juan's Personal Confession of Faith
tables.context: Persuasion Roll — In private audience, Juan makes deeply emotional confession about his need to believe the Church is pure and without corruption, explaining how his faith requires this and how impossible his position is if the Church itself sins. Juan kneels, vulnerable, asking Pope to 'protect' his faith. This is vulnerable and sincere rather than calculated political appeal.

ranges.label: MOVED BUT GUARDED
ranges.summary: Pope helps Juan to feet, clearly moved but struggling with response. Acknowledges Juan's faith honors Christ but must speak honestly about Church corruption existing. Admits Basel's reform demands have merit while explaining impossibility of promising purity Juan seeks. Admits he faces impossible choices daily. Response is kind but emotionally distant. Opens discussion but without forming deep bond.

ranges.label: GRATEFUL BUT BURDENED
ranges.summary: Pope pulls Juan to feet and embraces him longer than protocol. Deeply moved, acknowledging Juan's rare belief that Church can be pure. Speaks openly about being surrounded by power-seekers and cardinals who scheme. However, admits the pure Church Juan needs doesn't exist and he cannot promise protection from discovering corruption. Warms relationship but cannot fully embrace Juan's idealism.

ranges.label: DEEPLY MOVED - SPIRITUAL RECOGNITION
ranges.summary: Pope falls to knees beside Juan, tears streaming, sobbing deeply. Shares three years of doubt about whether God still wanted him as Pope. Sees Juan's innocent faith as answer to prayers for sign. Explains how crusade success and Juan's purity of belief remind him why he fights. Opens up completely about inner struggles. Embraces Juan like father. Forms deep personal bond about fighting for Church's ideals even when reality fails.

ranges.label: BREAKTHROUGH MOMENT - MUTUAL RECOGNITION
ranges.summary: Pope removes papal tiara, sends others away for private confession. Kneels beside Juan (not before), reveals deepest doubts about whether God abandoned him. Prayed for sign that papal authority matters; sees Juan's arrival and innocent faith as answer to prayer. Grips Juan's shoulders: 'You are God's answer.' Acknowledges corruption exists but promises: 'you will not face impossible choices alone.' Grants all petitions immediately. Forms deep spiritual bond.

ranges.label: TRANSFORMATIVE SPIRITUAL EXPERIENCE
ranges.summary: Pope collapses to knees beside Juan, deep sobbing that shakes his frame. Admits three years of questioning himself, whether he destroyed Church by resisting Basel. Sees Juan's innocent faith as what he and Pope Martin lost. Embraces Juan like father weeping. Stands with transformation visible; opens doors to cardinals, proclaims Juan's achievement proves papal authority. Grants petitions with extraordinary terms. Forms alliance of conscience.

ranges.label: DIVINE MOMENT - LEGENDARY BOND
ranges.summary: Everything from 66-82 plus afternoon light intensifies during embrace. Cardinal Orsini swears room glowed. Pope's face transforms completely—exhaustion and doubt vanish. Throws doors open to assembled cardinals. Publicly proclaims Juan as defender of faith itself, not just Church territory. Declares his spiritual/political transformation. Refuses to remain silent on Basel while foreign king still believes in Church's purity. Creates legendary moment.

ranges.label: ACTS OF GOD - HISTORICAL TRANSFORMATION
ranges.summary: Everything from 83-93 plus bells of St. Peter's spontaneously ring throughout Rome as Pope opens doors. Entire plaza of 800 crusaders kneels; thousands of Romans pray. Pope describes moment as God's judgment on papal-conciliar crisis. Over next three days: five Basel-supporting cardinals renounce conciliar supremacy; Colonna patriarch seeks reconciliation; Emperor Sigismund acknowledges God has rendered judgment. Your innocent faith fundamentally shifts Church history.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV's Response to Basel Escort Proposal
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan naively suggests the Pope accompany him to Basel with 800 crusaders for security, revealing a misunderstanding of papal authority and the Council's political dynamics.
tables.outcome_label: Alarm - Firmly explains why this is utterly impossible

ranges.label: Shock and Pain
ranges.summary: Pope is deeply hurt that Juan doesn't understand the stakes of his proposal, expressing profound disappointment.

ranges.label: Alarm
ranges.summary: Pope firmly rejects the idea, explaining in detail why appearing before Basel's Council would destroy papal authority and set catastrophic precedents for the future.

ranges.label: Touched but Concerned
ranges.summary: Pope appreciates Juan's good intentions but gently corrects his political naivety, offering guidance on how to navigate the crisis differently.

ranges.label: Appreciative
ranges.summary: Pope values Juan's intent while carefully explaining the geopolitical realities that make his proposal impossible, discussing alternative approaches.

ranges.label: Moved
ranges.summary: Pope is deeply touched by Juan's offer but explores why it's impossible, discussing concrete alternative ways Juan can support him.

ranges.label: Profound Recognition
ranges.summary: Pope sees Juan's offer as divinely inspired despite its impossibility, reframing the conversation toward what's actually achievable.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV's Response to Juan's Strategic Vision
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan articulates his vision for using the crusade treasury and military capability to help Constantinople against the Ottomans, while distinguishing genuine reform from Bohemian noble theft, showing sophisticated understanding of the underlying conflicts.
tables.outcome_label: Energized - Genuine excitement while maintaining wisdom

ranges.label: Alarmed
ranges.summary: Pope concerned Juan is overreaching with too much ambition, worried about catastrophic overcommitment.

ranges.label: Worried
ranges.summary: Pope appreciates the vision but troubled by its scope and complexity, seeing multiple obstacles Juan hasn't fully considered.

ranges.label: Cautious
ranges.summary: Pope values the vision but emphasizes practical complications, probing Juan's understanding of what each step actually entails.

ranges.label: Engaged
ranges.summary: Pope sees genuine potential and constructively discusses how to temper enthusiasm with realities of implementation.

ranges.label: Encouraged
ranges.summary: Pope finds the approach sound and begins strategizing concrete steps, offering practical guidance.

ranges.label: Inspired
ranges.summary: Pope seriously explores the vision's feasibility, addressing major obstacles while maintaining genuine hope about its possibilities.

ranges.label: Energized
ranges.summary: Pope becomes genuinely excited, seeing for the first time in three years a path that doesn't end in schism or surrender, though he maintains wisdom about the challenges.

ranges.label: Profound Hope
ranges.summary: Pope sees providential possibilities in Juan's vision, becoming actively engaged in exploring how this could transform Christendom's future.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV's Response to Juan's Sequential Strategy
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan proposes a step-by-step approach: first resolve Hussites through reforms and property enforcement, then pivot to helping Constantinople and fighting Ottomans, presenting this as a favorable Council outcome.
tables.outcome_label: Questioning - Probes assumptions about timeline and difficulty

ranges.label: Concerned
ranges.summary: Pope worried Juan significantly underestimates the formidable military reality of the Bohemian nobles who defeated five crusades.

ranges.label: Cautious
ranges.summary: Pope notes that each proposed 'step' is itself years of work, expressing doubt about Juan's timeline and understanding of difficulty.

ranges.label: Questioning
ranges.summary: Pope sees merit but rigorously probes Juan's assumptions about how easily each step can be accomplished, demanding he think through actual obstacles.

ranges.label: Engaged
ranges.summary: Pope finds the approach has merit but demands specific details about implementation for each step.

ranges.label: Constructive
ranges.summary: Pope works through practical obstacles with Juan, refining the strategy while maintaining realism about challenges.

ranges.label: Encouraged
ranges.summary: Pope finds the approach fundamentally sound and begins refining implementation details strategically.

ranges.label: Optimistic
ranges.summary: Pope becomes actively convinced a path forward exists and strategizes with Juan about how to execute it.

ranges.label: Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Pope recognizes this approach as potentially transformative, becoming convinced Juan has found a genuine solution to the crisis.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV's Response to Juan's Humility and Personal Constraints
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan admits his ambitions may be overconfident, acknowledges he only has intentions not concrete plans, reveals he must return for Isabel's childbirth, and commits to earning trust through action rather than demanding it.

ranges.label: Relieved but Concerned
ranges.summary: Pope relieved by Juan's humility but still has reservations about vagueness and implementation details.

ranges.label: Appreciative of Humility
ranges.summary: Pope appreciates Juan's self-awareness but questions whether timeline and constraints will permit meaningful engagement.

ranges.label: Reassured by Self-Awareness
ranges.summary: Pope encouraged by Juan's humility and willingness to admit limitations, though practical concerns remain.

ranges.label: Moved by Integrity
ranges.summary: Pope touched by Juan's commitment to Isabel, offering measured encouragement and support while maintaining realistic expectations.

ranges.label: Genuinely Touched
ranges.summary: Pope is genuinely moved by Juan's character and willingness to prioritize family duty, providing fatherly guidance.

ranges.label: Deeply Reassured
ranges.summary: Pope finds Juan's humility and character deeply reassuring, offering concrete support and discussing strategic partnership.

ranges.label: Profoundly Encouraged
ranges.summary: Pope is profoundly moved and reassured, committing fully to supporting Juan and discussing concrete strategic partnership, offering letters and trust.

ranges.label: Complete Trust Restored
ranges.summary: Pope experiences emotional breakthrough with Juan, committing completely to him as trusted ally and offering full papal backing.

tables.title: Emperor Sigismund's Response to Juan's Initial Message
tables.context: Diplomacy — Riders carry Juan's message to Emperor Sigismund explaining his intentions regarding Basel and requesting whether Sigismund might grant free passage through the Empire for a potential Bohemian campaign.
tables.outcome_label: Message exchange only - Letters traded via couriers

ranges.label: Complete Miss
ranges.summary: Routes never intersect and riders fail to locate the Emperor before diverging paths make meeting impossible.

ranges.label: Declined Meeting
ranges.summary: Riders find Sigismund but he declines to meet, pressing forward to Rome on his own schedule.

ranges.label: Near Miss
ranges.summary: Word reaches Juan that Sigismund passed through the region a day before or after Juan's party, making direct contact impossible.

ranges.label: Message Exchange
ranges.summary: Riders locate the Emperor who sends a detailed written response but cannot delay for face-to-face meeting due to coronation timeline.

ranges.label: Brief Encounter
ranges.summary: Brief roadside meeting of an hour or two with minimal substance exchanged, both parties pressed for time.

ranges.label: Half-Day Meeting
ranges.summary: Parties meet at an inn or town for several hours, allowing meaningful but limited discussion of Bohemian situation.

ranges.label: Full Day Meeting
ranges.summary: Emperor interested enough to spend full day in discussion, permitting substantive conversation about Hussite strategy.

ranges.label: Two-Day Meeting
ranges.summary: Emperor impressed and extends meeting to two days, discussing strategy in detail and offering substantial guidance.

ranges.label: Extended Meeting
ranges.summary: Emperor reroutes briefly to travel alongside Juan, permitting deep counsel and strategic alignment.

tables.title: Emperor Sigismund's Response to Juan's Letter
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan writes directly to Emperor Sigismund after receiving his initial message, expressing respect for Sigismund's experience, acknowledging his own limitations regarding Hussite warfare, and asking for Sigismund's support.
tables.outcome_label: Strong preliminary endorsement - Considers real partnership

ranges.label: Polite Dismissal
ranges.summary: Emperor sees Juan as another overconfident young king, politely dismissive of his pretensions.

ranges.label: Skeptical Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: Emperor appreciates Juan's tone but doubts the substance behind his words and promises.

ranges.label: Reserved Interest
ranges.summary: Emperor will reserve final judgment until they meet at Basel, committing to nothing beyond a conversation.

ranges.label: Respectful but Guarded
ranges.summary: Emperor sees potential in Juan but remains cautious, requiring proof of understanding before offering support.

ranges.label: Genuine Interest
ranges.summary: Emperor genuinely impressed by Juan's humility and anticipates substantive discussions at Basel.

ranges.label: Warm Reception
ranges.summary: Emperor sees Juan as a possible ally and offers encouragement, suggesting openness to partnership.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic
ranges.summary: Emperor actively looks forward to meetings with Juan and sees genuine possibility of strategic collaboration.

ranges.label: Strong Preliminary Endorsement
ranges.summary: Emperor sees Juan as far more than typical royal supplicant, seriously considering him as potential ally, with hints of concrete support if Basel discussions prove sound.

tables.title: Basel Council's Reception of Juan's Arrival
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan arrives at Basel with 50 crusaders, is greeted by the Byzantine delegation and his own Castilian delegation, delivers a brief public address requesting time to settle before meetings, deflecting detailed engagement.
tables.outcome_label: Neutral - Standard diplomatic arrival, nothing gained or lost

ranges.label: Disappointed
ranges.summary: Delegations view Juan as aloof and evasive; Byzantines offended at being deflected; first impression is cold.

ranges.label: Cool Reception
ranges.summary: Professional but underwhelming first impression; factions remain interested but unmoved by Juan's caution.

ranges.label: Mixed Response
ranges.summary: Some appreciate Juan's caution and diplomatic care; others wanted more substance and find deflection frustrating.

ranges.label: Neutral
ranges.summary: Standard diplomatic arrival—careful, proper, unremarkable; factions neither impressed nor offended, remain cautiously observant.

ranges.label: Respectful
ranges.summary: Juan's caution interpreted as wisdom and sign of serious purpose; factions remain intrigued and respectful.

ranges.label: Positive
ranges.summary: Juan's dignified, restrained approach impresses multiple factions; deliberate strategy seen as sign of capable leadership.

ranges.label: Impressed
ranges.summary: Juan's careful arrival strategy viewed as mark of serious purpose; all factions intrigued and eager to engage.

ranges.label: Masterful
ranges.summary: Juan's restraint builds significant anticipation; his authority and wisdom established immediately; Council eager for his engagement.

tables.title: Fray Hernando's Response to Juan's Confession Rationale
tables.context: Religion — In confession, Juan articulates his justification for his ambitions, explaining that he sees his role as protecting his family and all of Christendom, using love as moral foundation for his grand plans.
tables.outcome_label: Alarmed - Rationalization more dangerous than original pride

ranges.label: Alarmed
ranges.summary: Fray Hernando sees Juan's rationalization through love as MORE spiritually dangerous than simple pride, fearing messianic thinking has taken root.

ranges.label: Troubled
ranges.summary: Fray recognizes genuine faith but deeply troubled by how Juan uses love to justify any action, seeing pattern of dangerous self-deception.

ranges.label: Conflicted
ranges.summary: Fray must challenge Juan's flawed reasoning despite recognizing genuine sincerity and authentic love driving the words.

ranges.label: Thoughtful
ranges.summary: Fray acknowledges Juan's loving heart while probing logical leaps and false binaries in his reasoning about necessary action.

ranges.label: Moved but Firm
ranges.summary: Fray sees genuine love underlying Juan's words but maintains firm spiritual warning against messianic thinking and certainty.

ranges.label: Pastoral
ranges.summary: Fray accepts Juan's confession and offers careful spiritual guidance while maintaining realistic concern about spiritual dangers.

ranges.label: Deeply Pastoral
ranges.summary: Fray understands Juan's spiritual struggle deeply and provides wise guidance to navigate the tension between duty and pride.

ranges.label: Profound
ranges.summary: Fray transforms the moment into spiritual breakthrough, helping Juan achieve genuine insight into his motivations and spiritual state.

tables.title: Abbott Rodrigo's Assessment of Juan's Diplomatic Position
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan proposes a strategy to separate theological reform from the supremacy question, positioning himself as neither strictly pro-papal nor pro-conciliarist. Abbott Rodrigo evaluates whether this 'middle path' approach will be credible to Council factions.

ranges.label: Deeply Disappointed
ranges.summary: Abbott sees this as moral cowardice; bluntly states Juan is trying to keep papal benefits while avoiding obligations; warns this destroys Castilian credibility.

ranges.label: Concerned Rebuke
ranges.summary: Abbott forcefully points out the logical contradiction—'you cannot carry that decree and claim to be an outsider'; worries Juan doesn't understand the stakes.

ranges.label: Skeptical but Patient
ranges.summary: Abbott sees appeal's merits but systematically dismantles the 'I'm just a king' pretense; asks hard questions about what Juan owes Eugenius.

ranges.label: Troubled Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: Abbott admits the unity appeal has power but insists evasion on supremacy will be seen through; suggests modifications to make the position tenable without abandoning papal alliance.

ranges.label: Cautious Respect
ranges.summary: Abbott sees strategic wisdom in focusing on Constantinople but still presses on the silence problem; offers specific ways to strengthen the position while defending the Pope.

ranges.label: Thoughtful Engagement
ranges.summary: Abbott finds more merit than expected in the 'outsider warrior' framing; works with Juan to refine approach while noting remaining vulnerabilities and path forward.

ranges.label: Surprised Agreement
