ranges.summary: Abbott recognizes that claiming incompetence on theology might actually be the most honest position; helps craft language that makes the approach credible.

ranges.label: Genuine Admiration
ranges.summary: Abbott sees profound wisdom in refusing to play theological games Juan cannot win; enthusiastically helps develop the approach with only minor concerns.

tables.title: Cardinal Cesarini's Reaction to Juan's Spiritual Vulnerability
tables.context: Persuasion — After Juan finds Cardinal Cesarini weeping in prayer and asks to pray with him, Juan pours out his spiritual crisis and asks the Cardinal for guidance on maintaining faith amid temptation. Cesarini responds from his pastoral duty but within his emotional constraints.

ranges.label: Mortified Withdrawal
ranges.summary: Cardinal feels too exposed, makes hasty excuses and flees the chapel immediately.

ranges.label: Cold Dignity
ranges.summary: Cardinal composes himself with effort, politely refuses further prayer, cites pressing duties.

ranges.label: Uncomfortable Silence
ranges.summary: Cardinal says nothing, clearly conflicted, offers only brief blessing before departing.

ranges.label: Pastoral Deflection
ranges.summary: Cardinal offers standard spiritual counsel without personal engagement or vulnerability.

ranges.label: Polite Deflection
ranges.summary: Cardinal agrees to pray briefly together but keeps emotional distance, reveals nothing of his burden.

ranges.label: Quiet Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: Cardinal accepts Juan's request with dignity, admits to being troubled but shares little personal detail; offers generic spiritual counsel as his pastoral duty.

ranges.label: Guarded Openness
ranges.summary: Cardinal prays together with some warmth, hints at his own struggles without full disclosure.

ranges.label: Breaking Through
ranges.summary: Juan's words crack Cesarini's composure; he admits his own doubts more fully and responds with genuine pastoral care.

ranges.label: Pastoral Brotherhood
ranges.summary: Cardinal confesses he was just praying the same questions, opens his heart about the Council's impossible position.

ranges.label: Spiritual Communion
ranges.summary: Profound moment of shared faith and doubt; Cesarini becomes genuine confidant and spiritual partner.

tables.title: What Juan Sees in Basel Cathedral During Prayer
tables.context: Chaos — Juan enters Basel Cathedral seeking spiritual guidance and a sign to anchor his decision-making. He searches the sacred space for inspiration, asking 'What if I am wrong?' A d100 determines what, if anything, captures his attention.

ranges.label: Empty Silence
ranges.summary: Nothing speaks to Juan. Cold stone, guttering candles, indifferent architecture. No signs offered.

ranges.label: Cracked Pillar
ranges.summary: Juan notices a load-bearing column with visible fractures, barely holding weight above.

ranges.label: Arguing Monks
ranges.summary: Two Franciscans in heated whispered debate, unable to agree even at prayer.

ranges.label: Faded Fresco
ranges.summary: A painting of Christ with water damage that has obscured His face entirely.

ranges.label: Sleeping Priest
ranges.summary: An elderly canon slumped in his seat, exhausted from endless Council debates.

ranges.label: Dawn Light Through Glass
ranges.summary: Morning sun illuminates a window depicting Christ calming the storm.

ranges.label: Pilgrim's Staff
ranges.summary: A worn wooden staff left by a traveler, leaning forgotten against a pillar.

ranges.label: Mother and Child
ranges.summary: A common woman kneeling with her young son, teaching him to pray.

ranges.label: The Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian
ranges.summary: A sculpture showing the saint pierced but still standing firm.

ranges.label: Byzantine Icon
ranges.summary: An Eastern Orthodox icon brought by the Greek delegation, placed near the altar.

ranges.label: Two Candles Burning as One
ranges.summary: Separate candle flames that lean toward each other until their light merges into one.

ranges.label: Cardinal Cesarini at Prayer
ranges.summary: Cardinal Cesarini kneeling alone, tears on his face, weeping in desperate prayer before the Virgin's statue.

tables.title: Byzantine Metropolitans' Initial Reaction to Juan's Opening
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan opens the meeting by claiming he wants to understand the Byzantines' position before acting, offers general willingness to help, but provides no concrete commitments. The metropolitans, having waited eight months for Western aid with only theological debates, assess whether this is genuine partnership or more empty promises.

ranges.label: Bitter Skepticism
ranges.summary: Metropolitans see this as more Latin evasion; barely concealing frustration after eight months of nothing but theological debates.

ranges.label: Polite Dismissal
ranges.summary: Metropolitans thank Juan but clearly expect nothing; recite their needs mechanically without hope.

ranges.label: Testing Cynicism
ranges.summary: Metropolitans probe his words for hidden conditions, remain deeply guarded about Latin intentions.

ranges.label: Cautious Formality
ranges.summary: Appreciate respect shown but share little; wait to see if Juan's words translate to substance.

ranges.label: Measured Interest
ranges.summary: Begin explaining situation factually, watching his reactions carefully for signs of genuine commitment.

ranges.label: Guarded Hope
ranges.summary: Share their desperation somewhat, testing his sincerity with harder truths about Ottoman threat.

ranges.label: Genuine Engagement
ranges.summary: Moved by his respectful approach, open up about their real fears and strategic needs.

ranges.label: Surprised Respect
ranges.summary: His humility catches them off guard; share more than expected about their situation and hopes.

ranges.label: Cautious Trust
ranges.summary: See something different in him; reveal strategic realities frankly and discuss possibilities.

ranges.label: Hopeful Partnership
ranges.summary: Believe he may be sincere; discuss concrete military and logistical possibilities openly.

ranges.label: Profound Relief
ranges.summary: Finally someone who listens first; share their desperate situation fully and engage constructively.

ranges.label: Complete Openness
ranges.summary: See him as potential true ally; hold nothing back about Constantine's defenses, military needs, and strategic options.

tables.title: Byzantine Metropolitans' Response to Juan's Concrete Military Commitments
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan stands and commits 100,000 florins from Castile's treasury, 500,000 total with crusade funds, 1,000 Military Order knights, and 5,000 order troops. He shows the papal decree proving perpetual command and offers to write the order immediately. The metropolitans assess whether this is genuine or more hollow promises.

ranges.label: Suspicious Disbelief
ranges.summary: Numbers too good; metropolitans suspect a trap and demand to know the real conditions attached.

ranges.label: Bitter Testing
ranges.summary: Metropolitans challenge every number, probe hard for weaknesses in his commitments.

ranges.label: Grudging Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: Impressive but metropolitans press hard on delivery guarantees and papal cooperation.

ranges.label: Cautious Interest
ranges.summary: First real offer they've received in eight months; metropolitans remain deeply wary of complications.

ranges.label: Skeptical Respect
ranges.summary: Appreciate concrete terms but question logistics, papal approval, and timeline realism.

ranges.label: Measured Hope
ranges.summary: See substance here; need reassurance about papal cooperation and execution details.

ranges.label: Genuine Engagement
ranges.summary: Impressed despite themselves; begin discussing practicalities, ask tough questions about implementation.

ranges.label: Surprised Trust
ranges.summary: His honesty about unknowns paradoxically builds confidence; begin treating as potential partner.

ranges.label: Real Partnership
ranges.summary: See potential ally; share strategic assessment openly and discuss offensive possibilities.

ranges.label: Profound Relief
ranges.summary: First Western lord to offer substance without demanding religious submission; deeply grateful.

ranges.label: Emotional Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Years of desperation met with real hope; moved to show genuine emotion and commitment.

ranges.label: Complete Alliance
ranges.summary: See him as God-sent answer; commit fully to partnership and advocate strongly for closer ties.

tables.title: Byzantine Metropolitans' Response to Juan's Strategic Framework
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan lays out three stark options: delay the inevitable with honor, mass migration to Castile, or full offensive war against Ottoman Empire. He emphasizes that he will require complete control of any military campaign and acknowledges the enormous costs and risks. The metropolitans assess whether his honesty about harsh realities and commitment to personal risk earns their trust.

ranges.label: Wounded Pride
ranges.summary: Juan's honesty feels like humiliation; metropolitans recoil from 'you cannot save yourselves' framing.

ranges.label: Overwhelmed Resistance
ranges.summary: Too much too fast; metropolitans retreat to defensive posture, resist being dictated to.

ranges.label: Troubled Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: See truth but struggle with implications; raise many objections about sovereignty and control.

ranges.label: Painful Recognition
ranges.summary: Admit Juan is right but need time to process harsh realities and their implications.

ranges.label: Sober Respect
ranges.summary: Appreciate clarity but raise serious concerns about sovereignty surrender and war's scale.

ranges.label: Cautious Agreement
ranges.summary: Framework makes strategic sense; discuss practical concerns openly as partners.

ranges.label: Grateful for Honesty
ranges.summary: Finally someone speaks truth plainly; engage constructively with three options and practical realities.

ranges.label: Strategic Partnership
ranges.summary: See wisdom in approach; willing to present framework seriously to Emperor without major objections.

ranges.label: Deep Appreciation
ranges.summary: His respect for their choice combined with honesty earns real trust; commit to framework.

ranges.label: Profound Relief
ranges.summary: Someone who thinks clearly AND respects them; fully embrace his approach and advocate for it.

ranges.label: Complete Trust
ranges.summary: See him as true partner; eagerly facilitate Emperor meeting and plan joint operations.

ranges.label: Transformative Moment
ranges.summary: Believe God sent this ally; fully commit to partnership and see him as Constantinople's salvation.

tables.title: Fray Hernando's Reaction to Juan's Flexible Approach
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan proposes a measured, step-by-step diplomatic approach instead of forcing an immediate Council address, showing willingness to listen to his confessor's counsel about patience and proper channels.

ranges.label: Cautious Reservation
ranges.summary: Hernando expresses serious concern about Juan's plan to make 'declarations outside Council structure,' strongly counseling against it. He warns that personal declarations will antagonize the Council factions and suggests meeting with Cesarini may be premature given the Cardinal's fragile state. Hernando remains cautious despite Juan's apparent flexibility.

ranges.label: Measured Support
ranges.summary: Hernando supports the step-by-step approach and will arrange a Cesarini meeting, but counsels extreme care. He warns that personal declarations could appear arrogant and recommends patience over speed, offering to personally approach Cesarini as a fellow cleric.

ranges.label: Practical Guidance
ranges.summary: Pleased by Juan's flexibility, Hernando offers to personally approach Cesarini and frames the meeting as spiritual counsel rather than political maneuvering. He outlines a realistic three-day agenda and is more optimistic about the approach.

ranges.label: Encouraged Cooperation
ranges.summary: Visibly relieved that Juan accepted the counsel, Hernando is enthusiastic about spiritual companionship and confident he can arrange the Cesarini meeting quickly. He sees Juan's humility as genuine growth and offers specific strategic guidance.

ranges.label: Strong Endorsement
ranges.summary: Deeply moved by Juan's humility, Hernando believes the measured approach is divinely guided. He offers specific strategy for all meetings and dedicates himself fully to Juan's spiritual mission.

ranges.label: Profound Spiritual Moment
ranges.summary: Hernando recognizes transformative spiritual maturity in Juan. He experiences emotional response to the King seeking genuine guidance and sees this as answer to his prayers for Juan's soul.

tables.title: Fray Hernando's Response to Juan's Spiritual Confession
tables.context: Religion — Juan confesses his sins of presumption and arrogance, expressing humility about his inability to change the Church and commitment to spiritual reflection. Hernando must assess whether this is genuine transformation or another instance of Juan's pattern of agreeing then reverting.

ranges.label: Sharp Spiritual Rebuke
ranges.summary: Hernando points out Juan agreed to patience then immediately argued for his plan; sees this as exactly the spiritual danger warned about. He questions whether Juan truly seeks counsel or merely validation and may refuse to help with meetings.

ranges.label: Firm Challenge
ranges.summary: Hernando acknowledges Juan's honesty but challenges the 'trapped beast' arrogance. He notes Juan cites the decree to justify what he wanted anyway and demands reflection before any action, neither endorsing nor condemning the confession.

ranges.label: Cautious Engagement
ranges.summary: Willing to discuss political analysis but reiterates spiritual concerns first. Hernando examines the decree carefully and points out the gap between what it says and what Juan interprets, pushing Juan to examine his motives.

ranges.label: Measured Consideration
ranges.summary: Hernando sees merit in some political points while maintaining caution. He discusses the decree's actual language, offers conditional support if Juan can demonstrate patience first, and tests Juan's willingness to wait.

ranges.label: Reluctant Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: Hernando admits Juan's analysis has some validity and still concerned about eagerness but sees wisdom in exploring options. He agrees to discuss with the Cardinal but urges extreme caution and wants Juan to listen more than speak.

ranges.label: Thoughtful Support
ranges.summary: Hernando recognizes Juan's political insight while maintaining pastoral concern. He sees the decree as legitimate basis for careful engagement and balances encouragement with caution about spiritual foundations.

ranges.label: Surprised Approval
ranges.summary: Hernando finds Juan's reasoning more sophisticated than expected and sees potential wisdom in the approach if executed with humility. He cautiously supports exploration while maintaining spiritual oversight.

tables.title: Random Encounter in Basel - Who Juan Meets
tables.context: Chaos — Juan walks alone through Basel's streets in the afternoon, dressed as a noble but not announcing himself as king. He seeks inspiration and perspective from someone outside the Council's politics.

ranges.label: Trouble
ranges.summary: Juan is recognized despite his dress or gets into a confrontation with anti-papal faction. Possible robbery, threats, or witnessing violence that complicates his position in Basel.

ranges.label: Uncomfortable Encounter
ranges.summary: Juan meets with an aggressive beggar, cynical merchant, or someone with grudge against Castile. He is forced into awkward situation that reveals negative attitudes toward his kingdom or crusade.

ranges.label: Nothing Notable
ranges.summary: Quiet walk through Basel where people ignore the foreign noble. Juan sees city life but no meaningful encounters; returns having observed little new.

ranges.label: Observational Learning
ranges.summary: Juan witnesses Council delegates arguing in a tavern or observes how common people view the Church crisis. He learns through watching tensions and observing the real effects of Council politics.

ranges.label: Brief Meaningful Exchange
ranges.summary: Juan has a short conversation with a craftsman, merchant, or minor cleric who offers practical perspective on the Council's effects on daily life. The saddler Heinrich Möller compares Church reform to his craft, offering simple wisdom about fixing things properly.

ranges.label: Significant Encounter - Common Person
ranges.summary: Extended conversation with someone outside power structures—innkeeper, artisan, or elderly person. Juan sees the Church crisis through ordinary eyes and gains earthy wisdom.

ranges.label: Significant Encounter - Educated Stranger
ranges.summary: Juan meets a scholar, monk, or minor diplomat who challenges his assumptions through theological or political discussion without knowing his rank.

ranges.label: Remarkable Encounter
ranges.summary: Juan meets someone with unique perspective—former soldier, converted Jew, or traveling philosopher. Profound conversation reframes his thinking.

ranges.label: Unexpected Recognition
ranges.summary: Someone recognizes him despite his dress. How they respond and what follows creates an unexpected situation with potential complications.

ranges.label: Divine Providence
ranges.summary: Extraordinary coincidence or encounter that feels guided—exactly the person or situation Juan needed but couldn't have planned. The interpretation is left to Juan's understanding.

tables.title: The Saddler's Farewell to Juan
tables.context: Personal — Juan shares bread with the saddler Heinrich Möller and thanks him for the conversation, offering a simple gesture of fellowship before departing. The saddler's reaction reflects how moved he is by Juan's humility and the shared moment.

ranges.label: Gruff Dismissal
ranges.summary: The saddler grunts acknowledgment barely looking up. He takes the bread but makes no comment and returns immediately to work with only a brief nod as Juan leaves.

ranges.label: Polite but Distant
ranges.summary: The saddler thanks Juan for the bread and wishes him well in German-accented Latin, making no further comment. The farewell is cordial but unmoved.

ranges.label: Warm Acknowledgment
ranges.summary: The saddler appreciates the gesture genuinely and offers a simple blessing in return. Perhaps he shares small practical advice for the road and offers a respectful farewell.

ranges.label: Thoughtful Parting
ranges.summary: The saddler pauses his work to acknowledge Juan properly. He appreciates the silence they shared, offers final wisdom about letting go, and gives Juan a genuine warm farewell with real feeling.

ranges.label: Meaningful Connection
ranges.summary: The saddler is moved by Juan's humility and shares something personal about his own life. He wishes Juan well with genuine feeling and will remember this stranger.

ranges.label: Insightful Observation
ranges.summary: The saddler suspects Juan is more than he appears and makes a subtle comment about it. He offers wisdom specifically relevant to men of power and a knowing look.

ranges.label: Profound Moment
ranges.summary: The saddler shares something deeply wise or personal. He recognizes quality in Juan without knowing his rank and offers a blessing that carries significant weight.

ranges.label: Unexpected Gift
ranges.summary: The saddler offers Juan something small but meaningful in return—a tool, leather scrap, or advice worth more than gold. Mutual respect is established.

ranges.label: Future Connection
ranges.summary: The saddler reveals something about himself that matters and offers continued counsel if Juan returns. A sense of providence in the meeting is established.

tables.title: Who Prays at Dawn in Basel Cathedral
tables.context: Chaos — Juan enters the cathedral at dawn on May 30 to observe who is praying there. This encounter will shape his spiritual day and possibly introduce new perspectives.

ranges.label: No One Suitable
ranges.summary: Only scattered monks absorbed in private devotion, too absorbed to approach. The cathedral feels empty and isolating.

ranges.label: Local Basel Cleric
ranges.summary: A simple parish priest from the city—humble, uncomplicated faith with no knowledge of Council politics.

ranges.label: Elderly Benedictine Monk
ranges.summary: An ancient, nearly deaf monk offers peaceful presence and wordless companionship in prayer.

ranges.label: Young Seminarian
ranges.summary: A student from the university, nervous and uncertain about his own calling. Struggles visibly with faith questions.

ranges.label: Minor Council Delegate
ranges.summary: A low-ranking cleric from one of the delegations, weary and overwhelmed by Council politics.

ranges.label: Hussite Representative
ranges.summary: One of the Bohemian delegates praying alone, avoided by others. Potentially dangerous or illuminating encounter.

ranges.label: German Reform Advocate
ranges.summary: A middle-ranking German prelate passionate about Church reform but frustrated with Council's paralysis.

ranges.label: Italian Papal Loyalist
ranges.summary: A bishop loyal to Eugenius praying for the Pope's guidance; suspicious of the Council's direction.

ranges.label: French Conciliarist
ranges.summary: Bishop Jean de Rochetaillée, a member of the radical faction, prays for courage to challenge papal authority. He is initially suspicious of Spanish nobles but gradually opens to genuine dialogue through Juan's humility.

ranges.label: Cardinal Cesarini Again
ranges.summary: The papal legate returned to the same chapel, struggling with his own doubts. The encounter would be significant and potentially complicated by their earlier encounter.

ranges.label: Someone from Castilian Delegation
ranges.summary: Bishop Alfonso or another Castilian delegate, surprised to see their King alone at dawn.

ranges.label: Completely Unexpected Figure
ranges.summary: Someone who should not be there—an exiled cleric, disguised noble, or mysterious stranger.

tables.title: Bishop Jean de Rochetaillée's Response to Juan's Prayer
tables.context: Religion — Juan prays alongside Bishop Jean, offering a heartfelt prayer about presumption, serving God rather than fixing the Church, and personal concerns. The bishop must assess whether Juan's spirituality is genuine or politically motivated.

ranges.label: Defensive and Sharp
ranges.summary: The bishop takes Juan's words as veiled criticism of conciliarists and defends his position forcefully. He sees neutrality as moral cowardice and lectures about why the Council must prevail.

ranges.label: Suspicious and Probing
ranges.summary: The bishop questions Juan's motives—why would a papal ally speak against presumption? He tests whether this is a trap or genuine seeking and remains guarded but curious.

ranges.label: Polite but Unmoved
ranges.summary: The bishop appreciates the prayer's sincerity but remains convinced of his path. He offers standard response about God guiding the Council and remains unchanged in his convictions.

ranges.label: Thoughtfully Challenged
ranges.summary: Juan's self-criticism gives the bishop pause. He reflects on his own presumptions briefly and engages in genuine dialogue, but maintains his core belief in conciliar supremacy despite questioning his methods.

ranges.label: Meaningfully Engaged
ranges.summary: The bishop recognizes rare humility and shares his own struggles honestly. A genuine conversation between two men seeking truth, though they maintain different convictions.

ranges.label: Deeply Moved
ranges.summary: Juan's prayer pierces the bishop's certainty and he admits his own presumption struggles. He finds a kindred spirit in honest seeking and shows rare vulnerability.

ranges.label: Profound Connection
ranges.summary: The bishop is shaken by the prayer's honesty and reconsiders his fierce certainty. A moment of grace where both men are changed through encounter.

ranges.label: Spiritual Breakthrough
ranges.summary: Juan's words strike at the heart of the bishop's faith. He weeps or shows strong emotion and offers wisdom or confession that reshapes understanding.

ranges.label: Transformative Moment
ranges.summary: The bishop recognizes something holy in this encounter and experiences profound spiritual moment. Both men are blessed by the grace present.

tables.title: What Happens in the Council Session - Hussite Negotiations
tables.context: Chaos — Juan observes the Council session on May 30 where various factions debate the Hussite situation. The complexity of the issue and the Council's dysfunction will test his resolve to not intervene.

ranges.label: Dull Procedural Grind
ranges.summary: Hours of technical debate on minor points with nothing of substance. Tedious proceedings test Juan's patience severely.

ranges.label: Factional Shouting Match
ranges.summary: French and Italian delegates erupt into heated argument with Cesarini struggling to maintain order. Ugly display of division.

ranges.label: Byzantine Delegation Appears
ranges.summary: Metropolitans Bessarion and Isidore present formal petition for aid. Council's response reveals its dysfunction clearly.

ranges.label: Reform Decree Discussion
ranges.summary: Serious debate on simony or pluralism with good arguments made but no resolution. Council at its frustrating best—process without outcome.

ranges.label: Hussite Negotiation Update
ranges.summary: The Council discusses Bohemian situation with factions divided over property rights and reconciliation. The complexity reveals the Council's inability to make decisive choices on crucial matters.

ranges.label: Someone Mentions Castile
ranges.summary: The Castilian delegation's proposals are referenced in debate. Juan hears his kingdom discussed from outside perspective.

ranges.label: Cesarini's Burden Visible
ranges.summary: The papal legate's strain becomes apparent as he struggles to hold the center together. Juan witnesses the man's impossible task firsthand.

ranges.label: Unexpected Moment of Unity
ranges.summary: Brief flash of agreement on something significant, reminding that cooperation is possible. Quickly dissolves back to faction fighting.

ranges.label: Someone Recognizes Juan
ranges.summary: Despite his shadowed position, a delegate notices him. Reaction varies; Juan's anonymity is compromised.

ranges.label: Dramatic Political Move
ranges.summary: A major announcement or proposal shifts Council dynamics. Juan witnesses significant development firsthand.

ranges.label: Personal Message Delivered
ranges.summary: A messenger finds Juan with urgent news from delegation, Toledo, or the Greeks.

ranges.label: Crisis Erupts
ranges.summary: Something unexpected disrupts the session entirely. Major event unfolds before Juan's eyes.

tables.title: Cardinal Cesarini's Response to Juan's Request for Audience
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan sends a formal message through his delegation requesting audience with Cardinal Cesarini. He apologizes for the cathedral encounter and offers to present his papal decree. Cesarini must decide how to respond.

ranges.label: Refuses or Delays Significantly
ranges.summary: Too humiliated by the cathedral encounter, Cesarini sees the apology as political maneuvering. He makes excuses to avoid meeting or sends formal refusal with indefinite postponement.

ranges.label: Suspicious and Guarded
ranges.summary: Cesarini agrees to meet but is deeply wary. He grants short window and sends formal, cold response. The apology is noted but not fully trusted.

ranges.label: Cautiously Professional
ranges.summary: Standard diplomatic response granting audience at reasonable time. Neutral tone; will fulfill duty but without warmth; apology noted but not fully accepted.

ranges.label: Relieved by Protocol
ranges.summary: Grateful Juan used proper channels; appreciates the apology; grants audience promptly. Professional but not cold; willing to give Juan fair hearing.

ranges.label: Genuinely Appreciative
ranges.summary: Moved by the apology and respect shown, Cesarini grants earliest available time with warm tone in response. He sees Juan as potential ally rather than threat and welcomes the meeting.

ranges.label: Eager to Meet
ranges.summary: Desperate for a reasonable voice, Cesarini grants immediate or same-day audience. Response shows hope and sees Juan as possible answer to his prayers.

ranges.label: Deeply Moved
ranges.summary: The apology touches Cesarini profoundly and he includes personal note in response. He grants priority audience and begins to trust Juan's intentions despite remaining vulnerable.

ranges.label: Requests Informal Meeting First
ranges.summary: Cesarini suggests private conversation before formal audience, wanting candid speech. Rare sign of trust showing he sees kindred spirit in Juan.

ranges.label: Immediate Summons
ranges.summary: Cesarini sends for Juan at once—cannot wait. Urgent tone shows something has shifted; breakthrough moment imminent.

tables.title: Fray Hernando's Response to Juan's Confession about Specific Acts
tables.context: Religion — Juan has moved from abstract confessions about pride to naming specific acts: wounded left behind in ambush whose names he never learned, the dying young soldier at Loja, hundreds reduced to numbers in reports. He asks if their deaths 'must not have been for nothing,' seeking reassurance. Hernando must respond pastorally to this breakthrough confession.

ranges.label: Formal Absolution with Gentle Caution
ranges.summary: Hernando acknowledges the confession of real things but notes the ending question reveals the wound is still present—the need for deaths to justify the weight. He grants ego te absolvo but indicates they will work together on this issue.

ranges.label: Warm Recognition and Absolution
ranges.summary: Hernando expresses clear relief and recognition that this is what he has been waiting for—not philosophy but genuine grief and naming of real men. He grants full sacramental absolution (ego te absolvo) and offers pastoral comfort, noting the ending question shows the continuing wound but framing it with compassion rather than critique.

ranges.label: Deeply Moved Absolution
ranges.summary: Hernando becomes visibly emotional, acknowledging his own earlier harshness and admitting how long Juan has carried unforgiven weight. He grants absolution with trembling hand and deep personal commitment, addressing the ending question as the cry of a soul that has been spiritually starving too long.

tables.title: Fray Hernando's Response to Juan's Request to Become Confessor
tables.context: Religion — After receiving genuine absolution and showing profound vulnerability, Juan asks Fray Hernando to continue as his confessor going forward. Juan acknowledges he will stumble and fail but commits to trying to stay on God's path, and respectfully offers Hernando an honorable way out if desired. This is a vulnerable request for ongoing spiritual direction.

ranges.label: Formal Commitment
ranges.summary: Hernando accepts the role formally but without emotional warmth, emphasizing his vocation and the mutual stumbling that will occur. He commits to continue but his tone is professional rather than personally warm.

ranges.label: Committed Partnership
ranges.summary: Hernando's expression softens and he explicitly rejects the exit Juan offered. He acknowledges both will fail—Juan in presumption, Hernando in harshness—and frames it as two imperfect men trying to discern God's will together. He notes Juan's visible progress and commits warmly to the work.

ranges.label: Warm Acceptance
ranges.summary: Hernando becomes emotional, gripping Juan's shoulder and calling the work his calling. He acknowledges the profound difficulty of walking with someone who struggles with presumption and commits with trembling voice to help Juan distinguish God's voice from his own ambition.

ranges.label: Deeply Moved Covenant
ranges.summary: Hernando kneels beside Juan's chair, openly weeping, and declares this is his calling with full emotional and spiritual commitment. He grieves the months Juan carried unforgiven weight and pledges to walk alongside him through stumbling, promising to catch him when he falls into presumption.

tables.title: Community Response to Juan's Armored Speech on Spiritual Warfare
tables.context: Religion/Intrigue — Minutes after receiving profound absolution from Fray Hernando, Juan assembles everyone in crusade armor and delivers a speech reframing the spiritual struggle as internal warfare against sin and presumption. He commits to Constantinople aid tomorrow and emphasizes the importance of confession and seeking God's grace. This rapid shift from exhaustion to dramatic action triggers concern among clergy who see a problematic pattern.

ranges.label: Crusaders enthusiastic, clergy deeply concerned
ranges.summary: Crusaders respond enthusiastically with 'Non nobis Domine!' and raised swords, energized by the familiar language of spiritual warfare. However, Abboth Rodrigo and Bishop Cartagena exchange worried glances and Fray Hernando's watchful stance is noticed by the clergy. Afterward, Abbott approaches with gentle concern about the pattern: spiritual breakthrough immediately becomes grand gesture.

ranges.label: Mixed reception, pattern recognized
ranges.summary: Crusaders are moved and raising swords but clergy applaud politely and remain reserved. Abbott approaches afterward with concern: 'Beautiful words. But perhaps rest? Let transformation settle before declarations?' Fray Hernando's expression shows concern about the familiar cycle repeating.

ranges.label: Genuine but cautious response
ranges.summary: Crusaders respond powerfully to the message. Clergy are moved but thoughtful. Abbott speaks warmly but with gentle guidance: 'Your Majesty speaks from the heart. But the heart is still learning.' Fray Hernando's expression softens slightly—he sees the genuine transformation but also recognizes Juan's enduring patterns.

ranges.label: They see through pattern to truth
ranges.summary: Despite the concerning timing, something in Juan's bearing shows he carries weight differently now. Crusaders thunder their response. Even skeptical clergy recognize both the real spiritual transformation and the fact that Juan is doing what he does. Fray Hernando nods once—the grace underneath is real, even if imperfect.

tables.title: Clergy Response to Juan's Deflection of Concerns
tables.context: Religion/Intrigue — After the clergy gently raised concerns about Juan's immediate shift from exhaustion to grand gestures, Juan defended his actions by questioning whether they could identify an actual sin. They acknowledged perhaps no specific sin but concern about the pattern and timing. Juan then dismisses the conversation with 'Look at me, discussing theology like a priest' and announces he's going for a walk, inviting them to dinner instead. This deflects their pastoral concern.

ranges.label: Frustrated Recognition
ranges.summary: Fray Hernando closes his eyes and speaks with tired recognition: 'Your Majesty, you are doing it right now. We raise concern, you ask for specifics, we give them, you dismiss with no sin then and leave. This is the pattern.' His voice is exhausted but not harsh. The clergy let their king leave because he is the king, but the concern remains unaddressed.

ranges.label: Resigned Acceptance
ranges.summary: Abbott nods slowly with sadness in his eyes, saying only 'Yes, Your Majesty. Dinner.' Bishop bows. Fray Hernando says nothing but his expression shows understanding of what just happened. They permit their king to leave because he has the authority, but the spiritual concern is not resolved.

ranges.label: Respectful Acquiescence
ranges.summary: Abbott bows politely: 'Of course, Your Majesty. A walk will do you good. We will continue at dinner.' Fray Hernando appears unreadable but not disapproving, perhaps accepting that transformation takes time and Juan needs space to process in his own way.

ranges.label: Understanding Grace
ranges.summary: Abbott smiles gently: 'Yes, Your Majesty. Sometimes we need to move, to act, to share. Not everything must be examined to death.' Fray Hernando nods: 'Go on your walk. We will talk at dinner.' They see a young man who just received profound grace and accept that he needs to process it through action and movement.

tables.title: Crusader Volunteer Response
tables.context: Military — Juan asks Captain Robles whether crusaders would volunteer to travel ahead to Constantinople with the Byzantine delegation, assessing their willingness to depart from their original plans.

ranges.label: Very Poor Response
ranges.summary: Only 1-2 volunteers; most crusaders see the Constantinople mission as a suicide mission and prefer to settle in Granada with their land grants.

ranges.label: Weak Response
ranges.summary: 3-5 volunteers willing to go; concerns about family separation and uncertain timeline dominate crusaders' thinking.

ranges.label: Moderate Response
ranges.summary: 6-10 crusaders volunteer, balancing enthusiasm for the mission with caution about leaving families and uncertain conditions.

ranges.label: Strong Positive Response
ranges.summary: 11-15 experienced warriors step forward, motivated by the honor of continuing their crusade and the desperate cause of Constantinople's defense.

ranges.label: Exceptional Commitment
ranges.summary: 16-20+ volunteers eagerly embrace the opportunity, deeply inspired by Juan's moral authority and the urgency of the mission.

tables.title: Walk Through Basel — Random Encounter
tables.context: Personal — Juan takes a walk through Basel to escape the political intrigues of the Council, seeking perspective and perspective on the city's character.
tables.outcome_label: Elderly Basel Resident Sharing Council Memories

ranges.label: French Radical Faction Argument
ranges.summary: Juan overhears French radical delegates arguing loudly in a tavern about deposing Pope Eugenius, revealing deep factional conflict.

ranges.label: Theological Debate on Haec Sancta
ranges.summary: Juan witnesses heated theological debate between German and Italian doctors in cathedral square about whether councils are supreme over popes.

ranges.label: Market Complaints About Council
ranges.summary: Juan passes a market where merchants complain about Council delegates buying on credit and never paying.

ranges.label: Frustrated Hussite Delegates
ranges.summary: Juan overhears two Utraquist Hussite delegates speaking in Bohemian near an inn, clearly frustrated with the Council's progress.

ranges.label: Local Riot Against Foreign Clerics
ranges.summary: Juan comes upon a small riot of townspeople angry at foreign clerics, with local authorities breaking it up.

ranges.label: Normal Basel Life Away from Council
ranges.summary: Juan finds a quiet neighborhood away from Council chaos where he sees normal Basel life—families, craftsmen, and children playing.

ranges.label: Elderly Basel Resident Remembering Council of Constance
ranges.summary: Juan meets an elderly Basel resident (age ~75) who remembers the Council of Constance (1414-1418) and shares concerns about the pattern of Church councils repeating the same conflicts.

ranges.label: Cardinal Aleman's Secret Faction Meeting
ranges.summary: Juan witnesses Cardinal Aleman's faction meeting secretly in a side chapel, clearly plotting something significant.

ranges.label: German Princes' Discussion of Sigismund
ranges.summary: Juan crosses paths with German princes' representatives and overhears discussion of Emperor Sigismund's intentions toward the Council.

ranges.label: Procession of Relics
ranges.summary: Juan encounters a procession of local saints' relics through the city, competing with the Council's grandeur.

ranges.label: Moderate Delegates Seeking Common Ground
ranges.summary: Juan stumbles upon an informal gathering of moderate delegates from various nations seeking common ground on reform.

ranges.label: Cardinal Cesarini in Desperate Prayer
ranges.summary: Juan finds Cardinal Cesarini alone in a small church, praying desperately; Cesarini does not notice Juan's presence.

tables.title: Byzantine Reaction to Castilian Crusader Volunteers
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan offers 17 crusaders to travel immediately to Constantinople with the Byzantine delegation to assist in preparation and assessment of defenses.

ranges.label: Appreciate But Concerned
ranges.summary: Metropolitans appreciate the offer but express concern about Western soldiers inside Constantinople, citing the Fourth Crusade (1204) trauma; they explain Emperor John must approve.

ranges.label: Accept With Conditions
ranges.summary: Metropolitans accept the offer but require clarity on command structure, Emperor John's approval, and accommodation for language barriers; they express honest concerns about historical precedent.

ranges.label: Grateful With Practical Planning
ranges.summary: Metropolitans see the volunteers as a practical solution to preparation needs and acknowledge how Western Christian presence before the main force strengthens their position; they commit to securing Emperor's approval and establishing clear procedures.

ranges.label: Enthusiastically Grateful
ranges.summary: Both metropolitans visibly moved, viewing the volunteers as transformative proof of Juan's commitment; they commit to immediate departure preparations and assure Juan of Emperor John's likely acceptance.

ranges.label: Passionate Embrace
ranges.summary: Metropolitans overcome with emotion, seeing the volunteers as unprecedented proof of brotherhood rather than politics; they commit to giving the crusaders formal titles and positions in Constantinople's defense.

ranges.label: Transformative Commitment
ranges.summary: Both metropolitans propose sending more crusaders immediately if possible and suggest Juan could send additional waves of volunteers; they frame this as the model for how Christendom should respond to Constantinople.

tables.title: Council of Basel's Crusade Decree Response
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan proposes crusade structure (unified command, confession requirements, financial transparency) and parallel legislation approach; Council must deliberate whether to pass comprehensive crusade decree in coordination with Pope.

ranges.label: Complete Blockage
ranges.summary: French radicals block in all deputations; constitutional warfare consumes discussions; no decree passed within meaningful timeline (6+ months minimum); Council remains paralyzed.

ranges.label: Procedural Death
ranges.summary: German delegation pushes hard but systematic resistance prevents consensus; months spent in committee debates; no decree passed within relevant timeline; Pope acts alone instead.

ranges.label: Weak Endorsement Only
ranges.summary: After 8-10 weeks, Council passes watered-down statement acknowledging 'urgent need' without unified command, specific provisions, or papal cooperation; effect is symbolic only.

ranges.label: Partial Success
ranges.summary: 6-8 weeks of debate produces decree with vague unified command provision ('Christian princes in consultation'), softened spiritual requirements, and partial financial transparency; Pope issues similar but not identical bull.

ranges.label: Strong Decree
ranges.summary: Within 5-6 weeks, comprehensive crusade decree passes with unified command, confession requirements, and financial transparency; Pope issues matching bull achieving true parallel legislation.

ranges.label: Rapid Breakthrough
ranges.summary: 4-5 weeks produces strong decree through all deputations; Pope issues identical bull same week; parallel legislation works perfectly; French radicals isolated; Juan's command structure confirmed.

ranges.label: Transformative Unity
ranges.summary: 3 weeks achieve rare genuine consensus; perfect parallel legislation with Pope; all provisions adopted enthusiastically; French radicals marginalized; becomes model for future cooperation.

ranges.label: Historic Achievement
ranges.summary: 2-3 weeks achieve unprecedented speed and unity; perfect Pope-Council coordination; comprehensive decree sets new standard for Church cooperation; constitutional breakthrough achieved through demonstration.

tables.title: Intercepting Emperor Sigismund
tables.context: Travel/Logistics — Juan departs Basel on June 2, 1433 to intercept Emperor Sigismund who was crowned in Rome on May 31st. The success of this intercept depends on travel speed, intelligence gathering, and route coordination.

ranges.label: Complete Miss
ranges.summary: Juan and Sigismund take divergent routes (Juan goes west, Sigismund goes east). By the time Juan learns the Emperor's actual location, Sigismund has already passed. Juan must backtrack to Basel or wait there, losing 2-3 weeks. Meeting eventually happens at Basel but the intercept fails.

ranges.label: Difficult Chase
ranges.summary: 7-10 days of hard riding south asking at every town. Information is always a day or two old. Juan finally catches Sigismund in northern Italy, but both parties are travel-weary and the Emperor is pressed for time. Only a few hours available at a coaching inn, rushed circumstances.

ranges.label: Standard Intercept
ranges.summary: 4-6 days of riding with decent intelligence. Juan meets Sigismund in the Italian Alps at a monastery or small town where he's stopped for rest. Standard accommodations available. Have 1-2 days available before Sigismund must continue north.

ranges.label: Good Timing
ranges.summary: 3-4 days of riding with good intelligence network. Juan intercepts at a comfortable alpine town (Como). Good accommodations available. 2-3 days available together before either party needs to depart, allowing for substantive discussions.

ranges.label: Efficient Intercept
ranges.summary: 2-3 days of fast riding with excellent intelligence. Juan meets Sigismund at a well-provisioned location (major monastery or prosperous town). Comfortable circumstances. 3-4 days available before either party needs to depart, enabling extended strategic discussions.

ranges.label: Perfect Intercept
ranges.summary: Within 2 days, Juan intercepts Sigismund at an ideal location with excellent facilities. Sigismund has scheduled an extended stop (major city or important monastery). Potentially full week available. Excellent surroundings, good privacy for sensitive discussions.

tables.title: Sigismund's Initial Reaction to Partnership Proposal
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan proposes cooperation to address shared Christian concerns (church unity, Muslim threats). He offers no demands, only shared goals and collaborative partnership. Sigismund is testing whether Juan is genuinely different from other ambitious kings.

ranges.label: Polite Skepticism
ranges.summary: Sigismund hears idealism from another young king unprepared for harsh reality. The 'Kingdom of God' language sounds naive. He responds politely but without engagement—generic agreement that problems exist, but no opening for substantive conversation. Cool, professional, guarded. Testing whether Juan has substance or just grand words.

ranges.label: Cautious Testing
ranges.summary: Sigismund appreciates honesty but remains skeptical. He asks pointed questions: 'What does cooperation actually mean? What can you deliver beyond words? Why should I believe you're different?' He probes whether Juan understands real complexity or just has visions. Not dismissive, but demanding proof of seriousness and strategic depth.

ranges.label: Genuine Interest, Still Guarded
ranges.summary: Sigismund recognizes Juan DID complete Granada—actions matter. He engages more seriously, but wants to understand if Juan thinks strategically or idealistically. Shares frustrations cautiously. Real conversation begins, but he tests whether Juan grasps how hard these problems actually are. Waiting to see deeper understanding.

ranges.label: Real Engagement
ranges.summary: The combination of accomplishment and humility resonates. Sigismund opens up about struggles—Bohemia, church crisis, being ignored despite imperial title. Sees someone who acts rather than talks. Willing to discuss specific possibilities. Still some wariness, but genuine interest in partnership and a willingness to know Juan better.

ranges.label: Strong Connection
ranges.summary: Sigismund is deeply impressed. Finally finds a king who delivers AND admits limitations. Opens frankly about the weight of decades of failure and exhaustion from trying to hold things together. Sees potential real ally. Opens meaningful strategic discussion. Still cautious about immediate commitments but clearly moved.

ranges.label: Profound Recognition
ranges.summary: Something in Juan's combination—completed crusade, three-day ride, humble words—strikes Sigismund deeply. He's old, tired, nearly given up on finding kings with integrity. This feels different. Opens completely about failures and hopes. Real possibility of deep partnership. Rare moment of connection.

tables.title: Sigismund's Response to Signing Joint Declaration
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan proposes a formal joint declaration (signed by both rulers) supporting church reform via parallel legislation, and asks if Sigismund will sign. This is a commitment to coordinated action and shared position.

ranges.label: Needs More Time
ranges.summary: Sigismund respects the work but won't sign today. He wants his own advisors to review and needs to consider German implications. Not rejection—genuine caution. Proposes exchanging drafts and finalizing by letter over coming weeks. Partnership delayed, not dead.

ranges.label: Wants Modifications First
ranges.summary: Sigismund agrees in principle but insists on changes to specific provisions before signing. Perhaps annates position is too soft, or electoral reform needs carve-outs for imperial interests. Real negotiation over text required. Willing to work through issues but won't rubber-stamp Castilian proposals.

ranges.label: Conditional Agreement
ranges.summary: Sigismund will sign joint declaration but wants to shape the text himself—not just sign Juan's draft. Insists on careful framing that pressures both Pope AND radical conciliarists. Raises concerns about prince-elector elections, annates language, and Bohemian reconciliation. Real negotiation over specifics required before commitment.

ranges.label: Genuine Partnership Forming
ranges.summary: Sigismund sees this as the breakthrough he's sought. Commits to working on joint declaration together. Shares his own ideas about framing and timing. Discusses who at Basel and Rome might support this. Treats Juan as genuine strategic partner. Still cautious but fundamentally committed to the effort.

ranges.label: Strong Alliance
ranges.summary: Juan's combination of learning, concrete thinking, and proven delivery convinces Sigismund this could work. Commits fully to joint declaration. Opens about his contacts and strategies. Begins detailed planning—timing, messengers, approach sequence. Real trust developing between the rulers.

ranges.label: Complete Strategic Partnership
ranges.summary: Sigismund has waited decades for a partner like Juan. Commits enthusiastically, shares everything—his failures, remaining leverage, secret communications. They work as true equals planning the declaration. Beginning of profound alliance between pragmatic strategists.

tables.title: Emperor Sigismund's Disposition at the Signing Ceremony
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan and Emperor Sigismund are about to sign the Declaration of Como, a joint statement on Church reform that they negotiated through the night. The roll determines Sigismund's emotional demeanor and how ceremonially he approaches this pivotal moment.

ranges.label: Weary Formality
ranges.summary: Sigismund signs without ceremony, exhaustion evident. The partnership is real but treated as duty, not triumph. No personal flourishes or words, just signatures in silence.

ranges.label: Cautious Commitment
ranges.summary: Sigismund signs but adds verbal caveats about waiting to see how Rome and Basel receive the declaration. Committed but shadowed by thirty-five years of disappointment and expectation of eventual failure.

ranges.label: Measured Partnership
ranges.summary: Sigismund signs with professional dignity and a firm nod. Neither cold nor warm—the seasoned caution of an old ruler who has learned not to invest too much hope in any document. The partnership is real but temperate.

ranges.label: Genuine Regard
ranges.summary: Sigismund signs and offers something personal—perhaps a toast or acknowledgment of what the partnership means. The weariness lifts somewhat and genuine hope flickers in his eyes.

ranges.label: Ceremonial Flourish
ranges.summary: Sigismund embraces the moment fully. He calls for wine, proposes a formal toast, adds his personal signet. He speaks of this day being remembered and partnerships that change history.

ranges.label: Personal Gift
ranges.summary: Beyond signing, Sigismund offers something unexpected—a personal token, a promise beyond the document, an invitation extending the partnership into new territory. The ceremony becomes a genuine bonding moment.

tables.title: The Journey from Como to Toledo
tables.context: Chaos/Travel — Juan chooses to travel overland through France rather than by sea, prioritizing the certainty of arriving before Isabel's delivery (expected late July/August 1433). The roll determines how well the journey goes and when Juan arrives in Toledo.

ranges.label: STOP: Crisis Requiring Action
ranges.summary: A critical emergency occurs—Fray Hernando collapses and cannot be moved, the party encounters hostile forces, or a local lord detains the group. Narration stops when the crisis begins.

ranges.label: STOP: Complication Requiring Decision
ranges.summary: A significant obstacle emerges—mountain passes blocked, urgent messages arrive, or Fray Hernando falls seriously ill. Party must decide how to proceed.

ranges.label: Delayed Arrival
ranges.summary: Journey takes five weeks instead of four due to weather, illness, or horse problems. Juan arrives mid-July with 2-4 weeks before Isabel's expected delivery—anxious but present.

ranges.label: Standard Journey
ranges.summary: Four weeks as expected with minor inconveniences. Juan arrives in Toledo in first week of July with comfortable margin before Isabel's delivery.

ranges.label: Smooth Travel
ranges.summary: Good weather, fresh horses available, Fray Hernando recovers during the ride. Party maintains excellent pace. Three and a half weeks. Juan arrives Toledo late June, well-rested with ample time.

ranges.label: Swift Passage
ranges.summary: Everything aligns—summer weather perfect, local lords provide escorts recognizing the King, horses stay healthy. Three weeks. Juan arrives June 28th, nearly a month before Isabel's expected delivery.

ranges.label: Exceptional Speed
ranges.summary: Fortune favors the journey in ways beyond planning. Duke of Savoy provides swift horses and guides, Aragonese roads prove fast, every town has fresh mounts. Under three weeks. Juan arrives Toledo before June 25th.

ranges.label: STOP: Unexpected Development (Positive)
ranges.summary: Something remarkable occurs during the journey—a crucial messenger intercepts with important news from Rome or Constantinople, an unexpected significant meeting, or information changing Juan's plans. Narration stops at the development.

tables.title: Isabel's Emotional Reaction to Juan's Return
tables.context: Chaos/Personal — Juan kneels before Isabel, calls her 'my queen, my love,' kisses her hand, and promises not to leave her side during the pregnancy. The roll determines how Isabel emotionally processes this moment given her fear about the risky pregnancy.

ranges.label: Fear Surfaces
ranges.summary: Isabel's composure cracks immediately. Relief spills into fear—she confesses her terror about the physicians' warnings, that she won't survive, that she's been afraid. The reunion becomes about suppressed terror released.

ranges.label: Guarded Relief
ranges.summary: Isabel squeezes his hand and smiles, but something is held back. The words are right but walls are up—weeks of anxiety don't dissolve instantly. She needs time before truly believing he's staying.

ranges.label: Weary Gratitude
ranges.summary: The pregnancy has been hard on Isabel. She looks tired with dark circles, movements careful. Her smile is genuine but exhausted. She needs rest more than romance—the baby moves constantly and sleep is difficult.

ranges.label: Warm Welcome
ranges.summary: Isabel's composure holds but warmth shines through. She returns the hand-squeeze, her smile reaches her eyes. She speaks of the child's strong movements and is genuinely glad he's home—dignified, loving, appropriate for public.

ranges.label: Joy Breaks Through
ranges.summary: The queenly mask slips. Isabel laughs with pure relief, forgets propriety, pulls him up, invites him inside. Her happiness is unguarded and infectious as she wants to hear everything.

ranges.label: Intimate Reunion
ranges.summary: Isabel doesn't care who watches. She cups his face, studying him as if memorizing his features. She admits praying for him daily and thanks him for coming home, barely whispering the words.

ranges.label: Spiritual Peace
ranges.summary: Isabel radiates calm transcending mere relief. She says she knew he would return through prayer and faith. She places his hand on her belly and speaks of 'your son' waiting for him—the moment holds sacred quality.

tables.title: State of the Realm During Juan's Absence
tables.context: Chaos — Álvaro de Luna has managed affairs for two and a half months (April-June 1433). Diego de Daza's reforms continue, the Council of Great Houses functions, and Military Order Masters know of the petition to Rome. This roll determines the overall health of the kingdom and what complications Juan must address.

ranges.label: CRISIS: Major Rebellion or Threat
ranges.summary: A noble faction openly defies crown authority, Military Order Masters refuse cooperation, or external threat demands immediate response. Multiple urgent matters compete for attention.

ranges.label: Significant Problems
ranges.summary: Several concerning developments: Diego's reforms have stalled against noble obstruction, the Council fractured over a dispute, or Military Order Masters quietly organize resistance. Álvaro has contained damage but needs Juan's authority.

ranges.label: Minor Difficulties
ranges.summary: Routine problems accumulated—border dispute with Portugal, tax collection behind projections, a great house grumbling about reform burdens. Nothing critical but decisions await.

ranges.label: Stable but Static
ranges.summary: Kingdom ticks along without major incident. Reforms continue at previous pace—neither accelerating nor regressing. No crises but no significant progress. Álvaro maintained order but avoided initiatives needing royal approval.

ranges.label: Quiet Progress
ranges.summary: Things have gone well. Diego's reforms advanced slightly to 35% implementation, Council of Great Houses resolved a minor dispute without crown intervention, tax revenues meet projections. Realm is healthy and stable.

ranges.label: Notable Successes
ranges.summary: Genuine achievements reported—Diego's reforms reached 40% implementation, Council collected significant underpayments voluntarily, or a diplomatic opportunity emerged. Good news on multiple fronts.

ranges.label: Exceptional Progress
ranges.summary: Realm has flourished in Juan's absence. Reforms accelerating, revenues exceeding projections, Military Order Masters showing unexpected cooperation, or significant diplomatic success. Kingdom stronger than when Juan left.

ranges.label: Unexpected Opportunity
ranges.summary: Beyond good governance, something remarkable emerged—major foreign power seeks alliance, a long-standing problem resolved favorably, or an opportunity for expansion appeared that Juan could not have anticipated.

tables.title: Isabel's Pregnancy Progression
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Isabel is approximately seven months pregnant (conceived December 1432/January 1433) with her second child. She is 17 years old. Her first pregnancy (Catalina, January 1432) ended in a traumatic breech delivery with massive blood loss and severe infection that nearly killed her. Physicians had warned future pregnancies carried elevated risk. Juan has just returned from months abroad (Rome and Basel), and Isabel fears for both her own survival and her unborn child's.

ranges.label: Severe Complications
ranges.summary: Serious problems develop requiring bed rest; bleeding, severe swelling, or other alarming symptoms emerge; physicians deeply concerned and preparing for difficult birth.

ranges.label: Concerning Signs
ranges.summary: Baby not positioned well; Isabel experiencing significant discomfort; physicians worried but maintaining hope for safe delivery.

ranges.label: Difficult but Manageable
ranges.summary: Some worrying indicators but nothing critical; Isabel struggling with fatigue and pain; close monitoring required throughout pregnancy.

ranges.label: Normal Progression
ranges.summary: Typical late-pregnancy discomforts; baby's position uncertain but not alarming; physicians cautiously optimistic about safe delivery.

ranges.label: Good Progression
ranges.summary: Baby positioned correctly; Isabel handling pregnancy well despite previous trauma; physicians relieved and optimistic.

ranges.label: Excellent Progression
ranges.summary: Strong health, baby positioned perfectly; Isabel's body has healed better than expected from Catalina's traumatic birth; physicians genuinely surprised.

ranges.label: Exceptional
ranges.summary: Physicians are genuinely surprised by exceptional progression; everything proceeding better than anyone dared hope; baby positioned correctly; Isabel's health genuinely good; hope has replaced fear.

tables.title: Military Order Masters' Initial Reaction to Papal Decree
tables.context: Diplomacy Roll — Juan presents the papal decree (Fidei Defensio et Corona Triumphans) granting him perpetual and irrevocable control over the Military Orders of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara to the three Masters. The decree strips the Orders of their autonomy and places them under crown authority. The Masters are initially guarded, having come to Toledo expecting to manage a difficult transition.

ranges.label: Formal Compliance, Deep Resistance
ranges.summary: Masters accept decree's legitimacy but body language reveals profound unease; pointed questions about 'reform' border on challenge; written guarantees demanded; withdrawal into silence; minimal cooperation with extensive negotiations needed.

ranges.label: Cautious Acceptance, Significant Concerns
ranges.summary: Masters acknowledge new reality but press hard for specifics on reform, property protections, and guarantees against dissolution; the 1000-knight commitment made without consultation is raised as concern; productive meeting but trust must be built gradually.

ranges.label: Guarded Cooperation
ranges.summary: Masters accept Juan's vision but remain watchful; appreciate leadership continuity and clear mission but want specifics; request follow-up meeting to discuss practical details; professional rather than warm tone.

ranges.label: Constructive Engagement
ranges.summary: Masters genuinely receptive to Juan's vision; Don Pedro responds to clarity of purpose; Don Luis acknowledges crown authority could strengthen Orders; don Juan de Sotomayor relaxes when traditions emphasized; practical dialogue begins.

ranges.label: Positive Reception
ranges.summary: Masters respond well; Don Pedro moved by vision of continued crusading purpose; Don Luis offers concrete suggestions; Sotomayor proposes specialization roles; conversation shifts from defensive to cooperative.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Cooperation
ranges.summary: Juan's speech strikes right notes; Don Pedro declares renewed purpose; Don Luis acknowledges graceful handling of transition; Sotomayor volunteers knights for War Academy; Masters begin discussing implementation among themselves.

ranges.label: Wholehearted Embrace
ranges.summary: Masters genuinely inspired; Don Pedro weeps from relief and renewed purpose; Don Luis sets aside calculation and speaks from heart; Sotomayor pledges full commitment; meeting transforms into planning session with all three competing to contribute ideas.

tables.title: Don Juan de Sotomayor's Strategic Response on Constantinople
tables.context: Military Roll — Juan asks Don Juan de Sotomayor, Master of Alcántara, for his professional military opinion on the Constantinople situation. Sotomayor has just received written guarantees for Alcántara's continued existence and has been elevated in status. He is being asked to analyze a situation outside his direct experience but within his expertise in garrison warfare and difficult operations.

ranges.label: Defensive Deflection
ranges.summary: Sotomayor freezes, uncomfortable at being singled out; deflects to senior Masters; wastes opportunity and appears weak; room's mood shifts unfavorably.

ranges.label: Cautious Non-Answer
ranges.summary: Hedges extensively acknowledging inexperience; offers no insights, questions, or engagement with problem; technically honest but unhelpful and momentum dies.

ranges.label: Honest Limitation, Minimal Contribution
ranges.summary: Acknowledges inexperience but offers only generic observations about supply lines and garrison morale; nothing particularly useful and other Masters unimpressed.

ranges.label: Cautious but Constructive
ranges.summary: Admits limits but engages seriously; asks practical questions about reinforcement, duration, Greek support; frames contribution as garrison commander's perspective rather than pretending expertise.

ranges.label: Practical Military Thinking
ranges.summary: Draws on actual expertise in frontier posts; raises logistics, rotation, exit strategy; asks penetrating questions about Greek reliability; demonstrates solid judgment within experience.

ranges.label: Valuable Contribution
ranges.summary: Distinguishes between reinforcing defensible city versus sending men to lost cause; proposes phased approach with assessment before full commitment; includes extraction planning; Don Luis nods approval.

ranges.label: Impressive Insight
ranges.summary: Demonstrates unexpected strategic depth; outlines three-stage phased approach (vanguard, assessment, calibrated commitment); raises extraction planning and assessment mechanisms; Don Luis acknowledges wisdom; earns genuine respect.

ranges.label: Exceptional
ranges.summary: Seizes opportunity brilliantly; provides coherent framework addressing military and political dimensions; addresses own candidacy disarmingly making himself obvious choice without claiming it; even Don Luis approves political craftsmanship.

tables.title: Don Juan de Sotomayor's Political Navigation on Leadership
tables.context: Intrigue Roll — Juan has just asked Sotomayor to propose force composition and leadership for the Constantinople vanguard mission. Sotomayor must navigate between his own ambitions, the sensitivities of the senior Masters, and the political dynamics of three powerful men. His previous impressive military analysis (roll: 91) has established him as a serious voice, and he risks either overreaching or appearing to retreat.

ranges.label: Overreach
ranges.summary: Success goes to his head; proposes himself as commander too eagerly; Don Luis's expression hardens; room's mood shifts; credibility damaged by apparent self-promotion.

ranges.label: Retreat into Caution
ranges.summary: Fear of overstepping causes retreat; deflects ('Leadership must be Your Majesty's decision'); momentum dies; opportunity wasted and Juan must draw him out further.

ranges.label: Safe but Unremarkable
ranges.summary: Handles composition well (shared contribution from all Orders) but punts on leadership with only general criteria; competent but uninspired; Juan must guide further.

ranges.label: Diplomatic but Clear
ranges.summary: Proposes balanced composition and carefully suggests leadership criteria that happen to describe himself without naming himself; door opened without walking through it uninvited.

ranges.label: Graceful Positioning
ranges.summary: Addresses composition thoughtfully and handles leadership with political skill; acknowledges own interest openly as honesty rather than grasping; clearly available while appearing humble.

ranges.label: Masterful Navigation
ranges.summary: Proposes structure serving everyone: mixed force from all Orders plus crown observers, with leadership rotating in ways giving each Order stakes; reframes question about his candidacy disarmingly making himself obvious choice while appearing selfless; Don Luis actually nods approval.

ranges.label: Exceptional Statesmanship
ranges.summary: Transcends political trap entirely; reframes question elevating entire discussion; demonstrates mission success matters more than personal glory making himself only logical choice while appearing selfless; even Don Luis impressed.

ranges.label: Legendary Performance
ranges.summary: Performs at the highest level of political and military sophistication; masters competing interests; makes himself indispensable through demonstrated wisdom; transforms potential rivalry into admiration.

tables.title: The Deus Vult Covenant
tables.context: Personal Roll — Juan concludes his meeting with the three Military Order Masters by drawing his sword, kissing the blade, and invoking 'Deus Vult!' He invites the Masters to join him in this symbolic gesture of renewed crusading purpose and brotherhood. The meeting has recovered from its cautious start (roll: 15) through genuine consultation and respect, and now Juan is sealing this partnership with symbolic ritual.

ranges.label: Awkward Hesitation
ranges.summary: Moment falls flat; Masters exchange uncertain glances; silence stretches; muted responses; invocation dies in air; Juan has misjudged mood; trust building but brotherhood cannot be rushed.

ranges.label: Dutiful Compliance
ranges.summary: Masters draw swords and respond but with formality rather than fire; honoring king not sharing passion; gesture feels like ceremony rather than transformation.

ranges.label: Measured Participation
ranges.summary: Don Pedro responds first with genuine emotion; Sotomayor follows with gratitude-warmed conviction; Don Luis joins last with controlled response; genuine but uneven foundation.

ranges.label: Genuine Response
ranges.summary: Meeting's success translates into authentic participation; Don Pedro's sword rises with fierce joy; all voices join genuinely; partnership sealed but not yet thunderous.

ranges.label: Warm Embrace
ranges.summary: Masters respond with genuine enthusiasm; Don Pedro's joy rings clear; Sotomayor's conviction strong; Don Luis allows passion to enter; four voices create moment these men will remember.

ranges.label: Powerful Unity
ranges.summary: Something shifts in room; Don Pedro roars before Juan finishes; Sotomayor follows instantly; Don Luis joins with passion carrying decades of crusading faith; political complexities fade; four warriors pledge themselves to God's work.

ranges.label: Transcendent Moment
ranges.summary: Invocation catches fire; all three Masters respond with immediate full-throated conviction; Don Luis's dignity falls away revealing knight of Christ; Sotomayor's eyes shine; Don Pedro weeps unashamed; 'Deus Vult!' thundered like covenant not ceremony.

ranges.label: Legendary Brotherhood
ranges.summary: Four swords rise as one; Masters transform from political subordinates into brothers-in-arms; Don Luis steps forward and clasps Juan's sword-arm in gesture of brotherhood between equals; acknowledgment that this is not ceremony but permanent covenant forged in moment of genuine spiritual and martial commitment.

tables.title: University Rectors' Response to Educational Vision
tables.context: Diplomacy Roll — Juan proposes ambitious educational expansion: support for universities training administrative nobles, expansion into natural sciences and mathematics, learning from Muslim scholarly traditions, and founding a new university in Granada focused on natural sciences. He mentions that Islam has retained and expanded knowledge, and that Castile must advance to meet Ottoman challenges. The two Rectors are Don Diego de Anaya (Salamanca, age ~80, conservative) and Don Lope de Barrientos (Valladolid, age ~50, politically savvy).

ranges.label: Alarmed Resistance
ranges.summary: Both Rectors react poorly; Don Diego raises sharp theological objections to learning from Muslims; Don Lope distances himself from controversial proposals; mention of astrology draws correction and concern; both oppose Granada university as heretical; Juan has badly misjudged audience.

ranges.label: Defensive Caution
ranges.summary: Rectors exchange worried glances; Don Diego lectures on proper knowledge hierarchy with theology supreme; Don Lope carefully explains Church concerns; neither directly opposes but seek to delay and protect institutions.

ranges.label: Polite Skepticism
ranges.summary: Rectors receive ideas with professional courtesy but evident reservations; Don Diego acknowledges Islamic contributions in past tense; Don Lope raises practical concerns about Church approval; willing to discuss but uncomfortable with direction.

ranges.label: Cautious Engagement
ranges.summary: Rectors take proposals seriously while raising legitimate concerns; Don Diego corrects astrology to astronomy explaining distinction; Don Lope notes precedent for learning from Muslim texts with proper oversight; both concerned about Granada university but willing to discuss conditions.

ranges.label: Interested but Careful
ranges.summary: Rectors engage genuinely with vision; Don Diego shows intellectual curiosity about Islamic achievements; Don Lope sees opportunity for Valladolid; both raise concerns about Church approval as problems to solve rather than reasons to abandon.

ranges.label: Thoughtful Reception
ranges.summary: Rectors respond with more enthusiasm than expected; Don Diego recounts Salamanca's own history of learning from Arabic texts; Don Lope suggests frameworks for theological oversight; Granada university draws genuine interest rather than opposition with focus on practical safeguards.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Engagement
ranges.summary: Juan has struck a chord; Don Diego speaks with passion about knowledge that might be recovered; Don Lope immediately strategizes Church approval; both offer concrete suggestions and active partnership with concerns framed as problems to solve.

ranges.label: Inspired Response
ranges.summary: Rectors are genuinely excited; Don Diego speaks with fire of dreams from youth; Don Lope sees chance to shape something historic; both offer support and active partnership with immediate solution proposals.

ranges.label: Transformative Conversation
ranges.summary: Remarkable transformation occurs; Don Diego speaks with fire of finding calling again; Don Lope pledges Valladolid's full cooperation; conversation becomes planning session expanding Juan's initial vision; genuine intellectual partnership forged.

tables.title: Queen Isabel's Delivery Outcome
tables.context: Medical/Chaos — Isabel of Portugal, Queen of Castile, is in the final weeks of her pregnancy in early August 1433. After an exceptional pregnancy progression (Roll 100 in Chapter 2.10), she goes into labor on August 3rd. The delivery outcome will determine the fate of both mother and child, with factors ranging from miraculous success to catastrophic failure.

ranges.label: CATASTROPHIC - Both Lost
ranges.summary: Isabel hemorrhages catastrophically during labor. Despite physicians' desperate efforts, both Isabel and the unborn baby die within hours. Juan loses his wife and heir, triggering an immediate succession crisis and devastating grief.

ranges.label: DISASTER - Isabel Lost, Baby Survives
ranges.summary: The baby—a healthy boy—is delivered safely, but Isabel bleeds heavily afterward. After hours of futile attempts to stop the hemorrhaging, Isabel dies in Juan's arms while holding her newborn son once. The heir lives at terrible cost to his mother.

ranges.label: SEVERE CRISIS - Isabel Survives Barely, Long Recovery
ranges.summary: A healthy boy is born, but complications during delivery cause severe bleeding and infection. Isabel survives but hovers near death for weeks with high fever, eventually stabilizing but permanently damaged. Physicians forbid any future pregnancies.

ranges.label: DIFFICULT - Complications but Both Survive
ranges.summary: Labor is harder than expected with significant tearing and bleeding, but Isabel's robust health allows her to survive. Both mother and child make it through, though recovery will take 4-6 weeks and the physicians advise waiting 2-3 years before another pregnancy.

ranges.label: MODERATE - Normal Difficult Delivery
ranges.summary: Labor takes most of a day with expected pain and fear, but proceeds without major complications. A healthy boy is born with normal bleeding afterward. Recovery takes 2-3 weeks with no serious complications developing.

ranges.label: GOOD - Smooth Delivery
ranges.summary: The exceptional pregnancy proves prophetic. Labor is swift—baby arrives by evening with minimal assistance and bleeding. Isabel recovers within 1-2 weeks, and the physicians are cautiously optimistic about future pregnancies.

ranges.label: EXCELLENT - Remarkably Easy
ranges.summary: Against all expectation, the delivery is almost easy. Labor is mere hours, the baby practically presents himself, and Isabel's previous damage has healed remarkably. Recovery within a week; physicians believe future pregnancies are genuinely possible.

ranges.label: EXCEPTIONAL - Perfect Delivery, Perfect Child
ranges.summary: Everything goes right. Swift, gentle labor; vigorous, healthy infant; minimal bleeding; rapid recovery. By the next morning, Isabel is sitting up and demanding to see her daughter. Physicians are genuinely amazed.

ranges.label: MIRACULOUS - Twins
ranges.summary: A miraculous delivery of twins—twin boys, both healthy, both crying strong. The physicians cross themselves. Isabel weeps with joy. Castile has two princes—an heir and a spare, securing the dynasty twice over.

tables.title: Does King Alfonso V of Aragon Attend Fernando's Baptism Personally?
tables.context: Diplomacy — King Alfonso V of Aragon has been named godfather to Prince Fernando of Castile. He is currently managing his Naples campaign from Sicily. The question is whether he will personally attend the baptism in Toledo on October 15, 1433, or send a proxy (likely Queen María or another representative).
tables.outcome_label: Alfonso attends with full honors and extended stay

ranges.label: Critical Military Situation
ranges.summary: Alfonso cannot attend due to urgent military developments in Italy. He sends Queen María as proxy with substantial retinue and gifts, along with a personal letter expressing regret but explaining necessity. The relationship remains undamaged but the opportunity for personal connection is missed.

ranges.label: Queen María as Full Proxy
