ranges.summary: Alfonso decides rationally that he cannot leave Naples preparations for 2+ months. Queen María travels as full proxy with complete legitimacy and substantial retinue. Alfonso sends personal letter expressing genuine regret. This is an honorable solution, properly managed.

ranges.label: Abbreviated Personal Attendance
ranges.summary: Alfonso attends but with minimal entourage and tight timeline. He arrives days before and departs within a week after, clearly balancing obligations. Some tension about his abbreviated presence, but the essential act is accomplished and Juan understands the constraints.

ranges.label: Appropriate Ceremony
ranges.summary: Alfonso attends with appropriate ceremony, arriving a week before and staying through celebrations. He brings significant retinue befitting his status as godfather and participates fully in the baptism and feast, taking opportunity to discuss alliance matters with Juan.

ranges.label: Full Honors and Extended Stay
ranges.summary: Alfonso attends with full honors and extended stay, viewing this as investment in the Iberian alliance. He arrives early, participates fully, and uses the occasion for substantial diplomatic discussions about Constantinople expedition, Naples coordination, and future cooperation. His presence signals serious commitment to partnership.

ranges.label: Unexpected News or Proposal
ranges.summary: Alfonso arrives with significant developments in Naples (positive or negative) that he wants to discuss in person, or brings additional diplomatic proposals beyond the baptism. His attendance becomes more than ceremonial—a working summit disguised as family occasion.

tables.title: Constantinople's Condition in October 1433
tables.context: Chaos — The vanguard of 300 Castilian knights under Sotomayor landed in Constantinople on August 22, 1433. By mid-October, reports would be arriving about the actual condition of the city and the state of Ottoman pressure. This determines what kind of emergency Juan is facing.

ranges.label: Crisis: Ottoman Pressure Intensifying
ranges.summary: Murad II has increased military presence around Constantinople. Raiding parties probe defenses and tribute demands have increased. Wall sections are in critical condition. Sotomayor estimates the city can hold perhaps two years without major reinforcement. The situation is dire and desperate, requiring massive immediate intervention.

ranges.label: Dire: Slow Decay
ranges.summary: No active siege, but the city is dying slowly. Population has fallen below 50,000 across an area built for a million. Entire districts stand empty. Walls show decades of deferred maintenance. Ottoman control of surrounding territory means food prices are extortionate. Castilian knights are received gratefully but with skepticism—they've seen Western promises before. The Emperor requests sustained commitment, not just temporary reinforcement.

ranges.label: Precarious: Stable But Vulnerable
ranges.summary: Current Ottoman-Byzantine relations are tense but not actively hostile. The walls are acceptable in most sections but need significant work in others. The Castilian vanguard has been well-received as proof that Western aid is real. Sotomayor reports 1,000 knights could meaningfully strengthen defenses, but long-term survival requires either massive Western intervention or fundamental change in Ottoman power.

ranges.label: Hopeful: A Window of Opportunity
ranges.summary: Murad II is distracted by Karamanid challenges in Anatolia and Serbian/Hungarian resistance in the Balkans. Ottoman pressure on Constantinople has actually decreased since 1424. The walls are being repaired with Castilian funding. Morale has improved dramatically. The Emperor proposes ambitious coordination: Castilian naval power, joint operations, possible recovery of lost territories.

ranges.label: Encouraging: Byzantine Resurgence Possible
ranges.summary: The Morea under Constantine Palaiologos is successfully pushing back against Ottoman and Latin forces. Serbian and Hungarian resistance is tying down Ottoman armies. There is genuine possibility of a coordinated Christian counter-offensive if Western powers commit. The Emperor proposes unprecedented formal military alliance with specific commitments and joint command structures.

ranges.label: Unexpected: A Byzantine Proposal
ranges.summary: Beyond military alliance, the Emperor makes a dynastic proposal. With Juan widowed and needing to remarry, John VIII suggests a Byzantine princess to cement Castile's commitment through blood ties. The military situation is precarious but stable; the proposal is strategic positioning for the long-term.

ranges.label: Remarkable: Ottoman Internal Crisis
ranges.summary: News reaches Constantinople that Murad II faces serious internal challenges. A pretender has raised rebellion in Anatolia. For the first time in decades, Constantinople is not immediately threatened. The Emperor sees this as a once-in-generation opportunity: if Christian powers coordinate NOW, they might permanently weaken Ottoman power.

tables.title: Marriage Delegation to Ferrara — Success of Negotiation
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan's diplomatic delegation led by Don Íñigo López de Mendoza travels to Ferrara with papal endorsement to negotiate Juan's marriage to Lucia d'Este, niece of Marquess Niccolò III. The roll determines how favorably the Este family receives the proposal and whether Lucia herself accepts.

ranges.label: Outright Refusal
ranges.summary: The Este firmly refuse despite papal pressure. Something has gone wrong—perhaps rumors of Juan's mental instability, or Lucia has refused, or Niccolò has received a better offer. The delegation returns empty-handed with an apologetic letter. The marriage will not happen.

ranges.label: Conditional Refusal
ranges.summary: The Este are interested in principle but have serious concerns and request time to consider. Concerns cited include Juan's haste in remarrying, the distance from Italy, and questions about Castilian court culture. The door is not closed but significant additional effort would be required.

ranges.label: Negotiations Required
ranges.summary: The Este are willing to proceed but demand significant concessions: larger dowry arrangements, guarantees about Lucia's status and household, commitments about her Italian attendants, or territorial concessions. Final agreement is possible but not certain.

ranges.label: Cautious Acceptance
ranges.summary: The match is agreed in principle. Lucia has consented. Terms are reasonable. However, the Este want time for proper arrangements—wedding perhaps in spring 1434. Formal betrothal documents will be signed, but Lucia will not travel immediately.

ranges.label: Favorable Acceptance
ranges.summary: The papal endorsement and Juan's prestige carry the day. Lucia herself is intrigued by Juan's unconventional letter. The Este see strategic value in the alliance. Terms are agreed quickly, betrothal formalized. Lucia could travel to Castile by early 1434.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Acceptance
ranges.summary: Lucia is genuinely interested—Juan's letter struck a chord with a sharp-tongued woman tired of Italian marriage politics. Niccolò sees significant advantage in alliance with the conqueror of Granada. The Este propose accelerated timeline. Possibility of wedding before Juan's Constantinople expedition in spring 1434.

ranges.label: Exceptional Success
ranges.summary: Not only does Lucia accept, but she exceeds expectations. She requests to meet Juan privately before the wedding (unusual but intriguing), or Niccolò offers additional diplomatic commitments, or the match creates ripple effects that strengthen Castile's position in Italian politics generally. The delegation exceeds all expectations. Lucia departs for Castile immediately.

tables.title: Noble Reaction to Juan's Unconventional Conduct at Baptism Feast
tables.context: Chaos — Juan breaks protocol dramatically by leaving the high table to circulate personally among the noble families, carrying Catalina in his arms, sitting with houses, asking after their personal affairs, and ultimately leaving his daughter with the Velasco family (a house with historical grievances) while greeting other guests. This measures the collective reaction of the assembled nobility.

ranges.label: Backfire — Concerns Amplified
ranges.summary: The unconventional behavior rekindles whispers about Juan's mental state after Isabel's death. Nobles see manic energy, not warmth. The Velasco gesture is seen as slight to Álvaro. Overall impression: the king is becoming unpredictable, possibly unstable. Álvaro will hear troubling reports.

ranges.label: Mixed Reception — Confusion Dominates
ranges.summary: Nobles don't know what to make of it. Some are touched, others suspicious, most simply bewildered. The gesture doesn't land cleanly because it's so far outside expectations. No lasting damage, but no real benefit either. The story becomes 'the king did something strange.'

ranges.label: Polite Appreciation — Surface Only
ranges.summary: Nobles respond correctly in the moment but privately wonder about motivations. The warmth doesn't penetrate to genuine relationship-building. Protocol has been breached but not catastrophically. Life continues as before.

ranges.label: Genuine but Limited Warmth
ranges.summary: The families Juan spent significant time with (Mendoza, Manrique, Velasco) are genuinely touched. Others who received only brief acknowledgment appreciate the gesture but don't feel transformed. Overall positive but the effect is uneven. The Velasco gesture is noted and appreciated by that house.

ranges.label: Broad Positive Reception
ranges.summary: Most nobles interpret the circuit as Juan valuing them as people. Stories spread of the king feeding his daughter at table, asking after grandsons, letting Catalina play with Velasco girl. Juan's reputation for humanity grows significantly.

ranges.label: Strongly Positive — Loyalty Deepened
ranges.summary: The gesture lands powerfully. Nobles feel seen and valued by their king. The Velasco situation specifically begins healing old wounds—Don Pedro tells his household the king trusted them with his daughter. Families who had been neutral toward Juan find themselves warming. This will be remembered.

ranges.label: Transformative — Stories for Generations
ranges.summary: The night becomes legendary. For years afterward, nobles will tell their children: 'I was there when King Juan walked among us with Princess Catalina. He sat with us. He asked after our families. He trusted us with his daughter.' The gesture transcends politics and becomes part of Juan's personal mythology. Houses with grievances find them harder to maintain.

ranges.label: Watershed Moment — Noble Culture Shifts
ranges.summary: Juan's reputation soars and his behavior begins influencing how Castilian nobility think about kingship itself. Younger lords wonder if they should be more accessible to their vassals. Rigid hierarchies of the court soften. The Velasco reconciliation becomes a model for how old feuds might be buried. Juan has inadvertently begun reshaping relationships between crown and nobility.

tables.title: Lucia d'Este's Reaction to First Meeting with Juan
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan greets Lucia d'Este privately in the solar for the first time, introducing his children (Catalina and Fernando), providing Castilian wine and Ferrarese delicacies, and showing her the thoughtful setting he has prepared. Lucia has traveled across Europe based solely on a letter. This measures how well Juan's approach resonates with her.

ranges.label: Cool Reception
ranges.summary: Something is wrong—exhaustion from travel, disappointment with Juan in person, or the immediate introduction of children feeling like manipulation rather than warmth. Lucia is polite but distant. Her sharp tongue finds something to critique. The evening is awkward; the connection remains unformed.

ranges.label: Guarded Assessment
ranges.summary: Lucia remains in evaluation mode throughout. She is courteous and appropriate but gives nothing away. She watches Juan with those storm-grey eyes, measuring every gesture. She engages with Catalina politely but without warmth. The letter was promising; the man remains to be proven.

ranges.label: Cautious Interest
ranges.summary: The approach lands acceptably. Lucia appreciates the informality but maintains her reserve—she did not travel across Europe to fall into anyone's arms on the first evening. She warms slightly to Catalina but keeps Juan at careful distance. A foundation is laid, but not yet a connection.

ranges.label: Pleasant Surprise
ranges.summary: Lucia expected a king; she found a father. The children's presence softens her defenses more than she anticipated. She engages genuinely with Catalina, appreciates the Ferrarese touches, and her sharp tongue emerges playfully rather than critically. She is willing to be convinced.

ranges.label: Genuine Warmth
ranges.summary: Juan's approach matches his letter—this is the man she hoped to find. Lucia relaxes visibly, her political caution giving way to real engagement. She speaks to Catalina directly, makes wry comments about wine selection that invite response. The connection begins to form.

ranges.label: Delighted Recognition
ranges.summary: Lucia finds exactly what she traveled across Europe hoping to find—a man who sees her as a person and leads with his heart. Catalina's approval matters to her. The evening flows naturally into conversation, wine, and genuine laughter. The match will be good.

ranges.label: Immediate Connection
ranges.summary: Something clicks between them. The children, the simple 'I am Juan,' the thoughtfulness of the Ferrarese cheeses—everything lands perfectly. Lucia's carefully maintained reserve crumbles faster than she expected. She came prepared to evaluate; she finds herself instead simply enjoying. This is better than she dared hope.

ranges.label: Extraordinary Chemistry
ranges.summary: Lucia expected to meet a king and judge whether she could tolerate marriage. Instead she meets a man she actively wants to know better. Everything exceeds her hopes. By evening's end, the political arrangement has transformed into something that feels like the beginning of genuine partnership.

tables.title: Lucia d'Este's Reaction to Juan's Proposal
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan kneels before Lucia in the moonlit garden, presenting the sapphire ring specifically designed for her and Italian aesthetics. He has confessed his faith, listened to her concerns, offered genuine partnership, and is now formally asking her to choose him as her husband, despite the diplomatic arrangement already being agreed.

ranges.label: Hesitation — Fear Wins
ranges.summary: The moment is too much. Lucia's defenses snap back into place. She doesn't refuse but pulls back—asks for time, space, a chance to think. The evening ends awkwardly. The connection remains but the proposal hangs unanswered. Much repair work needed.

ranges.label: Cautious Acceptance
ranges.summary: Lucia says yes, but guardedly. The walls have not fully come down. She accepts the ring but her words are measured and careful. She is committing to the arrangement, not yet to the man.

ranges.label: Thoughtful Yes
ranges.summary: Lucia accepts with sincerity but without overwhelming emotion. She is moved and willing, but also realistic. She says yes knowing that trust must still be built and promises must be proven over time. A solid foundation, but not yet the deep connection Juan might have hoped for.

ranges.label: Warm Acceptance
ranges.summary: Lucia's answer is yes, and she means it. The evening has convinced her this match could be good. She accepts the ring with genuine pleasure and allows herself to hope. But part of her remains watchful, waiting to see if the man matches the promises.

ranges.label: Joyful Yes
ranges.summary: The walls come down. Lucia accepts with visible emotion—perhaps tears, perhaps laughter, perhaps both. The connection forged tonight has become something real and powerful. She is choosing him fully and without reservation. The partnership begins now.

ranges.label: Wholehearted Acceptance
ranges.summary: Lucia does not merely accept—she embraces. Perhaps she pulls him to his feet. Perhaps she kisses him. The connection has become real and powerful. She is not just agreeing to marry him; she is choosing him fully. The partnership begins immediately.

ranges.label: Transcendent Moment
ranges.summary: Something shifts. Lucia's acceptance becomes more than a yes—it becomes a vow. She speaks of what she sees in him and what she hopes to build together. The ring fits like it was always meant to be there. This is the beginning of a true partnership, perhaps even love.

ranges.label: Perfect Union
ranges.summary: Everything aligns perfectly. Lucia matches his vulnerability with her own, his vision with her dreams. The proposal becomes a mutual declaration—not just his asking and her accepting, but two people recognizing in each other something rare and precious. The marriage has not yet happened, but the partnership has already begun.

tables.title: Council of Great Houses: Development (November 1432 - November 1433)
tables.context: Intrigue — The Council was founded by Don Íñigo López de Mendoza as a voluntary noble cooperation system where great families police themselves and consult on major decisions. After one year of operation following the transformative baptism feast (87/100 roll), the Council's development is being assessed.

ranges.label: Unexpected Setback
ranges.summary: A scandal emerges that damages the Council despite favorable conditions. Perhaps an audit reveals something embarrassing about a founding member, or a bitter feud between members spills public. Four houses total; collections around 20,000 maravedís. Don Íñigo must manage a crisis before growth can resume.

ranges.label: Modest Progress
ranges.summary: Two new houses join, bringing total to five. Collections around 30,000 maravedís. The institution is stable but hasn't captured post-baptism momentum. Some houses remain cautious, wanting more track record. Solid foundation but patience required.

ranges.label: Solid Growth
ranges.summary: Three to four new houses have joined, including at least one previously skeptical. Total membership of six to seven great families. Collections of 40,000-50,000 maravedís. The Council meets regularly and has begun informal consultations on matters affecting the nobility. The model is proving itself.

ranges.label: Strong Development
ranges.summary: Five new houses join, bringing membership to eight families. The Enríquez and at least one other prominent house signed on. Collections exceed 55,000 maravedís. The Council is becoming recognized; non-member houses quietly inquiring about joining. Don Íñigo's vision is vindicated.

ranges.label: Remarkable Success
ranges.summary: Six to seven new houses join; the Velascos have either joined or signaled serious interest. Total membership approaches ten great families. Collections reach 70,000-80,000 maravedís. The Council has begun mediating disputes between members. Non-member houses feel pressure to join or explain their absence.

ranges.label: Exceeds Expectations
ranges.summary: Eight or more new houses join, including former skeptics. The Council represents clear majority of great nobility. Collections exceed 90,000 maravedís. The institution proposes its own initiatives—standardized practices, coordinated responses. Membership is mark of prestige; remaining outside requires explanation.

ranges.label: Transformative Institution
ranges.summary: The Council becomes the voice of Castile's high nobility. Virtually all great houses are members or seeking membership. Collections exceed 100,000 maravedís. The Council mediates disputes, coordinates charity, serves as formal consultative body. Don Íñigo celebrated as visionary. Crown-nobility relationship has fundamentally shifted toward partnership.

tables.title: Princess Catalina: Early Childhood Development (19 months old)
tables.context: Personal — Catalina is now 19 months old, having experienced both trauma (mother Isabel's death at 10 months) and extraordinary love (devoted father, stable household, new maternal figure). Her emerging personality and temperament are being assessed based on her interactions, learning speed, emotional resilience, and social adaptability.

ranges.label: Troubling Signs
ranges.summary: Catalina is withdrawn, prone to disproportionate tantrums, slow to warm to new people. She clings desperately to familiar faces and reacts poorly to change. Loss of mother may have affected her deeply. Emotionally fragile; will need extra patience, stability, and care.

ranges.label: Slow to Bloom
ranges.summary: Catalina is quiet and watchful, slow to speak compared to peers. Not unintelligent but cautious; observes before acting, holds back before engaging. Forms attachments slowly but deeply. Unclear whether natural temperament or response to early loss. Physically average.

ranges.label: Ordinary Child
ranges.summary: Catalina is a normal, healthy toddler—neither remarkably quick nor notably slow. Has good days and bad days, laughs and cries, tests boundaries and seeks comfort. No particular gifts or challenges yet. Attached to father and caregivers; adapts reasonably well to new situations. Developing at typical pace.

ranges.label: Bright and Willful
ranges.summary: Catalina shows clear intelligence—learns new words quickly, remembers things she's told, makes connections that surprise adults. But also stubborn with strong will and clear preferences. Knows what she wants and protests when denied. This will make her challenging to raise but may serve her well as adult. Physically healthy and energetic.

ranges.label: Warm and Quick
ranges.summary: Catalina combines genuine intelligence with sunny, affectionate disposition. Curious, eager to learn, quick to laugh, forms bonds easily. Handled mother's loss with remarkable resilience—sad at times but not broken. Adapts well to new situations. Genuinely delightful child who brings joy to those around her. Robust health.

ranges.label: Exceptional Child
ranges.summary: Catalina displays notably advanced development—speaking in complex sentences earlier than expected, demonstrating memory and reasoning that surprise experienced caregivers. Combines intelligence with emotional warmth and social confidence. Brave, generous, adaptable. Portuguese ladies remark she reminds them of Isabel at her best. Excellent health and physical coordination.

ranges.label: Remarkable in Every Way
ranges.summary: Catalina is extraordinary—kind of child who makes adults pause and reassess toddler capabilities. Intelligence obvious but not cold; combines quick understanding with genuine empathy. Reads emotions, comforts others, navigates social situations with uncanny grace for her age. Processed mother's absence in remarkably mature ways. Physically robust, coordinated, fearless. People remember her.

ranges.label: A Gift from God
ranges.summary: Catalina is touched by something beyond ordinary human capacity. Intelligence borders on unsettling—understands things no toddler should grasp, remembers everything, sometimes says things that make adults wonder if she sees more than they do. Paired with profound kindness and almost supernatural warmth. Healthy, beautiful, brave, wise beyond years. Destined for remarkable things.

tables.title: Journey to Madrid (December 1433)
tables.context: Chaos Roll — The royal party (King Juan, Queen Lucia, Princess Catalina, 40 men-at-arms, 2 Italian ladies, advance party) travels 13 leagues from Toledo to Madrid on the Castilian plateau in December weather.

ranges.label: Severe Weather Crisis
ranges.summary: A sudden winter storm descends on the plateau with driving sleet, bitter wind, and near-zero visibility. The party must seek emergency shelter in a village or roadside inn, arriving cold, miserable, and delayed by a full day. Catalina catches a minor chill that recovers in days.

ranges.label: Difficult Weather
ranges.summary: Heavy grey skies, biting wind, and intermittent freezing rain create miserable riding conditions. Catalina fusses and cries for much of the journey, refusing comfort. Everyone arrives exhausted and cold with frayed tempers.

ranges.label: Minor Delays
ranges.summary: A horse throws a shoe, a pack horse goes lame, or muddy roads slow progress significantly. Arrival is pushed to after dark. Catalina falls asleep mid-journey and wakes cranky. Uneventful but tedious.

ranges.label: Routine Journey
ranges.summary: Cold but manageable December weather. Catalina alternates between horses as planned, naps once under heavy cloaks, eats dried apricots, and arrives tired but content. A successful family trip with nothing remarkable.

ranges.label: Pleasant Journey
ranges.summary: Crisp, clear winter day with good visibility across the plateau. Catalina is delighted by everything, chattering happily and behaving beautifully. The party makes good time and arrives before expected. A genuinely enjoyable ride for the family.

ranges.label: Memorable Moment
ranges.summary: Something small but charming happens: Catalina says a new word, spots a hawk and is enchanted, or falls asleep in Lucia's arms in a moving way. The journey becomes a treasured family memory rather than mere travel.

ranges.label: Unexpected Encounter
ranges.summary: The party meets someone of interest on the road—a merchant with news from the north, a minor noble traveling to Toledo, or pilgrims heading south. An opportunity for brief but meaningful interaction.

ranges.label: First Snow
ranges.summary: Light snowfall begins as the party travels—Catalina's first real experience of snow. She is utterly enchanted, trying to catch flakes and squealing with delight. The landscape is dusted white at arrival.

ranges.label: Perfect Day
ranges.summary: Everything aligns: bright winter sun, crisp air, Catalina happy and well-behaved, easy pace, early arrival. The hunting lodge is warm and welcoming with fires already lit. The family settles in feeling genuinely relaxed.

tables.title: Lucia's Conception Timeline
tables.context: Fertility Roll — Juan (21) and Lucia (23) are both young and healthy, married December 3, 1433. The succession is urgent, and both are motivated to conceive. No known fertility complications for either party.

ranges.label: Delayed Fertility
ranges.summary: Despite regular relations, Lucia does not conceive through winter, spring, or summer 1434. No medical explanation—simply nature's uncertainty. Conception possible in autumn 1434 or later. Court whispers begin quietly.

ranges.label: Late Summer 1434
ranges.summary: Lucia conceives in July or August 1434. Pregnancy confirmed by early autumn. Child due spring 1435. A reasonable timeline, though the wait through spring and early summer brings some anxiety.

ranges.label: Early Summer 1434
ranges.summary: Lucia conceives in May or June 1434, likely around the time of or shortly after the Constantinople expedition. Pregnancy confirmed by mid-summer. Child due late winter/early spring 1435.

ranges.label: Spring 1434
ranges.summary: Lucia conceives in March or April 1434. Pregnancy confirmed by late spring. Child due December 1434 or January 1435. A welcome timeline—news arrives as Juan prepares for Constantinople journey.

ranges.label: Late Winter 1434
ranges.summary: Lucia conceives in February 1434. Pregnancy confirmed by early spring. Child due November or December 1434. The succession question begins to resolve relatively quickly.

ranges.label: Early Winter 1434
ranges.summary: Lucia conceives in January 1434, shortly after the Madrid retreat. Pregnancy confirmed by late February. Child due October 1434. Swift and reassuring for the kingdom that demonstrates fertility.

ranges.label: Immediate Conception
ranges.summary: Lucia conceives in December 1433—possibly during the Madrid retreat itself. Pregnancy confirmed by late January 1434. Child due September 1434. Extraordinarily quick, a sign of blessing according to medieval understanding.

ranges.label: Twins
ranges.summary: Lucia conceives immediately (December 1433) and carries twins—confirmed when she grows unusually large by spring. Due September 1434. High risk but potentially resolving succession questions dramatically. Medieval twin births are dangerous.

tables.title: Journey to Barcelona - Chaos Roll
tables.context: Military/Travel — Mid-January 1434. Royal party traveling Toledo → Zaragoza → Barcelona through winter conditions (approximately 150 leagues over 10-12 days). Party includes King Juan, Queen Lucia (pregnant, experiencing morning sickness), Princess Catalina (20 months), 700 Military Order knights, royal household, and supply train.

ranges.label: Disaster
ranges.summary: Multiple serious problems compound (severe illness strikes Lucia, mountain pass becomes impassable, Catalina falls seriously ill, horse plague affects cavalry mounts). Expedition's timeline severely compromised, arrival delayed by weeks.

ranges.label: Significant Difficulties
ranges.summary: One major problem dominates the journey (heavy snow closes direct mountain route, Lucia's morning sickness becomes severe requiring multi-day rest, accident injures key household member, supply wagon breaks axle, local tensions over billeting 700 knights). Arrival delayed by 4-7 days.

ranges.label: Troubled Journey
ranges.summary: Persistent minor problems accumulate (Lucia exhausted throughout, Catalina requires frequent stops, cold wet weather, several horses lame, inadequate lodgings in smaller towns, knights grumble). Everyone arrives tired and irritable, 2-3 days behind schedule.

ranges.label: Uneventful Passage
ranges.summary: Journey proceeds without notable incident. Weather manageable, Lucia copes adequately with her condition, Catalina has good and difficult days in normal proportion, lodgings vary adequate to comfortable. Arrival roughly on schedule in reasonable condition.

ranges.label: Pleasant Journey
ranges.summary: Favorable conditions predominate. Clear dry weather, Lucia's morning sickness proves manageable, Catalina delights in adventure and behaves well, Aragonese towns welcome Castilian king warmly, good lodgings throughout. Arrival on schedule with party in good spirits.

ranges.label: Excellent Progress
ranges.summary: Everything aligns favorably. Unseasonably mild weather, Lucia feels better than expected, Catalina charms everyone she meets, Aragonese nobles along route offer hospitality and fresh horses, mountain passes clear and dry. Possible arrival 1-2 days ahead of schedule.

ranges.label: Triumphant Procession
ranges.summary: Journey becomes a celebration. Word of Reconquista's completion has spread; Aragonese villages turn out to cheer the crusading king; local nobles compete to host royal family; Lucia blooms despite pregnancy; Catalina becomes beloved figure. Political benefits manifest clearly, relationships strengthened.

ranges.label: Remarkable Fortune
ranges.summary: Something unexpected and significantly positive occurs beyond mere good travel. In this roll: Catalina is accidentally left alone in Fraga and walks to the river where a boy (Tomás, the fuller's son) has fallen in. Without hesitation or help, she throws a rope to save him—an act of remarkable courage and quick thinking that becomes legendary. The town builds a shrine (La Capilla de la Princesita) and celebrates her annually. Tomás becomes a priest, telling the story his entire life.

tables.title: Naples Campaign Status - January 1434
tables.context: Intrigue/Military — Assessment of King Alfonso of Aragon's campaign to control Naples. Juan provided financial aid at Fernando's baptism (autumn 1433) and secured papal support. Historical context: Queen Joanna II of Naples is elderly and erratic; Louis III of Anjou currently holds most of the kingdom (historically dies November 1434); Pope Eugenius IV has switched support to Alfonso; René of Anjou (Louis's brother) is imprisoned by Burgundy.

ranges.label: Serious Setback
ranges.summary: Alfonso's preparations have suffered major blow (Genoese raid destroyed part of fleet, key baron switched to Louis III, disease swept through army, Milan sent aid to Louis III). Alfonso may need to abandon Naples entirely; writes he needs more help.

ranges.label: Stalled Progress
ranges.summary: Situation remains frozen. Alfonso sits in Sicily with forces unable to move. Louis III holds Calabria firmly. Papal support helpful diplomatically but not translated to military advantage. Frustrated and impatient, needs clearer path forward.

ranges.label: Holding Pattern with Minor Gains
ranges.summary: Small progress achieved. Alfonso secured additional Neapolitan barons through diplomacy; fleet is complete and ready; Louis III's health failing; papal endorsement weakened Angevin legitimacy. Situation promising but unresolved; Alfonso waiting for opportunity to strike by summer 1434.

ranges.label: Favorable Developments
ranges.summary: Tide turning toward Aragon. Louis III bedridden and his forces demoralized. Several major barons openly declare for Alfonso. Castilian money funded successful diplomatic mission neutralizing Milan. Joanna making secret overtures to re-adopt Alfonso. Alfonso preparing to move, expects action by summer 1434.

ranges.label: Significant Progress
ranges.summary: Alfonso achieved breakthrough. He has landed forces in southern Italy and secured major coastal stronghold (Reggio or Taranto). Louis III is dying and Angevin cause collapsing. Multiple Neapolitan nobles switched sides. Papal endorsement combined with Castilian prestige isolated Angevins diplomatically. René remains imprisoned. Alfonso writes Naples will be his within the year.

ranges.label: Major Success
ranges.summary: Campaign succeeded beyond expectations. Louis III has died (earlier than November), Alfonso moved immediately and controls significant territory. Joanna, facing reality, formally re-adopted Alfonso and named him sole heir with papal confirmation making revocation impossible. René's claim effectively dead. Alfonso expects to be King of Naples within months when Joanna dies (she is 63 and in poor health).

ranges.label: Triumph
ranges.summary: Something extraordinary occurred. Possibilities: Joanna II herself has died unexpectedly and Alfonso already proclaimed King of Naples by the barons; Alfonso achieved stunning military victory breaking Angevin power decisively; René of Anjou from his Burgundian prison formally renounced all claims to Naples in exchange for consideration. The three-kingdom alliance (Castile-Aragon-Naples) is no longer a dream but imminent reality.

tables.title: Aragonese Nobles' Initial Reception
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan's arrival in Barcelona as King of Castile, brother to Queen María, and champion of the Reconquista. Court reception following his arrival, before his public address. Nobles considering whether Juan represents opportunity or threat to Aragonese interests.

ranges.label: Hostile Undercurrent
ranges.summary: Reception formally correct but cold. Catalan nobles barely conceal resentment, seeing Juan's visit as Castilian swagger. Pointed comments about 'Castilian ambitions' and 'Aragon's diminished state.' Some nobles conspicuously absent. María embarrassed and angry. Juan must work hard to salvage positive relations.

ranges.label: Cool Politeness
ranges.summary: Forms observed but warmth lacking. Major nobles attend and say right things, but wariness behind courtesies. Pointed questions about why so many knights, Castilian intentions toward Mediterranean. Diplomatic rather than fraternal mood. Juan is treated as foreign king, not as family.

ranges.label: Correct but Reserved
ranges.summary: Proper reception befitting allied monarch. Applause for Reconquista acknowledged but not celebrated. Formal toasts to alliance. Mood diplomatic rather than warm. Nobles waiting to see what Juan wants before committing enthusiasm. Acceptable but not warm welcome.

ranges.label: Respectful Welcome
ranges.summary: Reception goes well. Nobles genuinely acknowledge Reconquista as achievement honoring all of Iberia, not just Castile. Catalina charms several older nobles. Questions about Constantinople show real interest. A few nobles mention relatives who fought alongside Castilians in past campaigns. Alliance feels functional and reasonably warm. Normal diplomatic success.

ranges.label: Warm Reception
ranges.summary: Genuine enthusiasm. Aragonese nobles are proud to host the Reconquista's hero—his glory reflects on all Christian Iberia. 'La Princesita de la Cuerda' story has made Catalina a celebrity; nobles compete for introductions. Multiple hospitality and hunting invitations offered. Several nobles express hope that sons might train at Juan's military academy. Alliance feels like true partnership.

ranges.label: Enthusiastic Embrace
ranges.summary: Court treats Juan almost as one of their own. Speeches praising Castilian-Aragonese brotherhood. Nobles who remember Juan from four years ago remark on his growth into kingship. Catalan merchants see opportunity rather than competition—proposals for joint ventures. Veterans of past campaigns weep openly. María visibly moved by warm reception. This is family, not just alliance.

ranges.label: Triumphant Welcome
ranges.summary: Juan's arrival becomes celebration of Iberian unity. Impromptu procession through Barcelona with Juan and María riding together. Church bells ring. Citizens line streets. Aragonese share in Castile's reflected glory. Concrete offers emerge: ships for Constantinople, trade agreements, military cooperation. Three-kingdom dream suddenly tangible. Alfonso's regency council formally requests Juan's counsel.

ranges.label: Historic Moment
ranges.summary: Something extraordinary transcends normal diplomacy. Powerful Catalan noble house that historically opposed Castilian influence makes dramatic public gesture of reconciliation; elderly veteran of Las Navas de Tolosa (1212) blesses Juan as fulfillment of two centuries of crusade; merchants' guild proposes formal Castilian-Aragonese trade union. The visit becomes turning point in Iberian relations that chroniclers will remember.

tables.title: Juan's Public Speech to the Court
tables.context: Persuasion — Juan addresses assembled Aragonese nobles after formal reception. Speech focused on humility about Catalan culture, shared credit for Reconquista's completion, references to 'kingdom of heaven' concept, and calls for unity. Reception follows positive dinner conversation with Don Guillem de Vic and Don Ramon de Perellós's warnings about factions.

ranges.label: Poorly Received
ranges.summary: Speech falls flat. Theological content seems self-important to Catalan ears. Humility rings hollow when followed by sermon. Aragonese faction openly disappointed Juan didn't counsel restraint on Naples. Neapolitan faction wanted substance, not prayers. Polite applause but cooler mood. Don Ramon winces. María looks concerned.

ranges.label: Lukewarm Response
ranges.summary: Mixed reception. Some appreciate humility and shared-credit framing. Others find speech too long, abstract, Castilian. Both factions unsatisfied—neither got what they wanted. Adequate applause but not enthusiastic. Speech changed nothing; nobles remain cautiously reserved.

ranges.label: Polite Appreciation
ranges.summary: Respectfully received. Humility lands well—Catalans appreciate king admitting ignorance and promising to learn. Catalina touches draw smiles. Theological content tolerated. Neither faction satisfied, but neither offended. Applause genuine if not thunderous. Status quo maintained.

ranges.label: Solid Reception
ranges.summary: Speech works. Humility disarms skeptics. Shared-credit Reconquista framing noted and appreciated—several nobles nod visibly. 'Kingdom of heaven' rhetoric resonates with pious contingent; cynics appreciate that he asked for prayers not gold. Factions unsatisfied but not hostile. Warm applause. Mood shifts slightly upward.

ranges.label: Well Received
ranges.summary: Speech succeeds. Catalan merchants appreciate respect shown their culture. Theological content delivered sincerely moves several older nobles. Shared Reconquista framing generates genuine warmth—'he sees us as partners, not subordinates.' Catalina references make people smile. Even unsatisfied factions acknowledge graceful navigation of competing demands. Strong applause. Several approach afterward with warmer demeanor.

ranges.label: Strongly Received
ranges.summary: Speech resonates deeply. Juan's combination of humility, sincerity, vision cuts through factional calculations. 'Kingdom of heaven' rhetoric comes across as authentic faith of man who seen miracles, struggles to understand them. Shared-credit framing generates real emotion—veterans wipe tears. Factions set aside disappointment, moved by something larger. Enthusiastic applause. Mood noticeably warmer.

ranges.label: Powerful Impact
ranges.summary: Speech transforms atmosphere. Juan's humility and sincerity, combined with vision, breaks through calculations. When he speaks of glimpsing heaven—at Alcalá, at Catalina's birth—hardened nobles find themselves moved. Promise to learn Catalan culture received as genuine honor. Shared Reconquista framing makes them feel part of something great. Even cynics impressed. Sustained applause, some calling out blessings. Factional tensions temporarily dissolve.

ranges.label: Transcendent Moment
ranges.summary: Something extraordinary happens. Perhaps elderly noble embraces Juan as brother; perhaps Bishop calls for impromptu blessing; perhaps Catalina does something that perfectly punctuates moment. Hall is transformed—faction lines blur, old grievances set aside. For shining moment assembled nobles glimpse the 'kingdom of heaven' Juan described. This speech will be remembered and quoted for years. Visit's entire character has changed.

tables.title: Rest of the Evening Reception - Diplomatic Performance
tables.context: Diplomacy/Personal — Following Juan's public address about unity and his announcement of Don Guillem de Vic's commitment to broker aid to King Alfonso. Juan, Lucia, and Catalina spend the evening receiving nobles, attempting to build on the momentum of the announcement. Tests Juan's consistency and ability to manage extended diplomatic engagement.

ranges.label: The Evening Sours
ranges.summary: Something goes wrong. Perhaps Catalina, exhausted and overstimulated, has tantrum that can't be contained; or Juan says something sounding like Castilian condescension when pressed by skeptical lord; or drunk noble makes insult that can't be ignored. Warm mood dissipates. Goodwill evaporates. People remember awkwardness more than inspiration. 'Third faction' of believers disperses. Tomorrow cynics will say they knew it couldn't last.

ranges.label: Diminishing Returns
ranges.summary: Evening drags. Juan repeats themes too often; what sounded inspiring once sounds rehearsed the fifth time. Lucia adequate but fails to sparkle. Catalina grows fussy and must be taken to bed early, denying Juan his most effective ambassador. Conversations become repetitive, wine leads to rambling. By end people tired rather than inspired. Nothing lost but nothing gained beyond already won. The announcement's impact fades into 'a nice moment.'

ranges.label: Mixed Results
ranges.summary: Evening fractures visibly. Neapolitan faction applauds with enthusiasm—Castile finally committing publicly! Aragonese faction stone-faced or perfunctory. Neutral middle watches both, calculating. Guillem receives congratulations from allies and cold shoulders from others. María's expression unreadable. Announcement clarified lines rather than transcended them. Some genuinely moved, others alienated. Don Ramon looks thoughtful—bold but was it wise?

ranges.label: Steady Progress
ranges.summary: Royal family performs competently. They meet dozens of nobles, remember names, make appropriate comments. Catalina generally adorable with only minor fussy moments. No dramatic breakthroughs but no failures. 'Third faction' believers remain enthusiastic; some fence-sitters tip positive. Aragonese faction reserves but not hostile. Count Pallars eventually approaches for brief, correct exchange—nothing warm but not cold. Solid diplomatic evening, foundation holds.

ranges.label: Good Impressions
ranges.summary: Family performs well. Lucia's Italian sophistication impresses Catalans who trade with Genoa and Venice—speaks knowledgeably about Mediterranean commerce. Catalina distributes charm strategically. Juan's consistency in message reassures those wondering if announcement was genuine or calculated. Several meaningful conversations: shipbuilder offers vessels for Constantinople, vintner proposes trade exchange, elderly dowager countess tells Juan he reminds her of her late husband 'who also believed impossible things.' Evening reinforces rather than undermines announcement's impact.

ranges.label: Memorable Night
ranges.summary: Something clicks. Juan's sincerity, Lucia's grace, Catalina's irresistible presence create cumulative effect. People approach skeptical and leave thoughtful. Gualbes patriarch has long conversation with Lucia about Ferrarese banking. Young knight from Aragonese faction breaks ranks, tells Juan privately he's tired of elders' bitterness. Catalina presented with carved horse, solemnly names it 'Friend,' story spreads through hall. Count Pallars offers something beyond courtesy: 'You've given us much to think about.' Even María smiles—real smile. Night will be remembered.

ranges.label: Exceptional Evening
ranges.summary: Evening becomes something more than diplomacy. Juan finds genuine conversations—about faith, family, what kingdoms owe each other. Lucia discovers shared love of poetry with Countess of Urgell, spend hour discussing Italian verse. Catalina falls asleep in arms of gruff Aragonese admiral who fought at Ponza—man's weathered face softens, his wife weeps quietly. Factions blur; people are just people. Count Pallars seeks Juan out, asks hard questions but listens. Dozens make personal commitments. María embraces Juan: 'I don't know what you've started, but I think it might be real.'

ranges.label: Transformative
ranges.summary: Evening takes on its own life. What began as reception becomes approaching movement. Nobles who came skeptical find themselves converted not by argument but by atmosphere. Sincerity is contagious. Stories multiply: the king who listened twenty minutes to minor baron; the little princess who comforted homesick page; the Italian queen who practiced Catalan phrases. Count Pallars doesn't become believer but stops being opponent, talks with Juan nearly hour. 'Third faction' isn't faction anymore—becoming consensus. Don Ramon: 'I've served three regencies. Never seen anything like this.'

ranges.label: Legend
ranges.summary: Years later people claim they were there the night kingdoms began to heal. Evening transcends politics. Perhaps Bishop leads impromptu prayer moving hall to tears. Perhaps Count Pallars and Don Guillem clasp hands publicly in reconciliation. Perhaps Catalina does something so perfectly timed that it becomes the story: the moment child of Castile and Portugal and Este brought Aragonese nobles together. Visit becomes turning point in Iberian relations. María writes to Alfonso that night: 'Our brother is something I do not have a word for. Come home when you can.'

tables.title: Pre-Audience Intelligence Gathering (Medici Connection)
tables.context: Diplomacy — Lucia attempts to gather intelligence about the Vatican's position and key figures before Juan's papal audience, using the Medici banking network to identify approachable Vatican officials.

ranges.label: Backfire
ranges.summary: Lucia's inquiries are noticed unfavorably. French-aligned cardinals interpret it as Juan trying to gather intelligence against the Pope. Vatican distance becomes colder when Juan enters his audience.

ranges.label: Locked Doors
ranges.summary: Everyone is waiting for the Pope to speak with Juan first. Capranica does not respond to overtures. Orsini remains unreachable. Vatican sends clear message: present yourself to the Holy Father first, then we'll see.

ranges.label: Context Without Access
ranges.summary: Medici agent provides useful background but no direct contacts. Learns Camera is financially desperate; 8-10 French cardinals oppose papal-Castilian ties; parallel legislation has not been rejected outright but Pope is cautious. Juan enters knowing the landscape but not the Pope's mind.

ranges.label: Capranica's Caution
ranges.summary: Cardinal Capranica agrees to brief conversation with Lucia in a church. Confirms Pope watched the Mass procession and was impressed; genuinely cares about Constantinople; hasn't rejected parallel legislation. Capranica won't commit without papal audience first.

ranges.label: The Banker's Whisper
ranges.summary: Medici identifies Camera official who owes them money and reveals: Eugenius desperate for Constantinople expedition; fears Juan might be too aligned with Council; termination criteria is something Pope has opinions on; French faction pushing suspicion of Castilian influence.

ranges.label: Capranica's Gamble
ranges.summary: Capranica invites Juan to evening conversation at his residence. Frankly explains: Eugenius needs Juan's expedition but fears dependency; parallel legislation intrigues him; French faction whispering Juan seeks to dominate Church; Eugenius will test Juan's humility. Provides map of terrain.

ranges.label: The Back Channel
ranges.summary: Cardinal Orsini sends private message explaining his coldness was instructed distance. Reveals: Eugenius fears accepting parallel legislation means admitting Basel has legitimacy; needs way to adopt reforms as papal initiative not conciliar victory; if Juan offers that, Eugenius will be receptive.

ranges.label: Providence
ranges.summary: Pope sends signal through multiple channels: Eugenius watched Mass procession and wept; sees 591 crusaders as Providence answering his crisis; sends private note: 'son of the Church who acts rather than merely speaks.' Audience won't be test but conversation between men who need each other.

tables.title: Fleet Storm Drill Exercise
tables.context: Military — Nine ships conduct a practice drill to test crew response to storm warning signals, using a surprise cannon signal from the San Marcos and a predetermined set of six emergency procedures.

ranges.label: Disaster
ranges.summary: Something goes badly wrong—collision, sailor falls, or rigging fails. Reveals serious flaw in equipment or discipline. No timing recorded as crew deals with emergency. Lesson learned brutally: they were not ready.

ranges.label: Confusion
ranges.summary: Signal catches fleet off-guard. Crews confused by unexpected source (San Marcos rather than Catalina). Scramble is ragged and slow. Transports struggle with horses. Fastest ship completes in 15 minutes, slowest twice that. Formation scatters rather than turning in unison.

ranges.label: Ragged but Functional
ranges.summary: Drill happens but ugly. Carracks perform adequately, transports struggle badly. San Vicente's hungover crew moves slowly. Lifelines tangled on one ship, another blows horn prematurely. Fleet turns toward Ostia eventually but straggling over an hour. Clear more drilling needed but foundation exists.

ranges.label: Mixed Results
ranges.summary: Some ships shine, others stumble. San Marcos fastest (they knew signal was coming). Transports show wide variance. San Vicente performs better or worse than expected. Average completion time 10 minutes. Fleet turns for Ostia resembling formation. Solid first attempt with clear areas for improvement.

ranges.label: Competent Execution
ranges.summary: Surprise works as intended. Crews weren't watching San Marcos and recover well. Briefing proves its worth; men know what to do despite being startled. Six steps happen in proper sequence on most ships. Fastest 6 minutes, slowest 12. Fleet turns for Ostia as group, not scattered.

ranges.label: Strong Performance
ranges.summary: Fleet surprises itself. When signal fires, training takes over. Competition drives them. Even San Vicente's hungover crew performs creditably. Fastest completion 5 minutes, slowest under 10. Formation holds as ships turn for Ostia. Foundation is solid; these men could survive real storm.

ranges.label: Impressive Coordination
ranges.summary: Something clicks—clarity of briefing or pride of men who lost shipmates. Fleet responds like single organism. Six steps flow one into next. Fastest ship completes in under 4 minutes. Transports finish in 6-7 minutes. Turn for Ostia crisp, formation maintained. Morales genuinely impressed.

ranges.label: Exceptional
ranges.summary: Surprise proves that crews respond magnificently to unexpected challenges. Memory of Mistral transformed from trauma into determination. Every ship executes six steps in under 6 minutes. Turn for Ostia parade-ground precise. Other vessels in port stop to watch—demonstration of serious intent. Small improvements identified but bones are strong.

ranges.label: Providence
ranges.summary: Actual weather change spotted minutes before signal. Drill becomes real. Fleet executes six steps as genuine preparation. Real squall hits and they weather it in perfect formation, or drill runs twice with even better second execution. Crew returns transformed, knowing they can trust each other in any crisis.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV's Initial Response to Juan
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan kneels before the Pope and asks an open question about how Eugenius has been faring before offering to help the Church. This is humble but also evasive, and Eugenius is a politician who has been burned before.

ranges.label: Cold Suspicion
ranges.summary: Eugenius does not warm. Returns to seat without invitation. Asks pointedly about Basel, suggests Juan's question implies conditions and prerequisites. Interrogates whether Juan comes as servant or negotiator with prepared terms.

ranges.label: Guarded Deflection
ranges.summary: Eugenius smiles thinly, diplomatic, revealing nothing. Avoids complaints, suggests Juan tell how Church fares from perspective of Basel. Polite distance maintained. Underlying question: whose side are you on?

ranges.label: Polite Distance
ranges.summary: Pope gestures Juan to stand but does not embrace. Returns to chair. Acknowledges Juan's accomplishments but maintains reserve. Notes he knows of Como declaration and bridge-building at Basel. Offers nothing, seeks to draw Juan out.

ranges.label: Testing the Waters
ranges.summary: Eugenius raises Juan, invites him to sit in informal seating. Admits honestly he learned trust is currency easily spent and slowly earned. Notes Basel complicates assessment of Juan. Questions whether Juan still believes middle path is possible.

ranges.label: Cautious Interest
ranges.summary: Expression softens. Eugenius acknowledges Juan's value (Reconquista, 600 knights) but probes about middle path. Notes middle paths anger everyone. Asks what Juan truly believes and what remains to be done. Offers no commitment but genuine listening.

ranges.label: Genuine Engagement
ranges.summary: Eugenius is moved by Juan's implicit offer to help without demands. Acknowledges faring poorly—Council presses, Camera bleeds, Colonna watch for weakness. Moves to window and invites Juan to share what he saw at Basel, admitting Vatican isolation makes him need trustworthy eyes.

ranges.label: Unexpected Warmth
ranges.summary: Eugenius rises as Juan kneels and raises him up. Emotional—admits lacking visitors without outstretched hands. Takes Juan to window privately, opens up about despair watching allies drift away. Offers to hear Juan truly. Suggests perhaps Juan is sign God has not abandoned Church.

ranges.label: Providence Recognized
ranges.summary: Eugenius immediately rises and lifts Juan bodily. Eyes bright with emotion. Admits he watched Mass procession from window and wept, seeing what Church should be. Grips Juan's shoulders. Will ask what Juan needs and give whatever is in his power, believing God sent him.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV Reacts to Juan's Concrete Papal Strategy
tables.context: Diplomacy — Juan proposes specific concrete strategy: Rome signs Basel's reforms immediately, enforces them aggressively (especially in France), then issues own papal decree on unaddressed subject and pressures Basel to follow. Eugenius has already been vulnerable and suspicious, now must assess feasibility.

ranges.label: Sharp Rejection
ranges.summary: Eugenius hardens. Coldly notes Juan speaks as though he commands legions. Points out France defied Rome for a century and Pragmatic Sanction treats papal authority as advisory. Rejects strategy as fantasy. Claims Juan seeks to make Rome dependent on Castilian swords while speaking of authority.

ranges.label: Suspicious Probing
ranges.summary: Eugenius listens but eyes narrow. Does not engage with strategy at all. Focuses on what Juan wants in return—notes gifts freely offered are never free, like Como. Demands Juan speak plainly about price. Threatens to assume worst if price not named.

ranges.label: Practical Objections
ranges.summary: Eugenius tilts toward logic but raises practical concerns. Questions enforcement (French bishops, appeals), Camera finances (annates reform cuts 75% revenue), and validity of counter-decree idea. Spreads hands: needs answers to practical questions, not principles.

ranges.label: Guarded Interest
ranges.summary: Pope considers strategy with cunning in it. Notes Council can't object to enforcing their own legislation. But questions whether Juan believes enforcement truly possible given French strength. Asks what role Castile plays. Still hasn't named his price.

ranges.label: Serious Engagement
ranges.summary: Eugenius leans forward with genuine interest breaking through. Sees forcing Basel to follow Rome's decree as inverting dynamic. Exchanges significant glance with Capranica. Turns from window asking how to overcome French resistance and what Juan wants (still no committed answer to his question about price).

ranges.label: Genuine Collaboration
ranges.summary: Something shifts. Eugenius glances at Capranica meaningfully, then speaks plainly to Juan. Your strategy has real merit. Hadn't considered enforcement using Basel's own decrees. Counter-decree possibility about Constantinople intrigues him. But needs resources, money, political support. What does Castile need from Rome?

ranges.label: Near Alliance
ranges.summary: Eugenius stops the secretary from writing. Dismisses Capranica. Admits strategy is sound, first concrete path offered in three years. Acknowledges Granada proves Juan understands action not argument. Bargains seriously: Tell us full position. If within our power, you shall have it.

ranges.label: Unexpected Openness
ranges.summary: Eugenius dismisses all attendants, is alone with Juan. Diplomatic mask falls. Admits no workable strategy heard in years. Accepts proposal in principle. Demands Juan name price for Constantinople, Castile, and himself personally. Within his power, Juan shall have it.

tables.title: Pope Eugenius IV's Response to Juan's Declaration of Faith
tables.context: Intrigue — Juan deflects Eugenius's demand for a price by reframing the conversation around faith and scripture. Juan asks what would Jesus do and what does gospel teach about fear and righteous action. Eugenius must confront his own faith and convictions.

ranges.label: Hardened Suspicion
ranges.summary: Eugenius's face closes. Cites previous betrayals (Cesarini, Sigismund at Como). Recites Juan's words back flatly. Says he hears a man refusing to name price because naming reveals its size. Dismisses Juan to antechamber, needs time to consider. Does not turn around.

ranges.label: Cold Testing
ranges.summary: Eugenius notes every cardinal, ambassador, and king has wanted something. Lists Juan's real interests (Granada heir, Alfonso's Naples claims, Military Orders). Suggests Juan's stated desire for only strong Church hides these actual ambitions.

ranges.label: Probing for Cracks
ranges.summary: Pope speaks softly but firmly. Believes Juan means the words but not the whole truth. Kingship demands concrete matters. Asks Juan to name all necessities—Constantinople support, Military Orders, other things. Will hear faith but also necessities.

ranges.label: Grudging Recognition
ranges.summary: Eugenius studies Juan long. Says he speaks as man of faith speaks, not as diplomat. Doesn't say he believes entirely but believes it sounds genuine. Asks critical question about how Juan imagines Christendom uniting without armies—who would answer this call?

ranges.label: Cautious Thaw
ranges.summary: Long silence then acknowledgment. Notes it's been long since anyone spoke to him of faith not as tool. Remembers why he became priest. Moved but uncertain. Says will not demand Juan name price. Will ask what's needed for Constantinople. Speaks of partnership not payment.

ranges.label: Moved but Guarded
ranges.summary: Eugenius visibly affected. Notes no one has spoken to him of faith in years. Wants to believe Juan but fearing belief is dangerous. Says Juan speaks of something beyond Church institutions. Wants to believe but asks carefully that Juan show actions align with words.

ranges.label: Beginning to Trust
ranges.summary: Eugenius visibly changes. Releases Juan's arm step back. Admits he's been losing faith in Church herself. Sees Juan as ally prayed for. Still uncertain but will trust provisionally. Tell us everything—Constantinople, Ottomans, reforms, Church-building visions. Will determine if trust warranted.

ranges.label: Genuine Connection
ranges.summary: Eugenius dismisses all attendants. Admits to Juan alone something said to no one: he's been losing faith in Church. Pain evident. Juan's words about church bells and farmers at Mass pierce his armor. Doesn't know if Juan is prayer's answer or most dangerous man he's met. Will learn by trusting. Gives whatever in his power if Juan helps remember why faith matters.

ranges.label: The Mask Falls
ranges.summary: Eugenius emotionally breaks. References moment 23 years ago in Venice church feeling God's presence. Says he's lost that certainty in papacy. Juan's words restore memory. Grips Juan's hands. Doesn't care about price anymore. Will give anything if Juan helps save Constantinople and Church and helps him remember why faith matters.

tables.title: Securing the Apostolic Camera
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Juan, Parentucelli, and Captain Pallavicini move to secure the Camera building with papal authority and 20 Vatican guards, while 591 Castilian knights await at St. Peter's. The building must be secured before the Mass announcement to prevent document destruction or official escape.

ranges.label: Disaster
ranges.summary: The building is nearly empty; key officials fled in the night with critical documents. The treasury vault stands open and bare. The corruption has escaped to fight another day, and the cardinals will know before the Mass.

ranges.label: Serious Complication
ranges.summary: A resistance confrontation erupts when an official connected to a powerful family refuses to yield. Juan must intervene personally before blood is shed or reform narrative becomes 'foreign thugs assault papal servants.'

ranges.label: Partial Success, Major Problem
ranges.summary: The building is secured but the senior clerk burned documents before being restrained. Visible smoke from the Camera alerts the cardinals during Mass, signaling something unexpected occurred.

ranges.label: Partial Success, Minor Problems
ranges.summary: Secured with both keys obtained but one keyholder claims he lost his key. The vault cannot be opened without breaking it down, appearing like looting rather than lawful seizure. Some records are clearly missing.

ranges.label: Adequate Success
ranges.summary: The Camera is secured, officials are confused but compliant, both keys obtained, no documents destroyed. However, the operation took longer than planned; the Mass will start late and some cardinals ask questions about the delay.

ranges.label: Clean Success
ranges.summary: Textbook operation. Pallavicini's men move efficiently, Parentucelli takes command with quiet authority, officials surrender without resistance. Keys obtained, documents secured, treasury sealed. Proceed to Mass on schedule.

ranges.label: Better Than Expected
ranges.summary: Clean success with Parentucelli immediately identifying irregularities in ledgers—evidence of systematic theft with names, amounts, dates. He can present specifics when the announcement comes, not mere accusations.

ranges.label: Unexpected Bounty
ranges.summary: All secured perfectly, and Parentucelli finds documentation that hadn't been destroyed. A frightened junior clerk volunteers information for protection. First defector provides evidence that makes the reform case unassailable.

ranges.label: Providence
ranges.summary: The treasury contains more than expected; funds about to be moved are caught mid-transfer. Captured documents are explosive, directly implicating a specific cardinal in crusade fund theft.

tables.title: The Papal Mass and Public Announcement
tables.context: Chaos Roll — Pope Eugenius IV delivers the public announcement of Camera reform, papal bull signing, and Basel decrees during Mass at St. Peter's Basilica with 591 Castilian knights, 11-12 cardinals, and hundreds of clergy and witnesses present. The moment will either unite or shatter the Church leadership.

ranges.label: Disaster
ranges.summary: Something goes terribly wrong. Rochetaillée denounces Spanish tyranny, other cardinals join him, ceremony dissolves into shouting. Some cardinals storm out demanding the Pope halt. Documents are signed but the moment is poisoned; Juan's oath received as threat, not pledge.

ranges.label: Hostile Reception
ranges.summary: Eugenius's voice wavers at key moments. Cardinals' faces harden. Audible protests erupt. Rochetaillée demands to know if the Pope acts freely or under duress. Signing proceeds under a pall; several cardinals ostentatiously refuse to witness.

ranges.label: Tense and Fractured
ranges.summary: The announcement proceeds but French faction whispers furiously throughout. When Parentucelli presents evidence, one cardinal laughs bitterly at his appointment. Momentum falters. Signing happens in strained silence.

ranges.label: Grudging Acceptance
ranges.summary: Eugenius finds his voice and announces with dignity. Cardinals listen in frozen silence—shock more than fury. Some show calculation. The signing proceeds. When Juan is called, cardinals watch with guarded expressions—not welcoming, but not openly hostile.

ranges.label: Solemn Dignity
ranges.summary: Eugenius rises to the moment. His voice steadies as he speaks of reform and cleansing corruption. Parentucelli presents evidence crisply, silencing objections. The cardinals listen, some pale, some thoughtful. When Juan is called, the atmosphere is grave but not hostile.

ranges.label: Growing Momentum
ranges.summary: Something shifts as Eugenius speaks. The Pope sounds like a man who believes in what he's doing. The reforms are liberation, not punishment. When the amnesty provision is read, visible relief crosses several faces. The signing becomes almost ceremonial.

ranges.label: Moment of Grace
ranges.summary: Eugenius's voice carries conviction that surprises everyone. At one point it breaks when speaking of the corruption he allowed—that crack of genuine emotion reaches the congregation. Cardinal Albergati weeps openly. Even Rochetaillée's expression flickers. The signing proceeds with solemnity.

ranges.label: Transformation
ranges.summary: The announcement becomes a moment of genuine spiritual power. Eugenius speaks as though words come through him. When Parentucelli presents evidence, it lands as diagnosis, not accusation. Cardinals who entered suspicious find themselves moved. One rises and pledges public support; then another.

ranges.label: Providence
ranges.summary: The hand of God moves visibly in St. Peter's. Light shifts through high windows, illuminating the papal throne in what witnesses will later call miraculous radiance. The Pope's words carry prophetic weight that silences opposition. Cardinal Albergati rises first to pledge; even Rochetaillée bows his head. When Juan is called forward, every soul understands they witness a hinge of history.

tables.title: Cardinal Jean de Rochetaillée's Reaction to the Announcement and Juan's Courtyard Conversation
tables.context: Diplomacy Roll — The French faction leader, who sat unmoved during the Mass, approaches Juan in the Vatican courtyard to discuss his position. Rochetaillée has his own agenda: to assess Juan directly and position himself regarding the reform's legitimacy. He must decide whether to recommend reconciliation with Basel or denunciation.

ranges.label: Cynicism Resurfaces
ranges.summary: Rochetaillée interprets Juan's simple faith as political theater. The physical warmth and honest words seem too perfect, triggering his political instincts to scream warning. He accepts the invitation cautiously but will not trust Juan personally. The bridge remains incomplete.

ranges.label: Guarded Interest
ranges.summary: Rochetaillée is moved but cannot fully surrender his wariness. He recognizes authenticity but cannot risk trusting what seems too good to be true. He will watch. He will wait. If Juan's actions match words over time, perhaps trust will follow.

ranges.label: Intellectual Acceptance
ranges.summary: Rochetaillée recognizes authenticity and processes it through his political mind. He accepts the invitation to work together but frames it practically: what specifically can they accomplish? The heart remains guarded; the head engages.

ranges.label: Warming Respect
ranges.summary: The shoulder-slap surprised him; the words surprised him more. Rochetaillée finds himself smiling slightly—reluctantly. He extends his hand: 'Yes. Let us work together, and see what we can build.' A genuine beginning, if not yet full trust.

ranges.label: The Walls Crack
ranges.summary: Something in Juan's directness—the physical warmth, absence of agenda, vision of children and happiness—reaches past Rochetaillée's defenses. He admits he spent eight years building walls. 'Perhaps it is time to build something else.' The conversion deepens genuinely.

ranges.label: Genuine Connection
ranges.summary: Rochetaillée laughs—unexpected, startling nearby knights. He grips Juan's arm in return and admits: 'I cannot remember the last time someone answered a political question with theology and meant it.' Real warmth enters the relationship; he asks if Juan will teach him to remember why he took holy orders.

ranges.label: Confession Unlocked
ranges.summary: Rochetaillée admits he came to assess Juan's trustworthiness and determine whether reconciliation was wise. Tears glisten in his eyes as he recognizes his eight years of fighting for power over spiritual renewal. He asks if they might pray together before he leaves.

ranges.label: Transformation Witnessed
ranges.summary: The cardinal who fought for institutional power finds himself undone by simple faith. His eyes glisten. 'Your Majesty—Juan—I have been a fool.' His voice drops. 'Thank you for reminding me what the Church exists to do.' He grips both of Juan's hands.

ranges.label: Partnership Forged
ranges.summary: This is not merely acceptance—it is commitment. Rochetaillée sees in Juan what he once hoped to see in himself: genuine faith expressed through action. He pledges to write d'Allemand demanding reconciliation and will tell him why: because he met a king who wants nothing except God's kingdom.

ranges.label: Brother Found
ranges.summary: Rochetaillée embraces Juan—cardinal embracing king, protocol shattered. 'I have been alone in this for so long,' he whispers. 'You have given me hope. Not for the Church—for myself. That I might still become what I was called to be.' A friendship begins that will outlast both their lives.
